But this criticism is not warranted by those passages which gave the fittest scope for such a quality,— as the invocation of the Great Mother (391—402),—the noble stasimon (676—729),—and the denunciations by Philoctetes of the fraud practised against him (927—962: 1004—1044). If, in the larger part of the play, the language is of a less elevated strain, this results from the nature of the subject; since the gradual unfolding of character, to which the plot owes its peculiar interest, is effected by the conversations of Neoptolemus with Odysseus or with Philoctetes, in which a more familiar tone necessarily predominates.

The versification, however, clearly shows, in one respect, the general stamp of the later period. If the Philoctetes is compared (for example) with the Antigone, it will be apparent that the structure of the iambic trimeter has become more Euripidean. The use of tribrachs is very large. Two such feet occur consecutively in the same verse (1029 kai\ nu=n ti/ m' a)/gete; ti/ m' a)pa/gesqe; tou= xa/rin;): a tribrach precedes a dactyl (1232 par' ou(=per e)/labon ta/de ta\ to/c), au)=qis pa/lin): or follows it (932 a)po/dos, i(knou=mai/ s), a)po/dos, i(keteu/w, te/knon). In two instances a verse ends with a single word which forms a ‘paeon quartus’ (1302 pole/mion, 1327 a)kalufh=),—a licence used, indeed, by Aeschylus, but in a trimeter which belongs to a lyric passage (Eum. 780). An anapaest in the first place of the verse occurs not less than thirteen times (308, 470, 486, 544, 742, 745, 749, 898, 923, 939, 941, 967, 1228),—without counting 815 (ti/ parafronei=s, where the first foot may be a tribrach), 549 (a proper name), or 585 (e)gw/ ei)m), a case of synizesis). Not a single instance occurs in the Antigone; and in no other play are there more than five. These relaxations of metre in the Philoctetes may be partly explained, perhaps, by the more colloquial tone which prevails in much of the dialogue. But at any rate the pervading tendency to greater freedom is unmistakable, and is certainly more strongly marked than in any other of the poet's plays.

div1.p: Scene:—A lonely place on the N.E. coast of Lemnos, near the promontory of Mount Hermaeum (1455 ff.). A rocky cliff rises steeply from the sea-shore (cp. 1000 ff.); in it is seen the cave of Philoctetes. ODYSSEUS and NEOPTOLEMUS enter on the left of the spectators.

div2.p: Prologue. Odysseus tells Neoptolemus that this is the spot where, ten years before, he had put Philoctetes ashore. Neoptolemus presently finds the cave, with traces in it which show that it is still inhabited. Odysseus then suggests that he should capture Philoctetes and his bow by a stratagem. He is to pretend that he has quarrelled with the Atreidae, and is sailing homeward. The youth at first refuses; but ultimately yields to the argument that only thus can he win the glory of taking Troy.—Odysseus returns to his ship, leaving Neoptolemus to watch for Philoctetes at the cave.

div3.p: a)kth\ me\n h(/de, implying the antithesis, tw=| de\ e)/rgw| h)/dh e)pixeirhte/on, which is virtually given by vv. 11 ff. For me/n thus deprived of its answering de/ by a change in the form of a long sentence, cp. Ant. 1199 ff.

a)/stiptos is the form given by L here, which also has stipth/ in v. 33. stipto/s, not steipto/s, is also the best attested form in Aristophanes Ach. 180, and in Theophrastus De Igne § 37. See Appendix.

ou)d' oi)koume/nh. Aeschylus and Euripides had both written a *filokth/ths, and each had composed his chorus of Lemnians,—thus making it seem strange that the sufferer should have been left so long without aid (Dion Chrysostom, or. 52). Sophocles wished to avoid that defect. Everything that is said of Lemnos throughout this play would naturally suggest a wholly uninhabited island. And the words ascribed to Philoctetes (vv. 220 f., 300 ff.) require us to suppose that he, at least, believed it to be so. The Iliad, however, represents *eu)/nhos, son of Jason and Hypsipylè, as reigning in Lemnos during the Trojan war (7. 467); and it was into ‘well-peopled Lemnos’ that Achilles sold Lycaon (21. 40). It is simplest to suppose that Sophocles, finding it convenient to have a desert island, ignored the Homeric notices. But it is also possible that he conceived the island as inhabited in some parts and desolate in others. This is the scholiast's view: e)n e)rh/mw| ga\r me/rei th=s *lh/mnou e)cete/qh. The area of Lemnos is about 150 square miles, or more than thrice that of Jersey. Philoctetes could not crawl far from his sea-side cave (cp. 163, 291).

krati/stou … trafei/s: strictly, ‘bred from’ (not, ‘reared by’) ‘a sire who was the bravest of the Greeks.’ patro\s is not a gen. of agency (like plhgei\s qugatro/s, Eur. Or. 497), but a gen. of origin, as 1284 a)ri/stou patro\s ai)/sxistos gegw/s: cp. O.T. 1082 th=s ga\r pe/fuka mhtro/s, O.C. 1322 mhtro\s loxeuqei/s. trafei/s is more forcible than gegw/s, as suggesting, not birth merely, but the inborn qualities. Cp. Ai. 556dei= d' o(/pws patro\s|dei/ceis e)n e)xqroi=s oi(=os e)c oi(/ou )tra/fhs, ‘thou must see that thou provest among thy father's foes of what mettle and what breed thou art.’ In Aesch. Th. 792qarsei=te, pai=des mhte/rwn teqramme/nai, the gen. seems again to be one of origin, ‘maidens who are true daughters of your mothers’ (i.e., who resemble them, rather than your intrepid fathers). Wakefield's conjecture e)/nq' w)= <)k> krati/stou was warranted by the commoner usage of trafei/s (with e)k, Soph. Ai. 557, Eur. Ion 693; with a)po/, Eur. Ion 262, Soph. Ai. 1229); but it was needless here.

*neopto/leme, four syllables, the voice gliding so rapidly over the first e that, with o, it gives the effect of only one syllable. So in 241, and Eur. Andr. 14, Eur. Tro. 1126.But the name is a word of five syllables in Eur. Or. 1655*neopto/lemos gamei=n nin, ou) gamei= pote. Elmsley thought that verse corrupt; the same variation occurs, however, in *qeoklu/menos, which is of four syllables in Helen. 9, but of five ib. 1168 and 1643.

to\n *mhlia=, belonging to Malis (‘the sheepcountry,’ from mh=lon, as the neighbouring Mount Oeta takes its name from oi)=s),—a district almost enclosed by hills, at the head (i.e., west) of the *maliako\s ko/lpos. That bay forms a deep recess in the south coast of Thessaly, just opposite the N.W. end of Euboea. Cp. n. on 490. The Iliad (2. 682) includes this region in the domain of Achilles, and assigns Philoctetes to the more northerly region of Thessaly, afterwards called Magnesia: see Introduction.—Her. , consistently Ionic, has, h( *mhli\s gh=, h( *trhxini/h: Attic writers always have *traxi/s: but Thuc. and Xen. say oi( *mhliei=s, while Aeschines, like later writers, has oi( *maliei=s. Cp. 725 *mhlia/dwn numfa=n.
e)ce/qhk)=a)pebi/basa: cp. Arist. Poet. 24ta\ peri\ th\n e)/kqesin, the story of Odysseus being put ashore by the Phaeacians in Ithaca ( Hom. Od. 13. 116 ff.).

6 f. Nauck's transposition of these two verses effaces a delicate touch. Odysseus is anxious to present his conduct in the best light. After e)ce/qhk' e)gw/, he hastens to add that he was merely obeying his chiefs (v. 6). And then, in vv. 7 ff., he palliates their conduct by describing how unendurable Philoctetes was.
katasta/zonta agrees with ui(o/n (5): po/da is acc. of respect: Ai. 9ka/ra | sta/zwn i(drw=ti.

diabo/rw|: Tr. 1084h( ta/laina diabo/ros no/sos (the venom of the hydra). So below, 313 bo/skwn th\n a)dhfa/gon no/son: 745 bru/komai. Aesch. fr. 253 (Philoctetes speaking) fage/dain' a)ei/ mou sa/rkas e)sqi/ei podo/s: a v. which Euripides borrowed in his own Philoctetes, changing sa/rkas e)sqi/ei to sa/rka qoina=tai ( Arist. Poet. 22).

loibh=s … quma/twn. The sacrifice regularly preceded the libation (cp. Il. 1. 462); the order here is prompted by metrical convenience (as in Il. 9. 500loibh=| te kni/sh| te), while the natural order is given below, 1033 (ai)/qein i(era/,...spe/ndein).
prosqigei=n, fig., ‘engage in’; so the simple qigga/nw (408, Ant. 546), and a(/ptomai: cp. Ant. 1005e)mpu/rwn e)geuo/mhn.

dusfhmi/ais, cries of anguish, such as he utters below (743, 785). Cp. Eur. Andr. 1144 kraugh\ d' e)n eu)fh/moisi du/sfhmos do/mois | pe/traisin a)nte/klagc) (cries of strife echoing in the Delphian temple from the rocks hard by). At a sacrifice, all present were first sprinkled with consecrated water, then silence was proclaimed, and then the offering began: Ar. Av. 958 au)=qis su\ perixw/rei labw\n th\n xe/rniba. | eu)fhmi/) e)/stw. *x*r. mh\ kata/rch| tou= tra/gou.

The sacrifice which the cries of Philoctetes interrupted must be that which an oracle had commanded the Greeks to offer at Chrysè's altar, in the islet Chrysè. Thence they sailed to Lemnos, which was close by, and put him ashore (270). The word strato/pedon could be said of a fleet (Thuc. 1. 117); but the reference in vv. 8 f. can hardly include attempts at sacrifice made between Chrysè and Lemnos.
a)kmh\ … lo/gwn: cp. El. 22 e)/rgwn a)kmh/. Possibly a covert criticism on the length of the prologue in some previous Philoctetes: cp. O. C. 1116 n.
mh\ kai\: this kai\=‘e'en’ (not ‘both’): cp. 46, 534.

e)kxe/w (aor. subj.), ‘waste’ ( El. 1291), which would properly be said of the labour bestowed on devising the scheme, is here applied, in the sense of ‘frustrate,’ to the so/fisma itself: cp. Eur. fr. 789 mo/xqwn tw=n pri\n e)kxe/ai xa/rin. (Cp. G. 4. 491 ibi omnis | Effusus labor.)

tw=| for w(=|: O. C. 747 n.— Aesch. and Eur. had both represented Odysseus as boldly confronting Philoctetes, who failed to recognise him; a marvel which Eur. excused by supposing that Athena had changed the aspect of Odysseus. These two verses remind us that dramatic probability required Odysseus to keep himself in the background. Cp. 70.

e)/rgon … so
: a familiar Attic phrase, as appears from its frequency in Ar. , either (a) with inf., as Nub. 1343, so
 e)/rgon, w)= presbu=ta, fronti/zein k.t.l.: or (b) as a parenthesis before an imperat., as Av. 862, i(ereu=, so
 e)/rgon, qu=e: Th. 1208, so
 e)/rgon, feu=ge. It occurs more often without e)sti/ than with it.

o(/pou )st). Three modes of writing these words are possible: (1) as above, with prodelision of the e)/ in e)/sti. Cp. O. T. 732kai\ pou= )sq' o( xw=ros...; Ar. Ach. 129a)ll' )*amfi/qeo/s moi pou= )stin; So Soph. O. C. 974w(s e)gw\ )fa/nhn, Soph. Ant. 457e)c o(/tou )fa/nh. (2) o(pou)/st), with crasis, the mode followed by the scribe of L: cp. 812 w(s ou) qe/mis g' e)mou)/sti. (3) o(/pou e)/sti, with synizesis, the mode preferred by several recent edd. The fact that the 2nd syll. of o(/pou has ictus appears to render (1) or (2) slightly preferable to (3); and (1) seems recommended by the analogy of )fa/nhn, )fa/nh, where, at the end of the verse, a synizesis would have had a very harsh effect.
o(/pou … e)ntau=qa, i.e., where (precisely) in this region. Ar. Ran. 432e)/xoit' a)\n ou)=n fra/sai nw=|n | *plou/twn' o(/pou )nqa/d' oi)kei=;

toia/d), i(/n), ‘such that in it’: i(/n)=e)n h(=| (for toio/sde...o(/s, see O. C. 1353). Cp. Eur. fr. 183 ne/mwn to\ plei=ston h(me/ras tou/tw| me/ros, | i(/n' au)to\s au(tou= tugxa/nei be/ltistos w)/n, where i(/n)=e)n w(=|.

h(li/ou diplh= … e)nqa/khsis, lit., ‘a twofold means of sitting in the sun.’ Cp. Probl. 5 § 36 e(sthko/tes e)n tw=| h(li/w|: ib. 16 § 1 e)a\n e)n h(li/w| teqw=si. So qakei=n e)n (or e)nqakei=n) h(li/w| could mean, ‘to sit in the sun’; and the genit. in h(li/ou e)nqa/khsis is objective, corresponding to the dat. with the verb. This is better than to make it a gen. of quality, as if the phrase meant, ‘a sunny seat in (the cave).’ The morning sun could be enjoyed at the seaward mouth of the cave, which had a s. or S. E. aspect (cp. 1457); while the afternoon sun fell on the other entrance, looking N. or N. W.

a)mfitrh=tos, ‘pierced at both ends,’ ‘tunnelled’: perh. suggested by Eur. Cycl. 707di) a)mfitrh=tos th=sde prosbai/nwn pe/tras (so Kirchhoff for podi/). This pass. sense of a)mfitrh/s (a)mfote/rwqen tetrhme/non, schol.), in which a)mfi/trhtos would be normal, cannot be illustrated by sidhrokmh/s (‘slain with the sword,’ Soph. Ai. 325), or dorikmh/s Aesch. Ch. 365), since those adjectives=‘succumbing to’ the sword, etc. (from the poet. sense of oi( kamo/ntes, etc.). But botoi=s sidhrokmh=sin in the former passage illustrates the use of a)mfitrh/s, properly masc. or fem., as a neuter adj.
au)li/ou, as 954, 1087: cp. 30 n.
ei)/per e)sti\ sw=n, a doubt the more natural since the island was volcanic (800).

a(/ moi proselqw
 … kurei=: ‘advance, I pray thee (moi), towards them’ [the cave and spring], ‘and sign (to me) whether he still occupies this same spot, or is elsewhere.’ The position of moi indicates that it is the ethic dat. ( O. T. 1512), rather than dat. with sh/maine, with which it can easily be understood.—In the Appendix reasons are given for the following views. (1) The words sh/main' ei(/t' e)/xei break the metrical rule, since ei)/t) must be considered as metrically belonging to e)/xei rather than to sh/maine, and therefore the 5th foot ought to be an iambus. But nevertheless the words are sound, since the natural stress on the first syllable of the imperative sh/main), coinciding with the rhythmical ictus, has the effect of making the next syllable (ain) seem relatively short to the ear. (2) In v. 23 the traditional xw=ron pro\s au)to
 is untenable. pro/s with acc. could here mean only, ‘looking towards,’ ‘facing’; it could not mean merely, ‘in the neighbourhood of.’ And e)/xei | xw=ron pro\s au)to
 to/nde could not mean either, ‘(the cave and spring) are situated facing just this spot’; nor, ‘he dwells facing this spot.’ We should read with Blaydes, xw=ron to
 au)to/n. (3) to/nd' e)/t), ei)/t) is the best correction of L's to/nd), h)/t) in v. 23: and e)/t) confirms the view that Philoctetes is the subject to the verbs. Odysseus is sure that the cave is somewhere near (16). His doubt is whether Philoctetes still lives in it, or has removed to some other part of the island.

ta)pi/loipa tw=n lo/gwn, not tou\s e)piloi/pous, because the lo/goi are thought of collectively, not singly; cp. 131; Ant. 499tw=n sw=n lo/gwn | a)resto\n ou)de/n: Tr. 682qesmw=n ou)de/n: Plat. Rep. 352 B ta\ loipa\ th=s e(stia/sews. The ref. is to the plan disclosed at 50 ff.
koina\, subst., ‘joint action’ (not adv., ‘jointly,’ as though the subject to i)/h| were ‘our plan,’ implied in ta)pi/loipa tw=n lo/gwn): cp. Thuc. 1. 8plwimw/tera e)ge/neto par' a)llh/lous.
e)c a)mfoi=n i)/h|, lit., ‘proceed from both’: cp. Eur. Hec. 294lo/gos ga\r e)/k t' a)docou/ntwn i)w\n | ka)k tw=n dokou/ntwn au(to\s ou) tau)to\n sqe/nei.

tou)/rgon ou) makra\n le/geis,=to\ e)/rgon o)\ le/geis ou) makra/n e)sti, ‘the task of which thou speakest is not far off,’ i.e. I can do thy bidding without going far. to\ e)/rgon is the search for (and in) the cave. This seems simpler than to take makra/n as=‘to a distance’ (O.T. 16), and tou)/rgon as=‘mission.’ For the adverb as predicate, cp. O. C. 586a)ll' e)n braxei= dh\ th/nde m' e)caitei= xa/rin, n.: Tr. 962a)gxou= d' a)/ra kou) makra\n | prou)/klaion (sc. o)/n), ‘the sorrow foretold by my lament is near, and not afar’: El. 1191po/qen tou=t' e)cesh/mhnas kako/n;
a)/nwqen, h)\ ka/twqen; i.e. above or below Neoptolemus, who is climbing the rocks. Odysseus is on the sea-shore. Cp. 1000 ff.

kai\ sti/bou g' ou)dei\s ktu/pos, ‘and of foot-fall, at least, there is no sound.’ The ge, which has been suspected, is fitting; he is still a little below the cave, and cannot yet see whether it is empty. Seyffert's kai\ sti/bou d' would be appropriate only if it followed the mention of some other sign that the cave was empty.

sti/bou, usu. ‘track (path),’ or ‘footprint,’ here, the act of treading: cp. 206 sti/bou kat' a)na/gkan, n. Remark how strongly ktu/pos (L's reading) is confirmed, as against tu/pos, by v. 30, where Odysseus says (in effect), ‘perhaps the reason why you hear no sound is that he is asleep within.’—Other readings are kai\ sti/bou g' ou)dei\s tu/pos (Tricl. and Brunck): kai\ sti/bou )st' ou)x e(=s tu/pos (Mudge): kai\ sti/bou )st' ou)/dei tu/pos (Bergk; though ou)=das is the only case of the noun found in Tragedy). These assume that there was sand or earth just in front of the cave on the side towards the sea. But vv. 1000 ff. imply that the cave's seaward mouth opened on steep rocks at some height above the beach. And if v. 29 referred to the presence or absence of foot-prints, v. 30 would lose its special point.
kaq' u(/pnon: Tr. 970kaq' u(/pnon o)/nta: but here w)/n need not be supplied; the phrase is adverbial, with kataulisqei\s kurh=|.

kataulisqei\s, ‘lodged’ (cp. 19 au)li/ou, 153 au)la/s), a word suitable to rough or temporary quarters, as to a bivouac: Xen. An. 7. 5. 15kathuli/sqhsan d' e)n tw=| pedi/w|: so Soph. El. 304(Electra speaking of her rustic cot tage) oi(/ois e)n pe/plois au)li/zomai (cp. ib. 168 a)gro/teiran au)la/n). katakliqei\s, the weak reading of some later MSS., was prob. suggested by kaq' u(/pnon.

kurh=| is the reading of our MSS., and, though their authority on such a point is not great, the subjunct. seems here slightly better than kurei=. o(/ra mh\...kurei=, ‘see whether he is not,’ would imply that in the speaker's mind there was little doubt on the subject: cp. notes on Ant. 278, Ant. 1253: Plat. Charm. 163 A a)ll' o(/ra mh\ e)kei=non kwlu/ei: Lach. 196 C a)ll' o(rw=men mh\ *niki/as oi)/etai/ ti le/gein: Theaet. 145 C o(/ra mh\ pai/zwn e)/legen. These are admonitions in the polite guise of suggestions. Now here we may, indeed, conceive Odysseus as saying mh\...kurei=: but, in the anxious uncertainty which he actually feels, it is more natural that he should say mh\...kurh=|. If it be said that general Attic usage rather favours the indic. after o(/ra mh/, we may refer to El. 1003 and fr. 82 (a)ll' o(/ra mh\ krei=sson h)=|) as a few places out of several where the subjunct. after o(/ra mh/ is proved by metre.

o(rw=. Neoptolemus, mounting the rocks, has now just reached the mouth of the cave. kenh\n is made more explicit by a)nqrw/pwn di/xa: ‘empty,—yes, there is no man there.’ Such iteration is natural when the mind confirms itself in a first impression, or dwells on a striking thought; so Verg. Aen. 4. 588 vacuos sensit sine remige portus (‘empty,—no rower there’); Ai. 464gumno\n fane/nta tw=n a)ristei/wn a)/ter ‘(when I return) ungraced,—aye, without the meed of valour.’ Cp. 487: O. T. 57 n., Ant. 445 n.

oi)kopoio/s … tis trofh/, ‘any comforts, such as make a human dwelling,’ in contradistinction to a wild beast's lair. trofh/ here=‘what sustains life,’—not only food and drink, but also provision for necessary repose and warmth: cp. Plat. Legg. 667 B e)dwdh=| me\n kai\ po/sei kai\ cumpa/sh| trofh=|, ‘food and drink and the comforts of life generally.’ The question of Odysseus is comprehensive; in reply, Neopt. can only mention a bed; but that does not require us to assume that Od.used trofh/ in the specific sense of ‘furniture.’ The objection which has been made to trofh/ here thus falls to the ground. Against Welcker's trufh/, remark:—(1) The irony would be misplaced here, where Od.is anxiously seeking information; it is otherwise in v. 37, where the slightly ironical tone of qhsau/risma shows the first gleam of sinister joy. (2) The phrase oi)kopoio\s...trufh/ would be infelicitous. The adjective itself shows that the substantive ought to denote the rudiments, not the refinements, of a home.

stipth/ ge k.t.l., ‘aye, a heap of leaves pressed down, as if for the use of one who sleeps in the place.’ Here ge serves to correct the suggestion contained in the negative question: ‘There is nothing there?’ ‘Yes, there is something.’ In this use it may be compared with the Fr.si, since it is corrective without being emphatic. (‘Vous n'avez pas été là?’—‘Si.’) Cp. 35. For the spelling stipth/, see v. 2. A bed of leaves (or rushes, etc.) was called stiba/s ( Eur. Tro. 507stiba/da pro\s xamaipeth=). [Eur. ] Rhes. 9 lei=pe xameu/nas fullostrw/tous (of soldiers bivouacking). stipth/ means, pressed down by the body of the person who has slept on it. Some take e)nauli/zonti/tw| as dat. of agent with stipth/ (pressed down by some one lodging here); but the order of words renders it simpler to take the dat. as one of interest. Hartung, whom Nauck follows, changes stipth/ to strwth/, finding a hint of the latter in one of the two scholia on this v. in L, xamaistrwsi/a e)k fu/llwn. But that may refer to the one word fulla/s: while the other scholium unequivocally refers to stipth/, —h(plwme/nh kai\ patoume/nh, (‘spread out, and pressed down,’) w(s koimwme/nou e)p' au)th=| tinos. If it be said that h(plwme/nh might refer to strwth/, we may reply that patoume/nh could refer only to stipth/: and by h(plwme/nh the schol. meant (I think) to express that the leaves formed, not a soft heap, but only a shallow layer. stipth/ is more graphic than strwth/: it suggests the recent impress of the body, and the cheerless discomfort of the couch.—For w(s with e)nauli/zonti/ tw|, cp. 203.

ta\ d' a)/ll), all parts of the cave except that covered by the bed of leaves: e)/rhma, ‘bare,’ i.e. without any sign of inhabitation. The second question, kou)de/n k.t.l., repeats the first in a more precise form.

au)to/culon, ‘of mere wood,’ means here, ‘of wood not artistically treated’; the piece of wood remained as nearly in its original state as was compatible with its serving for a cup. Cp. fr. com. 322 au)to/pokon i(ma/tion, a cloak of rough wool: Alexis *ku/prios 2 to\n d' au)to/puron a)/rton, the loaf of unbolten wheat-flour: see O.C. 192 au)tope/trou bh/matos n.
flaurourgou=: seemingly the only extant instance of the form flau=ros in a compound adj.

texnh/mat): the poet. plur. has a certain dignity, and there is possibly a shade of designed irony in its use here: Scut. 313 tri/pos, kluta\ e)/rga peri/fronos (*hfai/stoio: Eur. Or. 1053mnh=ma, ...ke/drou texna/smata (a coffin,...finely wrought of cedar): Virg. Aen. 5. 359 clypeum … Didymaonis artes.
purei=a, igniaria, ‘means of kindling a fire,’ the stones mentioned in 296, and perhaps also bits of wood with which to catch the spark.

kei/nou, predicate, cp. Plat. Apol. 20 E ou) ga e)mo
 e)rw= to
 lo/gon (=o( lo/gos, o(
 e)rw=, ou)k e)mo\s e)/stai).

qhsau/risma, ‘store’ (not so strong as ‘treasure’): the verb qhsauri/zw was used of ‘laying in’ supplies for household use ( Xen. Cyr. 8. 2. 24); cp. Soph. El. 497qhsau/risma *dionu/sou (store of wine). Yet here the word is ironical, since the ‘store’ is so wretched.

i)ou\ i)ou/, a cry of surprise, with which the watcher greets the beacon in Aesch. Ag. 25,—where it is ‘extra metrum,’ as in Soph. Ai. 737.It stands within the verse, as here, in Soph. O. T. 1071, Soph. O. T. 1182, Soph. Tr. 1143.

kai\ tau=ta/ g). In v. 29, kai\ sti/bou g), ge specially emphasises the word sti/bou: here, it does not specially emphasise tau=ta, but helps kai/ to introduce the new fact; i.e., it is not, ‘and here are rags,’ but rather, ‘yes, and here are rags.’ Wherever kai/ … ge occurs, it is well to note in which of these two ways it is used. Examples like kai\ tau=ta/ g) here are, below, 1296 kai\ pe/las g): O. T. 1132kou)de/n ge qau=ma: ib. 1319 kai\ qau=ma/ g' ou)de/n. Examples like kai\ sti/bou g) are, below, O. T. 674kai\ se/ g' ei)sa/cw: 1277 kai\ pe/ra g' i)/sq' h)\ le/gw.
a)/lla, ‘withal’ (i.e., besides the other objects already found): cp. O.T. 290 n.: Aesch. Theb. 424gi/gas o(/d' a)/llos.

qa/lpetai, ‘are drying’ in the sun at the seaward mouth of the cave (cp. 17). Not, ‘are warm’ to the touch,—as if recently used. Cp. Helen. 181 a(li/ou pe/plous | au)gai=sin e)n tai=s xruse/ais | a)mfiqa/lpous).

barei/as, ‘grievous,’ the epithet of the malady itself, as 1330 no/sou barei/as. Not ‘fetid’ (like gravis...hircus, Hor. Ep. 12. 5),—a sense in which baru/s occurs only when it is the epithet of o)smh/, a)tmi/s ( Hist. An. 9. 5), etc.

noshlei/as (subst. from noshlo/s, ‘morbid,’) here=the matter discharged from the ulcer in the foot; cp. 824. Isocr. uses noshleu/w as=‘to tend the sick,’ and Plut. has noshlei/a as either (i) ‘sickness,’ or (ii) ‘nursing of the sick.’
ple/a, tainted, stained with: cp. Xen. Cyr. 1. 3. 5(h( xei\r) ple/a soi a)p' au)tw=n e)ge/neto, has been defiled by those things: so plh/reis, Soph. Ant. 1017.
ou)x e(ka/s pou, as 163 pe/las pou, O.T. 1410 e)/cw...pou.
khri\, ‘plague,’ as 1166 kh=ra ta/nd' a)pofeu/gein,—but without ref. to the idea that the no/sos was ordained by fate (1326).

prosbai/h, in the sense of ‘advance,’ where we should have expected probai/h, is certainly strange. It is partly excused, however, by the fact that the speaker is himself outside of the cave, and so can the more naturally place himself in imagination at the external point towards which the movement is made,—saying, ‘come far,’ instead of, ‘go far.’ I do not feel sure, then, that prosbai/h is corrupt, though it is suspicious. If corrupt, it probably conceals a compound with pro/. In the Classical Review (vol. II. p. 324, 1888) I have conjectured proska/zoi, ‘limp forth.’ Minuscule b and k often resemble each other (thus in Ant. 1094lakei=n is corrected from labei=n). If proska/zoi had become prosba/zoi, thelatter would easily have generated prosbai/h. A verb describing painful movement would be fitting here, after nosw=n...kw=lon palaia=| khri/: cp. o)gmeu/ei (163), ei)luo/mhn (291). It is immaterial that this particular compound of ska/zw does not occur elsewhere; many verbal compounds occur once only, as, e.g., prodei/sas ( O. T. 90), prokli/nas ( O. C. 201). For other conjectures, see Appendix.

forbh=s no/ston. The defence of this much-impugned phrase depends on three points. (1) no/stos is poetically used in the general sense of o(do/s: I. A. 1261 (speaking of the Greeks), oi(=s no/stos ou)k e)/st' )*ili/ou pu/rgous e)/pi. (2) In forbh=s-no/stos, a food-journey, the gen. denotes the object of the no/stos: the principle is the same as in I. T. 1066 gh=s patrw/|as no/stos, ‘a fatherland-return,’ i.e. a return to it: Orph. Argon. 200 e)pi\ plo/on *)acei/noio, on a voyage to the Euxine. (3) The poet has not said, e)celh/luqe forbh=s no/ston (‘cognate’ acc.), but e)celh/luqen e)pi\ forbh=s no/ston, thus marking that no/ston denotes, not merely the act of going out, but the purpose of that act, viz., a quest. In other words, the presence of e)pi\ before it already tinges no/ston with the sense of zh/thsin: cp. Her. 4. 140u(pe/strefon e)pi\ zh/thsin tw=n *perse/wn.—The conjecture a)ll' h)\ )pi\ forbh\n no/ston e)celh/luqen seems, then, needless; but it is also open to a strong positive objection, viz. that no/ston then becomes a mere pleonasm. A cognate acc. added to e)celh/luqen ought here to qualify it in some manner (cp. Soph. Ai. 287e)co/dous e(/rpein kena/s).
h)\ fu/llon k.t.l. The constr. is, h)/, ei) fu/llon nw/duno/n ti ka/toide/ pou, (e)p' au)to/): rather than, h)\ (e)pi\) fu/llon, ei)/ ti nw/dunon (fu/llon) ka/toide/ pou.
nw/dunon, in active sense: Anthol. app. 57 farma/kois a)nwdu/nois.
to\n … paro/nta,—‘thy attendant,’— the young chief's pro/spolos, who is called skopo/s at v. 125. The phrase does not imply that he is actually at his master's side on the rocks.
mh\ kai\, cp. 13.
prospesw/n, of sudden and unforeseen approach ( O. C. 1157): the same phrase below, O. C. 156, and Eur. Heracl. 338.

e(/loito/ m). The enclitic me is warranted here (though e(/loit' e)/m' might seem more natural), since the words, mh\ kai\ la/qh| me prospesw/n, have already indicated Odysseus as the person chiefly menaced. It is as though he said: ‘We must take care that he does not surprise me; it would delight him more than to capture all the Greeks’; where the unemphatic ‘it’ would resemble the enclitic me as merely referring back to a case already indicated. A similar instance (and one that is certified by metre) occurs below, 1049 ff.: ou(= ga\r toiou/twn dei=, toiou=to/s ei)m' e)gw/: | xw(/pou dikai/wn ka)gaqw=n a)ndrw=n kri/sis, | ou)k a)\n la/bois mou ma=llon ou)de/n) eu)sebh=: where the e)gw/ in 1049 makes it needless to have e)mou= in 1051. Such cases are distinct from those in which the enclitic form of the pers. pron. is justified by the fact that the chief emphasis is on a verbal notion (e.g., 958: Ant. 546mh/ moi qa/nh|s su\ koina/, ‘share not my death’).—The first hand in L seems to have written e(/loite m) (sic): the corrector changed the second e to o, accenting the latter. If there had been reason to think that the first hand in L wrote e(/loit' e)/m), then I should have taken that reading, not as better than e(/loito/ m), but as equally good and better attested.— labei=n, ‘catch,’ ‘find in his power.’ molei=n in A was prob. a conjecture, or a mere error, rather than, as Boissonade supposed, a corruption of m' e(lei=n. For the difference between e(lei=n and labei=n (in regard to warfare), see Il. 5. 144e)/nq' e(/len *)astu/noon (‘slew’), and ib. 159 e)/nq' ui(=as *pria/moio du/w la/be *dardavi/dao, | ei)n e(ni\ di/frw| e)o/ntas (‘caught’). Cp. below, 101, 103; O. T. 266 zhtw=n to\n au)to/xeira tou= fo/nou labei=n (‘find’).—Blaydes says that labei=n is ‘clearly wrong,’ and reads balei=n (‘hit’).
a)ll), in assent, like ‘oh, well,’ —the implied adversative sense being, ‘nay, I have no objection’: cp. 232, 336, 645, 647.

e)/rxetai, sc. o( parw/n (45), ‘he goes,’ i.e., ‘I send him’ (said as he makes a sign to the pro/spolos). Cp. 1181 mh\...e)/lqh|s, ‘depart not’: Ant. 99a)/nous me\n e)/rxei: Tr. 595e)leu/setai (‘depart’).— te kai\ marks the full assent to v. 45: he shall go, and for that purpose.
fula/cetai, the fut. pass. in good prose also ( Xen. Oec. 4. 9): fulaxqh/somai was late. For other such futures, cp. 303: Ant. 93 n.
deute/rw| lo/gw|, ‘in further speech,’— continuing the former discourse. Cp. Pind. O. 1. 43deute/rw| xro/nw|,=u(ste/rw|.

e)f' oi(=s=e)pi\ tou/tois e)f' oi(=s, ‘for’ (i.e., ‘so as to aid’) ‘the objects for which,’ etc.; cp. O. T. 1457mh\ )pi/ tw| deinw=| kakw=|.—The sentence begins as if the form were to be, dei=...gennai=on ei)=nai, mh\ mo/non tw=| sw/mati, a)lla\ kai\ th=| gnw/mh|: he must show his true-bred spirit, not merely physically, but morally,—i.e., by bringing himself (to/lma, 82) to aid plans which may be repugnant to him. Neopt. supposed that his task was to take Phil. by force (pro\s bi/an, 90). Odysseus seeks to prepare the disclosure very gently. Hence the hypothetical clause which takes the place of a simple a)lla\ kai\ th=| gnw/mh|, viz., a)ll) h)/n ti kaino/n, k.t.l. After that clause, a modal partic., u(pourgou=nta (‘by serving’), ought to have balanced the instrumental dat. tw=| sw/mati. But, instead of it, we have a second infin., u(pourgei=n, depending, like ei)=nai, on dei=: just as, in independent sentences, a new finite verb is often substituted for a second participial clause ( O. C. 351 n.: Ant. 256, Ant. 816).

gennai=on, ‘true-bred.’ to\ gennai=on is, as Arist. defines it (Hist. An. 1. 1. 32), to\ mh\ e)cista/menon e)k th=s au(tou= fu/sews. Odysseus calls on Neopt. to prove himself a true son of his sire (cp. 3) by complete loyalty to his mission.
tw=| sw/mati: cp. Suppl. 886 i(/ppois te xai/rwn to/ca t' e)ntei/nwn xeroi=n, | po/lei parasxei=n sw=ma xrh/simon qe/lwn.
kaino/n, euphemistic, as oft.: cp. A. d. § 2 kaino/tata ga\r dh/, ei) xrh\ kaino/tata ma=llon h)\ kakourgo/tata ei)pei=n, diaba/llousi/ me.

w(=n (tou/twn a(\) pri\n ou)k a)kh/koas, ‘(some novel thing), viz., one of those things which thou hast not heard before’; i.e., ‘a part of my plans which has not hitherto been disclosed to thee.’ Cp. Eur. Med. 356ou) ga/r ti dra/seis deino/n, w(=n fo/bos m' e)/xei.

u(phre/ths, like u(phretei=n in 15, said of a friend and equal. Cp. Soph. El. 821(Orestes) *pula/dhn me\n ei(/let' e)n po/nois u(phre/thn, | dmw=as d' a)pwqei=: and so even in good prose, as Xen. An. 1. 9. 18.

ti/ dh=t' a)/nwgas; The division of the verse between the speakers (a)ntilabh/) serves at once to mark the surprise of Neopt. and to introduce the words of Od.with a certain abrupt force: cp. O. C. 722 n.

se dei= k.t.l. Two other examples of this constr. are extant: Ai. 556dei= s' o(/pws patro\s | dei/ceis e)n e)xqroi=s oi)=os e)c o(/ou )tra/fhs: Cratinus (the poet of the Old Comedy), *ne/mesis fr. 3 dei= s' o(/pws eu)sxh/monos | a)lektruo/nos mhde\n dioi/seis tou\s tro/pous. In both these passages, as in this, the constr. is used by an elder, or superior, in giving a precept of conduct. The admonitory tone thus associated with the formula confirms the text, as against Matthiae's conjecture, se dei=n yuxh\n o(/pws lo/goisin e)kkle/yeis le/gw. The acc. of the object (se) is like that in dei= se tou/tou: while the o(/pws clause (answering to the genitive there) is like that in e)de/onto *boiwtou\s o(/pws paradw/sousi ( Thuc. 5. 36§ 2). The partic. le/gwn explains the instrum. dat. lo/goisin more clearly; it is not instrumental (‘by speaking’), but temporal; i.e., literally, ‘as you go on speaking.’ It indicates that Neopt. is to converse alone with Phil. (cp. 70, o(mili/a), and is to deceive him in the course of their conversation. The next verse makes this still clearer:—‘When he asks, say,’ etc. A similar use of le/gwn, to denote the process of talk, is frequent in Herod. , when, after epitomising part of a speech, he gives the sequel in the speaker's own words; as 3. 156, ‘nu=n te,’ e)/fh le/gwn,... ‘And now,’ he went on to say,...(lit., said, as he went on speaking).—Other ways of taking le/gwn, which seem less good, are:—(1) As instrum. partic., with which au)tou/s is to be supplied from lo/goisin: ‘with words,...i.e., by speaking them.’ For this view, Schneidewin cp. Legg. 885 B o(/sa lo/gw| kai\ o(/sa e)/rgw| peri\ qeou\s u(bri/zei tis le/gwn h)\ pra/ttwn. (2) As instrum. partic., used absolutely, to emphasise lo/goisin,—‘with words,—I repeat, by speaking.’ (3) As instrum. partic., to be taken closely with lo/goisin, in the sense, ‘speaking vain words.’ This is Seyffert's view, who explains lo/gois le/gein as meris verbis dicere: a sense which the phrase could not bear.
e)kkle/yeis: here related to kle/ptein, fallere ( Tr. 243ei) mh\ sumforai\ kle/ptousi/ me), as e)capata=n to a)pata=n. Cp. 968. Il. 14. 217h(/ t' e)/kleye no/on pu/ka per froneo/ntwn.

le/gein, infin. for imper. (O. C. 481 n.); not depending on dei= in 54.— *)axille/ws, ˘¯¯. The e suffers synizesis again in 364, 582, 1066, 1237, 1298, 1312: though not in 4, 50, 241, 260, 1220, 1433.

to/d' ou)xi\ klepte/on: lit., ‘this thing’ (his parentage) ‘must not be represented falsely,’—i.e., the truth must not be hidden. kle/ptein ti can mean, ‘to do (or speak) a thing fraudulently’: Ai. 189kle/ptousi mu/qous, they speak false words. In Tr. 437mh\...e)kkle/yh|s lo/gon= ‘do not keep back the story’; but the simple kle/ptein could not literally express this.—krupte/on is a tame conjecture.
plei=s is more dramatic than plei=n, which would also be awkward after le/gein.

w(s pro\s oi)=kon. pro/s states the direction of the voyage: w(s merely adds an indication of the voyager's purpose: ‘thou art homeward bound.’ (Not, ‘thou art sailing as if for home,’ with ref. to the story being untrue.) Cp. Ai. 44h)= kai\ to\ bou/leum' w(s e)p' *)argei/ois to/d' h)=n; ‘was this plot, in his intention (w(s), against the Greeks?’ (though the actual victims were the cattle). Thuc. 4. 93pareskeua/zeto w(s e)s ma/xhn, made his dispositions with a view (w(s) to fighting. H. 1. 1. 12 a)na/gesqai h)/dh au)tou= me/llontos w(s e)pi\ naumaxi/an.

e)/xqos e)xqh/ras me/ga: cp. El. 1034ou)d' au)= tosou=ton e)/xqos e)xqai/rw s' e)gw/. For the aor. part. cp. 227, 309: Pind. N. 7. 88filh/sant) (having formed a friendship); Soph. O. T. 11 n., Soph. O. T. 649 n.
oi(/, with causal force (Lat. qui with subjunct.): O. C. 263 n.

e)n litai=s, by means of prayers: cp. 102 e)n do/lw|...a)/gein, 1393 e)n lo/gois | pei/qein: Ant. 764 n.— stei/lantes … molei=n: lit., having caused thee to set forth, so that thou shouldst come from home: cp. Ant. 164u(ma=s d' e)gw\ pompoi=sin e)k pa/ntwn di/ka | e)/steil' i(ke/sqai. Odysseus and Phoenix were sent from Troy to bring the young Neoptolemus from Scyros: 343 ff.

mo/nhn. If L's mo/nhn d' were sound, then stei/lantes (me/n) and e)/xontes de/ would express two reasons why the conduct of the Atreidae was bad:—‘when they had brought thee from home, and when that was their only way of taking Troy,’— the second clause implying that, as his presence was so momentous, his claim to good treatment was the stronger. But mo/nhn, without d), is clearly right. Then e)/xontes is causal, expressing the motive of stei/lantes,—‘having brought thee,... since they had no other way,’ etc. The insertion of d), if not a mere error, may have been due to a corrector who, not perceiving the relation of the two participles, thought that they required a copula.
a(/lwsin, means of capture: Thuc. 2. 75xw=ma e)/xoun pro\s th\n po/lin, nomi/zontes taxi/sthn ai(/resin [th\n ai(/resin Classen] e)/sesqai au)tw=n (the quickest way of taking the place).

tw=n *)axillei/wn o(/plwn, gen. depending on the principal verb h)ci/wsan, instead of an acc., ta\ *)axi/lleia o(/pla, depending on the infin. dou=nai. This construction arises from eagerness for compact expression of the main idea,— as here the main idea is completely expressed by v. 62. The ‘epexegetic’ infin., like dou=nai, is usu. the only word added: but here it is naturally supplemented by the words which denote the aggravating circumstances (e)lqo/nti...kuri/ws ai)toume/nw|). Legg. 941 D di/khs ou)=n ou)de/teron ou)dete/rou e)la/ttonos...o( no/mos a)cioi= zhmiou=n (instead of a)cioi= zhmiou=n di/kh|). Thuc. 3. 6kai\ th=s me\n qala/sshs ei)=rgon mh\ xrh=sqai tou\s *mutilhnai/ous. Cp. Soph. O. C. 1211 n.— kuri/ws, with good right (tuo iure), as heir of Achilles; cp. Dem. or. 36 § 32 kuri/ws do/ntos tou= patro\s...kata\ tou\s no/mous au)th\n gegamh=sqai.
pare/dosan, handed over,—a word suggesting fraud or treachery, as oft.; cp. 399.

le/gwn refers back to le/gein in 57 (with which, as infin. for imperat., the nomin. is rightly used in the 2nd pers., O. T. 1529 n.). Odysseus leaves the available epithets to his young friend's imagination. Cp. O. T. 1287boa=| dioi/gein klh=|qra kai\ dhlou=n tina | toi=s pa=si *kadmei/oisi to
 patrokto/non, | to
 mhtro/s, au)dw=n a)no/si) ou)de\ r(hta/ moi. I. T. 16 kai\ le/gei *ka/lxas ta/de: | ...‘pai=d' ou)=n e)n oi)/kois sh\ *klutaimnh/stra da/mar | ti/ktei’— to\ kallistei=on ei)s e)/m' a)nafe/rwn— | ‘h(
 xrh/ se qu=sai.’
kaq' h(mw=n, in this context, seems best taken as=kat' e)mou=: for the sing. me so closely following, see n. on Ant. 734po/lis ga\r h(mi=n a(me\ xrh\ ta/ssein e)rei=;
e)/sxat' e)sxa/twn: cp. O. T. 465a)/rrht' a)rrh/twn n.

66 *tou/tw| ga k.t.l. The reading tou/twn ga ou)de/n m' a)lgunei=s is probably that which stood in L's archetype; for the inserted n, by which ou)de/m) has been made into ou)de/nm), is due to the first corrector of L, who revised the work of the scribe by comparing the copy with the original. The first question, then, is whether that reading can be kept. It is required to mean:—‘for in regard to no one of these things’ (viz., the kaka/, taunts) ‘wilt thou pain me.’ But it would properly mean:—‘for thou wilt not cause me any of these pains.’ Cp. 1021 e)gw\ d' a)lgu/nomai | tou=t' au)/q' o(/ti zw= k.t.l., ‘I feel just this pain,—that I live,’ etc.: Ar. Ach. 2h(/sqhn de\ baia\... | a(\ d' w)dunh/qhn, k.t.l.: Soph. Ant. 550ti/ tau=t' a)nia=|s m) (cause me this distress). Before tou/twn ga ou)de/n m' a)lgunei=s could be accepted, it would be needful to show that a cognate acc. (ou)de/n) could thus replace an instrum. dat. The next question concerns its origin. It might be suggested that the ou)de/m) of the 1st hand in L came, not from ou)de/n m), but from ou)de/n), and that the sense is, ‘thou wilt pain no one of them’ (masc.),—so that kaq' h(mw=n in 65 should mean, Odysseus and the Atreidae. But this cannot be; for, here, there has been no direct mention of the Atreidae,—only of *)axaiw=n generally (59); and so, for contrast with pa=sin *)argei/ois (67), the pain denoted by a)lgunei=s must be pain to Odysseus. tou/twn ga ou)de/n' a)lgunei=s being thus set aside, we have to weigh (1) tou/twn ga ou)de
 a)lgunei= m),— Dindorf's conjecture; and (2) tou/tw| ga ou)de/n m' a)lgunei=s,—Buttmann's. Both being possible, the question is, which of them is most likely to have generated tou/twn ga ou)de/n m' a)lgunei=s. The fact that a)lgunei=s precedes e)rga/sei diminishes the probability that a)lgunei=s arose from a)lgunei= m) by assimilation of persons. Further, had ou)de/n m' a)lgunei=s come from ou)de
 a)lgunei= m), we might have expected to find a variant, ou)de
 a)lgunei=s m). If, on the other hand, the words ou)de/n m' a)lgunei=s are genuine, we have only to suppose a change of tou/twi into tou/twn. On these palaeographical grounds Buttmann's reading appears preferable to Dindorf's.

mh\: for ei) e)rga/sei mh/, instead of ei) mh\ e)rga/sei, cp. 332, 653, O. T. 328 n., El. 993: for mh/ as first word of a verse, when a word with which it is construed stands in the preceding verse, cp. O. C. 1349(ei)... | mh/), O. T. 348(o(/son | mh/).— balei=s here=e)mbalei=s (or prosbalei=s), ‘inflict’ on them: cp. Tr. 915 f. demni/ois | ...ba/llousan fa/rh: Eur. Phoen. 1534sko/ton o)/mmasi soi=si balw/n. In poetry the simple dat. (instead of dat. or accus. with a prep.) is sometimes thus used to denote the object to, or against, which an action is directed: cp. n. on Soph. Ant. 1232ptu/sas prosw/pw|. Not, ‘launch against them,’ as though the lu/ph were a missile; nor, ‘sow’ sorrow for them, like a)ni/as moi kataspei/ras, Soph. Ai. 1005.

ei)...mh\ lhfqh/setai, ou)k e)/sti k.t.l. ‘if the bow is not to be taken, then it is impossible’ etc. Here the condition expressed by the fut. ind. in the protasis is really a present one; the meaning is, ‘if it is (now) settled that the bow is not to be taken.’ Cp. Xen. An. 3. 4. 39ou)k e)/sti parelqei=n, ei) mh\ tou/tous a)poko/yomen: ‘it is an impossibility to advance, if we are not to dislodge these men’ (i.e. assuming that we do not mean to dislodge them). Practically, this is a more emphatic way of expressing the necessity of the act to which the protasis refers. Distinguish those cases in which the condition expressed by the fut. indic. is really future; as in 66 f., ei) mh\ e)rga/sei (‘if thou fail to do this’), balei=s: and in 75 f. ei)/ me ai)sqh/setai (‘if he shall perceive me’), o)/lwla (i.e. o)lou=mai): where e)a\n mh\ e)rga/sh|, e)a/n me ai)/sqh| would differ from the fut. ind. with ei) only as being somewhat less vivid.

ou)k e)/sti pe/rsai soi. The difference between soi and soi\ here resembles that between ‘thou canst never take’ and ‘thou canst never take.’ L supports soi\, which is, of course, quite tenable. But soi seems preferable, because (a) in giving a reason, as ga/r implies, why ‘all the Greeks’ will be pained, it seems less fitting to place the personal concern of Neoptolemus in the foreground; and (b) the necessary emphasis on soi\ in v. 70 would have a slightly awkward effect if the same pron. had been emphasised in v. 69. Cp. n. on 47, e(/loito/ m).

to\ *darda/nou pe/don, the land of Dardanus,—meaning *troi/a in its larger sense, the town with its territory (cp. 920 ta\ *troi/as pedi/a, 1435 e(lei=n to\ *troi/as pedi/on). So O. C. 380to\ *kadmei/wn pe/don=*qh/bhs pe/don (ib. 415). Dardanus, son of Zeus, was fifth ancestor of Priam ( Il. 20. 215 ff.). Cp. Pind. O. 13. 56pro\ *darda/nou teixe/wn: Helen. 1493 *darda/nou | po/lin.

w(s d' e)/st' e)moi\ me\n ou)xi/ k.t.l.: cp. Xen. An. 2. 5. 35oi( de\ pa/ntes me\n ou)k h)=lqon, *)ariai=os de\ kai\ *)arta/ozos k.t.l. —Odysseus anticipates the objection that, if there is to be a stratagem, he should conduct it himself,—as Aesch. and Eur. had made him do: cp. 13 n.
o(mili/a, merely ‘intercourse,’ in a general sense: the special meaning, ‘colloquy,’ (seen in the Gk. Mod. o(mile/w=‘to speak,’) is postclassical.
pisth\, trusted by Philoctetes; cp. 1272. be/baios, safe for Neoptolemus.

e)/norkos. Odysseus was bound by the oath which all the suitors of Helen had sworn to her father Tyndareus,— that they would come to her husband's aid, if he was robbed of her: I. A. 61 o(/tou gunh\ ge/noito *tundari\s ko/rh, | tou/tw| cunamunei=n, ei)/tis e)k do/mwn labw\n | oi)/xoito. So Ajax came to Troy ou(/nex' o(/rkwn oi(=sin h)=n e)nw/motos ( Ai. 1113). Paus. was shown the place, called *(/ippou mnh=ma, on the road from Lacedaemon into Arcadia, where Tyndareus, having sacrificed a horse, tou\s *(ele/nhs e)cw/rkou mnhsth=ras (3. 20. 9).

e)c a)na/gkhs: Odysseus feigned madness, in order to avoid going to Troy, but Palamedes detected the trick: cp. 1025 n.—tou= prw/tou sto/lou, partit. gen., thou hast not sailed ‘on’ (=‘as a member of’) the first expedition. Cp. Dem. or. 21 § 202 ou)damou= pw/pote o( *meidi/as tw=n sunhdome/nwn ou)de\ tw=n sugxairo/ntwn e)chta/sqh tw=| dh/mw| (‘has nowhere figured in the ranks of those who share the pleasure and joy of the people’).—The prw=tos sto/los is the original Greek expedition, as distinguished from the voyage of Odysseus and Phoenix when they brought Neop. from Scyros (343 ff.).
e)gkrath\s: for the omission of w)/n, even when, as here, the adj. marks a condition, cp. n. on Ant. 1327bra/xista ga\r kra/tista ta)n posi\n kaka/ i.e. bra/xista (o)/nta) kra/tista/ (e)sti).
o)/lwla: cp. O. T. 1166o)/lwlas, ei)/ se tau=t' e)rh/somai pa/lin: Xen. An. 1. 8. 12ka)\n tou=t), e)/fh, nikw=men, pa/nq' h(mi=n pepoi/htai. Plaut. Amphitruo 1. 1. 64 perii, si me adspexerit.

prosdiafqerw= ought not to be changed (as Tournier proposed) to prosdiafqei/rw. The force of o)/lwla, used in the sense of o)lou=mai, would be weakened, not enhanced, by a repetition of the device; while, on the other hand, the natural future prosdiafqerw= makes the rhetorical o)/lwla more impressive: cp. I. T. 1002 tou/tou de\ xwrisqei=s) (=ei) xwrisqh/somai) e)gw\ me\n o)/llumai, | su\ d' a)\n to\ sautou= qe/menos eu)= no/stou tu/xois.

au)to\ tou=to prepares the emphasis on klopeu\s, while it also refers back to 54 f. th\n *filokth/tou...e)kkle/yeis. The connection of thought is:—‘No; open force is out of the question; the object which our ingenuity must compass is precisely that (which I have already indicated),—viz., how the bow can be taken by craft.’
sofisqh=nai: cp. Ar. Av. 1401xari/enta/ g), w)= presbu=t), e)sofi/sw kai\ sofa/.
klopeu\s … genh/sei: cp. O. T. 721fone/a gene/sqai patro/s: O. C. 582o(/tan qa/nw )gw\ kai\ su/ mou tafeu\s ge/nh|.

e)/coida, *pai=. Erfurdt's correction of kai\ to pai= appears certain. The caressing tone of pai= (cp. O. T. 1008, Ant. 1289) is dramatically happy at this moment, when he has just used the jarring word klopeu/s. The arguments in defence of kai\ are examined in the Appendix.

fu/sei is excusably added to pefuko/ta, since the force of the latter had become weakened by usage (pefuke/nai oft. meaning little more than ei)=nai): as here, pefuko/ta...texna=sqai (without fu/sei) would not necessarily mean more than ‘apt to contrive,’—whether the aptitude was innate, or acquired. So Eur. Bacch. 896fu/sei pefuko/s: Plat. Crat. 389 C to\ fu/sei e(ka/stw| pefuko\s o)/rganon.
fwnei=n: for the inf. with pefuko/ta, cp. 88, 1052.

h(du\ ga/r ti kth=ma (to\ kth=ma) th=s ni/khs labei=n (e)sti): the possession consisting in victory (defining gen.) is a pleasant possession to win. kth=ma, which, without an art., stands as predicate, has to be supplied, with an art., as subject. So Plat. Theaet. 209 E h(du\ xrh=m' a)\n ei)/h tou= kalli/stou tw=n peri\ e)pisth/mhs lo/gou, i.e. (to\ xrh=ma) tou=...lo/gou h(du\ xrh=m' a)\n ei)/h, (‘our most successful definition of knowledge would be a pretty affair’): where (to\ xrh=ma) tou=...lo/gou is a mere periphrasis for o(...lo/gos. Eur. Andr. 957sofo/n ti xrh=ma tou= dida/cantos brotou\s | lo/gous a)kou/ein, ‘a wonder of wisdom was he who taught’ (etc.), where (to\ xrh=ma) tou= dida/cantos is a periphrasis for o( dida/cas. Sometimes the defining gen. has no art.: Eur. Andr. 181e)pi/fqono/n ti xrh=ma qhleiw=n e)/fu: i.e. (to\) qhleiw=n (xrh=ma) e)pi/fqono/n ti xrh=ma/ e)sti.—The reading h(du\ ga/r toi (instead of ti) is preferred by several edd. The combination a)lla\... ga/r toi is unusual (no example occurs in Soph. ); but that matters little, since here a)lla\ ga/r is not elliptically used (cp. Soph. Ant. 148 n.); i.e. a)lla/ goes with to/lma, and therefore ga/r, in the parenthetic clause, could be followed by toi as legitimately as if there were no a)lla/ in question. The reasons for preferring ti seem to be these: (a) toi would be bluntly sententious, while ti has a more delicate persuasiveness: (b) ti is elsewhere associated with the peculiar constr. used here: see Eur. Andr. 181, Eur. Andr. 957, quoted above, and ib. 727 a)neime/non ti xrh=ma presbutw=n e)/fu.—(to\ kth=ma) th=s vi/khs: for the defining gen., cp. 159 f., 403 f.: O. T. 1474ta\ fi/ltat' e)kgo/noin e)moi=n (‘my darlings—my two daughters’), Ant. 471to\ ge/nnhma th=s paido/s.
labei=n epexeg., as Ant. 439tau=q' h(/ssw labei=n | e)moi\ pe/fuke, n. The conjecture laxei=n would be as good, but no better.
to/lma, bring thyself to do it: cp. 481, O. C. 184, Ai. 528.
di/kaioi … e)kfanou/meqa sc. o)/ntes (cp. O. T. 1063e)kfanei= kakh/): Il. 13. 278e)/nq' o(/ te deilo\s a)nh/r, o(/s t' a)/lkimos, e)cefaa/nqh.
au)=qis, afterwards, — some other day: Ant. 1204 n.

nu=n d) k.t.l., has been suggested by the contrast with au)=qis, and so the thought already conveyed by to/lma is re-stated more explicitly: then h(me/ras me/ros braxu/ suggests, in its turn, ka)=|ta to\n loipo\n xro/non k.t.l., which repeats the sense of di/kaioi d' au)=qis e)kfanou/meqa. Cp. n. on Ant. 465 ff.

ei)s a)naide\s h(me/ras me/ros braxu\, ‘for one little roguish day’: h(me/ras me/ros braxu\=‘a short space (consisting in) one day’ (cp. Eur. Med. 1247a)lla\ th/nde ge | laqou= braxei=an h(me/ran pai/dwn se/qen, | ka)/peita qrh/nei). me/ros is a fraction of the life-time which is before him: and since h(me/ras-me/ros (‘dayspace’) forms one notion, a)naide\s has the same force as if it were a)naidou=s, agreeing with h(me/ras ( Soph. Ant. 794nei=kos—a)ndrw=n cu/naimon, n.). For several epithets joined (without copula) to one subst., cp. Soph. Ant. 586ponti/ais ... duspno/ois... | *qrh/|ssaisin... pnoai=s. For ei)s marking a limit of time, cp. below, 1076 xro/non tosou=ton ei)s o(/son ta/ t' e)k new\s | stei/lwsi nau=tai, k.t.l. —Others take ei)s a)naide\s by itself, as=ei)s a)nai/deian (h(m. me/ros br. being acc. of duration of time), ‘for shamelessness.’ Such an abstract sense for the neut. adj., without the art., seems impossible. Campbell compares Plat. Gorg. 504 C e)moi\ ga\r dokei= tai=s me\n tou= sw/matos ta/cesin o)/noma ei)=nai u(gieino/n (as though u(gieino/n stood for to\ u(gieino/n, or u(gi/eian): but cp. Cope's ver sion: ‘For my opinion is, that order in the body of every kind bears the name of ‘healthy’:’ i.e. o)/noma is equiv. to ‘epithet.’ In Thuc. 5. 18§ 4 dikai/w| xrh/sqwn kai\ o(/rkois, dikai/w| is certainly a subst. (‘law,’ in the sense of ‘legal procedure’): but that does not warrant a)naide\s as=a)nai/deia. —Blaydes, again takes ei)s a)naide\s in a concrete sense, as=‘for a shameless deed’ (supplying e)/rgon). We can hardly supply e)/rgon, though we might perhaps supply ti (cp. Soph. O. T. 517, Soph. O. T. 1312, Soph. Ant. 687). This view seems just possible, but very improbable.

do/s moi seauto/n, i.e. allow me to overrule your scruples, a phrase applicable to friendly remonstrance, as Tr. 1117do/s moi seauto/n, mh\ tosou=ton w(s da/knei | qumw=| du/sorgos: cp. n. on Ant. 718.Brunck cp. Adelph. 5. 3. 838 Mitte iam istaec: da te hodie mihi: | Exporge frontem.
ke)klhso: for the perf., cp. 119, El. 366, Tr. 736.
me\n merely emphasises e)gw/ ( Ant. 11 n.); it is not opposed to a)ll) in 90.

*laerti/ou: the same form (always in the 1st or 5th place, the a being long) 417, 628, 1357, Ai. 101: but *lae/rtou below, 366, 614, fr. 827: and *larti/ou, 401, 1286, Ai. 1, 380. Eur. , too, has these three forms: while in the Hom. Od., where the name occurs 22 times, *lae/rths alone is used.

tou/sde, referring back to ou(\s a)\n: cp. O. C. 1332oi(=s a)\n su\ prosqh=| toi=sd' e)/fask' ei)=nai kra/tos: so El. 441, Tr. 23, Tr. 820.Prose would here use tou/tous, because ou(=tos regularly (though not always) points back, while o(/de points forward. Buttmann's tou\s de\, though admissible, would be too emphatic: see Appendix.

pra/ssein lo/gous, as meaning, ‘to put words into acts,’ is not a strictly correct phrase, but the verb is used here, with some poetical freedom, as if ou(\s a)
 tw=n lo/gwn...tou/sde were a(\ a)
 lego/mena...ta/de: i.e. lo/goi are virtually ‘proposed deeds.’ The prose equivalent of this pra/ssein would be e)/rgw| e)pitelei=n ( Thuc. 1. 70). Distinguish Eur. H. F. 1305e)/prace ga bou/lhsin h(
 e)bou/leto, where the verb= e)ce/prace, ‘effected.’—Isocr. or. 1 § 15 has the converse maxim, a(\ poiei=n ai)sxro/n, tau=ta no/mize mhde\ le/gein ei)=nai kalo/n (cp. Soph. O. T. 1409).
e)k te/xnhs: for e)k=‘by means of,’ cp. 563, 710, El. 279e)k do/lou. Ant. 475o)pto\n e)k puro\s periskelh=.
pra/ssein: for the inf., cp. 80: for the repetition of the word from 87, cp. O. C. 554 n., Ant. 76 n.
ou)/t' au)to\s k.t.l.: instead of ou)/te ga\r au)to\s e)/fun, ou)/te o( e)kfu/sas (e)/fu): cp. O. C. 461e)pa/cios me/n, *oi)di/pous, katoikti/sai, | au)to/s te pai=de/s q' ai(/d).

ou)/q), w(s fasi/n, ou(kfu/sas: as in Il. 9. 312Achilles says, e)xqro\s ga/r moi kei=nos o(mw=s *)ai+/dao pu/lh|sin, | o(/s x' e(/teron me\n keu/qh| e)ni\ fresi/n, a)/llo de\ ei)/ph|: and in I. A. 926 e)gw\ d' e)n a)ndro\s eu)sebesta/tou trafei\s | *xei/rwnos e)/maqon tou\s tro/pous a(plou=s e)/xein.

pro\s bi/an: so 594 pro\s i)sxu/os kra/tos: cp. pro\s h(donh/n, pro\s xa/rin, etc.: a)/gein=a)pa/gein (cp. 941), as 102, 985 etc. —kai\ mh\ do/loisin: mh/ is generic (it does not, and could not here, go with the inf. a)/gein): i.e., the phrase means strictly, ‘and by such means as are not frauds’: cp. on 409 (mhde\n di/kaion), Ant. 494tw=n mhde\n o)rqw=s...texnwme/nwn.

ou) ga\r k.t.l.: the ga/r implies, ‘this ought to satisfy thee, for force cannot fail': it is thus already a trace of irresolution. e)c e(no\s podo\s, lit. starting from one foot,’ i.e. ‘when he has the use of only one foot,’—e)k marking that ei(=s pou/s is the condition which makes his victory impossible. Cp. n. on O. C. 848ou)/koun pot' e)k tou/toin ge mh\ skh/ptroin e)/ti | o(doiporh/sh|s. In El. 455*)ore/sthn e)c u(perte/ras xero\s | e)xqroi=sin...e)pembh=nai, (‘that, with victorious might, he may trample on his foes,’) the u(perte/ra xei/r is similarly the antecedent condition.
tosou/sde (sc. o)/ntas, cp. n. on e)gkrath/s, 75): the 15 seamen who form the Chorus will be at hand to help them.
pemfqei/s ge me/ntoi: ge emphasises pemfqei/s, and me/ntoi=‘however’: cp. O. T. 442 n.
prodo/ths: he is thinking of what Od.said in v. 53.—bou/lomai d): de/=a)lla/ ( Ant. 85).
e)camartei=n, aor., ‘to fail’ (regarded as an event occurring at some one moment); nika=n, pres., ‘to be victorious’ (a continuing state: O. T. 437 n.). Cp. 1397 pa/sxein...paqei=n.

a)rgo/n, fem.: in good Attic prose as well as verse this adj. is of two terminations, and the v. l. a)rgh/n here represents only a later usage: Aristotle (if our MSS. may be trusted) wrote in Meteor. I. 14 (Berl. ed. p. 352 a 13) h( me\n ga\r (xw/ra) a)rgh\ ge/gone, yet in Oecon. 2(Berl. ed. p. 1348 a 3) th=s xw/ras a)rgou= genome/nhs.

ei)s e)/legxon e)ciw
, going forth to those contests of real life by which the adult tries the maxims learned in youth. e)/legxos here is the test which the man applies to the principle (glw=ssan me
 a)rgo/n k.t.l.); not the test applied to the man himself. The latter is, however, the usual sense of this phrase: cp. fr. 101 ge/nos ga ei)s e)/legxon e)cio
 kalo
 | eu)/kleian a)
 kth/saito: Eur. Alc. 640e)/deicas ei)s e)/legxon e)celqw
 o(\s ei)=: Phaedr. 278 C ei)s e)/legxon i)w
 peri\ w(=n e)/graye.

brotoi=s ‘for men,’ i.e. in their estimation, an ethic dat. ( Ar. Av. 445pa=si nika=n toi=s kritai=s). pa/nq' h(goume/nhn, ‘taking the lead, having the chief influence (absol., as 386) in all things’: for the adv. pa/nta cp. Soph. O. T. 904pa/nt' a)na/sswn.—We might also take brotoi=s directly with h(goum. as= ‘showing the way in all things to men’) cp. 133): but here the notion required is that of ‘swaying’ rather than ‘guiding’; and in the former sense h(goume/nhn would take the genit. brotw=n. There is an allusion to the Athenian demagogues (cp. 388 didaska/lwn lo/goisi): as Cleon says ( Thuc. 3. 38) of the citizens in the ecclesia, ei)w/qate qeatai\ me\n tw=n lo/gwn gi/gnesqai, a)kroatai\ <*>e\ tw=n e)/rgwn (‘absorbed in the drama of debate, but content with rumours from the field of action’).

ti/ m' ou)=n. With Nauck, I adopt Wakefield's transposition here, while recognising that much may be said for ti/ ou)=n m). Two questions are involved, and should be kept distinct; viz. (1) whether Tragedy ever used the licence, denied to it by Porson ( Phoen. 892), of hiatus after ti/: and (2) whether Sophocles is likely to have written ti/ ou)=n m) rather than ti/ m' ou)=n here. As to (1), the strongest instance is Aesch. Theb. 704ti/ ou)=n e)/t' a)
 sai/noimen o)le/qrion mo/ron; where ti/ d' ou)=n, ti/ nu=n, ti/ dh=t) are all improbable. It would seem, then, that Aesch. , at least, sometimes admitted the hiatus; so that, if we transpose m) here, it does not necessarily follow that the same transposition should be made in Aesch. Eum. 902ti/ ou)=n m' a)/nwgas th=|d' e)fumnh=sai xqoni/; But the prevailing character of Sophoclean verse certainly favours ti/ m' ou)=n rather than ti/ ou)=n m). As against conjecturing ti/ nu/n m), it is well to note Soph. Tr. 1247pra/ssein a)/nwgas ou)=n me pandi/kws ta/de; Soph. Ai. 1364a)/nwgas ou)=n me to
 nekro
 qa/ptein e)a=n; though no argument can be drawn from the fact that ou)=n precedes me in those places. Cp. 733, 753, 917. See Appendix.
ti/ … a)/llo, sc. poiei=n: cp. 310, and n. on Ant. 497qe/leis ti/ mei=zon h)\ kataktei=nai m' e)lw/n;

le/gw s' … labei=n, ‘I say that thou art to take.’ In this constr., ‘say’ means ‘command’; the act commanded is denoted by the inf., and the agent by the acc., as subject to the inf. Cf. Ai. 1047se\ fwnw= to/nde to
 nekro
 xeroi=n | mh\ sugkomi/zein: O. C. 932ei)=pon me
 ou)=n kai\ pro/sqen, e)nne/pw de\ nu=n, | ta\s pai=das w(s ta/xista deu=r' a)/gein tina/: Tr. 137 ff. se\...e)lpi/sin le/gw | ta/d' ai)e
 i)/sxein. The agent can also stand in the dat. as object to the verb of saying: O. C. 840xala=n le/gw soi.—This verse has no caesura: cp. 1369: Ant. 1021ou)d' o)/rnis eu)sh/mous a)porroibdei= boa/s, with n. there. Distinguish these rare examples from those which have an elision after the 3rd foot (‘quasi-caesura’), as 276: Ant. 44h)= ga noei=s qa/ptein sf), a)po/rrhton po/lei;
e)n do/lw|: cp. 60.
pei/sant), i.e. by persuading him that it is for his own good to come to Troy,—instead of deceiving him by a pretext of taking him home to Greece (58).
ou) mh\ pi/qhtai, a strong denial: cp. 381, 418, O. C. 849 n.
pro\s bi/an d): persuasion will be in vain: and, when persuasion has failed, force will be useless (cp. 90).

ou(/tws...ti deino
 k.t.l. It seems truer to regard ti as adj. with deino
 than as adv. with ou(/tws: cp. Xen. Cyr. 5. 1. 24ou(/tw deino/s tis e)/rws...e)ggi/gnetai. For the enclitic tis preceding its noun, cp. 519, O. C. 280 n. In Herod. , indeed, ou(/tw dh/ ti (‘so very...’) often qualifies adjectives (1. 185, 3. 12, etc.): but in the Attic examples of ou(/tw ti with an adj. the latter is usually a neut. sing., as Posidippus *mu/rmhc fr. 2 ou(/tw ti polu/poun e)sti
 h( lu/ph kako/n.

i)sxu/os qra/sos, strength-confidence, i.e., strength which makes him confident. Against kra/tos, conjectured by Nauck and Blaydes, (the latter placing it in the text,) observe that qra/sos agrees well with ou) mh\ pi/qhtai. If Philoctetes is deaf to persuasion, and risks the alternative of having force used against him, he must have some resource which inspires him with such boldness.

i)ou\s: we might expect i)ou/s g), since the question in 104 is not, ‘what resource has he?’ but, ‘has he some resource?’ And in 104 we cannot well change ti to ti/. L has probably lost g) in some other places: see, e.g., on Ant. 648, Ant. 1241.But g) is not indispensable, and by its absence the reply gains a certain abrupt force. Cp. 985, Tr. 629.
e)kei/nw| g): ge emphasises the pron., ‘then we dare not even approach him,’—a man with such arrows as those.
prosmei=cai: the spelling mei/cw, e)/meica, is attested for saec. VI.—IV. B.C. by numerous Attic inscriptions (Meisterhans, p. 87, n. 690).
qrasu/, a thing that may be dared; Pind. has this pass. sense, Pind. N. 7. 50qrasu/ moi to/d' ei)pei=n. Cp. Plat. Rep. 450E ta)lhqh= ei)do/ta le/gein a)sfale\s kai\ qarrale/on.
mh\ do/lw| labo/nta, acc. as subj. to prosmei=cai, (it is not safe that one should approach him,) unless one has ensnared him; for labo/nta, cp. 47 n.

ta\ yeudh=. The art. with the neut. adj. gives a certain emphasis (‘those things which are false’), and the objection to it here would have point only if, instead of the adj., we had the subst., ta\ yeu/dh. For the same reason, ta\ yeudh= le/gein seems rather better than to\ yeudh= le/gein, though at first sight the latter is specious. In fr. 325 kalo\n me\n ou)=n ou)k e)/sti ta\ yeudh= le/gein, also, ta\ appears sound. Cp. Antiphon or. 1 § 10 au(/th ga\r kai\ tou\s ta\ yeudh= pareskeuasme/nous le/gein ta)lhqh= kathgorei=n poih/sei. Cavallin changes dh=ta ta\ to dhladh\, ‘evidently’ ( O. T. 1501): but this would be better suited to ironical reproof than to ingenuous surprise.

to\ swqh=nai: i.e. the success of the Greeks at Troy. The aor. inf. is used because the speaker is thinking of that success as an event (to be marked by the fall of Troy), not as a process or state (to\ sw/|zesqai). Cp. Andoc. or. 2 § 12 ou) peri\ tou= sw=sai ta\s *)aqh/nas o( ki/ndunos h)=n au)tou\s ma=llon h)\ peri\ tou= mhde\ au)tou\s swqh=nai (referring to the Athenian army at Samos in 411 B.C.): where, as here, the aorists infinitive mark the critical moments.

pw=s ou)=n ble/pwn k.t.l. By using ou)=n, he concedes (at least for argument's sake) what Od.has just said. ‘Granting, then, that a falsehood is not disgraceful when it has such a motive, how is one to have the face to tell it?’ In vv. 91 ff. we saw the first trace of irresolution: this verse marks a further step. He now demurs to play the part, not (as in v. 108) because it is immoral, but because it is distasteful and difficult. For pw=s ou)=n, cp. O. T. 124pw=s ou)=n o( lh|sth/s (‘granting that there was a robber, how then...?’): for pw=s … ble/pwn, O. T. 1371o)/mmasin poi/ois ble/pwn, n.
lakei=n of bold or impudent utterance, as Ar. Ach. 1046toiau=ta la/skwn: cp. Soph. Ant. 1094 n.

ei)s ke/rdos, for it, with a view to it: cp. Il. 23. 304path\r de/ oi( a)/gxi parasta\s | muqei=t' ei)s a)gaqa/: Eur. Phoen. 395a)ll' e)s to\ ke/rdos para\ fu/sin douleute/on: Xen. Cyr. 8. 1. 33i)dw\n a)\n au)tou\s h(gh/sw tw=| o)/nti ei)s ka/llos zh=n.

ai(rei=, the oracular pres., denoting what is to happen: Aesch. Ag. 126xro/nw| me\n a)grei= *pria/mou po/lin a(/de ke/leuqos: id. Aesch. P. V. 170to\ ne/on bou/leum' u(f' o(/tou | skh=ptron tima/s t' a)posula=tai: Her. 3. 155h)/dh w)=n, h)\n mh\ tw=n sw=n deh/sh|, ai)re/omen *babulw=na.
w(s e)fa/sket): when Odysseus and Phoenix visited Scyros, and persuaded him to come to Troy (345 ff.).

ou)/t' a)
 sc. pe/rseias: cp. El. 364th=s sh=s d' ou)k e)rw= timh=s tuxei=n, | ou)/t' a)
 su/, sw/frwn g' ou)=sa (sc. e)rw/|hs): Tr. 462(kou)/pw tis...h)ne/gkat)...o)/neidos): h(/de d' ou)d' a)
 (sc. e)ne/gkaito), k.t.l.

qhrate/) ou)=n gi/gnoit' a)/n, they would then become (by logical inference) desirable prizes: cp. Plat. Prot. 338C ei) de\ ai(rh/sesqe..., ai)sxro\n ga\r tou=to tw=|de gi/gn etai. So gi/gnomai denotes arithmetical process ( Thuc. 3. 17ai( pa=sai (nh=es) a(/ma e)gi/gnonto diako/siai k.t.l.), or legal succession to property (Isae. or. 5 § 44 a(\ e)kei/nwn e)gi/gneto). This usage of gi/gnomai is decisive for gi/gnoit) against ge/noit), a v. l. found in a few late MSS.
ou)=n, the conjecture of Triclinius, seems better here than the other corrections, qhrate/) a)\n gi/gnoit' a)/n (or gi/gnoit' a)/r)).

w(s … fe/rei, (be sure) that thou winnest: cp. Ai. 39*a*q. w(s e)/stin a)ndro\s tou=de ta)/rga tau=ta/ soi: Eur. Ph. 1664 *k*r. w(s ou)/tis a)mfi\ tw=|d' u(gra\n qh/sei ko/nin: id. Hec. 400 *e*k. w(s th=sd' e(kou=sa paido\s ou) meqh/somai.
fe/rei, reportas: cp. O. T. 500 n.

to\ dra=n: for the art., cp. O. C. 442to\ dra=n | ou)k h)qe/lhsan, and ib. 47 n. —Neoptolemus was already all but per suaded by the promise that he should take Troy. If, besides that reward, there is yet another, then his mind is made up.
sofo/s t|) … ka)gaqo/s: schol. sofo\s me\n dia\ to\ kle/yai, a)gaqo\s de\ dia\ to\ porqh=sai. Cp El. 1088du/o fe/rein e)n e(ni\ lo/gw|, | sofa/ t' a)ri/sta te pai=s keklh=sqai.
au(to\s: O. T. 458a)delfo\s au(to\s kai\ path/r, n.
keklh=|): for the forms of the optat. perf. pass., see n. on O. T. 49.
i)/tw is a defiance of the possible consequences (‘happen what may’): cp. Eur. Med. 819(Medea, having taken her resolve to kill the children) i)/tw: perissoi\ pa/ntes ou(n me/sw| lo/goi.

poh/sw. Numerous Attic inscriptions of the 5th and 4th centuries B.C. show that in this verb the letter i was regularly omitted before a following E-sound (e or h), though never before an O-sound (o or w): hence (e.g.) poei=, poh/sas, but poiou=si, poiw=n. It should be noted that po- and poi-, according as the E- or O-sound follows, sometimes occur in the same inscription: thus in C. I. A. 167, 55 (of 334—326 B.C.) we find poiw=n (thrice) in company with poh/sas. The omission of i before the E-sound was not, indeed, rigorous; thus an Attic inscription of the 5th cent. B.C. gives *eu)/frwn e)cepoi/hs' ou)k a)dah\s *pa/rios: but the facts prove that it was usual. See Meisterhans, Gramm. d. Att. Inschriften, p. 27. As to L, its practice is not constant. It almost always gives po, not poi, before e or h, when the first syllable is short,—as here, and in vv. 552, 752, 926, 1010. In a few such places where the first hand had written poi it has been corrected to po. But there are also a few places where poi remains. See Appendix. In writing poh/sw, etc., I. rely primarily on the epigraphic evidence belonging to the poet's own time: but L's prevailing practice must also be considered as strengthening the grounds for believing that those inscriptions represent the general rule.

pa=san ai)sxu/nhn a)fei/s. This verse does not (as some have objected) mark an abrupt change of mind; that change has come by a series of steps which the poet has indicated by light touches (91 ff., 110, 116, 118). Rather this very phrase hints that the feeling shown in v. 110 still lingers with him. He will do the deed, but there is still a sense of ai)sxu/nh which it costs an effort to shake off. These are the words of one who may yet feel remorse.

mnhmoneu/eis. Almost all recent edd. adopt the conjecture mnhmoneu/seis, but without necessity. The question, ‘dost thou remember my advice?’ naturally implies here, ‘dost thou intend to observe it?’—and so N.'s answer, sa/f' i)/sq), follows the present tense just as fitly as it would follow the future. For the place of ou)=n in the verse, cp. O. C. 1205, Tr. 1247.
a(/ … parh/|nesa: referring to 56 ff.

sunh/|nesa, ‘agreed’: O. C. 1508 n. Remark the two compounds of ai)ne/w at the end of two successive verses: cp. Ar. Eq. 1370 f. meteggrafh/setai, | ...e)ggegra/yetai: Soph. Tr. 1265 f. suggnwmosu/nhn | ...a)gnwmosu/nhn.

e)kde/xou, excipe. The idea of the compound is, ‘be ready for him,’—prepared to deal with him the moment that he appears. The figurative use of the word in Her. 4. 1 is essentially the same, —*sku/qas...katio/ntas e)s th\n sfete/rhn e)cede/cato ou)k e)la/sswn po/nos (as if it had been lying in wait for them).
katopteuqw=: cp. Ai. 829pro\s e)xqrw=n tou katopteuqei/s.

kai\ to\n skopo\n k.t.l. The skopo/s is the attendant of Neoptolemus who had been sent to watch the neighbourhood of the cave, lest Philoctetes should take Odysseus by surprise (46). Now that Odysseus is going back to his ship, such a skopo/s is no longer needed. And it is natural that Odysseus should expect to meet the sentinel, since the latter would be keeping watch on that side of the cave at which Odysseus himself had hitherto been standing; viz., the side nearest to the ships. nau=n here means the ship of Neoptolemus. See Introduction, p. xx, n. 1.

kai\ deu=r). If any undue delay occurred, Odysseus might reasonably suppose that Neoptolemus was failing to persuade Philoctetes. In case of such delay, then, Odysseus will send back N.'s man, disguised as the captain of a ship. The object of the disguise is that the supposed captain may tell a story which shall quicken the desire of Philoctetes to leave Lemnos, and shall also confirm his trust in Neoptolemus.

tou= xro/nou … ti katasxola/zein. Nauck's conjecture pe/ra sxola/zein would suit the sense; but it would leave the origin of the vulgate unexplained. I believe that Soph. has used katasxola/zein tou= xro/nou, somewhat boldly, in the sense of ‘to lag behind the due time,’—the use of sxola/zein in the sense ‘to linger,’ ‘to delay,’ permitting a genitive to be used, as after u(sterei=n, lelei=fqai, etc. The compound katasxola/zein may be compared with kaqusterei=n, where kata/ merely implies that the delay is to be regretted or blamed. At first sight there is much in favour of the more generally received view, that tou= xro/nou ti katasxola/zein means, ‘to waste part of our (precious) time by lingering.’ But the tone of that phrase seems very unsuitable here.
e)kpe/myw. The prep. is not otiose, as Burges thought, but marks that the person sent will come as the sender's agent.

nauklh/rou: the man, when he comes, pretends to be the captain of a small merchant-ship, trading between Greece and the Troad (547 ff.). In Plaut. Mil. 4. 3. 41 ff. the ‘skipper's dress’ (ornatus nauclericus) consists of a darkcoloured hat with broad brim (causia), and a garment of the same colour, well girt-up, and looped on the left shoulder, leaving the right arm bare, like the Greek e)cwmi/s. The colour of both hat and tunic is described by ferrugineus, (‘nam is colos thalassicust’). This was a dark violet, rather than, as Nonius (p. 549) makes it, iron-grey: see Conington on Verg. G. 1. 467, and Munro on Lucr. 4. 76.

tro/pois, as Aesch. Cho. 479tro/poisin ou) turannikoi=s qanw/n: often with e)n, as Aesch. Ag. 918gunaiko\s e)n tro/pois. Not tro/pon, which would mean, w(/sper nau/klhros doloi= th\n morfh/n: cp. Her. 2. 57o)/rniqos tro/pon... fqe/ggesqai=w(/sper o)/rnis fqe/ggetai.

a)gnoi/a: ignorance, on the part of Philoctetes, as to the real quality of the skopo/s. Disyllables in oia (as *troi/a) have final a_, but longer words have a^. Other exceptions are: Tr. 350a)gnoi/a m' e)/xei: fr. 521 a(noi/a tre/fei: fr. 748 palirroi/a buqou=: Aesch. Theb. 402a(noi/a tini/ (Blomf. e)nnoi/a|): Eur. Andr. 520kai\ ga\r a)noi/a | mega/lh (in anapaests): Ar. fr. 29 w)= paranoi/a kai\ a)naidei/a (do.).— prosh=|, may be an attendant circumstance, i.e., may aid our plan: cp. Soph. Ant. 1251h(/ t' a)/gan sigh\ baru\ | dokei= prosei=nai, n. — The reading a)gnoi/a| is certainly wrong: the sense would then be, ‘that he (the skopo/s) may be added to your company without suspicion’ (dat. of circumstance): it could not be, as Musgrave took it, ‘that thou mayest approach the man without seeming to know him’ (prosh=| being then 2nd pers. subj. aor. midd. of prosi/hmi).

ou(= dh=ta. Blaydes conjectures ou(= dh\ su/. But dh=ta is right. It means, ‘then, of course’—differing from dh/ by implying more clearly that the step prescribed by de/xou is the obvious one.— ou(==para\ ou(=, with de/xou: cp. O. T. 1163e)deca/mhn de/ tou. This is better than to take ou(=...au)dwme/nou as gen. absol.

poiki/lws, ‘craftily,’—i.e., in terms fitted to beguile Philoctetes. Not, ‘in riddling speech,’ as if the point of the artifice lay in second meanings which Neoptolemus was to divine. The word could, indeed, mean that (cp. O. T. 130h( poikilw|do\s *sfi/gc): but the more general sense agrees better with vv. 542—627.
au)dwme/nou, midd., as 852, Ai. 772: the pass. occurs below, 240, 430.

ta\ sumfe/ronta: for the neut., cp. 24 n. tw=n a)ei\ lo/gwn, the words spoken by him from moment to moment,—the tenor of his discourse. The phrase is explained by the dialogue between the disguised skopo/s and Neo ptolemus (vv. 542—627). The skopo/s tells a story; N. follows his lead, and strikes in from time to time with artful comments, —reasserting his hatred of the Atreidae, his sympathy with Philoctetes, etc. These opportunities, or ‘cues,’ are ‘the useful hints’ (ta\ sumfe/ronta).
soi\ parei\s ta/de, ‘having committed these matters to thee,’ —a parting reminder of the responsibility. Not, ‘having given thee these directions.’
*(ermh=s o( pe/mpwn do/lios=*(ermh=s do/lios o(\s pe/mpei, the god of stratagems, who escorts men on their way.

o( pe/mpwn: cp. Tr. 620(the herald Lichas speaks) a)ll' ei)/per *(ermou= th/nde pompeu/w te/xnhn: Aesch. Eum. 91(Apollo to Hermes) pompai=os i)/sqi, to/nde poimai/nwn e)mo\n i(ke/thn. So he is o(/dios, e)no/dios, h(gemo/nios, a(gh/twr, and, in relation to the dead, yuxopompo/s ( Soph. O. C. 1548 n.).

do/lios. Near Pellene in Achaia Pausanias saw a statue of *(ermh=s,—e)pi/klhsin me\n *do/lios, eu)xa\s de\ a)nqrw/pwn e(/toimos tele/sai (7. 27. 1). Cp. Ar. Th. 1202*(ermh= do/lie, tauti\ me\n e)/ti kalw=s poiei=s. The Corcyrean month yudreu/s was probably sacred to Hermes as yudro/s (=yeudh/s). In Babrius fab. 57 Hermes is conducting ‘a waggon-load of lies,’ when he is way-laid and robbed of his whole stock by Arabs. Especially, he is the arch-thief ( Hor. Carm. 1. 10. 7: cp. Ovid Fast. 5. 691).— His character of do/lios is similarly combined with that of pompo/s in El. 1396*(ermh=s sf' a)/gei do/lon sko/tw| | kru/yas, k.t.l.: and in [Eur.] Rhes. 216 a)ll' eu)= s' o( *mai/as pai=s e)kei=se kai\ pa/lin | pe/myeien *(ermh=s, o(/s ge fhlhtw=n a)/nac.
nw=|n, dat.: cp. on 98.

*ni/kh t' *)aqa/na *polia/s. The personified *ni/kh meant Victory not merely in war but in any contest. She was especially associated with Zeus; but his daughter was the only goddess with whom she was actually identified. Thus Eur. ( Eur. Ion 452 ff.): ta
...e)ma
 | *)aqa/nan i(keteu/w, | ...w)= ma/kaira *ni/ka, | mo/le. And Aristeides, in his oration on Athena, says of her, mo/nh me
 a(pa/ntwn qew=n, o(moi/ws de\ pasw=n, ou)k e)pw/numos th=s vi/khs e)sti/n [in such epithets as nikhfo/ros], a)ll' o(mw/numos (I. p. 29). At Athens the small Ionic temple of *)aqhna= *ni/kh stood on the platform of a bastion (pu/rgos) springing from the south wing of the Propylaea, on the right hand of one ascending to the Acropolis. The figure of the goddess, probably a work of Calamis, bore a helmet in her left hand, and in her right a pomegranate (si/dh), her regular attribute in the Athena-cult at Sidè in Pamphylia. As Benndorf has shown (Ueber das Kultusbild der Athena Nike, Vienna, 1879), the temple probably commemorated Cimon's victory over the Persians at the mouth of the Eurymedon, near Sidè (466 B.C.). This *)aqhna= *ni_/kh was the figure which at Athens came to be popularly known as the Wingless Victory, *ni/kh *)/apteros. Wings were the distinctive attribute of *ni/kh in art: and Athenians were familiar with the winged *ni/kh which the chryselephantine Athena of Pheidias, in the Parthenon, held in her outstretched right hand (cp. Ar. Av. 574). The conception of *)aqhna= *ni/kh was not exclusively Athenian. Thus Pausanias saw at Megara i(ero
 *)aqhna=s...kaloume/nhs *ni/khs (1. 42. 4).

The same remark applies to the name *polia/s. At Athens it denoted Athena as guardian of citadel, city, and land. Athena Polias was represented by the old bre/tas of olive-wood in the Erechtheum. But she bore the title *polia/s in many other places also, especially in the Ionic cities of Asia Minor,—as at Erythrae, Prienè, Teos, Phocaea (Paus. 7. 5. 3, 4: 2. 31. 9). Equivalent titles were *polia=tis, *poliou=xos, and (in a case noticed by Leake, Morea, II. p. 80) *(aghsi/polis. Cp. Aristeides I. p. 21: kai\ ei)si\n ai( po/leis dw=ra *)aqhna=s: o(/qen dh\ kai\ *poliou=xos a)/pasi ke/klhtai. Thus Sophocles, though writing for Athenians, is not making purely local allusions.
h(\ sw/|zei m' a)ei/: as in the Odyssey. In Ai. 14 he calls her filta/ths e)moi\ qew=n.

div2.p: Parodos. For the metres see Metrical Analysis. The framework is as follows. (1) 1st strophe 135—143 =1st antistrophe 150—158. (2) 2nd str. 169—179=2nd antistr. 180—190. (3) 3rd str. 201—209=3rd antistr. 210— 218. An anapaestic system (su/sthma) of six verses (144—149) follows the 1st strophe: another, of ten verses (159— 168) follows the 1st antistrophe; and a third, also of ten (191—200), follows the 2nd antistrophe. With respect to the manner in which the anapaests are interspersed with the lyrics, we may compare the Parodos of the O. C.(where see n. on 117),—the play which is probably nearest in date to the Philoctetes, both being among the poet's latest works. On the other hand, in the Parodos of the Antigone (an early play), there is a stricter symmetry between the anapaestic systems (see n. there on 100).

The Chorus consists of 15 men belonging to the ship of Neoptolemus, who is their prince and their ‘captain’ (naukra/twr, 1072). As he is so youthful (pai=s, ib.), they can address him as te/knon (141), pai= (201). It does not follow that they were actually ge/rontes, as the author of the prose Argument (p. 4) calls them.

This ode is well fitted for its place at the opening of the play. In the prologue Neoptolemus has been the pupil of a crafty veteran; now he is the young leader to whom the sailors look for guidance. Hitherto the foremost topic has been the importance of capturing Philoctetes; here our thoughts are turned to his sufferings. And so, when the ode closes, the mind has been prepared for the coming conflict of motives.

div3.p: e)n ce/na| ce/non: cp. 685 n.: O. C. 184cei=nos e)pi\ ce/nhs.
ste/gein … le/gein: for the likeness of form in the words (paronomasi/a), combined with likeness of sound (paromoi/wsis), cp. Isocr. or. 4 § 186 fh/mhn de\ kai\ mnh/mhn.

u(po/ptan: the subst. expresses a fixed habit of mind more forcibly than u(/popton would have done: cp. Thuc. 6. 60o( dh=mos...xalepo\s h)=n to/te kai\ u(po/pths e)s tou\s peri\ tw=n mustikw=n th\n ai)ti/an labo/ntas. Xen. Eq. 3. 9tou\s...u(po/ptas fu/sei (i(/ppous), naturally shy. The Chorus, now entering the orchestra for the first time, cannot be conceived as thinking of what Hom. Od.has said (70 ff.): but they know how Philoctetes has been treated, and may naturally expect him to be ‘shy’ of Greek strangers.
te/xna, the skill of the ruler, whose art is the highest of all: see on O. T. 380 f., te/xnh te/xnhs | u(perfe/rousa.
e(te/ras, not, another kind of skill, but rather, skill in another man: see on O. C. 230a)pa/tais e(te/rais.

gnw/ma, sc. gnw/mas prou)/xei. As dist. from te/xnh—the art of ruling — gnw/mh here is intellectual power generally. The latter would not be separately ascribed to the king, if we adopted gnw/mas, which is thus the weaker reading.
par' o(/tw|: in whose keeping. The anteced. is e)kei/nou understood: cp. 956: O. C. 1388ktanei=n q' u(f' ou(=per e)celh/lasai: Ai. 1050dokou=nt' e)moi/, dokou=nta d), o(\s krai/nei stratou=.
to\ qei=on *dio\s skh=ptron, the godlike Zeus-sceptre, i.e., sceptre derived from Zeus (gen. of source), dio/sdoton.
