a)na/ssetai implies a)na/ssw skh=ptron (an almost adverbial cogn. acc.), as=‘to rule with sceptre’: cp. O. C. 449skh=ptra krai/nein, to have sceptred sway.—The tone here is genuinely Homeric. Cp. Il. 9. 98 law=n e)ssi\ a)/nac kai/ toi *zeu\s e)ggua/licen | skh=ptro/n t' h)de\ qe/mistas, i(/na sfi/si bouleu/h|sqa.

se\ … e)lh/luqen, hath come to thee. There is perhaps no other example of the simple e)/rxomai with acc. of person: but there is an exact parallel in the rare use of bai/nw with acc. of person, Eur. Hipp. 1371kai\ nu=n o)du/na m' o)du/na bai/nei. Eur. Itis doubtless more than a mere coincidence that both these instances are lyric; and that a lyric boldness was felt in them may be inferred from the parody in Nub. 30, a)ta\r ti/ xre/os e)/ba me; If se\ d)...e)lh/luqen occurred in an iambic trimeter, the case for soi\ d) would be strong: but here, in lyrics, we should keep se\ d).—We cannot properly compare i(knei=sqai, or i(ka/nein, after which an acc. of pers. was common.

pa=n kra/tos, complete (i.e. sovereign) power. Distinguish the phrase with the art., Her. 6. 35, ei)=xe me\n to\ pa=n kra/tos *peisi/stratos, which gives the same meaning in a slightly different way (‘the whole power’).
w)gu/gion, predicate with e)lh/luqen, ‘from of old,’ i.e., ‘from thine ancestors’: for w)gu/gion, see O. C. 1770 n.

to\, ‘therefore’: Il. 3. 176a)lla\ ta/d' ou)k e)ge/nonto: to\ kai\ klai/ousa te/thka. So, in Attic, tau=ta, Xen. An. 4. 1. 21tau=t' e)/speudon kai\ dia\ tou=to ou)x u(pe/menon: esp. tau=t' a)/ra, Nub. 319, etc.—For the like use of tw=|, cp. O. T. 511 n.

144 f. The Chorus has asked, How are we to help? He replies, in effect, ‘The moment for you to help has not come yet. Meanwhile you can approach, and look at the cave. When Philoctetes returns, then you must be guided by the signs that I shall give you.’ The Chorus are supposed to be on the shore, below the cave, and at a point from which they have not a clear view of it. Invited by Neoptolemus, they now advance nearer. The word a)mfi/quron (159) implies that, having approached the seaward mouth of the cave, they can see right through it; and v. 161 (pou= ga\r o( tlh/mwn...;) confirms this; their own eyes now assure them that the cave is empty. But nothing indicates that they actually enter it.

e)sxatiai=s, locative dat. ( O. C. 411 n.), ‘in the extreme parts’ of the island,— those, namely, which are on the edge of the sea. This reading, which has the best authority, is also intrinsically better than the gen. sing.: to/pon e)sxatia=s (‘region, part, of the sea-marge’) would be an unusual phrase. Homer, indeed, uses only the sing. of this word: and it is very likely that Soph. was thinking of Hom. Od. 9. 182 e)/nqa d' e)n e)sxatih=| spe/os ei)/domen a)/gxi qala/sshs, ib. 5. 238 nh/sou e)p' e)sxatih=|, etc. But that is no reason why Soph. should not have used the plur., which was familiar in Attic (e.g. H. 2. 4. 4 tw=n a)grw=n... ei)s ta\s e)sxatia/s).

o(/ntina kei=tai, in which he is situated, abides. The verb is esp. suitable to a crippled sufferer; cp. 183: Il. 2. 721(of Philoctetes) e)n nh/sw| kei=to krate/r' a)/lgea pa/sxwn. Verbs of position (as ‘sitting’ or ‘standing’) sometimes take an acc. (which may be regarded as a kind of ‘cognate’ acc.), denoting the place in or on which one sits, stands, etc. Aesch. Ag. 183se/lma...h(me/nwn (on the same principle as e(/dran e(/zomai): Suppl. 987 ti/ pot' ai)qeri/an e(/sthke pe/tran; (as if one said, e(/sthke petri/nhn sta/sin): ib. 657 decio\n tetagme/nous | ke/ras (ta/cin). Poetry could say, then, to/pon...o(/ntina e(/sthke or te/taktai: and so also koi=tai. It is true that kei=tai to/pon is not precisely like kei=tai qe/sin ( Thuc. 1. 37h( po/lis...au)ta/rkh qe/sin keime/nh): for kei=mai served as perf. pass. of ti/qhmi (te/qeimai being midd.), and in kei=tai qe/sin the acc. is therefore as strictly ‘cognate’ as it would be in e)te/qh qe/sin. But the difference between kei=tai qe/sin and kei=tai to/pon is, in principle, only the same as that between e(/zomai e(/dran and e(/zomai zugo/n.

tw=nd' *ou(k mela/qrwn. For e)k I read ou(k. Wakefield and Hermann were right in feeling that the sense required tw=nd' e)k mela/qrwn to be connected with o(di/ths (‘metuendus vir qui ex hoc antro abiit’), and not with mo/lh|. Then, however, the article o( becomes indispensable. Let it be granted that we could say, o(rw= o(di/thn e)k tw=n mela/qrwn, ‘I see one leaving the abode,’—o(di/thn having the constr. of o(deu/w: as, in ta\s...kinh/seis tw=| sw/mati ( Legg. 631 C), the dat. after kinh/seis is that which might follow kinei=sqai. But no Greek could have written o(po/tan mo/lh| o(di/ths e)k tw=n mela/qrwn in the sense, ‘when he who has left the abode shall return to it,’—the movement denoted by e)k tw=n mela/qrwn being opposite to that denoted by mo/lh. For the order of words, tw=nde o( e)k mela/qrwn, instead of o( tw=nde e)k m., cp. O. T. 735kai\ ti/s xro/nos toi=sd' e)sti\n ou(celhluqw/s=o( toi=sde e)celhluqw/s. For other examples of this crasis in Soph. , cp. below, Soph. 639pneu=ma tou)k prw/|ras: Soph. O. C. 1540tou)k qeou= paro/n: Soph. El. 731gnou\s d' ou(c *)aqhnw=n deino\s h(niostro/fos.—With the simple e)k, only two versions are possible. (1) Taking e)k with mo/lh|: ‘when he shall come forth from this abode.’ But N. knows that Ph. is not now in the cave, and he cannot assume that, on returning, Ph. will enter it from the landward side, to emerge at the other. Philoctetes is, in fact, outside of the cave from his first appearance at v. 219 up to v. 675. (2) Taking e)k with proxwrw=n, as referring to the Chorus: ‘moving forth from this abode.’ But the Chorus never enter the cave,—they only look into it: and, in any case, a gradual retreat from it (pro\s e)mh\n ai)ei\ xei=ra) would be unsuitable. — Seyffert refers tw=nd' e)k mela/qrwn to the Chorus, but does not connect it with proxwrw=n, taking e)k in the pregnant sense of e)/cw w)/n: i.e., ‘having quitted the cave (=e)k), advance ever at my beck,’ etc. This seems impossible.

pro\s e)mh\n ai)ei\ xei=ra proxwrw=n, coming forward towards my (beckoning) hand,—i.e., at a sign given by me,—from time to time (ai)ei/). This phrase is explained by the part which the Chorus actually plays in the dialogue between Philoctetes and Neoptolemus,—interposing, from time to time, with some utterance fitted to confirm the belief of Philoctetes in the story which Neoptolemus is telling (317, 391, 508, 676, etc.). proxwrw=n, because the sailors would remain at some distance from their master while he conversed with Ph. , but would naturally move a step or two nearer at the moments when they offered their own remarks. Not in a fig. sense, ‘directing your course of action.’ pro\s e)mh\n … xei=ra, too, is literal (i.e., it does not mean simply, ‘following the lead’ of my words).

to\ paro\n qerapeu/ein, to provide for the need of the moment. Cp. Dem. or. 18 § 307 tou\s u(pe\r tw=n e)xqrw=n kairou\s a)nti\ tw=n th=s patri/dos qerapeu/ein. Cp. the proverb to\ paro\n eu)= poiei=n ( Plat. Gorg. 499C), ‘to do the best one can.’

me/lon … me/lhma: with a certain emphasis; cp. Eur. Andr. 868dei/m' <*> deimai/neis. The Chorus first reply to the last words of N., and then respond to his suggestion that perhaps they wish to see the abode of Ph. —The text is sound, when, with Triclinius, we have ejected to\ so\n (see cr. n.),—a gloss added by some one who, taking the o)/mma to be that of N., naturally felt the want of the pos sessive pron. The o)/mma is that of the Chorus, and is the subject to frourei=n: this appears certain, when we compare Soph. Tr. 225ou)de/ m' o)/mmatos | froura\n [froura\ L] parh=lqe, ‘nor hath it escaped my watchful eye.’ Dindorf takes o)/mm) as a sort of ‘cognate’ acc., ‘to watch with the eye,’ and compares Soph. Tr. 914ka)gw\ laqrai=on o)/mm' e)peskiasme/nh | frou/roun: but there the partic. is the warrant for it.

e)pi\ sw=| kairw=|=lit., ‘for thine occasion,’ i.e., ‘for the moment at which a thing can be done for thine advantage.’ The use of the sing. kairo/s with the possessive is rare, but is akin to a freq. use of the plur., as Isocr. or. 6 § 80 e)n toi=s h(mete/rois kairoi=s (i.e. at the moments advantageous for us) a)lla\ mh\ toi=s au(tw=n poih/sasqai tou\s kindu/nous. And how naturally o( so\s kairo/s might approximate (esp. in lyric poetry) to the sense of to\ so
 ke/rdos, is suggested by such phrases as that in Her. 1. 206ou) ga a)
 ei)dei/hs ei)/ toi e)s kairo
 e)/stai tau=ta teleo/mena, ‘seasonably for thee,’=‘for thine advantage.’

au)la\s poi/as: cp. 30. The plur. au)lai/ could denote a single chamber ( Ant. 945). The Chorus are not supposed to have been present when the cave was found, and do not yet know the nature of Ph. 's quarters.
e)/nedros, ‘resident,’ is not pleonastic, since nai/ei can be said of a wanderer with ref. to the place that he is in at a given moment: 892: O. C. 117 n.
xw=ron ti/n' e)/xei, i.e., where he is now: cp. 22, O. C. 37.
to\ ga\r ou)k a)pok. moi/ (e)sti) maqei=n: to/ is pron. in nom. case (cp. Tr. 1172to\ d' h)=n a)/r' ou)de\n a)/llo): maqei=n, epexeg. inf.— prospesw/n: 46 n.
ti/s to/pos … qurai=on; The iteration, and the want of coherence, are meant to mark eager anxiety.

e)/xei sti/bon here=‘is planting his steps’ (cp. 29), rather than, ‘is following a path’ (48): hence the narrow space implied by e)/naulon is no objection. But with Wakefield's ti/s e)/xei sti/bos the sense ‘path’ would be unavoidable.
oi)=kon … koi/ths, a home consisting in a rocky sleeping-place (defining gen.: cp. 81 n.).
a)mfi/quron: cp. 16.— The me\n implies, ‘but where he is, I know not.’ The Chorus then say, pou= ga\r...; i.e., (you surprise me;) for (if he is not here) where can he be?

forbh=s: cp. 43.—o)gmeu/ei, o)/gmos, from rt. a)g. of a)/gw (cp. agmen), is prop. any line drawn out by movement; then, esp., a furrow in ploughing ( Il. 18. 546, Theocr. 10. 2); or the track (‘swathe’) made by reapers through corn. Here the image is from ploughing; the furrow which the ploughman leaves behind him is compared to the track left by the helpless foot which Philoctetes drags after him. Cp. 291 ei)luo/mhn, du/sthnon e)ce/lkwn po/da (where see n.). The word o)gmeu/ei also serves to suggest the laborious character of the progress. Cp. Lucan 9. 721 (of a serpent) contentus iter cauda sulcare.
th=|de seems a necessary correction of to/nde, since sti/bon...to/nde would mean, ‘his path yonder’ (as though N. could point to it): not merely ‘his path in this neighbourhood’ (though invisible).

tau/thn, i.e. by making expeditions in quest of food,—referring to 162 f. Others take it to mean, ‘in the following manner,’—viz., qhrobolou=nta. This is possible ( O. C. 787): but then we should expect qhrobolei=n.
fu/sin=tro/pon.

stugero
 stugerw=s: cp. 1369 kakw=s.. kakou/s: O. T. 479me/leos mele/w| podi\ xhreu/wn. Tragedy applies stugero/s, in the sense of ‘wretched,’ not only to things ( Tr. 1016bi/ou...tou= stugerou=), but also to persons, as Ant. 144toi=n stugeroi=n (the sons of Oed.: where see n.). Almost all recent editors, however, have received Brunck's conjecture, smugero
 smugerw=s, i.e., ‘with painful toil.’ At first sight, this is favoured by the schol. here, e)pimo/nws, which can scarcely be explained as meaning ‘with grim resolve,’ and ought doubtless to be e)pipo/nws. Now, as Brunck points out, Hesych. has smugero
, e)pi/ponon, oi)ktro/n, moxqhro/n: smugerw=s, e)pi/ponws. So Eustath. p. 1463 e)/sti de\ smugerw=s, to\ e)pipo/nws, o)dunhrw=s. Yet the following considerations make me hesitate to forsake the MSS. (1) Is it so clear that, in this context, the schol. could not have used e)pipo/nws to explain stugerw=s, seeing that the notions of po/nos and ‘wretchedness’ are often so near to each other, esp. in poetry? (2) Apollonius Rhodius seems to be the earliest extant writer who uses smugero/s: 2. 374 smugerw/tatoi a)ndrw=n (most laborious'): 4. 380 smugerw=s, ‘painfully.’ Homer has only e)pismugerw=s: Hesiod has e)pismugero/s. On the other hand, the form mogero/s is used five times by Aesch. , thrice by Eur. , once by Soph. ( Soph. El. 93), and once by Ar. ; but smugero/s never.

e)pinwma=n, intrans., ‘direct his course towards,’ ‘approach’: cp. 717, where prosenw/ma also seems to be intrans., ‘bent his course towards’ the water. This intrans. use must come from the trans. sense of nwma/w ‘to ply’ the limbs, or ‘guide’ a chariot, etc., as Il. 10. 358gou/nata nwma=n: O. T. 468po/da nwma=n: Pind. P. 4. 18di/frous te nwma/soisin: we must mentally supply po/da, o(do/n, or the like. Apart from the two instances in this play, there appears to be no sound example of an intrans. nwma/w. See Appendix.
oi)kti/rw, the spelling attested by Attic inscriptions ( O. T. 13 n.).
o(/pws, ‘(thinking) how’: cp. Ai. 510oi)/ktire d), w)=nac, pai=da to\n so/n,...o(/son kako\n | kei/nw| te ka)moi\ tou=q), o(/tan qa/nh|s, nemei=s.

mh/ tou. The force of mh/ (as dist. from ou)) is here ‘generic,’ i.e., it presents the situation as typical of a class; ‘in a case where there is none to tend’: and this implies the cause of pity,—‘seeing that there is none to tend.’ Cp. 256, 715: O. T. 397 n.

mhde\ seems better than any of the proposed corrections (see cr. n.): and for mh/ tou khdome/nou..., mhde\ e)/xwn, cp. O. C. 737 ou)k e)c e(no\s stei/lantos, a)ll' a)stw=n u(/po | pa/ntwn keleusqei/s, n.: Tr. 291nu=n soi te/ryis e)mfanh\s kurei=, | tw=n me\n paro/ntwn, ta\ de\ pepusme/nh| lo/gw|.— The second syllable of the verse might be short (see Anal.), and therefore su/ntrofon could stand. But, as there is no other instance of that syllable being shortened in this strophe or antistrophe, Brunck's cu/ntrofon is better, and is received by Heinrich Schmidt (Compositionslehre, p. clxii.).
cuntr. o)/mm), the face of a man who lives with one; cp. Ai. 977w)= fi/ltat' *ai)/as, w)= cu/naimon o)/mm' e)moi/.

a)lu/ei, properly, ‘wanders in mind’; hence, here, of despairing perplexity, cp. 1194. This use of the word might be illustrated by Alexis *kubernh/ths 13 ei)=q' oi( me\n eu)porou=men, oi( d' a)lu/omen, ‘some of us are rich, while others are at their wits' ends.’

panti/ tw| xrei/as =each item or article of need, i.e., each new form in which need besets him. Cp. n. on Ant. 1229e)n tw=| (=ti/ni) sumfora=s. i(stame/nw|=o(/te i(/statai, as it arises. Cp. 1263: Il. 21. 240kukw/menon i(/stato ku=ma.

w)= pala/mai *qew=n: the ‘devices’ of the gods are their mysterious dispensations, which can bring such misery on a man who was once fortunate. Cp. Pind. P. 1. 48eu(ri/skonto qew=n pala/mais tima/n. I have accepted Lachmann's conjecture here, qew=n for qnhtw=n, because (1) there is a prima facie case for a short penult., answering to that of a)quro/stomos (188); and (2) qnhtw=n, so closely followed by brotw=n, is very awkward, while qew=n not only gives a forcible contrast with brotw=n, but suggests a thought well suited to the solemn pathos. Hermann defends qnhtw=n at the cost of reading a)quro/glwssos in 188. Heinrich Schmidt also keeps it, but re tains a)quro/stomos in 188, on the ground that, in this logaoedic measure, the ‘irrational syllable’ is admissible in the choree (ai_ qnht). A probably authentic example is deino/n in 218 (=qroei= in 209). pala/mai qnhtw=n, if sound, would mean, ‘the resources of men’ (as shown by Philoctetes): so Theognis 623 pantoi=ai kako/thtes e)n a)nqrw/poisin e)/asin, | pantoi=ai d' a)retai\ kai\ bio/tou pala/mai. Cp. the praise of man as pantopo/ros in Soph. Ant. 360.Not, ‘the (wicked) devices of men,’ as seen in the hero's enemies.

ge/nh, ‘races,’ in the narrower sense of ‘houses’ or ‘families,’ such as the princely house to which Philoctetes belonged: cp. Od. 15. 533u(mete/rou d' ou)k e)/sti ge/nos basileu/teron a)/llo. Not ‘generations,’ geneai/ ( O. T. 1186): nor, again, ‘sons of men,’—a sense which could not be justified by the bold phrase in Ai. 784, *te/kmhssa, du/smoron ge/nos. In Her. 3. 159 read i(/na sfi geneh\ (not ge/nea) u(pogi/nhtai.

oi(=s mh\ me/trios ai)w/n. ai)w/n here= not ‘life’ merely (as Ant. 583), but ‘fortune in life,’ as Tr. 34toiou=tos ai)w
 ei)s do/mous te ka)k do/mwn | ai)ei\ to
 a)/ndr' e)/pempe. mh\ (‘generic,’ 170) me/trios, ‘such as to exceed the ordinary lot,’—in prosperity, and afterwards in misery. The more highly placed a man is, the greater may be his fall. Cp. 505 f.: O. T. 1186 ff., O. T. 1282 ff. (the reverses of Oed.): Ant. 1161 ff. (those of Creon). Aesch. Eum. 528panti\ me/sw| to\ kra/tos qeo\s w)/pasen. Eur. Med. 123e)moi\ gou=n e)pi\ mh\ mega/lois | o)xurw=s ei)/h kataghra/skein. | tw=n ga metri/wn prw=ta me
 ei)pei=n | tou)/noma nika=|: where it is added that ‘excess of good fortune’ (ta\ u(perba/llonta) ‘brings greater calamities on houses, when the god is wroth,’ mei/zous d' a)/tas, o(/tan o)rgisqh=| | dai/mwn oi)/kois a)pe/dwken. Her. 7. 10file/ei ga o( qeo\s ta\ u(pere/xonta pa/nta kolou/ein.—Others take mh\ me/trios as, ‘exceeding the ordinary measure of woe.’ Cp. Eur. Tro. 717ou) ga me/tria pa/sxomen kaka/. I prefer the former view, because (a) the sense of ge/nh suggests the greatness that precedes the abasement; and (b) vv. 180 ff., which comment on oi(=s mh\ me/trios ai)w/n, show that these words suggested a contrast between Ph. 's past and present fortunes.

prwtogo/nwn: schol. eu)genw=n. Elsewhere prwto/gonos always = ‘firstborn.’ But as a)rxaio/gonos can mean ‘of ancient race’ ( Ant. 981), so prwto/gonos ‘of foremost race.’ Cp. Thuc. 3. 65§ 2 a)/ndres u(mw=n oi( prw=toi kai\ xrh/masi kai\ ge/nei.

i)/sws does not imply a doubt as to whether Philoctetes is of noble birth, but merely gives a certain vagueness to the surmise that no one else was nobler. Yet Nauck (following Burges) changes i)/sws to gegw\s because the Chorus must have known the hero to be noble. Cp. Tr. 301(Deianeira is pitying the captives sent to her by Heracles), ai(\ pri\n me\n h)=san e)c e)leuqe/rwn i)/sws | a)ndrw=n: where i)/sws does not mean that she doubts their former freedom, but merely that she does not know their fathers' names. Cp. pou in Thuc. 7. 77§ 2 (Nicias speaking of himself), ou)/t' eu)tuxi/a| dokw=n pou u(/stero/s tou ei)=nai. So we sometimes guard a statement by saying, ‘perhaps’ the greatest, etc.

ou)deno\s sc. a)ndro/s. ou)dei\s oi)/kwn prwtogo/nwn could mean either (a) no house of those houses, or (b) no man belonging to them; cp. Plat. Prot. 316B *)apollodw/rou ui(o/s, oi)ki/as mega/lhs. Here it is possible, indeed, to supply oi)/kou (‘a man inferior to no house,’ i.e., ‘to no member of a house’). But in compressed Greek comparison the type to\ e)kei/nou ge/nos ou)x u(/stero/n e)sti tw=n basile/wn (sc. tou= ge/nous), is commoner than e)kei=nos (for to\ e)kei/nou ge/nos) ou)x u(/stero/s e)sti tou= tw=n basile/wn ge/nous,—which latter would be the type here. Further, the fact that ou)deno\s (oi)/kou) depends on oi)/kwn would increase the awkwardness. The reading h(/kwn for oi)/kwn is specious; cp. Soph. Ai. 636ds e)k patrw/|as h(/kwn genea=s <a)/ristos>: though a)/ristos is there doubtful. But oi)/kwn is confirmed (a) by Eur. Ion 1073a( tw=n eu)patrida=n gegw=s' oi)/kwn: and (b) by the bold use of prwtogo/nwn, which oi)/kwn helps to interpret.— ou)deno\s u(/steros, as Plat. Tim.p. 20 A ou)si/a| kai\ ge/nei ou)deno\s u(/steros w)\n tw=n e)kei=.
e)n bi/w| belongs to a)/mmoros (destitute, in his life, of all things): it cannot go with pa/ntwn, as if we had pa/ntwn tw=n e)n bi/w|: but the sense is virtually the same.
mou=nos a)p' a)/llwn, alone, apart from his fellows: an epic phrase; Hymn. Hom. 3. 193 o( de\ tau=ros e)bo/sketo mou=nos a)p' a)/llwn: cp. Od. 16. 239mou/nw a)/neuq' a)/llwn.

stiktw=n (the epithet of an e)/lafos in El. 568, and of nebri/des in Eur. Bacch. 111) naturally suggests deer, and, acc. to one interpretation, is meant here to denote the class of ‘peaceful animals,’ as dist. from lasi/wn, beasts of prey. The latter epithet, it might be objected, could equally well suggest goats and sheep. Another and stranger view is that stiktw=n means birds (pictae volucres), as dist. from beasts. Obviously the poet used the epithets simply in order to call up a general picture of creatures that haunt the wilds; he was not carefully classifying them. Cp. 937.

meta\. The last syllable of a verse is of variable value (a)dia/foros, anceps); i.e., a short may stand for a long, as here, or vice versa. Cp. Heinrich Schmidt, Rhythmic and Metric, p. 58, who cites Aesch. Ag. 1531 eu)pa/lamon me/rimnan | o(/pa k.t.l.: the -a^n there serves as -a_n. So 188 (a)quro/stomos), 1089 (a)=mar), 1104 (u(/steron), 1110 (xersi\n), etc. It is needless, then, to alter meta/.
e)/n t' o)du/nais=e)n o)du/nais te (cp. O. T. 258 n.): for this e)n of circumstance, ib. 1112 e)n...makrw=| | gh/ra|, n.

*o)rei/a d', MeklerS. 's correction of barei=a d), occurs in his revision of Dindorf (6th Teubner ed., 1885), where it is placed in the text. But, so far as I know, the arguments for it have not yet been stated. It is one of those emendations, the probability of which cannot be adequately estimated at a first glance, but must be carefully considered in relation to the peculiarities of the MS. (1) We observe, then, that L has barei=|ad' a)quro/stomos. This favours the view that v. 188 began with a d) rather than a( d). But, as metre proves, that a must have been a_, not a^: and this points to an ending -ei/|a_, as in o)rei/|a. (2) Some corruptions in L, as in other MSS., have arisen through the genuine word being mistaken for one resembling it in form; as a)/xos has become a)/xqos in O. T. 1355.And this could occur even when the initial of the false word did not belong to the true word. See Tr. 887stono/entos e)n toma=| sida/rou. For toma=|, L there has stomai=: and this, not merely through the influence of stono/entos, but, evidently, because the scribe was thinking of sto/ma. Thus, even without assuming an intermediate a)rei/|a or a)rei=|a, we see that barei=|a was a possible corruption of o)rei/|a. Note, as increasing the probability, that v. 208, barei=a thlo/qen au)da/, stands in L in the middle of the same page (82 A) which contains this verse. (3) o)rei/a, as an epithet for Echo here, is illustrated by the only other place in the play where such echo is spoken of: 1458 polla\ de\ fwnh=s th=s h(mete/ras | *(ermai=on o)/ros pare/pemyen e)moi/. The qh=res have just been mentioned (185); and at 937 we have qhrw=n o)rei/wn. Cp. Hymn. Hom. 19. 21 korufh\n de\ periste/nei ou)/reos h)xw/. Echo is the ‘neighbour’ of Pan (Moschus 6. 1), himself o)ressiba/ths ( O. T. 1100).—For other conjectures, see Appendix.

a)quro/stomos is not extant elsewhere. Cp. Eur. Or. 903 a)nh/r tis a)quro/glwssos, i)sxu/wn qra/sei. Ar. Ran. 838e)/xont' a)xa/linon a)krate\s a)qu/rwton sto/ma. Theognis 421 polloi=s a)nqrw/pwn glw/ssh| qu/rai ou)k e)pi/keintai | a(rmo/diai.—Wecklein reads a)qurostomou=s) (comparing qrasustomei=n, polustomei=n), for the sake of the long final syll.: but see on meta\ in 184.

*)axw\ thlefanh\s, Echo, appearing afar,—as if she came forth from her secret abode in response to the voice. Eur. introduced Echo as an (unseen) speaker in his Andromeda; cp. Ar. Th. 1059 ff. (*)hxw/, lo/gwn a)ntw|do/s, e)pikokka/stria ‘mocker’). But she was not, in the classical age, a distinctly recognised dai/mwn: though Paus. (2. 35. 10) saw at Corinth a i(ero/n of h( *xqoni/a, locally called *)hxw/. Cp. Wieseler, Die Nymphe Echo (Göttingen, 1854).

pikrai=s | oi)mwgai=s u(pakou/ei is the best correction yet proposed for pikra=s oi)mwga=s u(po/keitai. With the latter verb, the dat. pikrai=s oi)mwgai=s would be required. The sense would then be, ‘Echo is subject to his cries,’ i.e., attends upon them, follows them, as a kind of understrain or accompaniment. Such a use of u(po/keitai is not merely forced; it is (to my mind) inconceivable. Prof. Campbell, keeping the gen. pikra=s oi)mwga=s, renders u(po/keitai ‘lies close to, i.e. keeps following upon’: and quotes Plat. Gorg. 465B th=| me\n ou)=n i)atrikh=|...h( o)yopoii+kh\ kolakei/a u(po/keitai: but that means, ‘Cookery is a flattery which ranges under medicine,’ i.e., corresponds to it, as the counterfeit to the genuine art. And, on any view of u(po/keitai, the dat. is needful. For u(pakou/ei, cp. Hom. Od. 4. 283(Helen was calling to the heroes in the wooden horse; they were eager) h)\ e)celqe/menal, h)\ e)/ndoqen ai)=y' u(pakou=sai, ‘to come forth, or to answer promptly from within.’ And ib. 10. 82 poime/na poimh\n | h)pu/ei ei)sela/wn, o( de/ t' e)cela/wn u(pakou/ei, ‘herdsman hails herdsman as he drives in, and the other, as he drives forth, makes answer.’ In classical prose, u(pakou/ein more often means to ‘respond’ in the sense of ‘comply.’ But the passages just cited prove that the word was also familiar as=‘to speak in reply’: nor was this latter sense confined to poetry; cp. Arist. Top. 8. 11(Berl. ed. p. 157 b 14) e)rwtw/menoi ta)nanti/a kai\ to\ e)n a)rxh=| polla/kis u(pakou/ousin, =a)pokri/nontai (the word used previously in the same passage).—Other emendations of u(po/keitai are examined in the Appendix.
qei=a, predicate, ‘from the gods’: cp. 1039, 1326.
ka)gw/, I also (as well as others): the kai/ gives a modest tone; Ant. 719 n.

kai\ ta\ paqh/m. kei=na. The kai/ here = ‘e'en’: its force is to mark that, from the very beginning, his troubles were heaven-ordained. This seems better than to take it as ‘both,’ answering to the kai\ nu=n in 195.

th=s w)mo/fr. *xru/shs, gen. of source, with e)pe/bh. Such a simple gen. usu. denotes the place whence ( O. T. 152*puqw=nos e)/bas), but the idea of ‘source’ could easily be connected with a person also; cp. O. C. 1515stra/yanta xeiro\s th=s a)nikh/tou be/lh. It is also possible to join paqh/mata … *xru/shs as ‘sufferings inflicted by her’: cp. 422 ta\ kei/nwn kaka/, n.: but (a) the order of words renders this less natural: and (b) a gen. after pa/qhma ought to denote the sufferer.— Philoctetes was bitten by a serpent that guarded the altar of Chrysè, in the islet of the same name, near Lemnos: cp. 1326.

w)mo/fronos, as cruelly punishing his intrusion. The Iliad (2. 723) speaks of him as e(/lkei moxqi/zonta kakw=| o)loo/fronos u(/dron. The relation of Chrysè to the gods is like that of Calypso in the Odyssey. The dai/mwn can work her will on the mortal; but only so far as the higher powers permit.

ou)k e)/sq' w(s ou), sc. ponei=: for w(s instead of the usual o(/pws, cp. Ant. 750tau/thn pot' ou)k e)/sq' w(s e)/ti zw=san gamei=s. This shows that we ought not to read ou)k e)/stin o(/pws ou) qew=n mele/th| (omitting tou).

tou= mh\ … tei=nai, ‘in order that he should not bend...’ tou= mh/ is not to be taken with mele/th| (‘care to prevent his bending’), but with the whole preceding sentence. This constr. occurs (a) after words of hindering, Xen. An. 3. 5. 11pa=s...a)sko\s du/o a)/ndras e(/cei tou= mh\ katadu=nai: (b) where the notion of hindering is not expressed, but only implied, as Thuc. 1. 23§ 5 ta\s ai)ti/as proe/graya..., tou= mh/ tina zhth=sai/ pote e)c o(/tou tosou=tos po/lemos...kate/sth. Id. 2. 22§ 1 e)kklhsi/an ou)k e)poi/ei..., tou= mh\ o)rgh=|...cunelqo/ntas e)camartei=n. So, in affirmative sentences, tou= without mh/: id. 1. 4 to/ te lh|stiko\n ...kaqh/|rei..., tou= ta\s proso/dous ma=llon i)e/nai au)tw=|.

tei=nai … be/lh, point them, like sagittas tendere ( C. 1. 29. 9): we need not suppose that a word proper to the bow (‘stretch’) is transferred to the arrows. ta\ qew=n, i.e., given by the gods (cp. 140 *dio\s skh=ptron), because the bow of Philoctetes was originally the gift of Apollo to Heracles ( Apollod. 1. 4. 11§ 9). Cp. 943.

pri
...e)ch/koi, not pri
 a)
 e)ch/kh|, although the tense of the principal verb (ponei=, understood in v. 196) is primary, since a secondary tense is implied in the phrase qew=n tou mele/th|: i.e., ‘he is suffering, because the gods ordained that he should suffer, until the time should be fulfilled,’ etc. Cp. Dem. or. 22 § 11 tou=ton e)/xei to
 tro/pon o( no/mos...i(/na mhde\ peisqh=nai mhd' e)capathqh=nai ge/noit' e)pi\ tw=| dh/mw|: ‘the law stands thus, that the people might not even have the power’: where ‘stands’ (e)/xei) implies ‘was made’ (e)te/qh). ge/nhtai would be regular there, as pri
 a)
 e)ch/kh| would be here: yet in both places the optat. is natural. The speaker is tracing a present fact to a past motive.
le/getai: the Trojan seer Helenus had said that Troy was to be taken by Philoctetes before the summer was over (1340).—tw=nde, tw=n belw=n: cp. on tou/sde, 87.

eu)/stom' e)/xe=si=ga e)/xe: for the neut. pl. as adv., cp. O. T. 883 n. Her. 2. 171tau/ths...moi pe/ri (th=s teleth=s) eu)/stoma kei/sqw, i.e., ‘it will be best to observe silence.’ Aelian De Nat. An. 14. 28 ta/ ge par) e)mou= e)/stw pro\s au)tou\s (the gods) eu)/stoma. Nub. 833 eu)sto/mei=eu)fh/mei.
ti/ to/de; ‘what now?’ So ti/ tou=to; O. C. 513.Here, as in 210 f., the rapid tribrachs mark excitement.
prou)fa/nh: cp. 189 thlefanh/s.

su/ntrofos, sharing his life, i.e., constantly attending on him, habitual to him: cp. Ai. 639ou)ke/ti suntro/fois | o)rgai=s e)/mpedos, the dispositions that have grown with his growth,—the promptings of his own nature. Thuc. 2. 50(the plague) e)dh/lwse...a)/llo ti o)
 h)\ tw=n cuntro/fwn ti (the familiar maladies). Polyb. 4. 20 (th
 mousikh
) su/ntrofon poiei=n. The genit. (fwto\s), though less usual than the dat., hardly requires us to view su/ntrofos as a subst. (‘companion’): cp. Phaed. 96D ta\ au)tw=n oi)kei=a, the things appropriate to them.

h)/ pou: cp. 215. Cavallin reads h)= pou with a note of interrogation after to/pwn: but they do not doubt that it comes from one of the two quarters. th=|d' … th=|de: O. T. 857 n. The Attic form seems warranted by the colloquial tone; then, with e)tu/ma, we return to lyric Doricism. to/pwn with th=|de: O. T. 108pou= gh=s;
ba/llei: the fuller phrase in Ant. 1187kai/ me fqo/ggos... | ba/llei di) w)/twn. So ba/lh|, simply, of smell, ib. 412.

e)tu/ma, real,—not due to a hallucination of the senses. Cp. Theocr. 15. 82 (with ref. to painted figures), w(s e)/tum' e(sta/kanti kai\ w(s e)/tum' e)ndineu=nti (‘move in the dance’), | e)/myux), ou)k e)nufanta/. Elsewhere the Attic fem. is e)/tumos ( Helen. 351, Ar. Pax 114).
sti/bon … e(/rpontos: cp. 1223: Ai. 287e)co/dous e(/rpein kena/s.

kat' a)na/gkan, i.e., under stress of pain: cp. 215 ptai/wn u(p' a)na/gkas. Eur. Bacch. 88e)n w)di/nwn | loxi/ais a)na/gkaisi.—The reading sti/bou kat' a)na/gkan would mean, ‘with painfulness of movement,’ sti/bou being then the act of planting the steps (cp. 29, 157). This is tenable; but I prefer sti/bon, because (a) the phrase with sti/bon seems a little forced, and (b) with the gen. tou... e(/rpontos the effect of an interposed gen. would be somewhat unpleasing.

ou)de/ me la/qei: this reiteration is natural, since the sound continues, and draws nearer. For the negative form after the positive, cp. El. 222e)/coid), ou) la/qei m' o)rga/, and ib. 131: Il. 24. 563kai\ de/ se gignw/skw, *pri/ame, fresi/n, ou)de/ me lh/qeis.

barei=a, grievous, i.e., expressing pain; so Eur. Hipp. 791h)xw\ barei=a. trusa/nwr should properly be active, ‘man-wearing,’ like fqish/nwr, ‘man-destroying’ (epith. of po/lemos, Il. 2. 833). And so some understand au)da\ trusa/nwr as=a lament for a disease that wears one: cp. on 695 f. sto/non...barubrw=t). This, however, seems verystrained. More probably the poet has boldly used au)da\ trusa/nwr as=au)da\ a)ndro\s tetrume/nou, like ai(=ma a)ndro/fqoron for ai(=ma a)ndro\s e)fqarme/nou ( Ant. 1022), ktu/pos dio/bolos for ktu/pos di/ou be/lous ( O. C. 1463). Cp. Nub. 421 feidwlou= kai\ trusibi/ou gastro/s, where trus. seems to be pass.,=tetrume/non bi/on e)/xontos, rather than act. (as if it imposed the hardships).
dia/shma ga\r qroei=. This, the reading of the MSS., seems sound. As to the metre, see n. on 218 (proboa=| ti ga\r deino/n).

a)ll' e)/xe. In many editions XO. is printed before these words, presumably to mark that they open the 3rd antistrophe. But, as the part of the Chorus is continuous from v. 202, a XO. here is confusing. It does not exist in L.

a)ll), hortative, like, ‘come, then.’ e)/xe … fronti/das ve/as: i.e. turn from thy reflections on his hard lot (162—168) to such thoughts as the moment of action demands. The effect of N.'s interpellation, le/g' o(/ ti, is to mark excitement, and to bring out the reply with greater force. See n. on O. C. 645.
ou)k e)/cedros: for they have now learned that he has a permanent dwelling here (cp. 153).
molpa\n … e)/xwn, engaged in it; cp. Od. 24. 515a)reth=s pe/ri dh=rin e)/xontes.

su/riggos: cp. Il. 18. 525(on the shield) du/w q' a(/m' e(/ponto nomh=es, | terpo/menoi su/rigci. Plat. Rep. 399D lu/ra dh/ soi...kai\ kiqa/ra lei/petai, kai\ kata\ po/lin xrh/sima: kai\ au)= kat' a)grou\s toi=s nomeu=si su/rigc a)\n ei)/h:—a good illustration of a)grobo/tas here. Theocr. 7. 27 fanti\ tu\ pa/ntes | surikta\n e)/menai me/g' u(pei/roxon e)/n te nomeu=sin | e)/n t' a)mhth/ressi. Cp. a)/luros, a)fo/rmiktos, a)ki/qaris, a)/xoros, as epithets of wailing, etc. ( Soph. O. C. 1223 n.).

poima
, not poimh
, is surely required here, where molpa
 precedes and a)grobo/tas, a)na/gkas, i)wa/n follow. Cp. O. C. 132, where L has ta=s eu)fh/mou.

a)grobo/tas, e)n a)grw=| bo/skwn: cp. O. T. 1103pla/kes a)gro/nomoi, n. Philoctetes is returning from wild places to his dwelling. This suggests the contrast with a shepherd who, playing his pipe, comes cheerily home from the ‘otia dia pastorum.’

a)ll' h)/ pou k.t.l. After ou) molpa\n e)/xwn we ought to have had a)lla\ ...bow=n: but a finite verb, boa=|, takes the place of a second participle, as oft.: see n. on O. C. 351.—Join u(p' a)na/gkas with ptai/wn rather than with boa=|: the a)na/gkh, or stress of pain (206),—from the ulcered foot which he drags after him (291),— causes him to stumble on the rough ground.

thlwpo\n i)wa/n, a cry heard from a distance. thlwpo/s = (1) ‘of distant aspect,’ (w)/y,) i.e., ‘seen afar’: then (2) simply, ‘distant,’ though the object is not visible: Ai. 564thlwpo\s oi)xnei=. It is in this general sense of ‘distant’ that thlwpo/s is here applied to a sound heard from afar. We cannot properly compare thlefanh/s, said of the personified Echo (189). In Aesch. Theb. 103ktu/pon de/dorka may imply the mental picture called up by the clash of arms, as Verrall observes.

nao\s a)/cenon … o(/rmon, a haven that has no ship for its guest; cp. O. C. 1383a)pa/twr e)mou=, ‘having no father in me’: and ib. 677 n. a)/cenos is here the opposite of polu/cenos rather than of eu)/cenos. Thus nao\s a)/cenon is not less correct, while it is more forcible, than nausi\n a)/cenon would be. The waters off the rock-bound coast are a o(/rmos a)/normos (cp. 302).— Others render, ‘the inhospitable anchorage of our ship,’—which was not visible from the cave (cp. 467), but might have been seen by Philoctetes from another point. The sense seems, however, to be:—‘his cry is caused, either by physical pain, or by a feeling of despair as he looks at the lonely sea.’ The Chorus have been dwelling on his two great calamities—disease, and solitude (173 f., 185 f.). In this closing strain, it is natural that the two motives of their pity should be identified with the two sources of his anguish.

proboa=| ti ga)r deino/n. Wunder thus transposes ga/r ti. It was hardly needful to defend the place of ga/r by I. T. 1036 (u(popteu/w ti ga/r): cp. below, 1450 f. Heinrich Schmidt seems right in holding that deino/n here does not require qrhnei= (for qroei=) in 209. Lachmann's conjecture, proboa=| ga\r ai)/linon, hardly deserved to be adopted by Blaydes. See Metrical Analysis.—Hermann's view, that in 209 dia/shma qroei= ga/r should be read, as here, proboa=| de/ ti deino/n, involves the arbitrary substitution of de/ for ga/r. It would be obvious to suggest proboa=| ti ga\r ai)no/n, or proboa=| ga\r e)leino/n: but neither is probable.

div2.p: First e)peiso/dion. Philoctetes tells his story to Neoptolemus; who pretends that he has quarrelled with the Atreidae, and is sailing home. He promises to take Ph. with him. At this point the emissary of Odysseus (126) enters, disguised as the captain of a merchantship. He says that the Greeks have sent men in pursuit of N.; while Odysseus and Diomedes are coming to take It Ph. is decided that N. and Ph. must sail at once; they then withdraw into Ph. 's cave.

div3.p: i)w\ ce/noi, ‘extra metrum,’ as 736 i)w\ qeoi/, O. T. 1468i)/q), w)=nac, etc. Here i)w/ is a cry of surprise. In O. C. 822i)w\ ce/noi (within the verse) is a despairing appeal (‘Alas, friends...’).

ka)k poi/as pa/tras. In judging between this reading and the variant nauti/lw| pla/th| (see crit. n.), the probabilities of corruption must be carefully weighed. Suppose, first, that the poet wrote ka)k poi/as pa/tras. A transcriber who found poi/as pa/tras in v. 222 might well assume that there was a fault either there or in v. 220: and since in v. 222 the words fit the construction, he might think that the fault was in v. 220. The substitute, nauti/lw| pla/th|, might then be suggested by kate/sxet) itself: cp. Ar. Ran. 1207nauti/lw| pla/th| | *)/argos katasxw/n (from the Archelaus of Eur. ). Emendations not less arbitrary were sometimes made in early times: see, e.g., on Soph. O. T. 134 and 1529. Next, suppose that nauti/lw| pla/th| was the true reading. It is clear and neat. To account for the variant ka)k poi/as pa/tras, we must then suppose either (a) that a scribe wrote those words by an oversight,—his eye having wandered to v. 222; which is the less likely, since v. 222 did not give him ka)k: or (b) that, nauti/lw| pla/th| having been somehow lost, he filled the gap with a clumsy loan from v. 222. Neither hypothesis seems so probable as that a double poi/as pa/tras should have led to guess-work in v. 220. Another point, though not a strong one, in favour of ka)k poi/as pa/tras is that the two questions (‘who, and whence?’) are habitually combined in such inquiries: e.g., Soph. El. 779xai/ret), w)= ce/noi: ti/nes | po/qen poreu/esq), e)ste/ t' e)k poi/as xqono/s; Her. 1. 35ti/s te e)w\n kai\ ko/qen...h(/kwn: id. 2. 115 ti/s ei)/h kai\ o(ko/qen ple/oi: 4. 145 ti/nes te kai\ o(ko/qen ei)si/. On the other hand, we cannot insist on L's authority as against A's; for L has sometimes lost a true reading which A has kept (as in Soph. Ai. 28).

But ka)k poi/as pa/tras in v. 220 and poi/as pa/tras in 222 cannot both be wholly sound. The first pa/tras might easily be corrected to xqono\s (with Wecklein). It is slightly more probable, how ever, that the second pa/tras arose from the eye glancing back. Thus in Ant. 831L has ta/kei (for te/ggei), due to takome/nan in 828. In v. 222 we might conjecture poi/as po/lews. (For po/lews in the 2nd place of the senarius, cp. O. T. 630.) The series of questions in vv. 220— 222 would then correspond with the Homeric ti/s po/qen e<*>s a)ndrw=n; po/qi toi po/lis h)de\ tokh=es; ( Od. 1. 170.)

kate/sxet). kate/xein (sc. nau=n, though nhi+/ is sometimes added) ei)s to/pon is the usu. prose constr., but poets use also a simple acc., as Helen. 1206 podapo\s d' o(/d' a(nh\r kai\ po/qen kate/sxe gh=n; The difference between kate/xw and prose/xw (236) is like that between ‘to put into harbour’ and to ‘touch at’; i.e., the latter implies a further destination; the former does not necessarily imply it, though it does not exclude it (cp. 270).

222 On the grounds given in n. on 220, I conjecture po/lews instead of pa/tras. But this does not affect the question of metre. It is more probable that, with Triclinius, we ought simply to place u(ma=s after ge/nous than (1) that Soph. wrote poi/as pa/tras (or po/lews) u(ma=s a)/n, k.t.l.,— a verse like 101: or (2) that we should read poi/as a)\n u(ma=s patri/dos, with Dind., who remarks that patri/dos holds that place in Soph. O. T. 641, Soph. O. T. 825, Soph. O. C. 428.
tu/xoim' a)\n ei)pw/n, be right in calling. Aesch. Ag. 1232ti/ nin kalou=sa dusfile\s da/kos | tu/xoim' a)/n; So kurw= Soph. El. 663.For the doubled a)/n, cp. Soph. O. T. 339 n.

sxh=ma k.t.l. The sense is, sxh=ma stolh=s u(pa/rxei *(ellhniko/n, prosfile/staton e)moi/. But, instead of that, we have sxh=ma u(pa/rxei (sxh=ma) *(ella/dos stolh=s, and the epithet (prosfile/staton), which would more naturally go with sxh=ma, is joined to stolh=s:—‘the fashion is, to begin with, (u(pa/rxei,) that of Hellenic garb,—the garb which I love best.’ The sxh=ma (habitus) denotes the general ‘fashion,’ or effect to the eye: stolh\ *(ella/s refers to the actual garments distinctive of Hellenes, such as xitw/n and i(ma/tion. Cp. Eur. fr. 476 *teuqra/ntion de\ sxh=ma *musi/as xqono/s (the fashion of garb worn by the people of Teuthrania in Mysia). In I. T. 246 podapoi/; ti/nos gh=s o)/nom' e)/xousin oi( ce/noi; Monk conjectured sxh=m) for o)/nom).—Nauck rejects this verse, because the hero loves the land, not the clothes, of Hellas; and because he cannot yet be sure that these Greeks are friends.

o)/knw| k.t.l. It seems simplest and best to construe thus: kai\ mh\ o)/knw| e)kplagh=te, dei/sante/s me a)phgriwme/non (cp. I. A. 1535 tarbou=sa tlh/mwn ka)kpeplhgme/nh fo/bw|); though e)kplagh=te could directly govern me ( El. 1045ou)de\n e)kplagei=sa/ se). In O. C. 1625sth=sai fo/bw| dei/santas e)cai/fnhs tri/xas, the dat. is causal (‘through fear’): in Tr. 176, fo/bw|...tarbou=san, it has an adverb. force (‘sorely afraid’; cp. O. T. 65).

a)phgriwme/non, made like to an a)/grios, or wild man: cp. the description of Philoctetes, as Diomedes and Odysseus found him at Lemnos, in Quintus Smyrnaeus 9. 364 ff.: au)ale/ai de/ oi( a)mfi\ ko/mai peri\ krati\ ke/xunto | qhro\s o(/pws o)looi=o... | kai/ oi( pa=n mema/ranto de/mas, peri\ d' o)ste/a mou=non | r(ino\s e)/hn, o)loh\ de\ parhi+/das a)mfe/xut' au)xmh\ | leugale/on r(upo/wntos. Attius Phil.fr. 14 quod te obsecro, aspernabilem ne haec taetritudo mea me inculta faxit. Cp. Tennyson, Enoch Arden: ‘Downward from his mountain gorge | Stept the longhair'd long-bearded solitary, | Brown, looking hardly human, strangely clad’...

kakou/menon, suffering hardship. Cp. Helen. 268 pro\s qew=n kakou=tai (he suffers reverses). Legg. 932 D tw=n kakou/ntwn h)\ kakoume/nwn, those who inflict or who suffer injury. This is a certain correction of the vulg. kalou/menon, which cannot be defended either as (1) pass., ‘called,’—explained by Blomfield as being here little more than o)/nta: or (2) midd., ‘invoking’ you. Soph. once uses the midd., Soph. O. C. 1385(a)ra\s) a(/s soi kalou=mai: but here the obscurity would be extreme.
a)ll), appealing, ‘nay’ ( O. C. 237 n.).

u(mw=n a(martei=n tou=to/ g), lit., to be disappointed, in regard to this, on your part. The gen. u(mw=n is not construed directly with a(martei=n (as though ‘to fail of you’ meant ‘to be repulsed by you’), but is like the gen. in O. T. 580pa/nt' e)mou= komi/zetai (‘from me’), ib. 1163 e)deca/mhn de/ tou. The acc. tou=to, again, is not directly governed by a(martei=n, but is analogous to the acc. of pronouns or adjectives which can stand, almost adverbially, after tugxa/nw and kurw=, as Aesch. Ch. 711tugxa/nein ta\ pro/sfora: see Soph. O. T. 1298 n. In L the reviser has written ei)s tou=to over tou=to, showing that he understood it thus. Cp. Eupolis fr. 25 le/g' o(/tou )piqumei=s, kou)de
 a)tuxh/seis e)mou= (so Meineke, with Priscian 18. 1175, who has kai\ ou)de
: though Bekker Anecd. 462 gives ou) ga). Thus Wunder's change of tou=to/ g) to tou=de/ g) seems needless, though the double gen. could be illustrated by 1315 (cp. O. C. 1170 n.), and the phrase by Eur. Med. 867ou) ta)
 a(ma/rtois tou=de/ g), a)ll' a)kou/somai.
a)ll), in assent: 48 n.
ou(/neka= o(/ti: Ant. 63 n.
feu=, expressing joyful wonder: Ar. Av. 1724w)= feu= feu= th=s w(/ras, tou= ka/llous.

to\ kai\ labei=n, ‘that I should e'en, really, have received....’ Cp. Eur. Med. 1051a)lla\ th=s e)mh=s ka/khs, | to\ kai\ prose/sqai malqakou\s lo/gous freni/ (‘nay, out upon my cowardice,—that I should e'en have admitted such soft pleadings to my soul!’). Xen. Cyr. 2. 2. 3ei)=pe pro\s au(to/n: *th=s tu/xhs, to\ e)me\ nu=n klhqe/nta deu=ro tuxei=n (‘to think that...!’).
toiou=d' a)ndro\s, not merely a Greek, but one of such gentle breeding as is announced by the stranger's mien and speech.
e)n xro/nw| makrw=|, after it: cp. Eur. Phoen. 305xro/nw| so\n o)/mma muri/ais e)n a(me/rais | prosei=don: Soph. O. C. 88 n.

prose/sxe has been much suspected, because prose/xw, in its nautical use, means, ‘touch at’ a place, not, ‘cause one to touch at it.’ But prose/xw, as=‘touch at,’ meant properly, ‘to guide one's ship towards’ ( Her. 9. 99prossxo/ntes ta\s ne/as),—nau=n being commonly understood. Where prose, then, would say, ti/nos xrh/|zwn prose/sxes (th\n nau=n); poetry might surely say, ti/s xrei/a prose/sxe se; ‘what need guided thy course to land?’ It may be added that prosh/gagen is itself an argument for prose/sxe. ‘Brought thee to this shore,—aye, brought thee to my side.’ prose/sxe implies only a passing visit to the coast; prosh/gage supplements it in a way suitable to the forlorn man's eager hope.
ti/s a)ne/mwn o( fi/ltatos;=ti/s (a)/nemos), a)ne/mwn o( fi/ltatos (w)/n); the art. emphasizes the superl.: see n. on Ant. 100to\ ka/lliston...tw=n prote/rwn fa/os.
ge/gwne, imperat. of the perf. ge/gwna, of which the subjunct. gegw/nw occurs O. C. 213(n.).
o(/pws ei)dw= without a)/n, as Ant. 776, Ai. 6, etc.: O. C. 889le/caq), w(s ei)dw= to\ pa=n.
ge/nos, acc. of respect: El. 706*ai)nia\n ge/nos: fr. 61. 3 ka)rgei/a| ge/nos. Verg. Aen. 8. 114 Qui genus (sc. estis)?

*sku/rou: for the gen., cp. O. T. 236 n. Scyros (still Skyro), the small island, about 25 miles long from N.W. to S.E. , which lies about 35 miles E. of Euboea, nearly in the latitude of Trachis. In 469 B.C. Cimon expelled the predatory Dolopes from the island, and brought the reputed remains of Theseus to Athens. Scyros then became a possession of the Athenians, in whose estimation it was a dreary and insignificant little place ([Dem.] or. 52 § 9): *skuri/a a)rxh/ suggested the same idea as vacuis aedilis Ulubris. The name means ‘stony.’ sku/ros (o(), which Curtius connects with cu/ein ‘to scrape,’ was used to denote ‘chips from hewn stones’ (latu/ph). At Cyrene the skurwth\ o(do/s ( Pind. P. 5. 93) was not a ‘paved’ road, but a road ‘hewn’ out of the solid rock.—Cp. Apollodorus 3. 13. 8: ‘Thetis, in the foreknowledge that Achilles must perish if he went to the war, disguised him in woman's attire, and left him, as a girl, in Scyros. There he grew up, and married Deidameia (*dhi+da/meia) daughter of Lycomedes [king of Scyros]; and a son was born to them, Pyrrhus, afterwards called Neoptolemus.’<
*neopto/lemos: ¯˘˘˘: cp. 4n.— oi)=sqa dh\ to\ pa=n: cp. 389: 1240: Ant. 402pa/nt' e)pi/stasai, n.

w)= fi/lhs xqono/s, O thou (who belongest to) a dear land. The possessive gen. can thus be used, without a subst., just as the gen. of origin (a special form of the possessive) is so used, Ant. 379w)= du/sthnos | kai\ dusth/nou patro/s. We cannot well repeat pai= with w)= fi/lhs xqono/s, because, though classical idiom allowed pai=des *(ellh/nwn, it would hardly allow pai=s *(ella/dos in the fig. sense, ‘a son of Greece.’ That would mean rather, ‘a boy belonging to Greece’ (cp. *(ella/dos neani/ai, I. A. 52). It seems needless to write w)= )k fi/lhs xqono/s.

qre/mma *lukomh/dous, because the infant Neoptolemus was left to the care of his maternal grandfather, Lycomedes (239 n.), after his father had gone to Troy. Cp. Il. 19. 326(Achilles speaks) o(\s *sku/rw| moi e)/ni tre/fetai fi/los ui(o/s. In O. T. 1143qre/mma=‘foster-son.’— sto/lw| (causal dat.), mission, errand: O. C. 358ti/s s' e)ch=ren oi)/koqen sto/los;— prose/sxes … gh=n. The usual dative would be awkward here, on account of ti/ni sto/lw|: and the acc. is warranted by the analogy of kate/xw gh=n as=kate/xw ei)s gh=n (221 n.): cp. 355 f. In Polyb. 2. 9. 2 me/ros de/ ti (tw=n le/mbwn) prose/sxe to\n *)epidamni/wn lime/na, Bekker is probably right in adding pro\s before to/n.—After gh=n a comma seems better than a note of interrogation: cp. ti/s po/qen ei)=s, etc. (220 n.).

e)c *)ili/ou toi dh\ k.t.l. Here toi =‘you must know,’ and dh\=‘then’ (i.e., ‘since you ask me’). The effect of the particles (which could be properly represented only by voice and manner) is to give an easy, ready tone to the answer. Cp. n. on O. T. 1171(though the tone there is somewhat different) kei/nou ge/ toi dh\ pai=s e)klh/zeq). Burges thinks that toi dh\, without a preceding ge, is strange, and conjectures )gw\ dh\. But toi/ and dh/ have each their proper force, which does not depend on ge: and here a ge before toi would have over-emphasised *)ili/ou.

ou) ga\r dh\ su/ g): (How can you be coming from Troy?),—for you certainly did not go there with us at first. For this use of ou) ga\r dh/...ge in rejecting an alternative supposition, see O. C. 110 n.—The order of the words almost compels us to join kat' a)rxh\n tou= … sto/lou: cp. Legg. 664 E kat' a)rxa\s tw=n lo/gwn. Then h)=sqa nauba/ths (cp. 1027) h(mi=n (dat. of interest)=‘sailedst in our fleet.’ But it would also be possible to join nauba/ths with tou= sto/lou (partitive gen., cp. 73), taking kat' a)rxh/n as=‘originally.’
h)= ga\r in eager question: 322, 654, O. C. 64.

po/nou, of warfare, the peculiarly Homeric use (as Il. 11. 601ei)soro/wn po/non ai)pu\n i)w=ka/ te dakruo/essan), also freq. in Herod. (9. 27 e)n toi=si *trwi+koi=si po/noisi): cp. Eur. Cycl. 107e)c *)ili/ou te ka)po\ *trwi+kw=n po/nwn.
ou) ga\r...; As in h)= ga/r (248) and pw=s ga/r (250), the ga/r marks surprise (‘your words are strange, — for ...’ etc.).
oi)=sqa ka/toid), as Ant. 1063 f. i)/sqi...katisqi: El. 922*h*l. ou)k oi)=sq' o(/poi gh=s ou)d' o(/poi gnw/mhs fe/rei. *x*r. pw=s d' ou)k e)gw\ ka/toid' a(/ g' ei)=don e)mfanw=s;

pw=s … ka/toid); ‘how do I know?’=‘of course I do not know.’ This form is more emphatic, because more direct, than pw=s a)\n h)/|dh (or ei)dei/hn), or pw=s e)/mellon ei)de/nai; But it is rare except in affirmation (i.e., with pw=s ou)...), as in El. l.c.; Xen. Oecon. 18§ 3 tou=to me\n oi)=sqa...ti/ d' ou)k, e)/fhn e)gw/, oi)=da; See, however, Her. I. 75 kw=s ga\r...die/bhsan au)to/n; (=‘how can they have crossed the river?’).

o)/nou) a)/r) is better than o)/noma/ g) (cp. fr. 315 u(mei=s me\n ou)k a)/r' h)=|ste to\n *promhqe/a;). The variant ou)d' ou)/nom) might seem to favour ou) tou)/nom), but the latter (without a)/ra) would be too abrupt: ou)d) is clearly genuine. More probably ou)/nom) (a form unknown to Tragedy) was merely a late attempt to mend the metre.— Ph. here asks, in effect: ‘Finding me, a lonely sufferer, here in Lemnos, cannot you guess who I am?’—and the youth answers, No. This is quite consistent with 261, where Ph. assumes that his name, when announced, will be recognised. Neoptolemus might have heard of him as possessing the bow of Heracles (262), and yet not have heard of him as suffering on Lemnos. We could not join o)/noma, as=‘mention,’ with kakw=n.
diwllu/mhn, all these ten years, while my former comrades have been active at Troy.<

i)/sqi me w(s mhde
 ei)do/t), rest assured that I know nothing. w(s marks the mental point of view (‘regard me in the light of one who knows nothing’): distinguish this use of it from that in 117 (n.). mhde
 is generic (170 n.), not due to the imperat.: cp. 415; Ant. 1063w(s mh\ )mpolh/swn i)/sqi th
 e)mh
 fre/na. For w(s cp. also below, Ant. 567: O. T. 848.
po/ll) adv., ‘very’: O. C. 1514 n.

pikro\s: schol. e)xqro/s. Cp. Eur. Phoen. 955(a soothsayer) h)
 me
 e)xqoa\ shmh/nas tu/xh|, | pikro\s kaqe/sthx' oi)=s a)
 oi)wnoskoph=|, ‘odious.’ Hence the conject. stugno\s (Nauck) is wholly needless. The active sense, ‘hostile,’ is more freq., as Soph. Ai. 1359nu=n fi/loi kau)=qis pikroi/.
ou(= mhde\ k.t.l., a man of whom no report (the generic mh/, 170n.).

oi)/kade, to Malis (4 n.),—where the tidings would have had a special interest: mhd' *(ella/dos gh=s mhdamou=, nor in any part of Hellas (for the gen., cp. 204 th=de to/pwn n.). As Neoptolemus is coming from Troy, the words have more force if we suppose the poet to use *(ella/s in the larger sense which was so familiar in his own day,— as including all lands inhabited by Greeks. Thus the *(ella/s of Her. comprises Ionia (I. 92) and Sicily (7. 157); and Soph. himself ( Soph. Tr. 1060) has ou)/q' *(ella\s ou)/t' a)/glwssos. The thought will then be, ‘he had not heard of me from the mainland of Greece before he left Scyros; nor has he heard of me, since he has been at Troy, from any part of the Greek world.’ It is no objection, of course, that the Homeric poems do not recognise the Greek colonies in Asia Minor; the Attic drama was not careful in such matters. Even, however, if we restricted *(ella/dos gh=s to Greece Proper, it would still be natural that Ph. should say, ‘neither to Malis, nor to any part of Greece.’ Nauck, thus limiting *(ella/s, pronounces the distinction unmeaning; he further objects to w(=d' e)/xontos (because Ph. means that, not merely his plight, but his existence, is unknown); and therefore rejects w)=d' e)/xontos oi)/kade | mhd' *(ella/dos gh=s.
mhdamou= need not be changed to mhdamoi=: cp. O. C. 1019o(dou= ...th=s e)kei= (=e)kei=se): El. 1099o(doiporou=men e)/nqa (=oi(=) xrh/|zomen.

pw should prob. be read instead of pou. The long lapse of time imagined renders pw forcible; while pou could mean only, ‘I ween’; it could not go with mhdamou= as=‘to no place whatsoever.’ In O. C. 1370, where pw is certain, L has pou from the first hand. In fr. 467, again, lo/gw| ga\r e(/lkos ou)de\n oi)=da/ pou tuxei=n, the correction pw (Dindorf) is clearly right.

si=g' e)/xontes, i.e., saying nothing about Ph. 's fate, but allowing it to pass out of men's minds. Cp. Soph. Ai. 954h)= r(a kelainw/pan qumo\n e)fubri/zei polu/tlas a)nh/r, | gela=| de\ toi=sde mainome/nois a)/xesin | polu\n ge/lwta.
te/qhle: El. 260(ph/mata) qa/llonta ma=llon h)\ katafqi/nonq' o(rw=.

ka)pi\ mei=zon e)/rxetai: cp. O. T. 638(ou)) mh\ to\ mhde\n a)/lgos ei)s me/g' oi)/sete; Thuc. 1. 118§ 2 e)pi\ me/ga e)xw/rhsan duna/mews: 4. 117 e)pi\ mei=zon xwrh/santos au)tou= (when he had made further progress).
e)c: cp. 910: Ant. 193pai/dwn tw=n a)p' *oi)di/pou, n.

o(/d' ei)/m' e)gw/ soi (ethic dat.) kei=nos: cp. El. 665h(/de soi kei/nh pa/ra: O. C. 138o(/d' e)kei=nos e)gw/, n.— klu/eis, pres., knowest by hearsay: cp. 591: O. T. 305ei) kai\ mh\ klu/eis tw=n a)gge/lwn: O. C. 792o(/sw|per ka)k safeste/rwn klu/w.
tw=n *(hr...o(/plwn: the bow given by Apollo to Heracles, and by him to Ph. , as a reward for kindling the pyre on Oeta: cp. 198 n., 670 n.
despo/thn: cp. Aesch. Th. 27toiw=nde despo/ths manteuma/twn. So dominus.
o(\n oi(: for the art. at the end of the v., see on Ant. 409h(\ katei=xe to\n | ne/kun.

xw( *kefallh/nwn a)/nac: cp. Il. 2. 631au)ta\r *)odusseu\s h)=ge *kefallh=nas megaqu/mous: who are there described as inhabiting Ithaca, Zacynthus, Samos (=Cephallenia, first so called in Her. 9. 28), and other islands off the coast of Acarnania, as well as part of the mainland itself. So Hom. Od. 24. 378(Laertes) *kefallh/nessin a)na/sswn. Buttmann thinks that both here and in 791 (w)=ce/ne *kefallh/n) the name is used scornfully. Its Homeric associations, at least, are honourable (cp. Hom. Il. 4. 330, *kefallh/nwn a)mfi\ sti/xes ou)k a)lapadnai/). To assume that the Cephallenians were despised because the Taphii, their neighbours, were pirates ( Hom. Od. 15. 427), seems a little unfair to them. But it is very likely that the name is used, if not with scorn, yet with a tone of dislike,—‘king of those crafty islanders.’ The Athenians had experienced the skill of Cephallenians in laying a deadly ambuscade ( Thuc. 2. 33).

a)gri/a| is followed by a)gri/w| in 267. The effect is certainly unpleasing. But with regard to such repetitions it must always be remembered that ancient poetry was far less fastidious than modern: see n. on 88 (pra/ssein). On the other hand, Eustathius, the witness for foini/w| in 267 (cp. cr. n.), was frequently loose in citation: see Ant., append., p. 249. The recurrence of e)/rhmon in 269 offends less, but is noteworthy. It is not surprising that interpolation should have been suspected. Three views have been held. (1) Prinz would reduce vv. 264—269 to three (see crit. note). This reconstruction is too violent to be probable. (2) Nauck would omit the words e)/rhmon, a)gri/a| | no/sw| katafqi/nonta. But cu
 h(=| in 268 confirms vo/sw|: it could not refer to e)xi/dnhs. And cu
 w(=| would hardly have become cu
 h(=|. (3) Jacob A. proposed to omit vv. 268-70. This would obviate the repetition of e)/rhmon, and of w)/|xont) (273); but it would also suppress the notice of Chrysè; which, however, Ph. would naturally mention, as he supposes that the whole story is new to the youth. I believe that there has been no interpolation, though Soph. has written with some verbal negligence. The point of vv. 264—267 is the putting ashore (e)/r- riyan): that of 268—270, the desertion (w)/|xont)).

th=s … e)xi/dnhs, that which guards Chrysè's shrine (1327). The definite art. is sufficiently natural, as Ph. is following the train of his own memories, —even if he supposes that N. has not heard of the e)/xidna before (cp. 255).— xara/gmati, the rent left by the serpent's bite: cp. Anacreontea 26 puro\s xa/ragm) (brand of fire,—on horses): [Eur. ] Rhes. 73 nw=ton xaraxqei/s (wounded).
cu\n h(=|, referring to no/sw|,— ‘in company with’ it,=h(=| cuno/nta, cp. 1022: O. T. 17su\n gh/ra| barei=s.
w)/|xont) would probably follow e)/rhmon, but gains emphasis by coming first; for the irregular order of words, cp. O. T. 1251 n.
th=s ponti/as *xru/shs, the small island near Lemnos (see n. on 8 ff., and Introd.). kate/sxon: 221 n.

a)/smenoi, because they could now slip away without being vexed by his entreaties and reproaches. The word adds an effective touch to the picture of their heartlessness. Dindorf's a)/smenon (received by Nauck and Blaydes) is far weaker; nor is it suitable. In Lys. or. 1 § 13 e)ka/qeudon a)/smenos means, ‘I gladly went to sleep’ (inchoative imperf.). Here, however, a)/smenon eu(/donta would mean, not ‘gladly going to sleep,’ but ‘gladly sleeping,’—as though with conscious satisfaction.
e)k pollou= sa/lou, after the rough passage from the islet of Chrysè to Lemnos (see on 8 ff.). Cp. Ant. 150e)k ...pole/mwn: ib. 163 pollw=| sa/lw| sei/santes.
kathrefei=, roofed over, i.e., here, over-arching,—forming a cave; cp. Ant. 885 n.

pe/tra|, ‘a rock,’ is a necessary correction of pe/trw|, ‘a stone.’ pe/tros is never used in the larger sense, nor could the epithet here justify such a use. Cp. Xen. An. 4. 3. 11e)n pe/tra| a)ntrw/dei: but ib. 7. 12 ou)dei\s pe/tros (i.e., none of the li/qoi mentioned in § 10) a)/nwqen h)ne/xqh.

oi(=a, adv.,=w(s, cp. 293, O. T. 751: fwti\ dusmo/rw|, as for some poor wretch, some beggar, for whom their least gifts were good enough. Cp. Ar. Ach. 424a)ll' h)= filokth/tou ta\ tou= ptwxou= le/geis; (sc. r(a/kh). Not, ‘rags such as my wretched state required’ (i.e. for dressing his wound, cp. 39).

kai/ ti kai\: cp. 308: fr. 304 kai\ dh/ ti kai\ parei=ka tw=n a)rtuma/twn: Thuc. 1. 107kai/ ti (adv.) kai\ tou= dh/mou katalu/sews u(poyi/a|: id. 2. 17 kai/ ti kai\ *puqikou= mantei/ou a)kroteleu/tion: Pind. O. 1. 28kai/ pou/ ti (adv.) kai\ brotw=n fa/tis k.t.l.
bora=s: to avoid the pollution of directly causing his death by starvation: cp. on Ant. 775forbh=s tosou=ton w(s a)/gos mo/non proqei/s.
oi(=) au)toi=s tu/xoi: cp. 315: Xen. An. 3. 2. 3oi)/omai ga\r a)\n h(ma=s toiau=ta paqei=n oi)=a tou\s e)xqrou\s oi( qeoi\ poih/seian.
su\ dh\ (which has been needlessly altered, see cr. n.) suits the earnest appeal: ‘try to imagine for yourself what I felt.’
a)na/stasin, cogn. acc. with sth=nai as=a)nasth=nai (cp. O. T. 50sta/ntes t' e)s o)rqo/n).
poi=) e)kdakru=sai (da/krua): cp. Eur. Ph. 1344 w(/st' e)kdakru=sai/ g' (burst into tears).

poi=) a)poimw=cai kaka/, ‘what woes I lamented.’ This version is recommended (a) by the fact that the following verses develope a picture of the kaka/: (b) by the ordinary use of a)poimw/zein with an acc. of the object deplored, as Ant. 1224: Eur. Med. 31: Eur. Alc. 635, Eur. Alc. 768: Aesch. fr. 134. But another version is also possible: ‘shrieked out reproaches.’ Here, however, he is speaking rather of his misery than of his resentment.

o(rw=nta nau=s me
 bebw/sas, a)/ndra de\ k.t.l.: cp. 1136 o(rw=n me
 ai)sxra\s a)pa/tas, stugno
 de\ fw=t' e)xqodopo/n. In both passages the irregular place of me/n is due to the writer having begun as if he intended to repeat the partic. of o(ra/w: as here, o(rw=nta me
 nau=s...o(rw=nta de\ a)/ndra ( O. T. 25fqi/nousa me
...fqi/nousa d), n.). Cp. Ai. 372 ff., n.

ou)x is equivalent to a repetition of ou)de/na. For o(/stis a)rke/seien, cp. 693 f. par' w(=|...a)poklau/seien (where, as here, the sentence is negative). I. T. 588 ff. ou)de/na ga\r ei)=xon o(/stis *)argo/qen molw\n | ei)s *)/argos au)=qis ta\s e)ma\s e)pistola\s | pe/myeie. And in a positive sentence, Soph. Tr. 903kru/yas' e(auth\n e)/nqa mh/ tis ei)si/doi. The relative clause with the optative is, in such instances, virtually a final clause (as here, ‘no one to help’). Instead of such an optative, we usually find in Attic the fut. ind., even after a secondary tense; as if here we had ou)x o(/stis a)rke/sei: e.g. H. 2. 3. 2 e)/doce tw=| dh/mw| tria/konta a)/ndras e(le/sqai, oi(\ tou\s patri/ous no/mous suggra/yousi.

The origin of this use of the optative is disputed. (1) According to one view, it is an extension of the deliberative use. From the direct question, ti/s a)rke/sh|; comes the indirect a)porw= o(/stis a)rke/sh|: and, after a secondary tense, h)po/roun o(/stis a)rke/seien. ( H. 7. 4. 39 h)po/rei o(/ ti xrh/saito tw=| pra/gmati.) In ou)de/na ei)=xon o(/stis a)rke/seien the interrogative sense of o(/stis has passed into a purely relative sense, and the clause has become final. For this view, see Sidgwick A. in Classical Review, vol. v. p. 148, 1891. (2) Others hold that this optative is simply a potential, equivalent to the optative with a)/n. Prof. W. G. Hale, after a full discussion, decides for this view: see Transactions of American Phil. Assoc., vol. XXIV. pp. 156—205, 1894.

no/sou ka/mnonti sulla/boito, put a helping hand to the disease, i.e., help to lighten its burden, for me in my suffering. As lamba/nomai/ tinos=to lay hold on a thing, so sullamba/nomai/ tino/s tini=to lay hold on it along with another person; i.e., to help him with it. Eur. Med. 946sullh/yomai de\ tou=de/ soi ka)gw\ po/nou. Thuc. 4. 47§ 2 cunela/bonto de\ tou= toiou/tou ou)x h(/kista, they mainly contributed to such a result. Cp. id. 4. 10 § 1 oi( cunara/menoi tou=de tou= kindu/nou.
pa/nta de\ skopw=n: de/ here=a)lla/: Ant. 85 n.

plh
 a)nia=sqai: for the absence of the art., cp. O. C. 608 n.: Antiphanes fr. incert. 51 katalei/peq' ou)de
 e(/teron h)\ teqnhke/nai. paro/n: cp. El. 959pa/resti me
 ste/nein | ... | pa/resti d' a)lgei=n. Musgave cp. Hor. Sat. 2. 5. 68 invenietque Nil sibi legatum praeter plorare suisque.

eu)ma/reian, ease (704), hence, abundance. Cp. Aesch. fr. 237 kou)/pw tis *)aktai/wn' a)/qhros h(me/ra | keno/n, po/nou ploutou=nt' e)/pemyen oi)/kade. The author of the ‘Letters of Phalaris’ had this passage in mind, Ep. 33 (Schaefer) e)dh/lwsen o(/ti pa/ntwn e)ndeei=s e)ste\ plh\n limou= kai\ fo/bou: tou/twn de\ [cp. tou/tou de\ here] u(ma=s kai\ li/an eu)moirei=n [v. l. eu)porei=n].

o( me\n xro/nos dh\ dia\ xro/nou k.t.l. The text has been boldly altered by some editors (see cr. n.), in order to get rid of dia\ xro/nou: but the iteration is itself a proof of soundness. Such iteration is constantly employed in expressing a succession of seasons or periods; ‘day by day,’ e)/tos ei)s e)/tos ( Ant. 340), par' <*>mar h(me/ra ( Ai. 475), Mod. Gr. xro/no se\ xro/no (‘year after year’), truditur dies die (Hor. Carm. 2. 18. 15), etc. The phrase dia\ xro/nou regularly means, ‘after an interval of time’: cp. 758: Lys. or. 1 § 12 a)sme/nh me e(wrakui=a h(/konta dia\ xro/nou: Xen. Cyr. 1. 4. 28 h)/kw dia\ xro/nou. So here, o( xro/nos prou)/baine/ moi, time was ever moving on for me, dia\ xro/nou, as (each) space of time was left behind. (The ‘each’ is implied in the imperfect prou)/baine, which denotes not a single advance, but a series of advances.) Suppose that the interval denoted by dia\ xro/nou is a month. ‘One month having elapsed’ (dia\ xro/nou—as each month came to an end), ‘time kept moving on’ (i.e. a new month began). Render, then, ‘Time went on for me, season by season.’ Cp. Tennyson, Enoch Arden: ‘Thus over Enoch's early-silvering head | The sunny and rainy seasons came and went | Year after year.’—Ellendt, rightly starting from the sense of dia\ xro/nou as ‘after an interval,’ wrongly explains it here as simply tarde, ‘pausenweise’: i.e. ‘time went on with many a pause’: as if, to Philoctetes, time seemed, at moments, to stand still. The error here consists in excepting the intervals denoted by dia\ xro/nou from the whole progress described by prou)/baine.—Not: ‘time kept moving on through time’: as if o( xro/nos were the moving point, while dia\ xro/nou denoted its course.—For prou)/baine, cp. Her. 3. 53tou= xro/nou probai/nontos: Lys. or. 1 § 11 proi+o/ntos de\ tou= xro/nou.

ka)/dei ti. The sense of ti here is nearly e(/kasto/n ti, just as tis sometimes =e(/kasto/s tis ( Thuc. 1. 40tou\s cumma/xous au)to/n tina kola/zein); a sense which the impf. e)/dei brings out, by implying successive needs at successive moments.— baia=|, of size, as Aesch. Pers. 447nh=sos... | baia/.

diakonei=sqai, midd.: schol. e)mautw=| e)cuphretei=sqai. That the midd. would suggest, to an Attic ear, ‘serving oneself,’ may be inferred from Legg. 763 A diakonou=nte/s te kai\ diakonou/menoi e(autoi=s, ‘serving (the State), and serving themselves’ (cp. Ar. Ach. 1017au(tw=| diakonei=tai). In later Greek, however, the midd. is sometimes no more than the act.; e.g. Lucian Philops. 35deciw=s u(phre/tei kai\ dihkonei=to h(mi=n.

u(popte/rous is perh. meant here to suggest ‘shy’ (and therefore hard to shoot); for the word often implies ‘taking wing’: cp. Helen. 1236 meqi/hmi vei=kos to\ so/n, i)/tw d' u(po/pteron: id. fr. 420. 4 u(po/pteros d' o( plou=tos. So Ai. 139pe/fo/bhmai, | pthnh=s w(s o)/mma pelei/as.

o(/ moi ba/loi: for the optat. referring to an indefinite number of acts in past time, cp. Lys. or. 23 § 3 ou(/s te e)ceuri/skoimi *dekele/wn, e)punqano/mhn: Xen. Cyr. 5. 3. 55ou(\s me\n i)/doi,...h)rw/ta.

neurospadh\s, ‘with drawn string,’ i.e., ‘drawn back along with the string.’ The epithet pictures the moment of taking aim, and thus suggests, though it does not literally express, the idea, ‘sped from the string.’ Not, ‘drawing the string back’ (by the pressure of the notch). Cp. Ant. 1216a(rmo\n...liqospadh=, an opening made by dragging stones away; where the adj. implies li/qwn e)spasme/nwn, as here the adj. implies a)po\ neura=s e)spasme/nhs.

a)/traktos. If the a) be for a)mf (as Curtius suggests, comparing a)/-bolos, cloak), the word meant, ‘what turns (trep) round’; hence (1) spindle; then (2) shaft, arrow: Tr. 714: Thuc. 4. 40§ 2, where a Laconian uses it, and Thuc. explains it by to\n o)i+sto/n. Aesch. adds the qualifying epithet tocikw=| (fr. 139).
au)to\s, having no dog to fetch it.

ei)luo/mhn (cp. 702), ‘crawl’; cp. Plat. Tim. 92A a)/poda...kai\ i)luspw/mena e)pi\ gh=s. The word suggests that each step with the sound foot is followed by a slight halt, while the other foot is dragged after it. Thus the notion is different from that of ei)li/podes (bou=s), where a ‘rolling’ gait is meant. Cp. on 163. A cornelian intaglio in the Berlin collection shows Philoctetes thus ei)luo/menos, with the help of a stick in his left hand, while the righ<*> holds his bow and quiver; the left foot is the wounded one. (Milani, Mito di Filottete p. 78: see Introd.) It is clear from 215 (ptai/wn) and 894 (o)rqw/sei) that the poet imagines him as striving to walk erect, and not as creeping prone, with the knee of the sound leg against the ground.

a)
 with the iterative impf. in apodosis, after optat. in protasis, as oft.: cp. Isocr. or. 6 § 52 to
 parelqo/nta xro/non, ei)...ei(=s mo/nos *lakedaimoni/wn bohqh/seien, u(po\ pa/ntwn a)
 w(mologei=to (‘it used to be allowed’) para\ tou=ton gene/sqai th
 swthri/an au)toi=s. Cp. 294 f.
du/sthnon, as 1377 dusth/nw| podi/.
e)ce/lkwn: cp. Eur. Phoen. 303gh/ra| tromera\n e(/lkw podo\s ba/sin.
pro\s tou=t a)/n: for the repetition of a)/n, cp. 223 n.: that of pro\s tou=to emphasises the limit of the painful effort.

pa/gou xuqe/ntos: cp. Tr. 853ke/xutai no/sos, ‘hath spread abroad’ (through his frame). Attius, Prometheus fr. 1 profusus gelus. Psalm cxlvii. 16: ‘He giveth snow like wool: he scattereth the hoar-frost like ashes. He casteth forth his ice like morsels.’
oi(=a: 273 n.— Nauck would delete this verse, because it is unreasonable that the hero should delay providing himself with firewood until the frost has set in.
cu/lon ti. Lemnos is now almost devoid of wood, save for a few plane-trees in the water-courses, and a little undergrowth.—For a)/n with iterative impf., cp. on 291 f.

e)n pe/troisi pe/tron. For the change of quantity, cp. 827 (u(/pne): O. C. 442oi( tou= patro\s tw_| patri\: ib. 883 a)=r' ou)x u(/bris ta/d);—u(/bris: Ant. 1310 f. dei/lai^os...—deilai/a|: El. 148a(\ *)/itun, ai)e\n *)/itun o)lofu/retai.

e)ktri/bwn, rubbing hard (e)k=‘thoroughly,’ i.e. till the spark comes). The v. l. e)kqli/bwn would mean, ‘pressing’ or ‘squeezing,’ and is unsuitable. Cp. Xen. Cyr. 2. 2. 15e)/k ge sou= pu=r...r(a=|on a)/n tis e)ktri/yeien h)\ ge/lwta e)caga/goito. The use of two stones would suggest concussion rather than friction. The Eskimos kindle fire by striking a piece of iron pyrites with a piece of quartz (instead of flint); the Alaskans of North America, and the Aleutian islanders (in the North Pacific), use two pieces of quartz, smeared with native sulphur. (M. Elie Reclus, in Encycl. Brit., art. ‘Fire.’) e)ktri/bwn might, however, cover the case of a slanting or scraping blow. In Lucian Ver. Hist. 1. 32 ta\ purei=a suntri/yantes refers to rubbing sticks together.

e)/fhn' a)/fanton fw=s, made the invisible light visible, i.e. drew the spark forth from its hiding place in the stone. Cp. Ai. 647(Time) fu/ei t' a)/dhla kai\ fane/nta kru/ptetai. Blaydes compares Synesius Ep. 138 spinqh=ra kekrumme/non kai\ a)gapw=nta lanqa/nein. G. 1. 135 Ut silicis venis abstrusum excuderet ignem.
a)/fanton could hardly be, ‘barely seen,’ as if the sense were that the feeble spark instantly vanished again.
oi)koume/nh ga\r ou)=n, ‘for indeed...’: cp. Ant. 489 n. Remark ou)=n in the thesis of the 3rd foot; so dh/ ( O. C. 23), and even per (ib. 896).
e)me/ has been suspected. But it serves to qualify the general sentiment by a reference to his special circumstances:—‘shelter and fire give all that a man needs—except, in my case, health.’

fe/re … ma/qh|s, L's reading, presents an unexampled construction. Elsewhere the subjunctive after fe/re occurs only in the first person, sing., as 1452, Nub. 787 fe/r' i)/dw: or plur., as id. Vesp. 1516 fe/re nun...cugxwrh/swmen. On the other hand, fe/r' ei)pe/ occurs eight times in Soph. (433; Soph. O. T. 390, Soph. O. T. 536, Soph. O. T. 1142: Soph. Ant. 534: Soph. El. 310, Soph. El. 376: Soph. Tr. 890). In Her. 4. 127fe/rete, tou/tous a)neuro/ntes sugxe/ein peira=sqe au)tou/s, the 2nd verb is imperat., not subj. If fe/re...ma/qh|s be retained, it can be defended only as an irregular equivalent for fe/re...fra/sw or the like (cp. Her. 2. 14fe/re de\ nu=n kai\ au)toi=si *ai)gupti/oisi w(s e)/xei fra/sw).

Several recent editors (see cr. n.) cut the knot by reading ma/qe. It is, however, improbable that, if ma/qe had been the genuine reading—giving so plain a construction—it would have been corrupted to the unparalleled ma/qh|s. A more attractive conjecture is Seyffert's ka)
 … ma/qois. If ka)
 had once become kai\ (a most easy change), then ma/qois might have been altered to ma/qh|s by a postclassical corrector. For the optat. with a)/n in courteous proposal or request, cp. 674: El. 637klu/ois a)
 h)/dh.

to\ th=s nh/sou, its case, condition: cp. Thuc. 8. 89ou)k e)do/kei mo/nimon to\ th=s o)ligarxi/as e)/sesqai: Legg. 712 D to\ ga\r tw=n e)fo/rwn...turanniko\n...ge/gone: id. Gorg. 450C to\ th=s te/xnhs: Eur. Alc. 785to\ th=s tu/xhs. Hence ta\ is a needless conjecture.

ou) ga/r tis o(/rmos e)sti/n. The absence of a safe o(/rmos is compatible with the existence of lime/nes (936 n.); and Philoctetes knows only the coast near his cave. If the Iliad calls Lemnos e)u+ktime/nh (21. 40), it also calls it a)mixqalo/essa (24. 753), which was probably understood in antiquity as ‘inhospitable’ (mi/gnumi); though a modern view co<*>nects it with mix-, o)mi/xlh, (our mist,) as=‘smoky,’ i.e., volcanic. In the time of Sophocles, Lemnos possessed two towns,—Hephaestia, on the N. coast, of which the site has lately been identified by Conze (Reise auf den Aeg. Inseln); and Myrīna, now Kastro, on the W. coast. There was once an excellent harbour at Hephaestia; there still is one at Kastro, the present seat of trade. Geod anchorage is also afforded by a deep bay on the N. coast (now ‘Purnia’), and by another on the S. (now ‘Mudros’).

ou)d' o(/poi ple/wn: nor (is there a place), sailing to which, e)cempolh/sei ke/rdos, a man shall sell off his wares at a profit. There is no e)mpo/rion. The acc. ke/rdos seems to be ‘cognate’ (=kerdale/an e)cempo/lhsin), rather than objective (as if e)cemp. meant, ‘achieve by trading’): cp. Her. 1. 1e)cempolhme/nwn (Ion.) sfi sxedo\n pa/ntwn: cp. Soph. Ant. 1036e)chmpo/lhmai n. (We cannot compare Soph. Tr. 92to/ g' eu)= pra/ssein...ke/rdos e)mpola=|, ‘brings in’ gain.) The subject to e)cempolh/sei is tis, easily supplied from nauba/ths (301).

cenw/setai, pass.: cp. 48 n. In Lycophron 92 this form is fut. midd. There is no class. example of cenwqh/somai. Attic, indeed, generally prefers the midd. form for the fut. pass. in ‘pure’ verbs (those of which the stem ends in a vowel).— For the fut. indic. in a relative clause of purpose, cp. Dem. or. 1 § 2 presbei/an pe/mpein h(/tis tau=t' e)rei= kai\ pare/stai toi=s pra/gmasin.
e)nqa/d)=deu=ro: cp. 256 mhdamou= n.

ploi=: this nom. pl. occurs also in Xen. An. 5. 7. 7kaloi\ ploi=: the dat. pl. in Antiphon or. 5 § 83 ploi=s. In L's sw/frosi the omission of the n e)felkustiko/n is doubtless a mere error; though Soph. sometimes lengthens i^ before br or bl in compounds ( Soph. Ant. 336, O.C. 996 n.).
brotw=n: cp. O. C. 279pro\s to\n eu)sebh= brotw=n.

ta/x' ou)=n tis … e)/sxe: ‘perhaps, indeed, some one has put in.’ ou)=n has a concessive force; cp. 1306 a)ll' ou)=n n. When ta/xa stands without a)/n, it usu.= ‘quickly’: but cp. Legg. 711 A u(mei=s de\ ta/xa ou)de\ teqe/asqe turannoume/nhn po/lin (where ta/x' a)/n is impossible). Here the force of ta/xa is, ‘I grant that visitors have come now and then; let us suppose such a moment.’
e)/sxe=prose/sxe, appulit: Thuc. 6. 62§ 2 e)/sxon e)s *(ime/ran. Cp. 221, 236.

polla\ ga\r k.t.l.: ‘for such things (viz., such necessities as a)/kwn implies) are likely to occur often (polla\ predicative adj., here practically equiv. to the adv.) in the long course of human life.’ Now and again in the course of his lifetime, a sailor might be driven to seek shelter even on such a coast as that of Lemnos. o( makro\s a)nqrw/pwn xro/nos is the long term of man's normal life; cp. Ant. 461ei) de\ tou= xro/nou | pro/sqen qanou=mai, ‘before my natural term.’ Cp. Her. 1. 32e)n ga\r tw=| makrw=| xro/nw| polla\ me\n e)/sti i)dei=n ta\ mh/ tis e)qe/lei, polla\ de\ kai\ paqei=n. e)s ga\r e(bdomh/konta e)/tea ou)=ron th=s zo/hs a)nqrw/pw| proti/qhmi. Id. 5. 9ge/noito d' a)\n pa=n e)n tw=| makrw=| xro/nw|. A reminiscence of these phrases may have been in the poet's mind.
ou(=toi referring to the indefinite tis (305): cp. Ant. 709ou)=toi referring to o(/stis in 707 (n.).

lo/gois e)leou=si … oi)kti/rantes. As a general rule, e)leei=n=‘to show pity or mercy in act’: oi)kti/rein, ‘to feel pity.’ Thus Dem. or. 28 § 20 sw/sate, e)leh/sate. [Dem. ] or. 57 § 45 e)leoi=nt' a)\n...dikaio/teron h)\ prosapollu/ointo. Lys. or. 31 § 19 oi(=s e(/teroi dido/nai par' e(autw=n ti (i.e. e)leei=n) proh|rou=nto, dia\ th\n a)pori/an oi)kti/rantes au)tou/s. See Heinrich Schmidt, Synonymik der griechischen Sprache, vol. III. pp. 577 ff.
kai/ pou/ ti: see on 274.
stolh/n: cp. 223 f. n.
e)kei=no … qe/lei sc. poih=sai: cp. 100 n.
sw=sai/ m' e)s oi)/kous: cp. Aesch. Pers. 737pro\s h)/peiron sesw=sqai: Soph. Ant. 189 n.

e)n limw=| te kai\ kakoi=si. Some critics suspect kakoi=si as not distinctive enough (see cr. n.); but it can surely denote those ‘hardships’ of his life which were superadded to the limo/s and the no/sos. For kai/ at the end of the v., cp. O. T. 267, O. T. 1234.
bo/skwn: cp. 1167.— a)dhfa/gon: so 7 diabo/rw|: 745 bru/komai. The no/sos is personified, as in 759 by e)ceplh/sqh.
bi/a: cp. 321: Tr. 38*)ifi/tou bi/an.

oi(=), Porson's correction of oi(=s, is certain. The sufferer prays that their sufferings may be like his own: cp. 275 n.: Ant. 927.With oi(=s, both au)toi=s (as= ‘themselves’) and a)nti/poin) become comparatively tame.
e)mou=: cp. El. 592w(s th=s qugatro\s a)nti/poina lamba/neis.

i)/sa could imply either (1) ‘as fully as they pitied you in their hearts,’— the sense in which the speaker means Ph. to take it: or (2) ‘only as much as they showed you pity in their deeds’: cp. Soph. Ant. 516 n. on e)c i)/sou.
e)poikti/rein is much better than Nauck's e)poiktirei=n, which, as expressing a presentiment, would call too much attention to the ambiguity of i)/sa.

e)n lo/gois. If e)n is sound, the phrase must mean ‘a witness present at (the utterance of) these words.’ Cp. Plat. Phaedo 115E mhde\ le/gh| e)n th=| tafh=|, ‘at the funeral,’ i.e., while it is taking place. The expression is unusual; but I hesitate to receive Gernhard's conject. w)\n.

suntuxw\n, ‘having found them bad men in my intercourse with them (su/n-).’ The force of the simple tuxw/n here prevails over that of the prep., and so a gen. replaces the regular dat. Since in O. C. 1483sou= tu/xoimi must be read for suntu/xoimi, there is no other extant example of suntugxa/nw with gen. But there are analogies for the exception: in 1333 e)ntuxw\n *)asklhpidw=n is the only instance of a gen. (instead of dat.) with e)ntugxa/nw, except Her. 4. 140lelume/nhs th=s gefu/rhs e)ntuxo/ntes. Again, Her. 552prostuxo/nti tw=n i)/swn and Soph. El. 1463e)mou= kolastou= prostuxw/n are isolated examples of a gen., instead of dat., with that compound. In 719 paido\s u(panth/sas (instead of paidi\) is also unique. Cp. Soph. Tr. 17koi/ths e)mpelasqh=nai (where the dat. would be normal). It may be added that here, where suntuxw/n expresses, not merely a meeting with the men, but an experience of their character, the gen. has a special excuse.—We cannot make suntuxw/n mean=‘having found them bad men, as you have done’ (i.e., su/n soi).
toi=s panwle/qrois: cp. Soph. El. 86xh( panw/leqros | mh/thr.
paqw/n, and not merely klu/wn.

324 f. The corruption in the MSS., qumw=|...xei=ra, is of the same nature as that in O. T. 376(me...sou= for se e)mou=). Cp. Plat. Rep. 465A ei)/ pou/ ti/s tw| qumoi=to, e)n tw=| toiou/tw| plhrw=n to
 qumo
 (sating his wrath) h(=tton e)pi\ mei/zous a)
 i)/oi sta/seis.

*mukh=nai, as the city of Agamemnon: *spa/rth, as that of Menelaus. gnoi=en, after the optative ge/noito: cp. Aesch. Eum. 297e)/lqoi (‘may she come !’)... | o(/pws ge/noito tw=nd' e)moi\ luth/rios: and Soph. O. T. 506 n.
eu)= g), euge: Ar. Eccl. 213eu)= g), eu)= ge nh\ *di/), eu)= ge: le/ge, le/g), w)=gaqe/. There is no other example in Tragedy of this colloquial eu)= ge without a verb.
