ti/nos ga\r: lit., ‘Now (ga/r, 249 n.), on account of what have you come thus charging them with (having provoked) the great anger (which you show)?’ ti/nos, causal gen., not with to\n...xo/lon alone, but with the whole sentence: cp. 751, 1308: O. T. 698di/dacon ka)/m), a)/nac, o(/tou pote\ | mh=nin tosh/nde pra/gmatos sth/sas e)/xeis.

w(=de, ‘thus’ (not ‘hither,’ as in O. T. 7).—xo/lon e)gkalei=n kata/ tinos=to make one's anger a subject of accusation against a person, i.e. to charge him with having provoked it. The causal ti/nos helps to explain the pregnant sense. Cp. O. T. 702le/g), ei) safw=s to\ nei=kos e)gkalw=n e)rei=s, ‘speak, if you can make a clear statement in imputing (the blame of) the feud.’

e)cerw=, mo/lis d' e)rw=. In such phrases mo/lis usu. stands in the first clause, with me/n: Ant. 1105mo/lis me/n, kardi/as d' e)ci/stamai, n. For e)cerw=—e)rw=, cp. 249 f. The feeling is like that of Odysseus when asked by Alcinous to tell his story: Od. 9. 12
soi\ d' e)ma\ kh/dea qumo\s e)petra/peto stono/enta
ei)/resq), o)/fr' e)/ti ma=llon o)duro/menos stenaxi/zw.
molw/n: to Troy, 353.

e)/sxe. The pres. e)/xei would mean ‘constrains’; cp. I. T. 1065 trei=s mi/a tu/xh tou\s filta/tous, | h)\ gh=s patrw/|as no/stos, h)\ qanei=n, e)/xei. The aor. (‘ingressive’) =‘came upon him with constraint’: cp. 1117: fr. 529 tou\s de\ doulei/as... | zugo\n e)/sx' a)na/gkas: Eur. Hec. 4e)pei\ *frugw=n po/lin | ki/ndunos e)/sxe dori\ pesei=n *(ellhnikw=|.
fra/sh|s … mh\ pe/ra: for the place of mh/, cp. 67 n.
toceuto\s … damei/s=to/cois damei/s. The adj. here defines the instrument, as oft. elsewhere the place ( O. T. 1411qala/ssion | e)kri/yat)), or the manner ( O. C. 1637kath/|nesen ta/d' o(/rkios).

w(s le/gousin implies that there was something mysterious in the death; Paris might seem to have inflicted it, but, in men's belief, the true slayer was Apollo. e)k, however, does not here denote ulterior, as dist. from immediate, agency (‘by doom of Phoebus’; O. T. 1453); it is here no more than u(po/.—According to one account, Paris shot Achilles, but with the aid of Apollo (as Athena had helped Achilles against Hector): so Il. 19. 416(the immortal steed Xanthus to Achilles) a)lla\ soi\ au)tw=| | mo/rsimo/n e)sti qew=| te kai\ a)ne/ri i)=fi damh=nai: and Hector's prophecy ( Il. 22. 359) o(/te ke/n se *pa/ris kai\ *foi=bos *)apo/llwn | e)sqlo
 e)o/nt' o)le/swsin e)pi\ *skaih=|si pu/lh|sin. Verg. Aen. 6. 57Phoebe, ...Dardana qui Paridis direxti tela manusque | Corpus in Aeacidae. Another account speaks of Apollo without naming Paris: so Il. 21. 278Achilles says that Thetis had predicted to him that he should die *)apo/llwnos bele/essin. Cp. Aesch. fr. 350. 8 (Thetis speaks of Apollo) au)to/s e)stin o( ktanw
 | to
 pai=da to
 e)mo/n. So, too, Hor. Carm. 4. 6. 1 ff. Quintus Smyrn. 3. 61 (Apollo, hidden in a mist) stugero
 proe/hke be/lemnon | kai/ e( qow=s ou)/thse kata\ sfuro/n. As to the vulnerable heel of Achilles, cp. Statius Ach. 1. 269, where Thetis says: progenitum Stygis amne severo | Armavi (totumque utinam!). Hyginus ( Fab. 107) fused the two versions by making Apollo take the guise of Paris.—The ‘cyclic’ epic which related the death of Achilles was the Aethiopis, ascribed to Arctînus of Miletus, c. 776 B.C. (Introd. to Homer, p. 153).

a)ll' eu)genh\s me
: a)lla/=‘well’ (said as if with a sigh); me/n has a reflective tone, ‘certainly,’—‘it must be granted.’ Cp. Plat. Gorg. 460A a)ll' e)gw\ me
 oi=mai, k.t.l. (The de/ in 337 does not answer to this me/n.) Cp. 524 a)lla\...me/ntoi n.— ktanw/n … qanw/n: A frequent parh/xhsis. Ant. 1263w)= ktano/ntas te kai\ | qano/ntas ble/pontes e)mfuli/ous. I. T. 553 h( ktanou=sa xw( qanw/n. Alc. 488ktanw
 a)/r' h(/ceis h)\ qanw
 au)tou= menei=s.
e)le/gxw … ste/nw: delib. subjunct.: for the pres., cp. O. T. 651 n.
oi)=mai me\n, as O.T. 1051: so dokw= me/n, O. C. 995 n.
kai\ ta\ s), ‘even...’. Cp. Tr. 1216a)ll' a)rke/sei kai\ tau=ta. For the elision in s), O. T. 64 n.

toigarou=n (‘so, then’) occurs also in O. T. 1519, Ai. 490, El. 1257.— au)=qis pa/lin ( O. C. 1418 n.) refers to 329 —331. He had there intimated that, on reaching Troy, he had suffered some grievous wrong. Yet it has been proposed to reject v. 342 on the ground that Ph. could not ask for the repetition of a story which he had not yet heard.

o(/tw|, ‘wherein,’ dat. of respect: cp. Thuc. 2. 65§ 12 sfale/ntes...a)/llh| te paraskeuh=| kai\ tou= nautikou= tw=| plei/oni mori/w|: id. 4. 73 § 4 tw=| belti/stw| tou= o(plitikou= blafqh=nai. The dat. o(/tw| has not been influenced by the e)n in the compound. For the acc. with e)nubri/zw, cp. Kaibel Epigr. Gr. 195 1 mh/ mou e)nubri/ch|s a(gno\n ta/fon. The e)n has the same force as in e)ggela=n: cp. Soph. El. 68e)n toi=s e)moi=s ga\r ou)k e)nu/brisas kakoi=s.

poikilosto/lw|, ‘with gaily decked prow’: not simply ‘gaily drest’ (like leuko/stolos, etc.). Cp. Aesch. Pers. 408eu)qu\s de\ nau=s e)n nhi+\ xalkh/rh sto/lon | e)/paisen, where sto/los poetically=e)/mbolon, the beak or ram, which was attached to the ship below the prow. The term a)krosto/lion was sometimes applied to the ‘figure-head’ (such as the head and neck of a swan). Here, poikilosto/lw| seems to denote some special adornment, intended to mark the solemnity of the mission. These envoys came, not only to announce the death of Achilles, but to salute his heir. Cp. Pind. P. 2. 62eu)anqe/a d' a)naba/somai sto/lon: where (whether sto/lon be taken as ‘prow,’ or, more tamely, as ‘voyage’) the epithet refers to the adorning of the ship with garlands on a festal occasion. So, too, when the Salaminia was about to leave Athens on the annual qewri/a to Delos, the priest of Apollo crowned the stern with garlands ( Phaed. 58C).—Others regard poikilosto/lw| as merely a constant epithet, equiv. to the Homeric miltopa/rh|os (now explained by some as referring ‘to a literal painting of a face upon the bows’; Leaf, Il. 2. 637). The v. l. poikilosto/mw| is merely a prosaic corruption.

di=o/s t' *)odusseu\s: this is the Homeric polu/tlas di=os *)odusseu/s. The epithet di=os (‘bright’) may be rendered ‘princely,’ or ‘noble,’ when applied to a chief (the idea of personal comeliness being included therein): or by the more general word, ‘goodly,’ in other cases. Cp. Note 2 to Butcher and Lang's Odyssey: ‘Froissart and Brantome apply respectful terms of moral excellence to knights and ladies whom they describe as anything but moral.’

xw( trofeu\s: Phoenix, who, having been driven from the house of his father Amyntor, was received by Peleus, and entrusted with the care of the infant Achilles: to whom he says in Il. 9. 485kai/ se tosou=ton e)/qhka (reared thee up to manhood), qeoi=s e)piei/kel' *)axilleu=, | e)k qumou= file/wn. Another legend represents Achilles as brought up by Cheiron ( Il. 11. 832).
ei)/t' a)/r' ou)=n, ‘or, after all (a)/ra), it may be (ou)=n)’: for ou)=n with the second ei)/te, cp. O. T. 90, and n. ib. 1049.

a)lhqe\s does not occur as=a)lhqw=s, though to\ (or to/ ge) a)lhqe/s is so used, like re vera. Here it has, indeed, an adverbial force, but is properly the acc. governed by le/gontes. So in Eur. Ion 275 we may point thus: ti/ dai\ to/d); a)=r' a)lhqe/s; h)\ ma/thn lo/gos; For ma/thn, falso, cp. also Soph. El. 63, Soph. El. 1298.
gi/gnoit): they said, ou) qe/mis gi/gnetai, it becomes unlawful (by the fact that Achilles is now dead): cp. 116 n.

a)/llon h)\ )m). If there had been any previous indication of Neoptolemus, the reading a)/llon h)/ m' would have been tenable (see on 47 e(/loito/ m)): as there is none, we surely require h)\ )m). Cp. Ant. 83mh\ )mou= prota/rbei.

ou) polu
 k.t.l.: ‘they did not cause me to make any long delay, or to refrain from sailing at once’: another way of saying, ‘they filled me with burning eagerness to sail at once.’ He speaks with a certain bitterness, meaning, ‘they well knew how to act their part, when they put the matter in that light.’ For e)pe/xw tina/ as=‘to cause one to pause,’ see Thuc. 4. 5kai/ ti kai\ au)tou\s o( strato\s e)/ti e)n tai=s *)aqh/nais w)
 e)pe/sxe, ‘partly, too, the fact that their army was in Attica caused them to delay’ (instead of marching out at once). Id. 1. 129kai/ se mh/te nu\c mh/te h(me/ra e)pisxe/tw (pres. imper.) w(/ste a)nei=nai pra/ssein ti. This sense of the trans. e)pe/xw and e)pi/sxw is not precisely the same as that in Soph. El. 517o(/s s' e)pei=x' a)ei\ | mh/toi qurai/an ou)=san ai)sxu/nein fi/lous, ‘restrained thee’ (by compulsory detention): i.e., ou) polu
 xro/non m' e)pe/sxon is not, ‘they did not succeed in restraining me long’ (as if they had been trying to do so); but rather, ‘they gave me no cause for delaying long’;— not, ‘non diu me cohibuerunt,’ but ‘effecerunt ne diu morarer.’

Instead of mh/ me naustolei=n, we might well prefer, with Blaydes, mh\ ou)xi\ naustolei=n, were it not that palaeographically it is so improbable. And for mh/ where mh\ ou) might be expected, cp. O. T. 1387ou)k a)\n e)sxo/mhn | to\ mh\ )poklh=|sai, n. The repetition of me, as subject to naustolei=n, may seem slightly inelegant; but it is not grammatically objectionable.—See Appendix.

ou) ga\r ei)do/mhn, ‘for I had (never) seen him.’ The comment zw=nta, written after ei)do/mhn in the margin of L, represents the simplest and best interpretation. Neoptolemos was born in Scyros, and remained there, under the care of his maternal grandfather, Lycomedes (243), until he went to Troy (see n. on 239 f.). Soon after the birth of Neoptolemus, his father Achilles had returned to Phthia; whence, some eight or ten years later, he went to Troy, without revisiting Scyros. Hence Neoptolemus can say that he had never seen his father. In this conception Sophocles is following the Iliad. From Il. 11. 765—782 it appears that Phthia, not Scyros, was the place from which Achilles went to Troy. And in Il. 19. 331 f. Achilles speaks of his son as having never seen Phthia; for, apostrophising the dead Patroclus, he says, ‘my soul had hoped that thou should'st return to Phthia,’—w(s a)/n moi to\n pai=da qoh=| e)ni\ nhi\ melai/nh| | *skuro/qen e)caga/gois, kai/ oi( dei/ceias e(/kasta, | kth=sin e)mh\n dmw=a/s te kai\ u(yerefe\s me/ga dw=ma.—Apollodorus (3. 13. 8) follows a different version, according to which Achilles had remained in Scyros till he was brought thence to Troy by Odysseus.—For the midd. ei)do/mhn in dial., cp. El. 977i)/desqe, ib. 892 kateido/mhn, Tr. 151ei)si/doito: in lyrics, below, Tr. 1113, Ai. 351; and in anapaests, Tr. 1004.Cp. o(rwme/nh (midd.) in dial., Tr. 306.—See Appendix.

e)/peita me/ntoi, answering to ma/lista me/n (350): cp. O. T. 647 f. ma/lista me/n...e)/peita (without de/): ib. 777 qauma/sai me
 a)ci/a, | spoudh=s ge me/ntoi k.t.l. In Eur. Med. 1145 ff. pri
 me
... e)/peita me/ntoi is not strictly similar, since e)/peita is there temporal.

xw( lo/gos kalo\s prosh=n, ‘there was a further charm’ (kalo/s predicate) ‘in the reason suggested,—if indeed I was to take,’ etc.: o( lo/gos is the reason for going, suggested by the envoys, (as distinguished from the natural i(/meros in the son's mind,) and is explained by ei)...ai(rh/soim). Not, ‘the fame, too, was attractive.’ For prosh=n cp. H. 3. 1. 28 misqo\s me\n h(mi=n...ei)/rgastai..., h)\n de/ ti prosergasw/meqa, kai\ tau=ta prose/stai. For a different use, cp. 129 n.

ei) … ai(rh/soim), oratio obliqua: he said to himself, ei) ai(rh/sw. For the fut. opt., cp. Xen. Cyr. 3. 1. 3ei)/ tina feu/gonta lh/yoito, prohgo/reuen o(/ti w(s polemi/w| xrh/soito (he said, ei) lh/yomai ...xrh/somai). For ei) with optat., where one's own former thought is indicated in dependence on a past tense, cp. Lys. or. 3 § 3 ai)sxuno/menos, ei) me/lloien polloi/ moi sunei/sesqai, h)nesxo/mhn (his thought had been, ai)sxu/nomai, ei) me/llousi).

ta)pi\ *troi/a| pe/rgam) (cp. 611), the citadel which crowns the city of Troy, the *pe/rgamos a)/krh of Homer ( Il. 5. 460, Il. 6. 512),—who uses only the sing. Hence Ilios is called ai)peinh/, o)fruo/essa ( Il. 22. 411): cp. Introd. to Homer, p. 148. For the prep. e)pi/, cp. Pind. O. 8. 32(Apollo and Poseidon) *)ili/w| me/llontes e)pi\ ste/fanon teu=cai (sc. pu/rgwn).
i)w/n, oft. added to a verb denoting enterprise: cp. Ant. 768 n.
ple/onti/ moi: dat. of relation, as oft. with ref. to time: cp. H. 2. 1. 27 e)pei\ h)=n h(me/ra pe/mpth e)piple/ousi toi=s *)aqhnai/ois. The distance from Scyros to Sigeum is about 125 miles.
ka)gw\: for kai/ in temporal parataxis (instead of o(/te), cp. O. T. 718 n.

pikro\n *si/geion. Sigeum, the N.W. promontory of the Troad (now Yeni Shehr), is fitly named, as being the point for which he, coming from Scyros in the S.W., would make; and also because the tumulus, traditionally known as the ‘tomb of Achilles,’ is near Sigeum. It is ‘bitter’ or ‘cruel’ to him, not only on account of his father's death, but through the memory of his wrongs. The epithet is here a fine dramatic touch: while the conjecture ka)gw\ )p' a)/kron, which many recent edd. adopt, is tamely prosaic. Cp. Od. 17. 448mh\ ta/xa pikrh\n *ai)/gupton kai\ *ku/pron i(/khai.
ou)ri/w| pla/th|, instrum. dat.; sped by oars, while a W. S. wind also filled his sails. Cp. ‘velis remisque,’ ‘ventis remis,’ etc.

kathgo/mhn, was coming into harbour at, with acc. instead of the usual acc. with ei)s: cp. 244 prose/sxes...gh=n (n.). Poetry is bold in its use of the simple acc. after verbs of motion; cp. 1175: O. C. 643do/mous stei/xein.
o)mnu/ntes after strato/s: so Il. 17. 755tw=n d' w(/ste yarw=n ne/fos e)/rxetai h)e\ koloiw=n, | ou)=lon keklh/gontes: cp. Ant. 1021 f. n.
zw=nt' *)ax. pa/lin: legend naturally revived the image of the father in his son; Nauck cites trag. fr. adesp. 363 ou) pai=s *)axille/ws, a)ll' e)kei=nos au)to\s ei)=.

e)/keit), ‘lay low in death,’ a poet. equiv. for ‘had died’ (not=proe/keito, ‘lay on the bier,’ ready for the e)kfora/). Cp. El. 1134o(/pws qanw\n e)/keiso th=| to/q' h(me/ra| | tu/mbou patrw/|ou koino\n ei)lhxw\s me/ros. Ant. 1174kai\ ti/s foneu/ei; ti/s d' o( kei/menos; Simonides fr. 60 kei=sai zw=n e)/ti ma=llon tw=n u(po\ ga=s e)kei/nwn. It is natural to suppose that the son's wish to arrive before the burial (351) was fulfilled; for the tidings of the death would have been sent at once, and he would have reached Troy not later, perhaps, than five days after it (cp. 354). In Hector's case the funeral took place only on the tenth day after his remains had been brought home ( Il. 24. 785). The conciseness of the narrative here, which does not refer to the obsequies (unless in )da/k- rusa), is Sophoclean: cp. Ant. 415 n. The welcome by ‘all the host’ (356) cannot be considered as a direct allusion to the funeral rites; cp. the reception of Teucer by the army ( Ai. 721 ff.).
)da/krusa: for the prodelision of the augment, cp. O. C. 1062taxei= )po/reusan: Ant. 457 n.
ou) makrw=| xro/nw|, after it: O. C. 1648xro/nw| braxei= strafe/ntes.

w(s ei)ko\s h)=n goes closely with fi/lous,—‘friends, as it was reasonable to suppose them.’ The only peculiarity is that w(s ei)ko\s h)=n here refers to a just hope felt at a past moment, and not to the fitness of a past fact (as if the sense was, ‘friends, as they naturally were,’—or, ‘having gone, as I naturally did’). Cp. Plat. Menex. 247B fi/loi para\ fi/lous h(ma=s a)fi/cesqe.

ta/ t' a)/ll' o(/s' h)=n: Homer describes the klisi/a of Achilles as handsomely furnished (cp., e.g., Il. 24. 597), and it now contained the treasures which Priam had brought as the *(ektore/hs kefalh=s a)perei/si) a)/poina (ib. 228—236: 579).

tlhmone/staton lo/gon, here=a)naide/staton, most audacious, shameless (in Eur. Hec. 562 the same phrase=‘most courageous speech’): Soph. El. 439ei) mh\ tlhmonesta/th gunh\ | pasw=n e)/blaste: Aesch. Cho. 383tla/moni kai\ panou/rgw| | xeiri/.
pa/resti/ soi, ‘it is open to thee,’ ‘thou hast free leave’; cp. Ant. 213 n.
*lae/rtou: cp. n. on 86 f.

dakru/sas, the tears of pain and anger started into his eyes. (For the aor. part., cp. Phaed. 116D kai\ a(/ma dakru/sas, metastrefo/menos a)ph/|ei.) Many recent editors change this to a)kou/sas, or a compound of it (see cr. n.). But the traditional reading is incomparably more forcible; it is also thoroughly Homeric in spirit; Il. 23. 385(Diomedes, when Apollo strikes the whip from his hand in the chariot-race) toi=o d' a)p' o)fqalmw=n xu/to da/krua xwome/noio. Cp. Iuv. 1. 168 Inde irae et lacrimae.
e)cani/stamai: he had been seated, as in converse with friends.
o)rgh=|: modal dat., O. T. 405 n., barei/a|, vehement: cp. mh=nin barei=an ( O. C. 1328, Ai. 656).
ka|talgh/sas: cp. Ant. 767nou=s d' e)sti\ thlikou=tos a)lgh/sas baru/s. This compound (in which kata/ is intensive) occurs elsewhere only in later Greek.
w)= sxe/tli) is said to Agamemnon: h)= )tolmh/sat) (cp. 360 )da/krusa) refers to him and Menelaus: so O. C. 1104prose/lqet), w)= pai= (said to Antigone, entering with Ismene).

pri\n maqei=n e)mou=, before ye had heard from me (that ye might do so). The phrase is so far unusual that, when manqa/nw takes a gen. (of the person) only, it usually=‘to understand,’ as Plat. Gorg. 463D a)=r' ou)=n a)\n ma/qois a)pokriname/nou; Id. Phileb. 51C ei)/ mou manqa/neis. Similar is Soph. O. T. 545manqa/nein...sou=, to comprehend thy teachings. Cp., however, Soph. O. T. 541, w(=n maqo/ntes,=‘having made inquiries of them.’ So here maqei=n is little more than a)kou=sai or puqe/sqai.

o( d' ei)=p' *)odusseu/s. Here o( is a substantival pronoun, and the proper name is added as by an after-thought: a Homeric use, as Il. 2. 402au)ta\r o( bou=n i(e/reusen, a)/nac a)ndrw=n *)agame/mnwn (cp. Monro Hom. Gram. § 258). Cp. Ai. 780 ff. o( d' eu)qu\s... *teu=kros: Phaed. 70B h)= d' o(/s, o( *swkra/ths.

w)\n kurei=. Hermann objected to the historic pres. as unsuitable to a parenthetic remark; but without cause. Cp. Ant. 253 f., with n.: Eur. Hec. 963 ff. sxe/s: tugxa/nw ga\r e)n me/sois *qrh|khs o(/rois | a)pw/n, o(/t' h)=lqes deu=r): e)pei\ d' a) fiko/mhn, ... | e)s tau)to\n h(/de sumpi/tnei. Brunck's h)=n kurw=n (cp. 544) is smoother, indeed, but could hardly have generated the MS. reading.
ta/de does not imply that the arms are present (one of Nauck's grounds for preferring dedra/kas)), but only that they are the subject of conversation.

parw/n, not merely, ‘being here at Troy’ (while Neoptolemus was absent, 379), but, ‘being present at the critical moment’: cp. 1405: Ar. Lys. 283tasdi\ de\... | e)gw\ ou)k a)/ra sxh/sw parw\n tolmh/matos tosou/tou; Eur. Hipp. 1242ti/s a)/ndr' a)/riston bou/letai sw=sai parw/n; (i.e., to go and save).— Acc. to Arctînus in the Aethiopis, it was Ajax who carried the body of Achilles out of the fray, while Odysseus kept the Trojans off (Proclus p. 479). In Od. 5. 309 f. Odysseus speaks of the day, o(/te moi plei=stoi xalkh/rea dou=ra | *trw=es e)pe/rriyan peri\ *phlei/wni qano/nti. In Ov. Met. 13. 284 he says: his...humeris ego corpus Achillis | Et simul arma tuli.
h)/rasson: cp. Ai. 725o)nei/desin | h)/rasson e)/nqen ka)/nqen: for the lit. sense, O. T. 1276.
kakoi=s toi=s pa=sin: the art. properly means, ‘with all the taunts that exist’: cp. Tr. 716fqei/rei ta\ pa/nta knw/dal).

ou)de
 e)ndee\s poiou/menos, making (on my part) nothing deficient, i.e. leaving nothing unsaid that occurred to me. For this use of the midd. poiou=mai, cp. O. C. 1144ou) ga lo/goisi to
 bi/on spouda/zomen | lampro
 poei=sqai.

ei) … a)fairh/soito: he said, (deino/n e)stin) ei) a)fairh/setai: cp. 353 n. For the double acc., cp. Eur. Andr. 613a)fei/lou pate/ras ...te/kna. Since the idea of the taker's interest is usually implied, the middle voice of this verb is more freq. than the active.
e)nqa/d' h(/kwn, brought to that point.—provoked so strongly: cp. O. T. 687o(ra=|s i(/n' h(/keis: ib. 1158 a)ll' ei)s to/d' h(/ceis.
ou) du/sorgos: as his mother speaks of his a)ganofrosu/nh ( Od. 11. 203).
pro\s a(ch/kousen with dhxqei/s, not with h)mei/yato. pro/s with acc., as=‘in view of,’ can always represent the cause of a feeling; cp. Tr. 1211a)ll' ei) fobei= pro\s tou=to.
a(\ e)ch/kousen, the taunts which had been addressed to him (382): here e)c merely strengthens the notion of ‘being reviled,’ as in e)coneidi/zw: cp. 676.
e)peidh\ kai\ le/geis, ‘since thou must speak thus,’—kai/ emphasising le/geis: cp. O. T. 1129: but ib. 412 e)peidh\ kai\ tuflo/n m' w)nei/disas is different, kai/ going with tuflo/n.
ou) mh/pot): 103 n.— th\n *sku=ron (240): the art. is scornful: cp. 1060.
e)kpleu/sh|s implies a further taunt: having come out so late, he will not even now stay and fight.

382 ff. The words a)kou/sas ka)coneidisqei/s form a rhetorical climax,— ‘having been addressed, yes, insulted, with such taunts’: kaka/ is object to a)kou/sas, and also ‘cognate’ acc. with e)coneidisqei/s. Wecklein's ingenious ka)coneidi/sas seems unlikely, since N. is dwelling on his wrongs rather than on his own heat in resenting them.
pro\s oi)/kous: the plur. implies, ‘the home country,’ as 60 e)c oi)/kwn molei=n. The sing. (suggesting rather the private home) occurs in 58, 240, 488, 548.
thtw/menos: O. C. 1200 n.
ka)k kakw=n, as the reputed son of Sisyphus, 417 n. Cp. O. T. 1397kako/s t' w)\n ka)k kakw=n.
tou\s e)n te/lei, the Atreidae: cp. Ant. 67 n.
pa=sa and su/mpas have here an adverbial force,—‘wholly’: cp. Ai. 275kei=no/s te lu/ph| pa=s e)lh/latai kakh=|.
e)/sti … tw=n h(goume/nwn: is under their influence: cp. O. T. 917e)/sti tou= le/gontos, n. (But in Ant. 738ou) tou= kratou=ntos h( po/lis nomi/zetai; ‘is deemed his property.’)

strato/s, ‘army’ (with reference to the Greek army at Troy): not=dh=mos,—a sense which occurs in Aesch. and elsewhere ( Soph. Ant. 8 n.), but which is nowhere requisite in Soph. , and which would be weak here, just after po/lis.
oi( d' a)kosmou=ntes brotw=n (the gen. as in 304), the unruly; those who violate the rights of others, as Odysseus has done: cp. Ant. 730 and 660.

didaska/lwn lo/goisi. This play was brought out in the spring of 409 B.C. The Revolution of the Four Hundred, in the summer of 411 B.C., was emphatically a case in which oi( h(gou/menoi—Peisander and his fellow oligarchs—had corrupted or intimidated a po/lis. The Army at Samos had illustrated the same process in the case of a strato/s,—the oligarchic officers, in correspondence with Alcibiades, having been the first agents of mischief. ( Thuc. 8. 47 and 75: Grote VIII. pp. 9 and 63.) Thus, to the ears of an Athenian audience, the poet's verses might well suggest a lightly-hinted apology for those citizens who, against their will, had been compromised by the conspirators.—Cp. Soph. O. C. 1537 n.
lo/gos le/lektai pa=s: cp. 241 n.

*)atrei/das. We notice the art with which, all through his story, Neoptolemus has contrived to throw the chief odium on the Atreidae. Thus, after calling their speech tlhmone/statos (363), he remarks incidentally that Odysseus was a goodtempered man (377); and though he calls him, indeed, ka/kistos (384), he hastens to add that the higher powers were more to blame (385). And now, at the close, he names the Atreidae alone. Thus he acts in the spirit of his mentor's advice (64 f.), but refines upon it.
fi/los: cp. 585 f.

Mindful of their young chief's precept—peirw= to\ paro\n qerapeu/ein (149)—the Chorus seize this moment in order to deepen the impression left on the mind of Philoctetes. It was in the land of the Trojans—often called ‘Phrygians’ —that Neoptolemus was wronged by the Atreidae. ‘Then and there’—say the Chorus—‘we invoked the most awful deity of the land, the great Earth Mother, the Phrygian Cybele—to punish our prince's wrong.’ The interposition of the Chorus is admirably effective for the purpose of making their master's indignation appear genuine.

This strophe, to which vv. 507—518 form the antistrophe, is a u(po/rxhma, or ‘dance-song’ ( O. T. 1086 n.). The dochmiacs of which it is mainly composed (see Metrical Analysis) are accompanied by animated movement, expressive of the lively resentment which these memories suggest.

From a mythological point of view the verses are of singular interest. The attributes given to the goddess belong to three groups. (1) pambw=ti *ga= recognises her in the primary character of an Elemental power. (2) ma=ter...*dio/s identifies her with Rhea. (3) o)reste/ra, leo/ntwn e)/fedre, and the mention of the Pactolus, present her as the specially Phrygian Cybele. But these three characters are completely fused in the unity of the ma/thr po/tnia.

o)reste/ra: cp. Helen. 1301, where the o)rei/a... | ma/thr qew=n is identified with Demeter. In order to appreciate the large significance of this epithet in relation to the ‘Phrygian Mother,’ we must remember that ‘Phrygia’ originally denoted the whole interior highlands of Asia Minor west of the Halys (Kiepert, Anc. Geo. § 64). pambw=ti: cp. the epithets bio/dwros (1162), fere/sbios, poulubo/teira, fusi/zoos, kourotro/fos, etc.

ma=ter au)tou= *dio/s: the *mhtrw=|on at Athens was sacred to Rhea Cybele: see on Ant. 1070 ff. The name Rhea (probably connected with e)/ra, earth) was doubtless older than Cybele (see Welcker Götterl. I. 221), and in Crete the ancient cult of Rhea seems never to have passed into that of Cybele, while in Asia Minor Rhea and Cybele came to be identified. Hence Demetrius of Scepsis (in the Troad) could say that Rhea was not worshipped in Crete, because, by Rhea, he understood Cybele (Strabo p. 472). The legends of the Cretan Ida were easily transferred to the Mysian: there was a *di/kth in the Troad (Strabo l.c.) as well as in Crete. Cp. Apoll. Rh. 1. 1139r(o/mbw| kai\ tupa/nw| *(rei/hn *fru/ges i(la/skonto. Propertius 3. 1. 27 Idaeum Simoenta (the river at Troy), Iovis cunabula parvi.

*paktwlo
: mentioned here as the river on which Sardis was situated, —that city being a famous seat of Cybele's worship. Her. 5. 102*sa/rdies me
 e)neprh/sqhsan (during the Ionian revolt in 502 C.B. ), e)n de\ au)th=|si kai\ i(ro
 e)pixwri/hs qeou= *kubh/bhs: to\ skhpto/menoi oi( *pe/rsai u(/steron a)ntenepi/mprasan ta\ e)n *(/ellhsin i(ra/. Hence an Athenian poet might well think of Sardis in speaking of Cybele. Lydiawas included in the older and larger meaning of Phrygia (cp. Ant. 825 n.).

eu)/xruson. When the attribute of a noun which has the article consists of more than one element (as here of me/gan and eu)/xruson), part of it may stand between the art. and noun, and the rest after the noun, without art.: cp. 986 to\ pagkrate\s se/las | *(hfaisto/teukton: O.T. 1199 ta\n gamyw/nuxa parqe/non | xrhsmw|do/n. The Pactolus brought down gold dust from Mount Tmolus, the range just south of Sardis ( Verg. Aen. 10. 142: Hor. Epod. 15. 19, etc.).
ka)kei=, at Troy also (as now in Lemnos).
e)phudw/man=e)pekalou/mhn: the only classical example of this compound.

*)atreida=n u(/bris pa=s), ‘all’ their insolence,—referring to the full account of it which N. has just given (363 ff.). Others understand: (1) ‘the complete’ or ‘consummate’ u(/bris: cp. 142 pa=n kra/tos (n.). Or (2), making pa=s) predicative, ‘went with all its force’ (cp. 385 n.).

ta\ pa/tria, which had belonged to his father, Achilles: a rare poetical use of pa/trios as=patrw=|os: cp. Pind. O. 6. 62patri/a o)/ssa, the voice of his father (Apollo). In Soph. O. T. 1394ta\ pa/tria... dw/mat)=‘the house of my fathers,’ pa/trios having its usual sense. But that sense is impossible here, since Achilles had been the first possessor of the arms wrought by Hephaestus.—paredi/dosan: cp. 64 n.
i)w\ calls on the goddess to note the wrong: ma/kaira, i.e. qea/, as Sappho fr. 1. 13 tu\ d), w)= ma/kaira, | meidia/sais' a)qana/tw| prosw/pw|.
taurokto/nwn, a general epithet, marking the fierceness of the creatures whom the goddess subdues: cp. Il. 18. 579smerdale/w de\ le/onte du/) e)n prw/th|si bo/essin | tau=ron e)ru/gmhlon e)xe/thn.

leo/ntwn e)/fedre is best taken literally, of riding on lions. Cybele riding sideways on a lion was often represented in works of art (statues, reliefs, coins). Pliny 35. 109 says that Nicomachus painted deum...matrem in leone sedentem. This painter belonged to the Thebano-Attic school, and flourished c. 360 B.C.: we may well suppose, then, that the lion-riding Cybele was familiar in the time of Sophocles. Cp. Eur. Ion 202pterou=ntos e)/fedron i(/ppou (Bellerophon).—But, as the Homeric i(/ppwn e)piba/s ( Il. 5. 328) refers to chariot-driving, so here leo/ntwn e)/fedre might also mean, in a car drawn by lions. An altarrelief of the Roman age, reproduced by Baumeister (Denkm. p. 801), from Zoega's Bassiril. (1. 13), shows her thus: two lions draw her car; she wears a shortsleeved chiton, while the long veil attached to the back of her mural crown flows down like a mantle; in her right hand is a laurel branch; her left rests on the rim of the tympanon, holding it upright on her left knee.—It is less likely that leo/ntwn e)/fedre means, ‘seated above lions’; i.e., on a throne with lions crouching below at each side. Arrian (Periplous 9) mentions such a representation, which, like the other two, seems to have been frequent.

se/bas must be acc. in appos. with teu/xea: it cannot be (as the first schol. suggests) a vocative addressed to the goddess. The armour of Achilles, made by the god Hephaestus, is a se/bas, an object on which men gaze with reverent wonder. So Thetis describes these arms as kala\ ma/l), oi(=) ou)/pw tis a)nh\r w)/moisi fo/rhsen ( Il. 19. 11). Cp. El. 685(Orestes) ei)sh=lqe lampro/s, pa=si toi=s e)kei= se/bas. The dat. tw=| *larti/ou must be taken with paredi/dosan, which requires it. And it seems best not to take that dat. with se/bas also. If we did so, the phrase would mean, ‘an object of reverence’ to Odysseus; not, an ‘honour’ or ‘glory’ to him. But, though tw=| *larti/ou is not construed with se/bas, their juxtaposition is forcible; ‘to him—those peerless arms.’ The long separation of the verb from its dative is excused by the fact that the interposed i)w\ ma/kaira... e)/fedre prepares the indignant emphasis on tw=| *larti/ou.

We should not, then, change se/bas to ge/ras. As Nauck remarks, the two words are confused in the schol. on Eur. Or. 383(vol. 2, p. 122, Eur. Or. 18Dind.). L affords an instance of g corrupted to s in 571 (e)/sw for e)gw/). In uncials se/bas might have originated from B for P. But the sense given by ge/ras would be tamer.

su/mbolon … lu/phs, a grieftoken, i.e. a token consisting in your grief (defining gen.; cp. 159 oi)=kon...koi/ths, n.). su/mbola were tallies, sometimes consisting of dice (li/spai, Plat. Symp. 193A) or knuckle-bones (a)stra/galoi) sawn in two. A message or request, purporting to come from a friend at a distance, could thus be tested. The bearer was asked to produce the other half of the divided token. See Her. 6. 86. 2a)podeiknu/ntes ta\ su/mbola, a)pai/teon ta\ xrh/mata: Eur. Med. 613ce/nois...pe/mpein su/mbol),=to give one credentials to friends abroad. When two persons established such signs between them, they were said su/mbola poiei=sqai: C. I. G. 87 poihsa/sqw de\ kai\ su/mbola h( boulh\ pro\s to
 basile/a to
 *sidwni/wn, o(/pws a)
 o( dh=mos o( *)aqhnai/wn ei)dh=| e)a/n ti pe/mph|...deo/menos th=s po/lews. As each half was called su/mbolon, the word can mean ‘counterpart’: Plat. Symp. 191D zhtei= dh\ a)ei\ to\ au(tou= e(/kastos cu/m- bolon.—Musgrave (ed. 1809) first compared Aristeides 1. 416 (=625 Dind.) dio\ kai\ pa=sin a)nqrw/pois i(kano/n e)sti pro\s au)th/n (Athens), w(/sper a)/llo ti su/mbolon, au)to\ to\ sxh=ma th=s a)tuxi/as. Cp. Plaut. Poen. 5. 2. 87 Ego sum ipsus quem tu quaeris.—Si ita est, tesseram conferre si vis hospitalem.

prosa/|deq), ye are in accord with me, i.e. your complaint strikes a note which finds an echo in my own mind. Cp. O. T. 1113cuna/|dei tw=|de ta)ndri\ su/mmetros (in respect of age). cuna/|dein is properly said of two or more voices which harmonise; prosa/|dein of a vocal accompaniment which harmonises with music. Cp. Eur. Ion 359prosw|do\s h( tu/xh tw)mw=| pa/qei.
tau=t' … e)/rga=tau=ta ta\ e)/rga ( O. C. 471 n.).

a)
 … qigo/nta=o(/ti qi/goi a)
: cp. Thuc. 7. 42o(rw=n...ei) e)pikrath/seie/ tis...r(a|di/ws a)
 au)to\ lhfqe/n (=o(/ti r(a|di/ws a)
 lhfqei/h). Soph. O. C. 761ka)po\ panto\s a)
 fe/rwn | lo/gou dikai/ou mhxa/nhma poiki/lon, n.—With panourgi/as, despite its derivation, pa/shs must be supplied: so in Soph. Ant. 300 f. panourgi/as is followed by panto\s e)/rgou.

a)f' h(=s mhde
 … poei=n: from (=as a result of) which he would be likely, in the end, to effect anything not just. His objects have always something unjust in them; and he is unscrupulous in the choice of means. When the optat. with a)/n (as here the implied qi/goi a)/n) stands in the antecedent clause, the optat. (without a)/n) often stands in the relative clause: cp. n. on O. C. 560deinh
 ga/r tin' a)
 pra=cin tu/xois | le/cas o(poi/as e)cafistai/mhn e)gw/. This usage confirms L's me/lloi against me/llei (though the latter would be tenable: cp. Ant. 375 n.).

mhde
 here admits of two distinct explanations, though the sense is virtually the same with either. (1) It is ‘generic’ (170 n.): i.e. his purposes are of such a kind as can have no honest result. Cp. 1006 mhde
 u(gie\s...fronw=n: Ant. 493o( qumo\s... | tw=n mhde
 o)rqw=s <*>v sko/tw| texnwme/nwn. I prefer this view. (2) It is ‘final’: i.e. me/lloi poei=n=poh/soi: ‘from which he shall not effect anything just.’ When the fut. indic. in a relative clause denotes purpose, the negative is mh/: cp. O. T. 1412e)kri/yat), e)/nqa mh/pot' ei)so/yesq' e)/ti (n.).
e)s te/los, ultimately (though his lo/gos may be plausible at first sight): cp. Her. 9. 37ou) me/ntoi e)/s ge te/los oi( sunh/neike to\ e)/xqos (‘in the end,’—though for a time he prospered).
poei=n: for the spelling, cp. on 120: for the pres. inf. after me/lloi, O. T. 967 n.

o( mei/zwn, the son of Telamon; Ajax the son of Oileus (the leader of the western Locrians) was mei/wn, ou)/ ti to/sos ge o(/sos *telamw/nios *ai)/as ( Il. 2. 528).— ou)k h)=n e)/ti zw=n. Soon after the death of Achilles, and either just before or just after the coming of Neoptolemus, the Atreidae had awarded the arms to Odysseus. The suicide of Ajax followed closely on the award. He died, then, either just before, or just after, the arrival of Neoptolemus at Troy. Neoptolemus implies that he left Troy for home just after the award (382). Since his indignation is feigned, it might be supposed that the interval between the award and his sailing (for Lemnos) had really been longer. But, even if that interval had been as brief as he represents it, he might still have known, before leaving Troy, that Ajax was dead.

a)ll' h)=...; In this formula h)= asks the question: a)lla/ marks surprise, as it so often marks remonstrance (‘nay, can it be so?’ or, ‘what, can that be true?’). The fact that a)ll) is absent from L (see cr. n.) has led some editors to prefer the conjecture h)= ga/r. But it may be observed:—(a) a)ll' h)= was a comparatively unfamiliar phrase, and therefore the fact that the other MSS. have it is presumptive evidence of its genuineness. (b) The preceding pw=s ei)=pas cannot be urged as an objection: cp. Eur. Alc. 58pw=s ei)=pas; a)ll' h)= kai\ sofo\s le/lhqas w)/n; Eur. Itis true, however, that such a preface to a)ll' h)= is unusual: cp. Soph. El. 879: Aesch. Ch. 220: Eur. Alc. 816, Helen. 490, Heracl. 425, Hipp. 932, [Eur. ] Rhes. 36. —Remark that in O. C. 26, where a)lla\ and h)= are separated, the peculiar force of a)ll' h)= is not present.
w(s mhke/t' o)/nta: see on 253.

oi)/moi ta/las, ‘woe is me’ (not, ‘alas, poor Ajax’): as O. T. 744 n.— a)ll' ou)x: the negative is repeated, for greater emphasis, in 418: cp. Ant. 5o(poi=on ou) | tw=n sw=n te ka)mw=n ou)k o)/pwp' e)gw\ kakw=n, n.—o( *tude/ws go/nos, Diomedes. Philoctetes had no personal grievance against him, but dislikes him as being a man of the same stamp as Odysseus, with whom the tenth book of the Iliad associates him in stealing the horses of Rhesus. In Il. 6. 230 it is Diomedes who proposes to Glaucus that the latter should exchange ‘golden armour for armour of bronze.’ Lesches, in the Little Iliad, and Euripides, in his Philoctetes, made Diomedes come to Lemnos to fetch Philoctetes: see Introd. Cp. 592.

ou(mpolhto\s *sisu/fou *laerti/w|, ‘the son of Sisyphus, bought by Laertes,’ —because Anticleia was said to have been pregnant when Laertes married her. The word e)mpolhto/s probably means that Laertes gave a large ‘bride-price’ (e(/dna) to Anticleia's father, Autolycus. So the scholiast, polla\ dou\s xrh/mata h)ga/geto. This is simpler than to suppose that e)mpolhto/s is merely ‘acquired’ (as a bad bargain), like lwbhto\n e)mpo/lhma in Tr. 538.

The legend is not Homeric, but is already known to Aesch. (fr. 169), and is congenial to the spirit in which the dramatists often conceive Odysseus; cp. Soph. Ai. 190, fr. 143 (w(s o( *si/sufos polu\s | e)/ndhlos e)n soi/): I. A. 524, Cycl. 104: Lycophron 344 (th=s *sisufei/as d' a)gku/lhs lampouri/dos, ‘crafty fox’): Ov. Met. 13. 31 sanguine cretus | Sisyphio, furtisque et fraude simillimus illi.

With regard to the order of words, note:—(1) o( e)mpolhto\s *sisu/fou=o( e)mp. *sisufi/dhs, the simple gen. of origin being placed as *sisu/fou pai=s would have been; though usually such a simple gen. comes immediately after the art. (as Ai. 450h( *dio\s gorgw=pis a)da/matos qea/). (2) *laerti/w| merely supplements e)mpolhto/s, and hence can be placed as though it were an afterthought; the principle is the same as in O. C. 1514ai( polla\ brontai\ diatelei=s: cp. n. on O. T. 1245.—The genit. *laerti/ou (see cr. n.) cannot be defended by understanding, (1) ‘the son of Laertes, bought from Sisyphus’; or (2) ‘the bought son of Laertes-Sisyphus,’ i.e., of a father, nominally Laertes, but really Sisyphus.
e)/dei: cp. 1363 xrh=n: O. T. 256 n.
kai\ me/ga qa/llontes, full greatly prosperous: cp. Plat. Rep. 272D tou=to... kai\ ma/l' eu)/kriton.

ti/ d); ou) k.t.l. The fact that the first hand in L wrote w) (sic) is a good reason for believing that either ou) or au)= was the original reading. With au)=, the proper punctuation would be,—ti/ d' au)= palaio\s ka)gaqo\s fi/los t' e)mo/s, | *ne/stwr o( *pu/lios, e)/stin; ‘And then, again, what of Nestor,—is he alive?’ Cp. Ai. 101ei)=en, ti/ ga\r dh\ pai=s o( tou= *laerti/ou, | pou= soi tu/xhs e(/sthken; and ib. 983. But the context strongly favours ou). Philoctetes is wondering how the Atreidae and Odysseus had been allowed to work their will without hindrance. ‘How could Ajax allow it?’ ‘He was dead.’ ‘Well, but is not Nestor alive? He used to restrain them.’ For ti/ d), cp. O. T. 941ti/ d); ou)x o( pre/sbus *po/lubos e)gkrath\s e)/ti;— With respect to the reading ti/ d' o(\s, we observe:—(1) o(\s might easily have been generated by the unmetrical conjecture o( which has been written in L above w): (2) the ellipse of e)sti/ after o(/s would be peculiarly awkward here, where the principal verb is e)/sti.
palaio/s, simply ‘old’: not, (as some take it,) ‘one of the good old school.’ For kai/ … te, cp. 581, 656.

ta/ ge kei/nwn kaka/, their misdeeds, at least: cp. Tr. 773tou= sou= kakou=, thy crime. The ge means that, if Nestor could not ward off all troubles from the army, at any rate he was able to prevent acts of flagrant wrong on the part of such men as Odysseus and Diomedes. Placed thus between ta/ and kei/nwn kaka/, ge must emphasize that phrase only; it cannot here be taken with the whole sentence (‘restrained, at least...’), as in O. C. 1278(n.). Philoctetes alludes either to what he had seen on the voyage to Troy, or to what his occasional visitors had reported.—For the place of the art., cp. Ant. 67to\ ga\r | perissa\ pra/ssein, n.
e)ch/ruke: the compound occurs only here. For e)ru/kein as=arcere, cp. Theocr. 7. 127 ta\ mh\ kala\ no/sfin e)ru/koi.

*)anti/loxos. Pindar is our earliest authority for the story of Antilochus saving his father Nestor's life: he brings it in à propos of a son who had driven his father's chariot in the Pythian games, and won the race (Pyth. 6. 38 ff.). Memnon was pressing Nestor hard, and one of the horses in Nestor's chariot had been wounded by Paris. Nestor called for help to Antilochus, who diverted Memnon's attack from his father to himself, and was killed; thus winning the fame, u(/patos a)mfi\ tokeu=sin e)/mmen pro\s a)reta/n. The Odyssey notices that Antilochus was slain by Memnon, but does not say that he fell in saving his father (4. 188). At the end of the Iliad Antilochus is still living (23. 785 ff.); in Il. 8. 90 it is Diomedes who rescues Nestor (from Hector). Pindar's source was the Aethiopis of Arctînus, in which Achilles avenged Antilochus by slaying Memnon.

o(\s parh=n go/nos, the son who was at his side:—not (I think) with direct reference to the saving of Nestor's life by Antilochus,—this is more than parh=n could suggest, without further explanation (cp. 373),—but rather in the general sense that the son was the stay and comfort of his father's old age.—The MS. reading, o(/sper h)=n go/nos, would clearly imply that Antilochus was Nestor's only (or last surviving) son. The Iliad describes Nestor as having two sons at Troy, Thrasymedes and Antilochus (17. 378); and according to the Odyssey (3. 413 ff.) six sons were left to Nestor after the death of Antilochus, one of these being Thrasymedes. If it be suggested that the Aethiopis may have represented Antilochus as the last surviving son, we may reply that this is extremely improbable, when it is remembered that several Ionian colonies claimed to have been founded by the Neleidae, descendants of Nestor who emigrated from Pylus (Introd. to Homer, p. 167). The same consideration condemns Seyffert's o(/s g' e)/t' h)=n. Cavallin's o(/s pot' h)=n is free from this objection, but is somewhat weak.—See Appendix.

du/) au)= tw/d' a)/ndr' e)/lecas, a correction which I published in 1869 (see cr. n.), still appears to me the most probable. Porson's du/) au)= tw/d' e)ce/deicas is founded on the schol. in L, gr. du/) au)tw\ d' e)ce/deicas, and may be deemed certain so far as the words du/) au)= tw/d) are concerned. But no one has justified the use of e)ce/deicas. We see the proper uses of the word in O. C. 1021i(/n' au)to\s e)kde<*>ch|s e)moi/ (point them out, discover them, to me): El. 348to\ tou/twn mi=sos e)kdei/ceias a)/n (‘manifest’). Eur. Hipp. 1298paido\s e)kdei=cai fre/na | tou= sou= dikai/an. But here the word is strangely inappropriate, ‘thou hast pointed out,’ instead of, ‘thou hast named.’ And e)/lecas, the most natural word, is in all the MSS. Eur. Itseems very rash, then, to assume, on the strength of the schol., that e)/lecas is spurious, and e)ce/deicas genuine, especially when we remember the quality of some of the variants which rest on the same authority; e.g., in v. 423, the schol. on ka/k' e)ch/ruke gives gr. ka)cekh/rucen. L's reading, du/) au)/tws dei/n' e)/lecas, with an erasure of two letters after dei/n), may well have arisen from du/) au)= tw/d' a)/n[dr] e)/lecas. The word *d*e*i*n would easily have been suggested by *d*a*n if the *d*p had from any cause been obscured: or, again, a misreading of *d*a*n as *d*e*i*n may have led to the omission of *d*p. In minuscule writing the process would have been hardly less easy.

As to the reading du/) au(/tws dei/n' e)/lecas, two things seem clear. (1) au(/tws, or, as it is better written, au)/tws, yields no fitting sense here. It could not mean, ‘in those few words.’ It would rather mean, ‘just as in the former cases.’ Cp. O. T. 931 n. (2) du/o...dei/n' e)/lecas, oi(=n, would be most awkward, whether rendered (a) ‘thou hast told dreadful news about two persons’ (du/o masc.), or (b) ‘thou hast told two calamities concerning persons,’ etc. (du/o neut., with tou/toin understood from o<*>n).

du/) … a)/ndre: Ajax (415) and Antilochus. Prof. Campbell says that v. 415 is ‘too remote to allow of this’: but vv. 416— 420 form merely a parenthetic contrast suggested by the death of Ajax, and with v. 421 we come to the father of Antilochus. If du/) a)/ndre are to be Nestor and Antilochus (as Campbell holds), o)lwlo/toin has to mean ‘desolate’ in the case of the living father, and ‘dead’ only in the case of the son. But surely oi(/de in 428 must include both the men mentioned in 426.
a)\n h)qe/lhs), as O. T. 1348: so below, O. T. 1239a)\n...e)boulo/mhn, O. T. 1278h)/qelon...a)/n. Cp. Ai. 88 n.
skopei=n here=prosdoka=n, a rare use. More often skopei=n=‘look for’ in the sense of zhtei=n: Xen. An. 5. 7. 32skopei=te pau=la/n tina.
oi(/de, Ajax and Antilochus; perh. he thinks of Achilles (331) too.

*)odusseu\s d' e)/stin au)= ka)ntau=q): ‘while Odysseus survives in this case also,’ —outliving Ajax and Antilochus (oi(/de, 428), as he had already outlived Achilles (371). Once more, death has spared the worse man (436). According to other views, (1) ka)ntau=qa=‘and’ [not ‘also’] ‘in a case where’; i.e., ‘not only does he live, but he has survived men so much his betters.’ (2) ka)ntau=qa=‘and in such a crisis as this,’—i.e., when, Achilles being dead, the Greeks at Troy could ill spare true men. (3) The schol. explains ka)ntau=q) by e)n toi=s zw=sin: but this ignores kai/, and makes e)ntau=qa weak.—Some think that the phrase used by Philoctetes was intended to have a second meaning (‘here in Lemnos’) for the spectator; but this is improbable.

au)to\n, illum, not ipsum: the latter would be fitting only if Odysseus had been responsible for the deaths of the others. au)da=sqai: cp. El. 1478zw=ntas qanou=sin ou(/nek' a)ntauda=|s i)/sa, speakest of the living as if they were dead.

palaisth\s: cp. Ar. Ran. 877o(/tan ei)s e)/rin o)cumeri/mnois | e)/lqwsi strebloi=si palai/smasin a)ntilogou=ntes (‘when they enter the strife, contending with subtle, tortuous tricks’). Aeschin. or. 3 § 205 pa/laisma tou=t' e)sti\ dikasthri/ou, a trick of the law-courts.

e)mpodi/zontai: the word seems to have been suggested by palaisth/s,—alluding to a wrestler tripping up his adversary: cp. Ar. Eq. 262(with ref. to the tricks by which Cleon outwits his simple victims), dialabw/n, a)gkuri/sas, | ei)=t' a)postre/yas to\n w)=mon au)to\n e)nekolh/basas (‘you put one of your legs between his,—hook it round them,— force his shoulder back,—and fall heavily on him’).
qew=n, a monosyll.: O. C. 964 n.
pou= ga\r: for ga/r, cp. 249 f.
soi, ethic dat., implying, ‘how was it that you did not find him ready to help you at that crisis?’ Cp. O. C. 81h)= be/bhken h(mi\n o( ce/nos;
ta\ fi/ltata, of one person, as Eur. Ion 521ta\ fi/ltaq' eu(rw/n (i.e. to\n uio/n): but of several persons, Soph. O. C. 1110 etc.
lo/gw| … e)n braxei=: cp. El. 673te/qnhk' *)ore/sths: e)n braxei= sunqei\s le/gw. Aesch. P. V. 505braxei= de\ mu/qw| pa/nta sullh/bdhn ma/qe.
tou=t), instead of to/d), referring to what follows: cp. n. on O.C. 787.
po/lemos k.t.l.: the gnw/mh stands as an independent sentence, unconnected with the prefatory tou=t' e)kdida/cw: cp. Ant. 612e)parke/sei no/mos o(/d): ou)de\n e(/rpei k.t.l.

e(kw
, ‘by choice’: i.e., war has a marked preference for killing good men, though, of course, it kills some bad men too. The word e(kw/n does not involve a definite personification of po/lemos (like that in Ar. Pax): we can say, h( fu/sis bou/letai poiei=n ti ( An. Gen. 4), without writing *fu/sis. Cp. fr. 652 tou\s eu)genei=s ga ka)gaqou/s, w)= pai=, filei= | *)/arhs e)nai/rein: oi( de\ th=| glw/ssh| qrasei=s | feu/gontes a)/tas e)kto/s ei)si tw=n kakw=n: | *)/arhs ga ou)de
 tw=n kakw=n lwti/zetai. Anacreon fr. 101 *)/arhs d' ou)k a)gaqw=n fei/detai, a)lla\ kakw=n. The same thought is implied in the phrase of Andoc. , or. 3 § 30 pollou\s me
 *)aqhnai/wn a)pole/santes a)risti/ndhn, —as if the a)/ristoi had been selected.

kat' au)to\ tou=to/ ge, in accordance with this very thing, = ‘on this very ground’: cp. Isocr. or. 18 § 34 ou)k a)/cion ou)/te kata\ xa/rin ou)/te kat' e)piei/keian ou)/te kat' a)/llo ou)de\n h)\ kata\ tou\s o(/rkous peri\ au)tw=n yhfi/sasqai.

fwto\s, about him (gen. of connection): cp. 441: n. on O. C. 307.—ti/ … kurei=. kure/w, in ref. to a person's fortunes, can be either (1) intrans., with adv., as El. 1424*h*l. *)ore/sta, pw=s kurei=te; *o*r. ta)n do/moisi me\n | kalw=s: or (2) trans., with acc., as Aesch. Ch. 214e)pei\ ti/ nu=n e(/kati daimo/nwn kurw=; (‘what do I obtain?’). Here kurei= seems to be intrans., while ti/ is virtually adverbial: cp. Soph. O. C. 1704e)/pracen oi(=on h)/qelen (=o(/pws h)/qelen), ‘he has fared as he would.’

poi/ou de\ tou/tou: cp. 572: O. C. 67*c*e. e)k tou= kat' a)stu basile/ws ta/d' a)/rxetai. *o*i. ou(=tos de\ ti/s lo/gw| te kai\ sqe/nei kratei=; (=ti/s e)/stin ou(=tos o(\s kratei=;) —where, as here, de/ continues a conversation by putting a question which the last speaker's words suggest.

e)rei=s, i.e., of whom do you mean to speak. Cp. O. C. 595*o*i. pe/ponqa, *qhseu=, deina\ pro\s kakoi=s kaka/. *q*h. h)= th
 palaia
 cumfora
 ge/nous e)rei=s;

Brunck's conjecture, tou=to for tou/tou, has been preferred by some; because, where a verb of speaking or asking thus takes a simple gen., the object of the verb is usu. represented, either (a) by an acc., as in El. 317tou= kasignh/tou ti/ fh/s; or (b) by a relative clause, as above in 440 by ti/ nu=n kurei=; But in O. C. 307klu/wn sou= (‘hearing about thee’) is an exception to the supposed rule. Further, e)rei=s is here merely a short expression for e)cerh/sei ti/ nu=n kurei=.

*qersi/ths=‘the bold one,’ qe/rsos being the Aeolic form of qa/rsos (Bekker Anecd. p. 1190. 2), as kre/tos of kra/tos: cp. *(aliqe/rshs, *qe/rsandros. Here he survives Achilles. But, according to the commoner legend, he died before him. Achilles had slain the leader of the Amazons, Penthesilea. Thersites thrust his spear into the eyes of the corpse, and taunted Achilles with his love for her; when the hero killed him. This was the version given by Arctînus in the Aethiopis (Proclus, Chrestom. p. 478). It was the subject of a play (prob. a satyric drama) by Chaeremon, called *)axilleu\s *qersitokto/nos (Suidas, s.v. u(pa/rxwn, calls it simply *qersi/ths). See Nauck, Frag. Trag. p. 607.

o(\s ou)k a)
 ei(/let) k.t.l. This sentence deserves study as an example of Attic expression. (1) ou)k a)
 ei(/leto= ‘never used to choose.’ Xen. Cyr. 7. 1. 10o(po/te prosble/yeie/ tinas...ei)=pen a)/n. In this use the aor. differs from the impf. by marking a moment; as ei(/leto expresses the making of the choice, while h(rei=to would express the sentiment of preference. (2) o(/pou mhdei\s e)w/|h, ‘in a case where no one was for allowing him to speak’: the optat. denotes indefinite frequency (as 289 o(/ moi ba/loi). Cp. prosble/yeie in the example just cited. mhdei/s is ‘generic,’ i.e. marks the occasion as being one of a class: cp. 170 n. And since ou)k e)w== ‘dissuade,’ ‘remonstrate,’ o(/pou mhdei\s e)w/|h =o(/pou pa/ntes mh\-e)w=|en, ‘where all were protesting.’ Cp. Ai. 1184ta/fou melhqei\s tw=|de, ka)
 mhdei\s e)a=|,=ka)
 pa/ntes mh\-e)w=|sin, ‘though all the world forbid.’ (3) ‘He would never choose to speak (only) once’ = ‘he would always choose to speak often’; —a mei/wsis of the same order as ou)x h(/kista for ma/lista. Thus the whole sense is—a)ei\ a)
 ei(/leto polla/kis le/gein, o(/pou pa/ntes siga=n keleu/oien. Remark that, in the negative form actually used, the aor. inf. (ei)pei=n) suits ei)sa/pac better than a pres. inf. (le/gein) would have done.

Sophocles here reproduces the two salient traits of the Homeric Thersites: (1) he is irrepressible: Il. 2. 212*qersi/ths d' e)/ti mou=nos a)metroeph\s e)kolw/|a, | o(/s r() e)/pea fresi\n h(=|sin a)/kosma/ te polla/ te h)/|dh: (2) he disgusts those whom his bluster was intended to amuse or flatter; ib. 222 tw=| d' a)/r' *)axaioi\ | e)kpa/glws kote/onto.— tou=ton oi)=sq): for the construction, cp. 534, 544, 549, 573: O. C. 1197 f., Ant. 1242 f.
au)to/n should not be changed to au)to/s, which would be too emphatic here. He speaks in a careless tone. The following nin, though it was not necessary, affords no argument against au)to/n.
e)/mell), sc. e<*>nai: cp. Ant. 448 n.
e)pei\ ou)de/n: the synizesis as in 948, 1037; fr. 479. 3 e)pei\ ou)d' o( krei/sswn.—Cp. frag. adesp. 276 (Nauck) ou)de\n kako\n <ga\r> r(a|di/ws a)po/llutai.
periste/llousin, cherish, protect (as Her. 9. 60 etc.), a sense derived from that of ‘dressing’ or ‘wrapping up’ (cp. Soph. Ant. 903).
ta\ panou=rga: for the neut., instead of tou\s kakou/rgous, see on O. T. 1196.

palintribh=, lit. ‘rubbed again and again,’ hence, thoroughly versed in knavery (cp. no/moisin e)ntribh/s, Ant. 177). So Nub. 260 le/gein genh/sei tri/mma, kro/talon, paipa/lh: ib. 447 eu(rhsieph/s, peri/trimma dikw=n.
a)nastre/fontes: alluding esp. to the story of Sisyphus cheating Pluto: cp. 621 n.

ta\ de\: cp. 442 n.— ta\ xrh/st): cp. El. 972filei= ga\r pro\s ta\ xrhsta\ pa=s o(ra=n (=ta\s xrhsta/s).— a)poste/llous): cp. O.C. 1664 e)cepe/mpet) (of Oed.): Plat. Symp. 179E (qeoi\ *)axille/a) ei)s maka/rwn nh/sous a)pe/pemyan. Eur. Ion 1274a)/rdhn a)\n e)ce/pemyas ei)s *(/aidou do/mous (me). The word is so natural after a)nastre/fontes that Nauck's alteration of it to prouselou=s) is strange indeed.

pou= xrh\ ti/qesqai: where am I to place these things (in a theory of divine government), i.e., what am I to think of them? For this use of the midd. ti/qemai, cp. 473, 876: Dem. or. 18 § 299 (tau=ta) po/rrw me/ntoi pou tw=n e)moi\ pepoliteume/nwn ti/qemai (‘rank them far below...’).
pou= d' ai)nei=n: and in what respect to praise them: cp. O. T. 390pou= su\ ma/ntis ei)= safh/s; and ib. 355 n.

o(/tan k.t.l. The simplest form of question would have been:—‘What is one to think of these things, seeing that they conflict with one's belief in beneficent gods?’ This is amplified into—‘What is one to think of these things, seeing that, while one praises the dealings of the gods, one finds (by these facts) that the gods are bad?’ e)painw=n is best taken in a simple temporal sense, (=‘at the same time that one praises,’) rather than as tentative (‘while one tries to praise’), or concessive (‘though one praises’).
Theognis, in a similar strain, asks how a mortal is to revere the gods when he sees good men afflicted and bad men prosperous (743—752).
e)gw\ me\n: Ant. 11 n.
*oi)tai/ou, since Poeas was king of the Malians; cp. 4 n.

thlo/qen … ei)sorw=n, ‘eyeing them from a distance, i.e. holding aloof from them. The phrase is figurative; it is not an oxymoron, like e)n sko/tw| o(ra=n ( O. T. 1273), as though it meant ‘never seeing them.’ This thlo/qen ei)sora=n is a poetical counterpart of po/rrwqen a)spa/zesqai,— familiar in Attic as meaning ‘to give a wide berth’ to an objectionable person or thing: Plat. Rep. 499A oi(/wn zhtei=n me
 to\ a)lhqe\s...ta\ de\ komya/ te kai\ e)ristika\ ...po/rrwqen a)spazome(nwn. Eur. Hipp. 102pro/swqen au)th
 (Aphrodite) a(gno\s w)
 a)spa/zomai. Antiphilus (c. 60 A.D. ) in Anthol. 9. 29 (speaking of the golden age), eu)=t' a)po\ xe/rsou | thlo/qen, w(s *(/aidhs, po/ntos a)peble/peto. Cp. the phrases, tinged with a similar irony, in O. T. 795, O. T. 997.
fula/comai, midd. sc. au)tou/s: cp. fr. 428 dissa\ ga\r fula/ssetai, | fi/lwn te me/myin kei)s qeou\s a(marta/nein.
o(/pou=par' o(/tois, followed by tou/tous: cp. Ai. 1081o(/pou d' u(bri/zein dra=n q' a(\ bou/letai parh=, | tau/thn no/mize th\n po/lin k.t.l.

deilo\s is rightly restored by Brunck for deino\s of the MSS. It alludes to Odysseus as a trickster (407) and a coward (1025). Cp. Ant. 326ta\ deila\ ke/rdh, where, again, L has the false reading deina\. deino/s, by itself, would mean simply ‘able.’ As Arist. says, deino/ths is the faculty of finding means to an end; a)
 ou)=n o(<*>skopo\s h)=| kalo/s, e)paineth/ e)stin: a)
 de\ fau=los, panourgi/a (Eth. N. 6. 13). So, in v. 440, the bad sense of deinou= is hinted by glw/ssh. Campbell quotes Isocr. or. 12 § 48 to show that deino/s could, by itself, mean ‘a clever rogue’: there, however, deinh/n (said of Sparta) means ‘formidable’ (=fobera/n just before), and the sense of deinh
...nomi/zein is presently repeated in fobei=sqai...kai\ dedie/nai.
*sku=ros: see on 240.
e)carkou=sa/ moi … w(/ste (me) te/rpesqai do/mw|, sufficient to make me content with my abode (and resigned to seeing no more of the army).
xai=re is repeated, as Ar. Pax 582xai=re xai=r), ib. 1363 xai/rete xai/ret), etc. w(s me/gista: cp. me/ga xai=re (Hom. hym. 1. 466 etc.).
metasth/seian: Helen. 1442 ble/yon pro\s h(ma=s kai\ meta/sthson kakw=n.
w(s au)to\s qe/leis: Hom. hym. 2. 417 r(ei=a ma/l' e)prh+/unen e(khbo/lon, w(s e)/qel:, au)to/s.

plou=n h(mi\n ei)/kh|: a very rare instance of ei)/kw tini/ ti as=concedo aliquid alicui. We cannot compare O. C. 172ei)/kontas a(\ dei=, or Ai. 1243, ei)/kein a(\ toi=s polloi=sin h)/resken kritai=s, where the acc. merely denotes the things in regard to which one is to yield. Still, Il. 23. 337ei)=cai/ te/ oi( h(ni/a (‘to give the horse rein’) seems to confirm ei)/kh| here. The analogy of parei/kw suggests to me that the constr. here would be somewhat softened if, instead of plou=n, we might read plei=n: cp. Legg. 934 C o(/pws a)\n h(mi=n parei/kwsi qeoi\ ... nomoqetei=n. But the change, though tempting, is not necessary.

kairo\s, the need of the moment; for the semi-personification, cp. 1450; El. 75kairo\s ga/r, o(/sper a)ndra/sin | me/gistos e)/rgou panto/s e)st' e)pista/ths: ib. 39 o(/tan se kairo\s ei)sa/gh|. kalei=, as Eur. Hec. 1042bou/lesq' e)peispe/swmen; w(s a)kmh\ kalei= | *(eka/bh| parei=nai. Lucian (Demonactis vita 65) quotes, as a familiar stage ‘tag,’ kairo\s de\ kalei= mhke/ti me/llein.

plou=n … skopei=n, to watch for (428 n.) favourable weather: cp. Antiphon or. 5 § 24 (the speaker had been detained in port by adverse winds) plou=s h(mi=n e)gi/gneto, kai\ a)nh/geto ploi=a a(/panta. Thuc. 1. 137me/xri plou=s ge/nhtai.

mh\ )c a)po/ptou, not at a distance (from the ship); strictly, so that the quarter in which their ship lies shall not be a)/poptos, i.e., ‘seen (only) at a distance.’ Cp. Galen 3. 222 e)c a)po/ptou qeasa/menos, and append. on O. T. 762(p. 230, 2nd ed.). At the cave they are close to the sea, and can judge of the weather as well as at another point on the coast. But he means that they must be close to their ship, in order to sail as soon as ever the wind changes. At present it is adverse (640) for a voyage to Scyros: i.e., it is south or south-west (cp. 355).—Others take e)c a)po/ptou skopei=n as=‘to watch from a place where one cannot (properly) see,’ a sort of oxymoron, like e)n sko/tw| o(ra=n.
pro/s nu/n se patro\s...pro/s t' ei)/ ti k.t.l.: cp. n. on O.C. 250 pro/s s' o(/ ti soi fi/lon e)k se/qen a)/ntomai.

i(ke/ths strengthens i(knou=mai much as in O. T. 760, e)cike/teuse th=s e)mh=s xeiro\s qigw/n, the verb is strengthened by the added phrase, which serves to mark the attitude of formal supplication. Cp. below, O. T. 930.For i(knei=sqai=i(keteu/ein, cp. 932, O. C. 275 and 1011: Ai. 588: El. 136.
oi(/ois o(ra=|s … e)nnai/onta,—the disease, and the wretched dwelling: o(/soisi/ t' e)ch/kousas,—the painful provision of food, water, fuel and fire (285 —299). Cp. 174 f.

e)n pare/rgw| qou= me, lit., regard me (451 n.) as a secondary task: i.e., ‘give me a place, however lowly, in thy care.’ The thought is: ‘I should not have asked you to alter your course for me; but since you are going home at any rate, let this good deed be an accident of your voyage.’ Cp. Soph. El. 509h)=lqon ga\r au)tou= pro\s ta/fon, pa/rerg' o(dou= (as an incident of the journey). Thuc. 1. 142(with ref. to naval skill) ou)k e)nde/xetai... e)k pare/rgou meleta=sqai.
e)n pare/rgw|=e)n pare/rgou me/rei ( Plat. Rep. 370C).
dusxe/reia: cp. 900.
e)/coida, by the bitter experience to which he alludes in 1031 f.
forh/matos, freight, as fore/w is said of ships ( Od. 2. 390).

to/ t' ai)sxro\n k.t.l. The objections which have been made to this verse seem idle. Philoctetes is appealing to the generous instincts of the young man. ‘To noble natures, what is (morally) shameful is hateful, and what is worthy appears glorious.’ eu)klee/s implies, ‘even if there is no applause to be gained, the gennai=os is rewarded by the sense that he has merited true eu)/kleia,—i.e., that his deed is, in itself, honourable.’ Then, in vv. 477—479, Philoctetes passes to a different and a lower argument,—viz., that Neoptolemus will incur reproach if he refuse to do this act of mercy, and that, in the other case, he will have men's praises. All the difficulties which have been raised have come from failing to see (1) that the subjective sense of eu)klee/s is justified by the fact that toi=si gennai/oisi is an ethic dat.,—‘in the sight of the generous,’—not a dat. of interest: and (2) that the considerations urged in 475 —479 are of two distinct orders.

e)klipo/nti tou=t) = e)a
 e)kli/ph|s tou=to, if thou forsake, abandon, this deed (which is a duty laid on thee): cp. I. T. 750 ei) d), e)klipw
 to
 o(/rkon, a)dikoi/hs e)me/.

o)/neidos is strengthened by ou) kalo/n, as in 842 by ai)sxro/n, in O. C. 753 by a)/qlion, in O. T. 1035 by deino/n. Ellendt, indeed, is with those who trace here an original ‘middle’ sense of o)/neidos as=‘a thing said of one’ (good or evil). It would be equally reasonable to infer a neutral meaning for kh/r from Tr. 454kh\r pro/sestin ou) kalh/.
plei=ston=me/giston: cp. Ant. 1051: Od. 4. 697ai)\ ga\r dh/, basi/leia, to/de plei=ston kako\n ei)/h: | a)lla\ polu\ mei=zon k.t.l.
mo/lw )gw\: cp. El. 472ei) mh\ )gw/.
i)/q), in entreaty; cp. 750, O. T. 1468 n.
h(me/ras … mia=s. The distance from Lemnos to Scyros is about 75 miles; and, acc. to v. 354, the voyage from Scyros to Sigeum (about 125 miles) took less than two whole days.
to/lmhson: cp. 82 n.

o(/ph|, L's reading, is here not less good than o(/poi: it goes with e)mbalou= only. a)/gwn is added as in 488, O.C. 910, 1342: here it expresses how passive he is content to be in the hands of Neoptolemus.

a)ntli/an, the hold of the ship, where he could be stowed away beneath the rowers. Cp. Athen. p. 37 D kata- balw\n e)mauto\n u(po\ tou\s qala/mous (the places of the qalami=tai, or lowest rank of rowers) w(s e)/ni ma/lista katwta/tw e)kei/mhn. Dionysius comicus (350 B.C.) *qesmofo/ros fr. 1. 40 describes a seaman as e)c a)ntli/as h(/konta, i.e., the man was one of the qalami=tai. Cp. Her. 8. 118: Xerxes is making a long voyage in stormy weather; but he and the numerous Persian nobles with him are all on the deck (e)pi\ tou= katastrw/matos), while only the Phoenician sailors occupy the part below (koi/lhn ne/a). So, too, in [Dem. ] or. 32 § 5, during a voyage of many days, all the passengers live on deck, the koi/lh nau=s being used by the rowers only.

prw=|ran … pru/mnhn. Lucian (Navig. 5), speaking of a large vessel, mentions ai( kata\ pru/mnan oi)kh/seis, but ordinarily only the kubernh/ths would be located at the stern, as the prw|reu/s at the prow. pru/mna was the later Attic form: but pru/mnh is used by Attic poets for metre's sake, as Vesp. 399 h)/n pws pru/mnhn a)nakrou/shtai. Cp. 1451.
o(/pou (or o(/ph|) is necessary: o(/poi could not stand either for o(/poi beblhme/nos, or for e)kei=se o(/pou. The corruption of u to i is one of the commonest.
me/llw … a)lgunei=n, instead of a)lgunw= (the relative clause, with the fut. indic., expressing purpose): cp. 409. For the fut. inf. after me/llw, cp. O. T. 967 n.
i(kesi/ou: cp. 1181: Suppl. 616 *zhno\s i(kesi/ou ko/ton | me/gan profwnw=n: Od. 13. 213*zeu\s sfei/as ti/saiq' i(keth/sios (see Introd. to Homer, p. 54).
go/nasi: cp. Eur. Phoen. 293gonupetei=s e(/dras prospi/tnw s): and n. on Soph. O. T. 2.

a)kra/twr. As O. C. 1236 is the only extant Attic example of a)krath/s as =‘weak,’ so is this the only example of a)kra/twr in that sense. Plato uses a)kra/twr in the regular Attic sense of a)krath/s as =impotens sui ( Rep. 579C e(autou=...a)kra/twr). The scholium here (if it be not rather a fusion of two distinct scholia) recognises both meanings: a)sqenh\s, e(autou= kratei=n mh\ duna/menos.

h)\ pro\s oi)=kon to\n so\n k.t.l. He asks N. to convey him, either merely to the youth's own home (Scyros), or, better still, a little further, viz., to Euboea (cp. n. on 240); whence it will be easy to reach Malis (492).

ta\ *xalkw/dontos *eu)boi/as staqma/, the Euboean abode of Chalcodon, i.e. Euboea, his realm. Cp. Tr. 1191to\n *oi)/ths *zhno\s u(/yiston pa/gon. In Il. 2. 536 ff. Elephenor, son of Chalcodon, figures as the leader of all the Euboeans in the Greek army, who are called *)/abantes, and represent six towns, including Carystus at the extreme south of the island, Chalcis at the middle point of its west coast, and Histiaea in the extreme north.

Schneidewin remarks that Philoctetes, the former comrade of Heracles, might naturally name Chalcodon, who had been the companion of Heracles in an expedition against the Eleans ( Paus. 8. 15. 6). But that was merely a local Arcadian myth; and Pausanias finds it inconsistent with the better-known Theban tradition, according to which Chalcodon was slain by Amphitryon in a war between the Euboeans and Thebans (9. 19. 3). At any rate the Attic poet might think of the Attic legend, according to which Theseus had sent his sons for protection to Chalcodon's son Elephenor, before retiring from Athens to Scyros ( Plut. Thes. 35).

ei)s *oi)/thn. The three names here—Oeta—Trachis—the Spercheius— mark the great features of the region. Typhrestus, at the southern end of Pindus, throws off two ranges towards the eastern sea. One runs nearly due east, and skirts the s. borders of Thessaly: this is Othrys, the lofty ‘brow’ which looks down from the north on the plain of Malis. The other—Oeta, the ‘sheep-land’ —runs s. of Othrys, and parallel with it at first; then, turning S. and E. , it throws out cliffs which enclose the plain of Malis on S. and W. Trachis—‘the rugged’— stood below those cliffs; they themselves were called ‘the Trachinian Rocks.’ ( Her. 7. 198o)/rea u(yhla\ kai\ a)/bata periklh/|ei pa=san th\n *mhli/da gh=n, *trhxi/niai pe/trai kaleo/menai.) The Spercheius— ‘the vehement’—rises at the base of Typhrestus. As it runs eastward, its broad valley separates the ranges of Othrys and Oeta. It passes through the plain of Malis, and enters the Malian Gulf. Its old mouth was about five miles N. of Trachis: the present mouths are more to the south.

*traxini/an … deira/da, the chain of heights which bounds the plain of Malis on S. and W.,—the *trhxi/niai pe/trai of Herod. (see last n.), the ou)/rea *mhli/dos ai)/hs of Callimachus (Hymn. Del. 287). Acc. to Thuc. 3. 92 the dwellers in Malis were classed as *traxi/nioi (highlanders, like the Attic *(upera/krioi), *para/lioi (by the Malian Gulf), and *(ierh=s (a doubtful name).

All MSS. have deira/da kai\ to\n, making an anapaest in the 4th place. Toup proposed dera/da. As de/rh was the Attic form of deirh/, an Attic poet might possibly have ventured on dera/s. But there is no trace of such a form, while deira/s is frequent. Further, *deira/des was the name of an Attic deme of the Leontis tribe (Bekker Anecd. p. 240, 26), and deira/s would thus be familiar to Attic ears in ordinary life. Thus Toup's remedy, though attractive by its simplicity, is really a very bold one.

I am more disposed to think that deira/da is sound, and that the corruption lies in the words kai\ to\n. I conjecture, *traxini/an te deira/d) h)d) e)s eu)/roon. Soph. , like Aesch. and Eur. , admitted h)de/ in iambics (see n. on Soph. Ant. 673). The corruption might arise from the fact that *d was the second letter of two successive syllables. A scribe, copying *d*e*i*r*a*d*e*d (or, after 403 B.C., *d*e*i*r*a*d*h*d), might accidentally omit *e*d (or *h*d). The verse would then stand, *t*r*a*x*i*n*i*a*n*t*e*d*e*i*p*a*d*e*s*e*u*r*o*o*n. A subsequent transcriber might easily suppose that *d*e*i*r*a*d*e*s (taken for deira/des, not deira/d' e)s) was a mere blunder for deira/da. And, *d*e*i*p*a*d*a having been replaced, the copula would next be supplied, and the verse patched up, by inserting *k*a*i*t*o*n.—For other conjectures, see Appendix.

eu)/roon. Tragic iambics sometimes admit uncontracted forms in -oos: e.g. Aesch. fr. 37 diplo/oi: id. fr. 275 xeima/rroon: id. Aesch. Theb. 493purpno/on: on the other hand, id. fr. 293 e(pta/rous: Aesch. P. V. 852platu/rrous: ib. 917 pu/rpnoun.

Like the Homeric e)u+/rroos, e)u:rrei/ths, the epithet refers simply to the beauty of the river, not to that swiftness (spe/rxomai) from which it takes its name ( Il. 16. 176*sperxeiw=| a)ka/manti: Lucan 6. 366 Ferit amne citato | Maliacas Spercheus aquas). Rising at the foot of Typhrestus, and fed by affluents from Othrys and Oeta, the Spercheius has a considerable volume of water even in the hot season (Tozer, Geo. of Greece, p. 81).
o(\n (=peri\ ou(=)...de/doik): cp. Tr. 297tarbei=n to\n eu)= pra/ssonta, mh\ sfalh=| pote.

palaio
=palaio/n (e)stin) e)c o(/tou, a parenthetic clause equiv. to a simple adverb (pa/lai) going with de/doika. Cp. Isocr. or. 5 § 47 ou)=toi ga a)/rxontes tw=n *(ellh/nwn ou) polu\s xro/nos (sc. e)sti
) e)c ou)= kai\ kata\ gh=n kai\ kata\ qa/lattan ei)s tosau/thn metabolh
 h)=lqon. Ai. 600e)gw\ d' o( tla/mwn palaio\s a)f' ou(= xro/nos | ...eu)nw=mai.—In L palaia
 is manifestly a mere blunder for palaio
. Those who read palai/) a)
 explain it in one of two ways. (1) ei)/h is to be supplied with it, —bebh/kh|, or be/bhke, being read in 494. Such an ellipse of ei)/h is impossible. (2) The a)
 is to go with bebh/koi in 494. Cp. Tr. 630de/doika ga | mh\ prw\| le/gois a)/n: Thuc. 2. 93prosdoki/a ou)demi/a (h)=n) mh\ a)/n pote oi( pole/mioi...e)pipleu/seian. But in this constr. the a)/n which belongs to the optative verb could not precede the mh/. In Eur. Med. 941ou)k oi)=d' a)
 ei) pei/saimi, the place of a)/n has a special excuse, viz., the analogy of sentences with the inf. (such as ou)k a)
 oi)=mai pei=sai).

mh/ moi bebh/kh|. moi is ethic dat. ( Ant. 50 n.) The subjunct. is right here: cp. 30 kurh=|, n. The indic. be/bhke would also be correct ( Dem. or. 19 § 96 de/doika mh\ lelh/qamen), but would express conviction rather than anxious fear.—For be/bhka as=oi)/xomai, of death, cp. Eur. Andr. 1026be/bake d' *)atrei/das a)lo/xou pala/mais.
toi=s i(gme/nois, instr. dat.: for e)/stellon, cp. 60 n.—The partic. i(gme/nos occurs only here. In Tr. 229 we have i(/gmeqa.

au)to/stolon pe/myanta, having sent with his own sto/los, i.e., having sent a ship of his own. Cp. Anthol. 7. 585 (on a fisherman who died by the burning of his boat at sea), au)to/stolos h)=lqen | ei)s *)ai+/dhn, neku/wn porqmi/dos ou) xate/wn, ‘he went to Hades in his own ship’ [because it perished along with him],—not needing to use Charon 's bark. Musaeus Leandr. 255 au)to\s e)w\n e)re/ths, au)to/stolos, au)to/matos nhu=s, where, similarly, au)to/stolos =‘providing his own sto/los,’ i.e. ‘selfwafted,’—answering to the word vector in Ovid's parallel v., Idem navigium, navita, vector ero (Ep. 18. 147).—If au)to/stolon were understood as=‘setting forth in person’ (cp. mono/stolos, o(mo/stolos), then pe/myanta would be best taken as ‘having escorted me’ (cp. 913, 1465), and would go closely with e)ksw=sai. Nauck, interpreting au)to/stolon in this second way, substitutes pleu/santa (the conj. of Blaydes) for pe/myanta. This would certainly make the v. easier; but it is not necessary.

do/mous is a clearly true correction of do/mois. The latter could not mean, ‘to my home,’ but only, ‘for the joy of the house’ (dat. of interest). On the other hand cp. Ant. 810a)lla/ m' *(/aidas...a)/gei | ta\n *)axe/rontos a)kta/n: O. C. 1769*qh/bas d' h(ma=s | ...pe/myon.

497 ff. After ta\ tw=n diako/nwn we might have expected h)melei=to or the like (‘the messengers' part was neglected’), but poiou/menoi follows, as if he had written oi( dia/konoi. This is one of the irregularities which often arise from a change in the form of the writer's thought; it is not merely a case of constr. kata\ su/nesin (like ta\...meira/kia...dialego/menoi, Plat. Lach.p. 180 E). Hence it is no objection to this view that ta\ tw=n diako/nwn, for oi( dia/konoi, would be unexampled. —Others take ta\ tw=n diako/nwn as an adverbial parenthesis: ‘or (as is the way with messengers) they forgot me,’ etc. The objection to this is that, in such phrases, the sing. to\ is used, never the plur. ta\: e.g. Phaed. 77D dokei=s su/ te kai\ *simmi/as...dedie/nai, to\ tw=n pai/dwn, mh\...o( a)/nemos au)th\n...diafusa=|: id. Soph. 261B sxolh=| pou, to\ kata\ th\n paroimi/an lego/menon, o(/ ge toiou=tos a)/n pote e(/loi po/lin.

w(s ei)ko/s expresses that such neglect might have been expected, while oi)=mai conveys the belief that it was actually committed; tautology cannot be pleaded, then, as a ground for conjecturing oi)/moi.
e)n smikrw=|: cp. 875: Her. 3. 154e)n e)lafrw=| poihsa/menos (Tac. Ann. 3. 54 in levi habendum).

me/ros. The reading me/rei would be tenable: cp. Dem. or. 2 § 18 e)n ou)deno\s ei)=nai me/rei. And it is true that tou)mo\n me/ros is usu. adverbial (quantum in me est, or quantum ad me attinet: cp. Soph. Ant. 1062 n.). But here me/ros gives a much finer verse.
h)/peigon, trans. (cp. 1451). When the act. e)pei/gw seems intrans., it is so because the acc., like sto/lon here (e.g., dro/mon, o(do/n) is understood: El. 1435h(=| noei=s, e)/peige nu=n.

pompo/n te kau)to
 a)/ggelon, at once escort and, in thine own person, messenger: i.e., Neopt., when he brings Ph. home on board his ship, will at the same time bring the earliest tidings of Ph. 's fate. Ph. had asked his former visitors to act merely as a)/ggeloi: and they had failed to do so. Now he has found a man who will be his pompo/s, and, thereby, also his first a)/ggelos. Cp. Her. 1. 79(Cyrus) e)la/sas...to
 strato
 e)s th
 *ludi/hn au)to\s a)/ggelos *kroi/sw| e)lhlu/qee, ‘had himself brought the first news,’ i.e., no a)ggeli/a had preceded him. See n. on Soph. O. C. 1511(au)toi\ qeoi\ kh/rukes).

h(/kw: after vainly appealing to others. The word is tinged with the fig. sense, ‘I have been brought by my fortune to thee,’ etc.: cp. 377 o( d' e)nqa/d' h(/kwn. [Dem. ] or. 45 § 85 tou/tw| me\n xai/rein le/gw, ou(\s d' o( path/r moi pare/dwke bohqou/s, ei)s tou/tous h(/kw.

deina\ ka)pikindu/nws … kei=tai, are so ordained (by the gods) as to be full of fear and peril: (for the combination of adj. and adv., cp. 345.) The infin. paqei=n follows this phrase as it might follow ki/nduno/s e)stin or the like ( Plat. Crat. 436B ou) smikro\s ki/nduno/s e)stin e)capathqh=nai). The general sense is:—‘There is always a danger for men that, after they have been prosperous, they may be unfortunate.’ Not: ‘It is always doubtful whether men are to fare well or ill,’—like Plat. Prot. 313A e)n w(=| pa/nt' e)sti\ ta\ sa/, h)\ eu)= h)\ kakw=s pra/ttein. Of the two co-ordinated clauses, paqei=n me\n eu)=, paqei=n de\ qa/tera, the second is that on which the emphasis falls; the first serves for contrast with it:—‘that, as they have fared well, so they may fare ill.’ Cp. Soph. Ant. 616polloi=s me\n o)/nasis a)ndrw=n, | polloi=s d' a)pa/ta (‘though to many a blessing, yet to many a false lure’): Soph. O. C. 1536eu)= me/n, o)ye\ de/, ‘though surely, yet late.’
qa/tera: Dem. or. 22 § 12 a)gaqa\ h)\ qa/tera, i(/na mhde\n ei)/pw flauro/n.

e)kto\s o)/nta: 1260: Ant. 619 n.— ta\ dei/n' o(ra=n, to keep one's eye on dangers looming in the distance, as a steersman watches rocks ahead: cp. Il. 23. 323(the wary charioteer) ai)ei\ te/rm' o(ro/wn,— keeping his eye always on the kampth/r, as he drives round it. Thus the schol.'s eu)labei=sqai is true to the sense.
eu)= zh=|, lives prosperously, as kakw=s zh=n=to live unhappily ( El. 354). So Pind. ( Pind. P. 4. 131) calls festivity eu)zw/|as a)/wton. But in Soph. O. C. 1535eu)=...oi)kh=|= ‘lives aright.’

to
 bi/on, the fortunes of one's life: the subject to la/qh| is o( bi/os. Cp. El. 207(xei=res) ai(\ to
 e)mo
 ei(=lon bi/on | pro/doton.
: antistrophe to 391—402. The pity expressed by the Chorus may well be sincere; but in this utterance of it, their first aim is to aid their master's design. Verse 510 shows this.

po/nwn a)=qla, ordeals consisting in po/noi, sufferings. Cp. Tr. 505a)/eql' a)gw/nwn. The plur. a)=qla can thus be used in the sense of a)=qloi: but the sing. a)=qlon does not occur as =a)=qlos. In Suppl. 1034 to/d' a)=qlon=‘this prize.’

oi(=a, Porson's correction of o(/ssa, is probably right. It is the more natural word in such a wish: cp. 275, 315. And o(/ssa may have been suggested by pollw=n. An iambic trimeter set in lyrics might, indeed, tolerate o(/ssos,—as the corresponding trimeter (392) has the Doric a(\ for h(\. But o(/ssa in Aesch. Pers. 864, to/sswn in Aesch. Ag. 140, and to/sson in Soph. Ai. 185, seem to be the only instances of these forms in Tragedy. oi(=a is clearly better than a(/ssa (=a(/tina): for which cp. O.T. 425 n.—For the acc. oi(=a with tu/xoi, cp. O. T. 1298 n. The conject. la/xoi is unnecessary.
pikrou/s, odious; cp. 254 n. This sense seems more suitable here than ‘bitter against thee,’ when pikrou\s...e)/xqeis would be like misou=nt' e)mi/sei ( Ai. 1134).
e)gw\ me\n (cp. 453)...poreu/saim' a)\n is a respectful suggestion,—‘I, for my part, would convey him,’—i.e., ‘If I were you, I would do so.’
to\ kei/nwn kako\n, the evil done by them: cp. 422.

metatiqe/menos. This compound re<*>ly takes one acc. only, meaning to ‘transpose,’ ‘shift,’ a thing: and hence, either to ‘adopt’ or to ‘discard.’ Here the compound is used like the simple verb, and the force of the prep. is adverbial. tiqe/menos to\ kei/nwn kako\n tw=|de ke/rdos= ‘counting their misdeeds as his gain’: cp. Od. 21. 333ti/ d' e)le/gxea tau=ta ti/qesqe; If, after the word ‘counting,’ we inserted, ‘by transference,’ this would give the force of meta/. The kako/n is to be shifted from the reckoning against the Atreidae to the reckoning in favour of Philoctetes. Their demerit is another reason for benefiting him.
e)pime/monen: the only instance of me/mona in Soph. (Cp. Aesch. Theb. 686me/monas: Eur. I.A. 1495 and I. T. 655 me/mone.)

eu)sto/lou, here prob., ‘well-equipped’; though at v. 780 eu)stalh/s (the commoner form) = ‘expeditious.’ Cp. Apoll. Rh. 1. 603o)/sson e)s e)/ndio/n ken e)u+/stolos o(lka\s a)nu/ssai.—For the double epithet, without copula, cp. Hom. Od. 7. 34nhusi\ qoh=|si pepoiqo/tes w)kei/h|si: Soph. Ai. 710qoa=n w)kua/lwn new=n.

ta
 qew=n ne/mesin. Hermann's deletion of e)k after ta
 is necessary, since ta
 qew=n=*larti/ou in 401. Possibly the e)k arose from a reminiscence of Her. 1. 34e)/labe e)k qeou= ne/mesis mega/lh *kroi=son.— Cp. 601 f., 1035 ff.
nu=n me\n … o(/tan de\: i.e., ‘beware lest, though now thou art facile, yet,’ etc.: cp. n. on 503.

eu)xerh\s, easy-going (cp. 875): tis gives a slightly contemptuous tone; cp. Aesch. P. V. 696prw/| ge stena/zeis kai\ fo/bou ple/a tis ei)=s. For its position, cp. Soph. Ai. 29kai/ moi/ tis o)pth/r.— parh=|s, as a spectator who is not yet required to make any personal sacrifice. Not from pari/hmi, as = ‘comply.’

th=s no/sou with plhsqh=|s: cunousi/a|, causal dat.: sated with (wearied of) the disease, through consorting with it. It is also possible to join the verb with cunousi/a|, and to make the gen. depend on the latter: when the omission of th=| would be an instance like tw=n e)xqrw=n kaka/ ( Ant. 10 n.). The objection is that, though plhsqh=nai can take a dat. when it means simply ‘to be filled’ ( Thuc. 7. 75da/krusi pa=n to\ stra/teuma plhsqe/n), it usu. takes a gen. when it means ‘to be sated.’

au(to\s toi=s lo/gois tou/tois, the same with (=consistent, in your action, with) these words. Plat. Euthyd. 298A h)\ su\ ei)= o( au)to\s tw=| li/qw|; If tou/tois were absent, then toi=s lo/gois could be a dat. of respect, ‘the same in regard to your words,’ like au(to/s ei)mi tw=| bouleu/mati ( Soph. O. T. 557 n.). But tou/tois shows that the other constr. is meant.
ou)k e)/sq' o(/pws: cp. 196.

a)lla\ … me/ntoi: cp. Ant. 567.The fact that a)lla\ recurs so soon, in v. 526, has caused a corruption to be suspected in the latter place (see crit. n.): but there it has a different tone (‘come, now’).
