This elasticity of meaning in a)lla/ is one reason why classical poetry so readily allows it to be repeated at short intervals (cp. e.g. 645, Ant. 647, Ant. 651: O. C. 238 ff. a)ll' e)pei\...a)ll' e)me\...a)ll' i)/te: El. 137— 140, El. 879—882: Tr. 592—594). As to the tolerance of such repetition generally, cp. 762: O. C. 554 n.
ai)sxra\: for the plur., cp. 1395, O. C. 485 n.
sou= ge/ m) is better than sou= g' e)/m): the latter would imply an ungraceful emphasis on the speaker's personal dignity.
pro\s to\ kai/rion: cp. Ai. 38h)=...pro\s kairo\n ponw=;
ponei=n, epexegetic of e)ndee/steron, ‘in respect of toiling’: cp. O.C. 335 oi( d' au)qo/maimoi pou= neani/ai ponei=n;

o(rma/sqw, let Philoctetes set out with us for the ship at once. taxu/s=taxe/ws: cp. 808, 1080. xh( nau=s, the ship, on her part. If the sick man's shipmates make no difficulty, the ship will make none: i.e., it will be easy to find room for him on board (cp. 481). Neoptolemus is on his guard against betraying elation. He speaks as if the granting of Ph. 's prayer was now a simple matter, —and one which did not greatly interest him.

a)parnhqh/setai is usu. taken as passive: either (1) ‘the boon shall not be refused’: or (2) ‘he shall not be refused his wish.’ This second version is inadmissible. Clas sical Greek allows a)parnou=mai dou=nai/ ti, but not a)parnou=mai to
 ai)tou=nta. And with either version the change of subject would be harsh. Rather the verb is deponent, with h( nau=s for subject. Prof. Ridgeway, supporting this view (Trans. Camb. Philol. Soc. I. p. 244), illustrates the personification of the ship from Od. 10. 131a)spasi/ws d' e)s po/nton e)phrefe/as fu/ge pe/tras, and Arist. Pol. 3. 13.§ 16, where the ship Argo—endued by legend with a voice—is described as refusing to carry Heracles (ou) ga e)qe/lein au)to
 a)/gein th
 *)argw/).—It is true that the classical fut. of a)rne/omai, where it occurs, is a)rnh/somai ( Soph. O. T. 571, etc.). But there is no classical instance of a)rnhqh/somai as fut. pass. And since the aor. h)rnh/qhn is always deponent, analogy suggests that a deponent use of a)rnhqh/somai would have been possible. Cp. diale/gomai, aor. diele/xqhn (deponent), fut. dialexqh/somai (deponent), as well as diale/comai. In later Greek a)rnhqh/somai occurs, indeed, as pass. (St Luke xii. 9, a)parnhqh/setai, ‘he will be disowned’), but also as deponent (LXX. Is. xxxi. 7a)parnhqh/sontai, with v.l. a)parnh/sontai).
mo/non=modo, as oft. in wishes or commands ( Tr. 1109prosmo/loi mo/non, etc.).
bouloi/mesqa: the optat. in the relative clause, because sw/|zoien stands in the principal clause: as 961 o)/loio mh/pw pri\n ma/qoim). Cp. 325 n.: O. C. 778 n.

w)= fi/ltaton me\n k.t.l.: for the epanaphora, with change from fi/ltatos to a synonym, cp. Ant. 898fi/lh me\n... prosfilh\s de\...fi/lh de\, n. For the nom. h(/distos a)nh/r after the voc., cp. 867, 986.
pw=s a)\n … genoi/mhn, a wish; cp. 794: O. C. 1457: so ib. 1100 ti/s a)\n...doi/h...;

i)/wmen clearly means, ‘let us be going’ (from Lemnos). Cp. 645 xwrw=men. It expresses his joyful impatience to avail himself of N.'s offer here, and naturally follows the preceding verses. If, on the other hand, we take i)/wmen to mean, ‘let us go into the cave,’ we shall have no direct expression of Ph. 's eagerness to leave Lemnos: and the invitation to enter the cave will come with an awkward abruptness after the first words of gratitude. But if i)/wmen means, ‘let us be going from Lemnos,’ then we must accept ei)soi/khsin, unless we can substitute for prosku/sante some partic. which could go with ei)s oi)/khsin. For prosku/sante ei)s oi)/khsin could not mean, ‘having gone into the dwelling to salute it.’ I once suggested th/nde prosku/yant' e)/sw | a)/oikon ei)s oi)/khsin, i.e. ‘after one look’ into it; but I now doubt whether the classical usage of prosku/ptw would bear this. We may rather believe that Soph. hazarded the otherwise unknown word ei)soi/khsis, much as in Soph. O. C. 27 he ventured on e)coikh/simos. It implies a verb ei)soike/w (nowhere found, except as a v.l. for e)noike/w in Anthol. 7. 320), capable of being used thus,—a)/ntron ei)sw/|khse, ‘he entered the cave and made his dwelling there’=a)/ntron ei)selqw\n w)/|khse. Then ei)soi/khsis would be properly, the act of so making a dwelling, or the dwelling made. (ei)soiki/zw, to bring in as a settler, is irrelevant.) See Appendix.— prosku/sante, a farewell salutation (as by kissing the soil), because the cave had so long given him shelter: see below on 1408.
w(s … kai\: cp. 13.
a)f' w(=n: Her. 1. 216a)po\ kthne/wn. zw/ousi kai\ i)xqu/wn.
die/zwn, sustained life (under difficulties), as Her. 3. 25poihfage/ontes die/zwon: so diatre/fomai, diagi/gnomai.

oi)=mai ga\r k.t.l.: for I think that even the bare sight would have deterred any one but myself from enduring these things: ou)dei\s a)/llos a)\n e)/tlh ta/de, ei) qe/an mo/nhn e)/labe. The first glance at such a dwelling would have made any other man renounce the attempt to live in it. Instead of kai\ o)/mmasin mo/nhn qe/an labo/nta, ou)k a)\n tlh=nai, we have ou)d) o)/mmasin...tlh=nai,—ou)d) thus serving to weld the sentence into a more compact whole.

mo/nhn need not be changed to mo/non, though the latter would be more usual: cp. O. T. 388e)n toi=s ke/rdesin | mo/non de/dorke: Ant. 361*(/aida mo/non feu=cin ou)k e)pa/cetai.—Some govern ta/de by qe/an labo/nta as=qeasa/menon (cp. O. C. 223 n.), and take tlh=nai with the partic.: ‘endure to have looked upon.’ This is forced. For tlh=nai with simple acc., cp. Tr. 71, O. C. 1077, etc.
prou)/maqon, by painful steps (pro/): cp. 1015 prou)di/dacen.

e)pi/sxeton is said to N. and Ph. , who are moving towards the cave. ma/qwmen, absol., let us learn,—viz., what tidings the new comers are bringing. The conjecture me/nwmen (or mei/nwmen) would merely repeat the sense of e)pi/sxeton.—This hortative subjunct. occurs even in the 1st pers. sing., as Eur. Hipp. 567e)pi/sxet), au)dh\n tw=n e)/swqen e)kma/qw: id. H.F. 1058 si=ga, pnoa\s ma/qw.
a)llo/qrous, prop., speaking a foreign tongue: here, simply = a)llo/trios, just as in Tr. 844a)llo/qrou | gnw/mas=merely a)llotri/as gnw/mhs.
w(=n maqo/ntes, i.e., having learned (their news) from them: cp. 370 n.
au)=qis=‘at a later moment,’ as Ai. 1283.— ei)/siton (imperat., not indic.): for the dual, after maqo/ntes, cp. Laches p. 187 A au)toi\ eu(retai\ gegono/te: and n. on O. C. 343.

542 Odysseus said that he would send back the skopo/s, disguised as a merchant captain, if N. seemed to be tarrying too long (126 ff.). The actor who now comes on as e)/mporos would not, however, be the same who played the skopo/s (a mute person), but the tritagonist, who played Odysseus. The sailor who accompanies him is a mute person; and that part may have been taken by the former representative of the skopo/s.

As N. has already ensnared Ph. , and is on the point of starting with him, there is no actual need for the intervention of the e)/mporos. But Odysseus, at the ship, could not know this; and we are to suppose that he had become impatient. The scene which follows heightens the dramatic interest by bringing out the horror with which Ph. regards the idea of returning to Troy.
cune/mporon, fellow-traveller, as Tr. 318, etc.
fra/sai se, pou= k.t.l.: for the constr., cp. n. on 443 f., ad fin.
kurw=n ei)/hs: cp. O. T. 1285ou)de/n e)st' a)po/n.
doca/zwn me\n ou)/: cp. Ant. 255tumbh/rhs me\n ou)/, n.

o(rmisqei\s: the same constr. with the pass. in H. 1. 4 § 18, pro\s th
 gh=n o(rmisqei/s,=o(rmi/sas th
 nau=n, or o(rmisa/menos, having brought one's ship to anchor. tau)to
 … pe/don, the same land (Lemnos); not, strictly, the same ‘spot.’

ou) pollw=| sto/lw|, with no large company (i.e. with one ship, and only a small crew to handle it): as Tr. 496su\n pollw=| sto/lw|=‘with a numerous train.’ If sto/lw| were taken as ‘fleet,’ the phrase could hardly be, a mere equivalent for mia=| nhi/, but would suggest at least a plurality of vessels.

*pepa/rhqon (now called *sko/pelos), a small island near the Thessalian coast, about 12 miles E. of the south end of Magnesia. The island of Sciathus lies between it and the mainland; Euboea is only 20 miles distant to the S.W., and Scyros about 40 to the S. The E. name is well-chosen, then, to make Philoctetes feel that he is listening to a neighbour of his old home. Peparethus, though not more than some 12 miles in length, with a greatest width of 5 or 6, contained three towns. Its famous wine is ranked by Aristophanes with those of Pramnus, Chios and Thasos (fr. 301). The author of [Dem. ] or. 35 § 35 names Peparethus, along with Cos, Thasos and Mendè, as a seat of the wine-trade with the Euxine. An Alexandrian physician, Apollodorus, recommended the wine of Peparethus before all others, adding that its repute would be still higher, did it not require six years to attain perfection ( H. N. 14. 9). The epithet eu)/botrun here is peculiarly fitting, since Pliny speaks of the island as quondam Evoenum dictam (ib. 4. 23). And so Heracleides Ponticus fr. 13 says of it, au)/th h( nh=sos eu)/oino/s e)sti kai\ eu)/dendros. It also produced good olives (Ov. Met. 7. 470).—In the Iliad the Greeks at Troy import wine from Lemnos (7. 467) and from Thrace (9. 72).

h)/kousa tou\s nau/tas o(/ti: cp. Ai. 1141su\ d' a)ntakou/sei tou=ton w(s teqa/yetai: M. 4. 2. 23 to\n *dai/dalon ou)k a)kh/koas, o(/ti h)nagka/zeto douleu/ein;— pa/ntes: and therefore he could not have been anticipated in bringing the news.— Dobree's conjecture, sunnenaustolhko/tes, has been generally accepted by recent edd. If the MS. oi( nenaustolhko/tes is retained, then soi\ is possess. pron.: ‘that all those who had made the voyage were thy men.’ The objection to this is the want of point in the participle.

e)/doce/ moi k.t.l. The constr. of prostuxo/nti is made somewhat awkward by the negative before poei=sqai. ‘I decided to sail, not in silence, or before I had told thee, (but only when, having told thee,) I had received a due reward.’ It would have been clearer to have written either: (1) e)/doce/ moi fra/santi to
 plou=n poei=sqai, prostuxo/nti tw=n i)/swn: or (2) e)/doce/ moi mh\ si=ga to
 plou=n poei=sqai, pri
 fra/saimi kai\ prostu/xoimi tw=n i)/swn. The justification of the actual form is that mh\ si=ga, pri
 fra/saimi, is felt as a more emphatic equivalent for a simple fra/santi. For the dat. prostuxo/nti (instead of an acc.) with the inf., cp. Xen. An. 2. 1§ 2 e)/docen ou)=n au)toi=s suskeuasame/nois...proi+e/nai. The acc. is, however, more usual, as ib. 3. 2. 1 e)/docen au)toi=s profulaka\s katasth/santas sugkalei=n tou\s stratiw/tas, since it excludes a possible ambiguity: cp. Soph. Ant. 838 n.— The use of prostuxo/nti (‘having obtained, met with’) is like that in Soph. El. 1463e)mou= kolastou= prostuxw/n.

tw=n i)/swn: by ta\ i)/sa is meant a reasonable recompense for his trouble. This sense of i)/sos (aequus) is virtually the same as in such phrases as e)pi\ toi=s i)/sois kai\ o(moi/ois ( Thuc. 5. 79), etc. Similarly the messengers in Soph. O. T. 1005 and Soph. Tr. 190 expressly say that they have come in the hope of being rewarded.—Others join prostuxo/nti with soi, ‘when thou shouldst have received (the information) due.’ Nauck understands, ‘since I have met with the same fortune as thine’—i.e., have put in at the same coast. (Cp. Soph. El. 1168cu\n soi\ metei=xon tw=n i)/swn.)

a(\ toi=sin k.t.l. The antecedent to a(\ is not tw=n sautou= in 553: rather the relative clause is epexegetic. ‘Thou knowest nothing of thine own affairs, — i.e., of those new counsels (sc. peri\ tou/twn.) which,’ etc.
ve/a, in addition to the former wrong (60).

ou)ke/t' e)cargou/mena, deeds which are no longer allowed to remain a)rga/, i.e., in which the doers are not slack. After the bouleu/mata had become e)/rga, by the taking of the first steps, the action might still have been sluggish. But these e)/rga are drw/mena,—advancing towards completion. So Plut. Mor. 2E gh=... e)carghqei=sa, land which has been allowed to lie fallow. Arist. uses the pf. act. e)chrghke/nai as=‘to have become torpid’ (Eth. N. 1. 8: Pol. 5. 10). Cp. O. T. 287a)ll' ou)k e)n a)rgoi=s ou)de\ tou=t' e)praca/mhn.

a)ll), ‘well’: cp. 232, 336.— h( xa/ris … th=s promhqi/as, the favour of (conferred by) thy forethought; cp. O. T. 764fe/rein...xa/rin, Tr. 1217pro/sneimai de/ moi | xa/rin braxei=an. promhqi/as, the poet. form (cp. Ant. 943 n.); for the sense, (‘kind thought for one,’) cp. O. C. 332sh=|, pa/ter, promhqi/a|.
ei) mh\ kako\s pe/fuka: Xen. Cyr. 5. 1. 21xa/rin tou/twn e)gw\ u(mi=n e)/xw me/n, ei) mh\ a)dikw=.

prosfilh\s, grata, well-pleasing,—gratefully remembered. Aesch. Theb. 580h)= toi=sin e)/rgon kai\ qeoi=si prosfile/s. The difficulty felt as to prosfilh/s (see crit. n.) has arisen from the assumption that xa/ris here=‘gratitude.’

a(/per g). It is not surprising that ge should have been suspected here, since L has a(/per e)/lecas. But the emendations which have been suggested (see cr. n.) are improbable. If any were to be made, I should rather suggest a(/per ka)/lecas. L seems, however, to have lost ge in some other places (cp. 105 n.): and here the particle appears defensible, if regard is had to the tone of the passage. Neoptolemus, mindful of his part, receives the (supposed) stranger's announcement with politeness, but without manifesting much concern. ‘I am really very much obliged to you for the trouble which you have taken. But perhaps you would kindly say what, precisely, it is to which you allude.’ So a(/per g)=‘just those things which,’—the ge merely adding a slight emphasis to a(/per.
new/teron, not simply ne/on (554), but ‘startling,’—ominous of some new wrong: cp. Thuc. 4. 51mhde\n peri\ sfa=s new/teron bouleu/sein.
a)p' *)argei/wn with bou/leuma, not with e)/xeis,—a plot on their part: for this a)po/, cp. O. C. 293.— e)/xeis with moi, ‘hast for me,’ i.e., announcest to me. Cp. Ant. 9 n.
foi=nic: cp. 344.

oi(/ te *qhse/ws ko/roi: Demophon,—the ruler of Athens who figures in Heracleidae,—and his brother Acamas, who in the same play is a mute person at his side (v. 119). These *qhsei/da, o)/zw *)aqhnw=n ( Eur. Hec. 125), are plausibly represented as foes of Neoptolemus, since their father Theseus was treacherously slain in Scyros by Lycomedes ( Paus. 1. 17. 6). Arctinus of Miletus (c. 776 B.C.), the author of the *)ili/ou *pe/rsis, made Neoptolemus the hero of his epic, and introduced the two sons of Theseus in the episode of the wooden horse. On the Acropolis of Athens Pausanias saw the dou/reios i(/ppos commemorated in bronze. ‘Menestheus and Teucer,’ he adds, ‘are peeping out of it, —and the sons of Theseus’ (1. 23. 8).— These Theseidae do not appear in Il.or Od.; nor does their father, except where Nestor speaks of having known him ( Il. 1. 265), and in a doubtful verse of the ne/kuia ( Od. 11. 631).
e)k bi/as: cp. 945.

lo/gois is changed by Nauck to do/lois, because the antithesis between force and persuasion is not suitable here; ‘since Neoptolemus must assume a hostile intention in the diw/kontes.’ But why should he not suppose that the Atreidae, finding him indispensable, wish to entice him back by smooth lo/goi? (Cp. 629 lo/goisi malqakoi=s.) In v. 102 ti/ d' e)n do/lw| dei= ma=llon h)\ pei/sant' a)/gein; the antithesis is between a false story and persuasion by honest argument. But lo/gos (whether true or false), as a means of prevailing, can also be contrasted with force, as in 593 f., h)\ lo/gw| | pei/santes a)/cein, h)\ pro\s i)sxu/os kra/tos. And that is the antithesis meant here.
kaq' o(rmh\n, impetuously, like kata\ spoudh\n ( Thuc. 1. 93): cp. a)po\ mia=s o(rmh=s (id. 7. 71).

w(s tau=t' e)pi/stw drw/men). Where w(s occurs in such phrases with an imperative, it regularly belongs to the partic.: cp. 253 w(s mhde\n ei)do/t' i)/sqi m) (n.). But here w(s tau=ta...drw/mena could not strictly stand for w(s drw/mena...tau=ta. The suspicions which the text has excited are, so far, natural. Yet I think that it is sound. The irregularity seems to have arisen from the fact that w(s, prefixed to an assurance, could either (a) belong to a partic. (as in 253, 415, etc.), or (b) introduce the whole sentence, as 117 w(s tou=to/ g' e)/rcas du/o fe/rei dwrh/mata. Thus the Attic ear had become accustomed to w(s as the first word of such an assurance in either type. And so w(s could be given that place in a sentence of type (a), even though the partic, did not immediately follow. That is, I do not suppose that w(s tau=t' e)pi/stw drw/mena is for w(s drw/men' e)pi/stw tau=ta: but rather that, instead of saying simply tau=t' e)pi/stw drw/mena, he can prefix w(s, because the associations of type (b) had blunted the feeling for what was essential in type (a),—viz., that the partic. (or partic. with mh/) should immediately follow w(s.
pro\s ta/d). After ou)=n, it is slightly better to take these words as= ‘for this purpose’ ( O. T. 766pro\s ti/;), rather than as=‘in view of these facts’ (= pro\s tau=ta, O. T. 426).
au)ta/ggelos, carrying his own message: O. C. 333.
kei=no/s g): the ge throws a slight stress on the pron., ‘oh, he’: cp. 424.
o( *tude/ws pai=s, Diomedes, who, in the Philoctetes of Eur. , accompanied Odysseus to Lemnos (see Introd.).— e)/stellon=e)ste/llonto: cp. 640: Her. 4. 147e)/stelle e)s a)poiki/hn.

pro\s poi=on au)= to/nd' … e)/plei; ‘who was this other person in quest of whom Odysseus himself was sailing?’ au)= is oft. thus used after interrogatives: cp. Ant. 7ti/ tou=t' au)= fasi\ pandh/mw| po/lei | kh/rugma qei=nai...; (For pro\s poi=on...to/nde as=poi=os h)=n o(/de, pro\s o(/n, cp. 441.) Not ‘was sailing again’ (with ref. to his former voyage to Scyros, 343). If au)= is a true correction here (as it has been deemed by almost all recent edd.), the corruption a)\n in the MSS. is the reverse of that which has probably occurred in O. C. 1418(n.).

If a)
 is kept, it must be explained in one of two ways. (1) Taking a)/n with e)/plei: ‘who is this, for whom he would have been sailing?’ (=‘presumably sailed’). Cp. Od. 4. 546h)/ ken *)ore/sths | ktei=nen, ‘or Orestes would have slain him,’=‘or, it may be, O. slew him.’ (2) Taking a)/n with poi=on to/nde, as if o)/nta were understood: ‘Who might this man be, for whom he sailed?’ On this view, a)/n does not affect e)/plei, and pro\s poi=on a)
 to/nde=poi=os o(/de a)
 ei)/h, pro\s o(
 e)/plei. This is possible: though here pro\s poi=on a)
 to/nde would more naturally suggest poi=os o(/de a)
 h)=n.
soi, ethic dat.: cp. 261.
ta\ plei/on), the further details which N. might naturally wish to learn: cp. O. C. 36pri/n nun ta\ plei/on' i(storei=n (n.).

seauto
 cullabw
, a phrase of colloquial tone (cp. Shaksp., ‘be packing’): Ar. Av. 1469a)pi/wmen h(mei=s sullabo/ntes ta\ ptera/, and n. on Soph. O. T. 971: Soph. Ant. 444su\ me
 komi/zois a)
 seauto
 h)=| qe/leis.

ti/ me...diempola=| … pro/s se; what bargain is he making with thee concerning me? From the words a)lla\ to/nde in 573 onwards, the pretended e)/mporos has spoken to N. in lower tones; while N. has taken care to pronounce v. 575 loud enough for Ph. to hear. The object of this by-play is to quicken Ph. 's interest in the coming story (603 ff.), and his anxiety to leave Lemnos. Seyffert's change of ti/ me into ti/ de\ is no improvement. It is natural that Ph. , the a)nh\r u(po/pths (136), should suspect some design against himself. The e)/mporos had suddenly assumed an air of mystery; and, on learning Ph. 's name, had urged N. to save himself (seauto\n sullabw/n). The dia/ in diempola=| expresses traffic: cp. fr. 521. 7 (a woman bewailing the lot of her sex), w)qou/meq' e)/cw kai\ diempolw/meqa (as by a bargain between suitor and parents). —Cp. 978: Ant. 1036.

ei)s fw=s, opp. to kata\ sko/ton (578): cp. 1353: El. 639ou)de\ pa=n a)naptu/cai pre/pei | pro\s fw=s: O. T. 1229ei)s to\ fw=s fane/i: fr. 832 pa/nt' e)kkalu/ptwn o( xro/nos ei)s to\ fw=s a)/gei. Yet Nauck has ejected ei)s fw=s from the text, and conjecturally substituted safw=s. He wishes also to replace le/cei by xrh/|zei. But for the fut. cp. O.C. 114 e(/ws a)\n e)kma/qw | ti/nas lo/gous e)rou=sin. So here le/cei = me/llei le/cein.—For kai/ … te cp. 421.
spe/rm): cp. 364.
stratw=|: the dat. as Eur. Hec. 863*)axaioi=s ei) diablhqh/somai, etc. In prose usu. pro/s tina or ei)/s tina: also para/ tini, or e)/n tisi.
a(\ mh\ dei=, quae non oporteat (generic mh/).

drw=n a)ntipa/sxw: the emphasis is here rather on the verb than on the partic.: ‘I receive many benefits from them, in return for my services.’ The schol. has: u(p' e)kei/nwn eu)ergetou/menos a)nteuergetw= au)tou/s, w(s du/natai pe/nhs eu)ergetei=n, dhlono/ti u(phretei=n. This makes drw=n more prominent than a)ntipa/sxw, —evidently because the schol. thought that oi(=) a)nh\r pe/nhs referred only to drw=n,—‘so far as a poor man can confer benefits.’ But that clause refers to a)ntipa/sxw also: the benefits which he received were important for such as he was. Cp. O. T. 763a)/cios...oi(=) a)nh\r | dou=los (‘for a slave’), and ib. 1118 pisto\s w(s nomeu\s a)nh/r.

xrhsta/ q): polla\ (or polla/ te) kai\ xrhsta\ is commoner than polla\ xrhsta/ te (though cp. Aesch. Theb. 338polla\ ga/r, eu)=te pto/lis damasqh=|, | e)h/, dustuxh= te pra/ssei): and on the other hand we find polla\...kala/ (fr. 79), polla\...sofa/ (fr. 99), etc. Still, xrhsta/ q' seems more probable here than xrhsta/ g'.

e)gw/ ei)m). This synizesis is extremely rare, though that of w and ou is less so ( O. T. 332e)gw\ ou)/t), n.). Indeed there is no other certain instance in Tragedy; for in Soph. El. 1332ou)d' e)gw\ ei)s so\n ble/faron pela/sw ought not to be compared. There ou)d' e)gw\ is a dactyl, by epic hiatus, as in Il. 1. 29th\n d' e)gw\ ou) lu/sw. In Comedy we have Vesp. 1224 e)gw\ ei)/somai, where Burges reads tax' ei)/somai.
fi/los me/gistos: cp. Ai. 1331fi/lon s' e)gw\ me/giston *)argei/wn ne/mw.

lo/gwn appears slightly preferable to the MS. lo/gon here: and either would have been written *l*o*g*o*n in the poet's time. w(=n is most simply taken as=tou/twn ou(/s: though, if lo/gon were retained, it might also represent (peri\) tou/twn a(/.

o(/ra k.t.l. Some take this verse as an exchange of veiled hints between the accomplices. But why should the e)/mporos fear that N. was likely to trip in his part? Rather it is merely a piece of acting, like the feigned ‘aside’ in 573, and with the same object—viz., to impress Philoctetes.
pa/lai, referring back merely to the moment at which he began to press his question,—i.e., to 580: cp. O. T. 1161 n.—For the a)ntilabh/, marking excitement, cp. 54, 466.
poiou=, instead of ti/qou. Cp. O. T. 54w(s ei)/per a)/rceis th=sde gh=s, w(/sper kratei=s, n.
le/gwn: cp. O. C. 1038(n.) xwrw=n a)pei/lei nu=n, threaten (if you will) —but set out. So here, ‘hold me responsible if thou wilt—but answer.’
le/gw. So Tr. 1130le/gw: te/qnhken k.t.l.: Ant. 245(where the reluctant speaker is at last brought to the point) kai\ de\ le/gw soi.

)pi\ tou=ton. Such aphaeresis after a stop is rare: but cp. I. A. 719 me/llw: 'pi\ tau/th| kai\ kaqe/stamen tu/xh|: [Eur. ] Rhes. 157 h(/cw: )pi\ tou/tois to/nd' u(fi/stamai po/non: Nub. 1354 e)gw\ fra/sw. )peidh\ ga\r k.t.l.
tou=ton, this man here, (=to/nde,) Philoctetes.
592 Although Odysseus and Diomedes had been named in 570, it is obviously natural that their names should be repeated in this more explicit statement.
diw/motoi. The adj., not found elsewhere, answers to dio/mnumi ( Tr. 255) or dio/mnumai (ib. 378, Ai. 1233) as=‘to swear solemnly.’

h)= mh
, prefacing an oath, as Tr. 256(diw/mosen) h)= mh
...doulw/sein: ib. 1185 o)/mnu... | h)= mh
 ti/ dra/sein; The formula occurs first in Il. 1. 76o)/mosson | h)= me/n (Ion. for mh/n) moi a)rh/cein. It is used also in threats, O.C. 816 h)= mh
... luphqei\s e)/sei (n.).

pei/santes k.t.l.: cp. 102.—pro\s i)sxu/os kra/tos. i)sxu/s is the physical strength at the disposal of the captors; kra/tos, the mastery which this strength will give them. Thus the gen. defines the source of the kra/tos. Cp. Aesch. P. V. 212w(s ou) kat' i)sxu\n ou)de\ pro\s to\ kartero\n | xrei/h, do/lw| de\ tou\s u(persxo/ntas kratei=n: where kat' i)sxu/n expresses the available strength, and pro\s to\ kartero/n the triumphant exertion of it. (As to pro\s i)sxu/os xa/rin in Eur. Med. 538, see on Soph. Ant. 30.) For pro\s cp. 90 n.
ple/on, predicate: cp. 352, 601.
qate/rou=h)\ o( e(/teros: cp. O.C. 568 ple/on ...sou==ple/on h)\ soi/ (n.).
ti/nos … pra/gmatos xa/rin; cp. O. T. 698o(/tou pote\ | ...pra/gmatos.
xro/nw| tosw=|de=dia\ xro/nou tosou/tou, after so long a time: cp. 722: El. 1273i)w\ xro/nw| makrw=| filta/tan | o(do\n e)paciw/sas... fanh=nai.
e)pestre/fonto, bethought them (impf.) of caring for: Dem. or. 10 § 9 ou)de\n e)fronti/sate ou)d' e)pestra/fhte ou)de\n tou/twn. Cp. Soph. O. T. 134pro\ tou= qano/ntos th/nd' e)/qesq' e)pistrofh/n.
a)/gan ou(/tw, with e)pestre/fonto: El. 884w(=de pisteu/eis a)/gan.

The order of the words is remarkable, not only because ti/nos is so far from pra/gmatos, but also because it is closely followed by tou=d), so that, when the ear caught the first words, the sense expected might naturally be, ‘Who was for this man for whom’ etc. (cp. 441). The motive has been the wish to emphasise the pron referring to Philoctetes (tou=d)). A somewhat similar instance is Ant. 944e)/tla kai\ *dana/as ou)ra/nion fw=s | a)lla/cai de/mas e)n xalkode/tois au)lai=s.

ei)=xon … e)kbeblhko/tes: cp. El. 590e)kbalou=s' e)/xeis. The perf. part. ( O. T. 701) is much rarer than the aor. part. in mere periphrasis. When joined to the perf. partic., e)/xw has usu. a separate force; as Xen. An. 1. 3. 14polla\ xrh/mata e)/xomen a)nhrpako/tes (‘have carried off, and hold’). So ib. 4. 7. 1 e)n oi(=s kai\ ta\ e)pith/deia pa/nta a)nakekomisme/noi (had carried up, and kept).
xro/nion (masc.): O. C. 441 n.
ti/s o( po/qos: cp. O. C. 205ti/s o( polu/ponos a)/gei; (n.)
i(/ket): Il. 1. 240h)= pot' *)axillh=os poqh\ i(/cetai ui(=as *)axaiw=n.

qew=n bi/a, constraint imposed by the gods; an unusual phrase, but suitable here, where spontaneous yearning (po/qos) is opposed to the external pressure of destiny. Cp. fr. adesp. 424 ou) ga\r pro\ moi/ras h( tu/xh bia/zetai (i.e., one does not die before one's appointed time). Ant. 1140biai/as...no/sou.
ne/mesis: cp. 518.
a)mu/nousin, requite, punish: O. C. 1128.
o)/noma d' w)noma/zeto: Eur. Ion 800o)/noma de\ poi=on au)to\n o)noma/zei path/r; Symmetry with *pria/mou me\n ui(o/s required o)nomazo/menos: cp. 215 n. (boa=| for bow=n).

*(/elenos,—distinguished as *priami/dhs from Helenus son of Oenops, a Greek hero slain by Hector ( Il. 5. 707), —figures in the Iliad as at once a seer and a warrior. He gives counsel at critical moments to his brother Hector ( Il. 6. 76, Il. 7. 44); with his brother Deïphobus, he leads a third of the Trojan host in the attack on the Greek camp ( Il. 12. 94). The story of his capture by Odysseus does not belong to the Iliad, but was probably included in the *)ilia\s *mikra/ of Lesches (c. 700 B.C.),—the epic which contained the return of Philoctetes to Troy (see Introd.). Ovid associates this exploit with two other similar feats of Odysseus,—the capture of the horses of Rhesus, when their master, and the Trojan spy Dolon, were slain ( Il. 10),—and the theft of the Palladium: Met. 13. 99Conferat his Ithacus Rhesum imbellemque Dolona, | Priamidemque Helenum rapta cum Pallade captum. In Verg. Aen. 3. 346 ff., Helenus, then settled in Epeirus, prophesies to Aeneas.

The statement of the e)/mporos is only part of the truth. Helenus had indeed been captured, and had said that Troy could not be taken without Philoctetes. But he had also said that Troy was destined to be taken that summer,—as if he knew that fate had decreed the return of Philoctetes,—who was then to be healed by the Asclepiadae, and to share with Neoptolemus the glory of the victory (1329—1342). Odysseus, however, believed that Philoctetes would not listen to persuasion, but must be brought back by a stratagem (103). And so the object of the e)/mporos in referring to Helenus is merely to convince Philoctetes that Odysseus is coming, in order that the sufferer may become still more anxious to depart with Neoptolemus for Greece, as he supposes.
a)kou/wn, with ref. to general repute, as 1313.
lwbhta\ e)/ph, insulting, contumelious words: for the act. sense, cp. Tr. 538lwbhto\n e)mpo/lhma, a bargain that ruins one.
e)s me/son with e)/deic), rather than with de/smion...a)/gwn: cp. Pind. fr. 42 kalw=n me\n w)=n moi=ra/n te terpnw=n e)s me/son xrh\ panti\ law=| | deiknu/nai.

ta/ t' a)/lla … pa/nta, including the command to bring Neopt. from Scyros (cp. 346). This phrase serves to emphasise the statement introduced by kai\: cp. Ant. 506a)ll' h( turanni\s polla/ t' a)/ll' eu)daimonei=, | ka)/cestin au)th=| k.t.l.
ta)pi\ *troi/a| pe/rgam): cp. 353 n.

ou) mh/ pote pe/rsoien. Helenus said, ou) mh\ pe/rsete. It is certain that ou) mh/ was used with the 1st or 3rd pers. of the fut. indic. in strong denial,—having then the same force as ou) mh/ with the subjunctive, which was the commoner construction. There is no need, then, for changing ou) mh\ pe/rsoien into ou) mh\ pe/rseian (as though he had said ou) mh\ pe/rshte). In oratio obliqua after a secondary tense this fut. indic. with ou) mh/ could be retained (as if here we had pe/rsousin): or it could be represented by a fut. inf. (as if we had e)/fh au)tou\s ou) mh/pote pe/rsein). See the examples in n. on O. C. 177.
ou) dhpote pe/rsoien would be a weaker reading.

a)/gointo: he said, e)a
 mh\ a)/ghsqe, if ye shall not bring. Blaydes places his conjecture a)ga/gointo in the text, and also suggests a)/cointo. Either would serve; but a)/gointo is right also. In a conditional sentence, the pres. subj. can have either of two meanings: (1) e)a
 a)/ghsqe, kalw=s e(/cei,—‘if ye shall bring, it will be well’—a particular supposition referring to the future: or (2) e)a
 a)/ghsqe, kalw=s e)/xei,—‘if ye (ever) bring, it is (always) well,’—a general supposition referring to the present. Here, of course, a)/gointo represents (1). Cp. Xen. Cyr. 3. 2. 13h)
 me
 po/lemon ai(rh=sqe, mhke/ti h(/kete deu=ro a)/neu o(/plwn...h)
 de\ ei)rh/nhs dokh=te dei=sqai, a)/neu o(/plwn h(/kete: ib. 5. 3. 27 e)a
 ou)=n i)/h|s nu=n, po/te e)/sei oi)/koi; For similar instances of this pres. subj. (referring to the future) represented by the optative in oratio obliqua, cp. Dem. or. 18 § 148 ei) me
 toi/nun tou=to...tw=n e)kei/nou summa/xwn ei)shgoi=to/ tis (representing e)a
 ei)shgh=tai/ tis), u(po/yesqai to\ pra=gma e)no/mize (pa/ntas). Xen. Anab. 6. 1. 25e)do/kei dh=gon ei)=nai o(/ti ai(rh/sontai au)to/n, ei)/ tis e)piyhfi/zoi (=e)a/n tis e)piyhfi/zh|).
nh/sou, gen. after a verb of motion: 630, El. 324do/mwn...e)nta/fia... fe/rousan: O. T. 142 n.

617 The words oi)/oito me
 ma/lista are parenthetical, just as if we had ei)ko/tws me
 e(kou/sion labw/n: and the optat. is used as if ei)=pen o(/ti dhlw/soi had preceded. Cp. Lys. or. 13 § 19 le/gei o(/ti, e)a

...eu(rh/sesqai. Similarly a clause with ga/r can take the optat. in oratio obliqua: H. 7. 1. 23 ge/gwn w(s mo/nois me
 au)toi=s patri\s *pelopo/nnhsos ei)/h, mo/noi ga au)to/xqones e)n au)th=| oi)koi=en.
ma/lista with oi)/oito, indicating what he thought most likely: cp. El. 932oi)=mai ma/list' e)/gwge, and O.C. 1298 n.
tou/twn with mh\ tuxw/n (=ei) mh\ tu/xoi): the place of the pron. is emphatic; cp. 598 n.

ka/ra te/mnein= kefalh\n a)pote/mnein (or poet. karatomei=n). The Homeric Odysseus twice uses this expression; Il. 2. 259mhke/t' e)/peit' *)odush=i ka/rh w)/moisin e)pei/h—if he does not chastise Thersites; and Od. 16. 102au)ti/k' e)/peit' a)p' e)mei=o ka/rh ta/moi a)llo/trios fw/s —if he should not punish the suitors.— e)fei=to, usu. ‘commanded’ or ‘enjoined’; here rather, ‘gave leave.’ [In Xen. An. 6. 6. 31h( stratia/ soi u(fei=to o(/ ti e)bou/lou poih=sai, e)fei=to is only a doubtful v. l.]
to\ speu/dein: for the superfluous art., cp. O. C. 47(tou)canista/nai) n.

soi kau)tw=|: the kai/=‘both,’ yet can follow soi because the thought is, ‘I recommend haste to you, both in your own interest and in that of your friends.’— pe/ri: a very rare addition to the gen. with kh/domai: as a general rule, however, verbs of ‘caring’ can take either the simple gen. or gen. with prep. (as fronti/zw, me/lei, etc.).

h( pasa bla/bh, that utter pest. In this phrase pa=sa is justified by the figurative application; i.e., when a man is called a bla/bh, instead of saying o( pa=s bla/bh w)/n, he who is altogether a bane, we can say h( pa=sa bla/bh, the bane which is altogether such. The tendency is the same which appears, e.g., in le/gei...ei)=nai tau/thn (instead of tou=to) o)rqo/thta o)no/matos ( Plat. Crat. 443E: Soph. O. C. 88 n.).—So Aegisthus is o( pa/nt' a)/nalkis ou(=tos, h( pa=sa bla/bh, Soph. El. 301.Cp. 927 pa=n dei=ma.

peisqh/somai. No entreaties can recall the dead to the upper world; and no entreaties will recall him to Troy. We need not object to peisqh/somai that a Greek would think of the departed as glad to revisit the sunlight. The point is that the dead are deaf to the voice that would bring them back.
ga\r implies the suppressed thought, ou)/toi stelei=.
w(=de=‘at this rate’ (=‘if I go to Troy’): so oft. ou(/tw.

pro\s fw=s a)nelqei=n. Nauck writes a)\n e)lqei=n, taking the sense to be: ‘I shall be made to believe that I could return,’=o(/ti e)/lqoimi a)/n. But (a) a)nelqei=n is confirmed by the context: cp. Ar. Pax 445ei)s fw=s a)nelqei=n, etc.: and (b) it gives a more direct and forcible sense.

ou(kei/nou path/r, Sisyphus. The scholiast gives the story as it was told (probably) by the logographer Pherecydes (flor. 470 B.C.?), who is quoted in ref. to Sisyphus by the schol. on Il. 6. 153.Sisyphus had directed his wife to leave him unburied. On reaching the shades, he denounced her impiety to Pluto, and obtained leave to go back and punish her. Having thus returned to earth, he stayed there,—e(/ws (adds the scholiast) met' a)na/gkhs kath=lqen. Theognis (v. 702) is the earliest witness:—*sisu/fou *ai)oli/dew, | o(/s te kai\ e)c *)ai+/dew polui+dri/h|sin a)nh=lqen, | pei/sas *persefo/nhn ai(muli/oisi lo/gois.

sumfe/roi, be your helper: a sense derived from the idea of sharing a burden: El. 946cunoi/sw pa=n o(/sonper a)\n sqe/nw. Not, ‘be in accord with you’ (vobiscum conspiret, Herm. : Ar. Lys. 166a)nh/r, e)a\n mh\ th=| gunaiki\ sumfe/rh|).
ta/de: for the plur. cp. 524 n.
a)\n with dei=cai.
new\s a)/gont), leading him ashore from his ship: cp. 613 n.
ou)/: is clearly right: cp. 993, 997, Tr. 415.Welcker's ou( (=‘whereas’) is much weaker: so, too, is h)= qa=sson, or ou) qa=sson...a)/poun;
plei=ston e)xqi/sths: cp. O. C. 743plei=ston... | ka/kistos, n.
a)/poun, deprived of the use of one's feet, xwlo/n: cp. Metaphys. 4. 22 le/getai...a)/poun kai\ tw=| mh\ e)/xein o(/lws po/das kai\ tw=| fau/lous.
pa/nta lekta/, k.t.l. For the omission of me/n in the epanaphora cp. 779: Ant. 806 n.

w(s … o(ri/zh|. The MS. o(ri/zei cannot be defended here, either with w(s as=‘since,’ or with the conjecture e(/ws as=‘while yet.’ The words clearly express the eagerness of Ph. to put a space of sea between himself and his pursuer. And he has no reason to believe that his pursuer is still distant.
tou)k prw/|ras: cp. 1451 kata\ pru/mnan.
a)nh=|, as in 764: and so 705 e)canei/h. Cp. Her. 2. 113ou) ga\r a)ni/ei (pres.) ta\ pneu/mata.
stelou=men: 571 n.

ou)/k, a)lla\ k.t.l. The tone of this idiomatic phrase would be nearly rendered (here, at least) by ‘nay, but.’ The ou)k refers to a)ei\ kalo\s plou=s k.t.l.: ‘This is not a case of flight from imminent peril; but (on the contrary) our pursuers also are being delayed.’ Cp. Plat. Euthyd. 277A a)=ra su\ ou) manqa/neis; ...ou)/k, a)ll), h)= d' o(/s, manqa/nw.—I do not think, then, that any alteration is necessary. Of the conjectures (see cr. n.) Doederlein's oi)=d): is perhaps the best. O. Heine's a)ll' ou)xi\...; is also possible.
a)ll), followed by a)ll) in 647: n. on 524 f.

xwrw=men … labw
. The subject to the plur. verb being e)gw\ kai\ su/, the sing. partic. agrees with su/,—a constr. harsher in form than in reality. Cp. Ar. Av. 202deuri\ ga e)sba\s... | e)/peit' a)negei/ras th
 e)mh
 a)hdo/na, | kalou=men au)tou/s. Aesch. Eum. 141a)ni/stw, ka)polakti/sas' u(/pnon | i)dw/meq). Eur. Med. 564kai\ cunarth/sas ge/nos | eu)daimonoi=men (so Elms., for -oi/hn). Dem. or. 14 § 15 a)peble/yate pro\s a)llh/lous, w(s au)to\s me
 e(/kastos ou) poih/swn.—Dobree's conjecture, labo/nq), was suggested by Soph. O. C. 1164, where the MSS. give molo/nt) at the end of the v.: but that should prob. be mo/non.
kai/per ou) pollw=n a)/po: and so it will not take long to choose them out. For the use of the prep., cp. Thuc. 1. 110o)li/goi a)po\ pollw=n.

new/s ge th=s e)mh=s e)/pi. The correction of the MS. e)/ni to e)/pi is necessary and certain. Of e)/ni (=e)/nesti) only three explanations are possible. (1) Some hold that the gen. new/s depends on the idea of e)/sw or e)/ndon implied in e)/ni: ‘is contained in my ship.’ Cp. Ai. 1274e(rke/wn... e)gkeklh|me/nous: Eur. Ph. 451 to/nd' ei)sede/cw teixe/wn. But there the notion ‘within’ is implied far more clearly than by e)/ni here. (2) Or new/s is an absolute local gen., ‘in the ship’; cp. El. 900e)sxa/ths d' o(rw= pura=s...bo/struxon. (3) Others take e)/ni with labei=n supplied from labw/n in 645: ‘what is there which it is not possible to obtain from my ship?’ No one of these views is tenable.

pa/nu is fitting enough, where he is dwelling on the value of the herb to him; and it certainly is not weaker than the substitutes which have been proposed for it (see cr. n.). Meineke (Analecta Soph. p. 317) makes the arbitrary assumption that pa/nu was not used by Soph. in dialogue; though it is certainly used by him in anapaests ( Soph. O. C. 144).
ti/ ga\r e)/t): ‘Now what else...?’
ga/r introduces the question, as oft., when a speaker turns to a new point: cp. 1405: Ai. 101ei)=en: ti/ ga\r dh\ pai=s o( tou= *laerti/ou, | pou= soi tu/xhs e(/sthken;

ei)/ moi/ ti to/cwn (‘I fain would fetch) any of these arrows that may have been overlooked and may have slipped away from me.’ The vaguer interpretation, ‘any appurtenance of this bow,’ is not the best here. Philoctetes, who has been afield in quest of game, carries his bow and his quiver (cp. 291 n.); but he is afraid that one or more of the arrows may have been accidentally left behind in the cave. to/ca, in poetry, can mean either (1) bow, (2) bow and arrows, or (3) arrows. For sense (2), cp. Il. 21. 502: Leto picks up the arrows which had dropped from the quiver of Artemis (492 taxe/es d' e)/kpipton o)i+stoi/):—sunai/nuto kampu/la to/ca | peptw=t' a)/lludis a)/lla meta\ strofa/liggi koni/hs (where kampu/la is the epithet of the bow only). For (3), Eur. Ion 524ei)/sw to/ca pneumo/nwn labei=n.
a)phmelhme/non, a rare compound, of which this perf. partic. occurs in Her. 3. 129.

parerru/hken, has slipped aside (as by dropping from the quiver); not, ‘has slipped from my memory.’ Cp. Xen. An. 4. 4a)leeino
 h)=n h( xiw
 e)pipeptwkui=a, o(/tw| mh\ parerruei/h (slip off). Plato has the word in a fig. sense, Legg. 781 A polla\ u(mi=n pare/rrei, polu\ a)/meinon a)
 e)/xonta ei) no/mwn e)/tuxen h)\ ta\ nu=n (escaped your care).
w(s li/pw mh/=w(s mh\ l.: cp. 67 n.: labei=n: cp. 81.

ou) ga\r a)/ll' e)/st), a)ll' a(\ k.t.l. L's reading, ou) gar a/ll) (sic) e)/sq' a(\ clearly points to the reading in the text, since a)ll) might easily have been omitted by a scribe who mistook it for a repetition of a)/ll). And *g confirms this. For a)/llos closely followed by a)lla/, Seyffert cp. Od. 8. 311a)ta\r ou)/ ti moi ai)/tios a)/llos, | a)lla\ tokh=e du/w (cp. ib. 11. 558). Remark that this reading is further corroborated by the form of the statement. It is peculiarly Sophoclean to have three clauses, in which the second is opposed to the first, and the third repeats the sense of the first,—as here a(\ basta/zw= tau=t): see on Ant. 465.—A's reading a)/lla g' e)/sq' a(\ is weaker, and also less likely to have generated L's.
w(/ste after e)/stin, as sometimes after dunato/n, e)qe/lw, de/omai, pei/qw, etc.: cp. O. C. 969 n.

qeo/n. So the Arcadian Parthenopaeus swears by his spear-head (ai)xmh/), h)\n e)/xei ma=llon qeou= | se/bein pepoiqw/s ( Aesch. Theb. 529). Idas, one of the Argonauts, says, ou)d' e)/m' o)fe/llei | *zeu\s to/son, o(ssa/tio/n per e)mo\n do/ru (Apoll. Rhod. 1. 468). Mezentius: Dextra mihi deus et telum, quod missile libro, | Nunc adsint ( Verg. Aen. 10. 773). Capaneus: Ades O mihi dextera tantum: | Tu praesens bellis et inevitable numen; | Te voco, te solam, superum contemptor, adoro (Statius 9. 548). Here, however, Neoptolemus regards the bow as a ‘god,’ not so much because it is invincible, as because it had belonged to Heracles.—For the fig. use of qeo/s, cp. O. T. 27 n.
cumfe/rh| cannot mean, ‘what is pleasing to you’ (as Nauck takes it, ‘was genehm ist’), but only, ‘what is profitable for you.’ The latter sense, however, is quite consistent with e)rw= in 660.

kai\ mh\n … ge: Ant. 221 n.— pa/res, ‘let it go,’ ‘think no more about it.’ There is no real ground for thinking this word corrupt. parie/nai can mean omittere no less than concedere. Cp. Ant. 1193kou)de\n parh/sw...e)/pos. Legg. 754 A mh\ toi/nun gignw/skonte/s ge parw=men au)to\ a)/rrhton. Pind. P. 1. 86mh\ pari/ei kala/.
o(/sia … qe/mis: cp. El. 432ou) ga/r soi qe/mis | ou)d' o(/sion (n.).
o(/s g), as 1215, O. T. 35, etc. The relative, with this causal force, refers to an antecedent (soi/) which is understood: O. C. 263 n.
fa/os, life, in place of imminent death.
de/dwkas, followed by an aor. (666): cp. 928 f.
xqo/n' *oi)tai/an: 490 n.—The repetition of the pron. o(/s has much the same rhetorical effect as the repetition of the verb (de/dwkas) would have with us.

a)ne/sthsas pe/ra. If pe/ra is genuine, the sense is:—‘When I was under the feet of my foes, thou hast lifted me up, (placing me) beyond their reach.’ pe/ra could be either prep. with e)xqrw=n, or adv.: the former is best for contrast with e)/nerqen. While suffering in Lemnos, Ph. was e)/nerqen tw=n e)xqrw=n. If he is restored to his home in Greece (and he assumes that this is certain), then they can touch him no more. Thus pe/ra blends the thought of conveyance across the sea with the image of ‘uplifting’ which is expressed by a)ne/sthsas. The very fact of such a blending seems in favour of pe/ra. Sophocles not seldom admits a partial fusion of the figurative with the literal: see on Soph. O. T. 886, Soph. O. T. 1300 ff., Soph. Ant. 117.—No emendation is satisfactory. If we read e)xqrw=n e)/nerqen o)/nt' a)ne/sthsa/s m) u(/per, we should have to suppose that the loss of the letters m' u(/ had led to the expansion of per into pe/ra (pe/rai in L). But such a loss is not very likely. In Soph. Ant. 1301, where pe/ric prob. arose from peri\ c[i/fei], the lost letters were the last of the verse. I had thought of a)nasth/sas pa/rei: but prefer to retain pe/ra.—Cp. Soph. El. 1090zw/|h|s moi kaqu/perqen | xeiri\ kai\ plou/tw| toso/nd' e)xqrw=n, o(/son | nu=n u(po/xeir nai/eis.
tau=ta (nom.) pare/stai soi, (w(/ste) kai\ qigga/nein (au)tw=n). qigga/nw never takes an accus. in class. Greek: Ant. 546 n.

kai\ do/nti dou=nai. These words are not only genuine, but mark a delicate turn of phrase. Instead of saying, ‘You shall be allowed to handle the bow, on condition of returning it,’ he says, ‘You shall be allowed to handle the bow and to return it.’ The clause kai\ do/nti dou=nai coheres closely with qigga/nein. The condition which qualifies the boon is thus lightly and courteously hinted,— being inserted between the words (qigga/nein, ka)cepeu/casqai) which express the privileges conceded. Cp. 774 ou) doqh/setai | plh\n soi/ te ka)moi/.—The aorist dou=nai expresses the moment of giving, and e)peu/casqai the moment of vaunting; while the pres. qigga/nein denotes the continuing act of touching. Cp. Dem. or. 2 § 26 polu\ ga\r r(a=|on e)/xontas fula/ttein h)\ kth/sasqai pa/nta pe/fuken.

669 The acc. mo/non is correct; it represents the nom. of the direct form, eu)/xei e)piyau=sai mo/nos. Here, however, after do/nti, it is slightly awkward. Nauck wishes to read mo/nw|. I should prefer to keep mo/non and insert s) after a)reth=s. The direct form implied would then be, eu)/xei se\ e)piyau=sai mo/non. Cp. Plat. Gorg. 474B e)gw\ ga\r dh\ oi)=mai kai\ e)me\ kai\ se\... h(gei=sqai.
eu)ergetw=n, by kindling the pyre for Heracles: cp. 801 ff.

These three verses, called ‘manifesto spurii’ by Dindorf, are clearly genuine. If they are rejected, then Neoptolemus deigns no reply beyond xwroi=s a)\n ei)/sw to the gracious and cordial speech of Philoctetes. In proof that the verses are pointless, Dindorf says:—‘Neque enim quidquam beneficii a Philocteta accepit Neoptolemus, ut eu)= paqw/n dici possit.’ Blaydes, though he does not bracket the verses, assents to this argument:—‘Certainly eu)= paqw\n cannot well apply to Neoptolemus.’ But eu)= paqw/n refers, of course, to Philoctetes. Neoptolemus means:—‘I am not sorry that chance drove me to Lemnos, and thus enabled me to gain your friendship. One who is ready to requite a benefit (viz., conveyance to Greece) by such a kindness as this (the promised loan of the bow), must indeed prove to be a priceless friend.’

eu)= dra=n eu)= paqw
: O. C. 1202(ou) kalo
) au)to
 me
 eu)= | pa/sxein paqo/nta d' ou)k e)pi/stasqai ti/nein. Thuc. 2. 40ou) ga pa/sxontes eu)= a)lla\ drw=ntes ktw/meqa tou\s fi/lous.—So, of injury, Soph. O. C. 271paqw
 me
 a)nte/drwn.
kth/matos: cp. Ant. 701e)moi\ de\ sou= pra/ssontos eu)tuxw=s, pa/ter, | ou)k e)/stin ou)de\n kth=ma timiw/teron.

xwroi=s a)
 ei)/sw: Tr. 624stei/xois a)
 h)/dh. Cavallin gives these words, as well as the following, to Philoctetes, because the invitation to enter the cave ought to come from him, whose home it is. But then the words kai\ se/ g' ei)sa/cw lose their proper force; for we have to understand Ph. as saying,—‘Pray enter: — or rather —I will lead you in.’ But ge can only emphasise se/: and therefore xwroi=s a)
 ei)/sw must be said to Philoctetes. In these words Neoptolemus reverts to the wish which he had already expressed (645, 651) that Ph. should fetch from the cave anything that he needed for the voyage.

to\ ga\r | nosou=n: for the art. as penult. word of the v., cp. O. T. 231; O. C. 265, O. C. 351: Ant. 67, Ant. 78.to\ … nosou=n, my sick estate: cp. Thuc. 1. 36to\ me\n dedio\s au)tou=...to\ de\ qarsou=n (his mood of fear or courage).

div2.p: The only proper sta/simon of the play. 1st strophe (676—690)=1st antistrophe (691—705): 2nd str. (706— 717)=2nd antistr. (718—729). For the metres see Metrical Analysis.

We have already had two short choral songs,—strophe and antistrophe,—in which the Chorus sought to aid Neoptolemus by confirming the story of his quarrel with the Atreidae (391—402), and by affecting to believe that Greece is indeed the goal of his voyage (507— 518). We need not suppose that the pity which they expressed in vv. 507 ff. was wholly feigned; still, that particular expression of it belonged to the part which they were acting.

It is otherwise now. The Chorus are alone. Down to the end of the 2nd strophe (717) they are simply uttering what they feel. Then at v. 718 Philoctetes and Neoptolemus reappear from the cave; and in the 2nd antistrophe the Chorus once more seek to help their master's design.

div3.p: e)ch/kous), as if by rumour from a far-off place: cp. Aesch. Eum. 397pro/swqen e)ch/kousa klhdo/nos boh/n. Above, in 378 and 472, this compound was merely a strengthened a)kou/w.

o)/pwpa d' ou) ma/la. Cp. Hieron 1. 12 oi( de\ tu/rannoi ou) ma/la (nequaquam) a)mfi\ qewri/as e)/xousin. The emphasis contrasts the sufferings known only by hearsay with those which have just been so vividly placed before their eyes.

to\n pela/tan. Ixion treacherously murdered his father-in-law, *dhi+oneu/s, and, when no mortal would minister the rites of purification to him, was cleansed of his crime by Zeus. He requited this grace by attempting the bed of Hera; and Zeus then commanded Hermes to bind him on a wheel of fire in the lower world.

The comparison with Ixion is the more forcible here, since reference has just been made to the gratitude shown by Philoctetes (672). Ixion was the great example of ingratitude. Cp. Pind. P. 2. 21qew=n d' e)fetmai=s *)ici/ona fanti\ tau=ta brotoi=s | le/gein e)n ptero/enti troxw=| | panta=| kulindo/menon: | to\n eu)erge/tan a)ganai=s a)moibai=s e)poixome/nous ti/nesqai.

le/ktrwn … tw=n *dio\s: cp. 1406 be/lesi toi=s *(hrakle/ous. Buttmann preferred the Triclinian tou= *dio/s,—which is admissible (cp. Ant. 10 n.),—as emphasising the proper name; but tw=n is clearly right.

kata\ droma/d' a)/mpuka … *kro/nou pai=s. As given in the MSS. (see cr. n.), these verses are longer than the corresponding vv. of the antistrophe, 693 f., par' w(=|sto/non...ai(mathro/n. If both *)ici/ona and de/smion are to be kept here, the antistrophic verses must be expanded. But those verses appear to be sound as they stand. The question is, then, whether *)ici/ona or de/smion should be omitted here. I prefer to omit *)ici/ona, for two reasons.

(1) The poet's tendency to omit the proper name in mythical allusion, when the context made his meaning clear, might be illustrated from Ant, 133, where Capaneus is described, yet not named; and from 966—987 of the same play, where Cleopatra—whose fate is being compared with Antigone's—is only indicated as the mother of the Phineidae (980) and the daughter of Boreas (985).

(2) de/smion is not, indeed, necessary to the sense. As in prose we have a)nabiba/zein e)pi\ to
 troxo/n ( Andoc. or. 1 § 43), so, here, the sense would be adequately given by kat' a)/mpuka … e)/balen. And it might fairly be suggested that de/smion had crept into the text from the schol., kat' a)/mpuka dh\] kata\ to
 tro/xon (which should be troxo
, see Soph. Ant. 1065 n.) dedeme/non. Then, omitting de/smion, we might keep the order of the MS. words, merely changing kat) to a)n):

*)ici/on' a)n' a)/mpuka dh\ droma/d' w(s e)/balen (where dh/ = ‘as men say’). But, on the other hand, poetical considerations seem in favour of de/smion. It adds force to the picture of a terrible doom imposed by an irresistible power. —Other views are discussed in the Appendix.

a)/mpuka, here, the rim of the wheel; elsewhere always ‘head-band.’ But its etymology (a)mpi/=a)mfi/) might easily suggest this poet. use, esp. as droma/da (perh. suggested by troxo/s) helps it out. The schol. seems to have read a)/mpuka.
Cp. Hesych., a)/mpukes, troxoi/: ou(/tw *sofoklh=s e)n *filokth/th. Musgrave's a)/ntuga is certainly tempting, and may be right; but it does not seem necessary.
tou=d) = h)\ to/nd): cp. 597 qate/rou, n.

ou)/t' e)/rcas tin), ou)/ ti nosfi/sas. A partial reminiscence of Od. 4. 690ou)/te tina\ r(e/cas e)cai/sion ou)/te ti ei)pw/n, as Eustathius saw (p. 763, Od. 2): *(omhriko\n de/ ti kai\ para\ *sofoklei= e)n *filokth/th| to\ ou)/te ti r(e/cas, kako\n dhladh/: ou(/tw ga\r noei=tai, ei) kai\ pantelw=s e)kei= siwpa=tai to\ r(exqe/n. Here the last three words prove two things,—viz., that Eustath. read ou)/te nosfi/sas, and that ou)/te ti r(e/cas in his citation of Sophocles was a mere slip for ou)/t' e)/rcas tin): since, if his text of our verse had really contained ti, he could not have said, siwpa=tai to\ r(exqe/n. (He has other such slips: see Appendix on Ant. 292.) Schneidewin's emendation, ou)/ ti for ou)/te, appears certain. e)/rdein tina/ ti can mean, ‘to do a wrong to a man’: e)/rdein tina/, without ti, could not possibly mean it. Ought we, then, to write ou)k (for ou)/t)) e)/rcas? Probably not. Cp. Ant. 249ou)/te tou genh=|dos h)=n | plh=gm), ou) dike/llhs e)nbolh/, and O. C. 972 n.— nosfi/sas, robbed, defrauded. We find not only nosfi/zein tina/ tinos, but also nosfi/zein tina/ ti (as Pind. N. 6. 64se/ t' e)no/sfise... | kla=ros...a)/nqe) *)olumpia/dos); and this is the constr. here. The antithesis is between bia (e)/rcas) and do/los (nosfi/sas): Ixion had murdered his father-in-law, and had sought to steal the love of Hera.

i)/sos w)\n i)/sois, lit. ‘equitable towards the equitable’ (i)/sois dat. of relation),—respecting the rights of others, as they respected his. In describing a man of peaceful and estimable character, the Greek tendency is to say, ‘he neither did nor suffered wrong’; i.e., he was not aggressive, nor was he forced into unpleasant relations with his fellow-men by their action,—since he provoked no enmities. See, e.g., Lysias or. 12 § 4 ou)deni\ pw/pote ou)/te h(mei=s ou)/te e)kei=nos di/khn ou)/te e)dikasa/meqa ou)/te e)fu/gomen, a)ll' ou(/tws w)|kou=men dhmokratou/menoi w(/ste mh/te ei)s tou\s a)/llous e)camarta/nein mh/te u(po\ tw=n a)/llwn a)dikei=sqai. This is the Athenian ideal of the xrhsto/s, e)pieikh/s, a)pra/gmwn. And this is what i)/sos w)\n i)/sois expresses here. It does not imply that he dealt with i)/soi in one way, and with a)/dikoi in another, but merely denotes that reciprocity of fair dealing which his fairness caused. Hence the version, ‘living at peace with his fellowmen,’ is truer to the sense than (e.g.), ‘just among the just.’ Cp. Ai. 267koino\s koinoi=si lupei=sqai, to share the grief of friends who grieve. For i)/sos as=aequus, said of persons, cp. O. T. 677 n.

L has i)/sws (sic) e)n i)/sois. The objection to reading e)/n g) is twofold. (1) The idea suggested would then be the same as in Eur. fr. 693 (quoted by Schneidewin), toi=s me\n dikai/ois e)/ndikos, toi=s d' au)= kakoi=s | ...pole/mios. Here, however, the point is the generally inoffensive life of Ph. ,— not the distinction between his conduct towards just and unjust men respectively. (2) The participle w)/n, though not indispensable, is very desirable. It is possible that the blunder i)/sws in L may be connected with the original presence of w)/n in the text.
w)/lluq): for the impf., cp. 252 diwllu/mhn.

The MS. text here is w)/lluq' w(=d' a)naci/ws: to/de qau=m' e)/xei me. A comparison with the antistrophe (701 f.) strongly confirms Erfurdt's transposition, qau=ma/ m' e)/xei, and Dindorf's insertion of toi after to/de, since to/de toi qau=ma/ m' e)/xei then corresponds with the certainly genuine words in 702, to/t' a)\n ei)luo/menos. The next question is how w)/lluq' w(=d' a)naci/ws should be reconciled with the MS. words e(/rpei ga\r a)/llot' a)/lla| in v. 701. Hermann's change of ei(=rpe ga\r to ei(=rpe d) has been generally received; it is gentler than that of w)/lluq) to w)le/keq) (Dindorf), or to w)/lluto th=|d) (Campbell). It is less easy to decide whether a)naci/ws or a)/lla| should be altered. Keeping a)/lla|, Dindorf changes a)naci/ws to a)ti/mws, and Wecklein to a)eikw=s: Linwood proposed a)noi/ktws. We must then suppose that a)naci/ws was a gloss, since such a corruption of the letters would be difficult. But it seems better to keep a)naci/ws, and to suppose, with Campbell, that a)/lla| has come from a)ll(ax)a=|.—See Appendix.

a)mfipla/ktwn: the Doric form is clearly required in a strophe which contains pela/tan, moi/ra|, qnatw=n, biota/n. Cp. Ai. 597a(li/plaktos, El. 484xalko/plaktos. For the active sense, cp. O. T. 969 n. The a)mfi/plakta r(o/qia are those which beat around the rocky promontory near his cave (1455). Hesych. defines r(o/qion as ku=ma meta\ yo/fou gino/menon: cp. Ant. 259 n.—The corrupt klu/zwn in L (for klu/wn), which violates both sense and metre, was taken by the schol. as=kluzo/menos. (Buttmann strangely accepted this, comparing, for the gen., the Homeric lou/esqai...potamoi=o.)

biota\n kate/sxen, obtinuit, ‘kept his hold upon’ the life which might well have slipped from him. This is a common sense of kate/xw, though a bold application of it. Not, sustinuit, ‘endured,’ as Dindorf renders.

i(/n' au)to\s h)=n pro/souros, where he was his own sole neighbour. So when a man sends no a)ggeli/a before him, he is said to arrive as his own a)/ggelos: when no herald precedes him, he is au)to\s kh=ruc (n. on 500). Cp. Aesch. Cho. 866mo/nos w)\n e)/fedros | dissoi=s, ‘his own sole supporter against two foes,’ i.e., there is no e)/fedros at his back, to fight the man who vanquishes him. Lucian Timon 43 qeoi=s que/tw kai\ eu)wxei/sqw, mo/nos e(autw=| gei/twn kai\ o(/moros (where o(/moros strongly suggests that Lucian was thinking of our passage). Martial 5. 24. 8 Hermes (the gladiator) suppositicius sibi ipse, ‘his own substitute,’ i.e., never requiring one, because never defeated. Seneca Herc. Fur. act 1 sc. 1 Quaeris Alcidae parem? | Nemo est nisi ipse. Massinger, Duke of Milan act 4 sc. 3, ‘And, but herself, admits no parallel.’ —Remark that e(autw=| (which Meineke sought to represent by changing h)=n to oi() is not needed, since pro/souros=‘near the borders,’ i.e., ‘neighbour to the place’ (in which Ph. was), and thus represents, not gei/twn simply, but gei/twn th=| xw/ra|. For the Ionic form cp. o(/mouros, cu/nouros, thlouro/s ( Soph. O. T. 194 n.).

ou)k e)/xwn ba/sin, without the power to walk; cp. 632 a)/poun. —Bothe's pro/souron ou)k e)/xwn ba/sin (‘hearing no footstep of neighbour’) is plausible at first sight. Then au)to\s h)=n =‘he was alone’ ( O. C. 1650 n.). But the vulgate is far more forcible. By his pro/doulon … ba/sin Seyffert meant, ‘having no foot to serve him.’—The conjecture, ou)x e)/xwn ba/sin | ou)/tin' e)s e)/gxwron (‘having access to no neighbour’) is very weak. Those who adopt it (cp. cr. n.) join kakogei/tona with sto/non: see next n.

kakogei/tona=kakw=n (or kakoi=s) gei/tona, a neighbour to his sufferings: i.e., one to be near him while he suffers. The word does not imply (as some have objected), ‘a neighbour in (i.e., sharing in) his sufferings.’ Nor is there any ground for saying that kakogei/twn could mean only kako\s gei/twn.

Compounds to which kako/s gives the first part are of two classes, according as the kako- element is (1) adj. or (2) subst. In class (1) there are again two types. (a) The commonest is that of kako/bios, =kako\n bi/on e)/xwn: i.e., the compound denotes ‘possessing’ the subst. as qualified by kako/s. (b) A rarer, chiefly poet., type is that of *kakoi+/lios as simply=kakh\ *)/ilios. In class (2) (a) the kako- is most often equiv. to the subst. kako/n or kaka/ in the acc., governed by a verb: as kakopoio/s=kaka\ poiw=n. (b) But sometimes this kako- represents a gen. or dat., depending on another noun: thus kako/mantis, ‘prophet of evil’ ( Aesch. Pers. 10 etc.)=kakw=n ma/ntis. Cratinus used kako/doulos as = kako\s dou/lois (‘cruel to slaves’), *qra=|ttai fr. 7. And so kakogei/twn could belong either to (1) b,= kako\s gei/twn: or, as it actually does here, to (2) b, kakw=n gei/twn. Cp. a(ligei/twn, a)strogei/twn, a)stugei/twn.

The schol. joined kakogei/tona as epithet with sto/non: par' w(=| dh\ to
 kako
 gei/tona, to
 ai(mathro
 sto/non, a)poklau/seie. And so Cavallin. Bugge, again, takes kakogei/tona as a subst., ‘his evil neighbour’ (i.e. ‘his disease’),—governed by sto/non ...a)poklau/seie: comparing El. 123ta/keis ...oi)mwga
 | ...*)agame/mnona.
par' w(=|: in the negative statement par' o(/tw| would be more usu.: cp. Ant. 220 n. For the optat. a)poklau/seien see on 281 a)rke/seien.

a)nti/tupon: Lucian De domo 3 th=s fwnh=s e)paniou/shs kata\ to\ a)nti/tupon kai\ pro\s au(th\n a)nastrefou/shs. The force of the epithet here is proleptic,—‘so as to excite a responsive lament.’ It reminds us that the cries of Ph. were answered by Echo alone (cp. 1459).

barubrw=ta … ai(mathro/n: the epithets of the no/sos are given to the sto/nos prompted by it: ‘a lament for a plague that gnawed his flesh and drained his blood.’ This is not too bold for the style of tragic lyrics; and the boldness was perhaps somewhat softened to a Greek ear by the fact that sto/non was in the acc. For, though this acc. is really ‘cognate’ to a)poklau/seie, yet the case itself might help to suggest that barubrw=ta and ai(mathro/n described the object of the klauqmo/s. With barubrw/s cp. diabo/ros (v. 7, n.). Cp. 208 au)da\ | trusa/nwr. Schneidewin cites also Aesch. Theb. 348blaxai\ d' ai(mato/essai | tw=n e)pimastidi/wn | a)rtitrefei=s bre/montai. It seems possible that this may have been in Soph. 's mind: but it is less bold, since blaxai\ ai(mato/essai tw=n e)pim. merely= blaxai\ tw=n ai(matoe/ntwn e)pim. (like nei=kos a)ndrw=n cu/naimon, etc.). A truer parallel is [Eur. ] Rhes. 260 kako/gambron | ...go/on, =go/on peri\ kakou= lambrou=. We might add Soph. El. 752fo/nion oi)mwgh\n klu/w. The conjectural insertions which have been made in these vv. are noticed in the Appendix on vv. 678 f.

o(\s ta
. The MS. text has ou)d' o(\s ta
,—a syllable too much. ou)d) may have been conjecturally added, to link this clause to the last; while ta
 is not so likely to have been inserted. And o(\s ta
 is intrinsically better here than ou)d' o(\s.

ai(ma/da: schol. th\n tou= ai(/matos r(u/sin. The word is found only here.— khki_ome/nan is usu. called passive. But it is surely rather a poet. middle form. A transitive khki/w occurs first in postclass. Greek (Rh. 4.600baru\n a)nakhki/ei a)tmo/n), while Phaedr. 251 B suffices to show that the intrans. khki/w was familiar in There Attic. is no other example of khki/omai. Cp. 784 khki=on. The i is short in Homer ( Il. 7. 262a)nakh/ki^on, Od. 5. 455kh/ki^e).
e(lke/wn, a disyll. by synizesis.

e)nqh/rou refers to the angry appearance of the ulcer, which has not been assuaged (h(merw/qh) by proper treatment; cp. Aesch. Ag. 562e)/nqhron tri/xa: Dioscorides 3. 11. 1 teqhriwme/non e(/lkos. H. N. 26. 14 efferantia se ulcera.

ei)/ tis e)mpe/soi, sc. ai(ma/s. This, the MS. reading, is plainly right. The verb e)mpi/ptw was regularly used with regard to an attack of disease: cp. Tr. 1253pri
 e)mpesei=n sparagmo/n: Thuc. 2. 48(o( loimo\s) e)s th
 *)aqhnai/wn po/lin e)capinai/ws e)ne/pese: ib. 49 lu\gc toi=s plei/osin e)ne/pipte kenh/. Cp. below. 808 (the disease) o)cei=a foita=| kai\ taxei=) a)pe/rxetai. In the next v. Schneidewin rightly gave e(lw/n for the MS. e(lei=n. For the constr. kateuna/seien fu/llois, e(lw
 (au)ta/), cp. Soph. O. C. 475(e)/reyon) neopo/kw| mallw=| labw/n (n.).

Some read ei)/ tin' e)mpe/soi, or ei(/ ti sumpe/soi, keeping e(lei=n: ‘if any leaf should fall in his way, to pluck,’ or, ‘if it should be his fortune to pluck any leaf.’ But e)mpi/ptein ought to be said of the wanderer, not of a stationary object which he finds. And sumpe/soi is too suggestive of a ‘coincidence’ to be a fitting word here.—Campbell, reading forba/dos e)/k te ga=s e(lei=n, takes the const. to be (ou)k h)=n) o(/stis kateuna/seien e(lei=n te (instead of e(/loi te). This is as if one said, ou)x ei)=xen o(/stis e)/lqoi kai\ bohqei=n.
forba/dos: cp. 391 pambw=ti: fr. 279 e)c *)wle/nou gh=s forba/dos komi/zomai.
ei(=rpe k.t.l. Join a)\n with ei(=rpe: cp. 290 n.: for ei)luo/menos, ib. As to the reading in these verses, see on 686 f. The phrase a)/llote a)llaxh=| occurs in Xen. Mem. 1. 4. 12.
pai=s … w(s: like a child that cannot yet walk firmly without the help of its nurse. Cp. Aesch. Eum. 38, where the aged priestess, tottering with fear, is said to be a)nti/pais.

o(/qen=e)kei=se o(/qen: cp. Xen. An. 1. 3§ 17 mh\ h(ma=s a)ga/gh| o(/qen ou)x oi)=o/n te e)/stai e)celqei=n. o(/qen u(pa/rxoi, after ei(=rpe a)/n, answers to o(/qen a)\n u(pa/rxh| after a primary tense: cp. 289 n.

eu)ma/reia … po/rou, ‘facility of resource,’—i.e., the means of supplying his needs. For eu)ma/reia cp. 284; for po/rou, Eur. Alc. 213ti/s a)\n po/ros kakw=n | ge/noito...; He had to find food, water, fuel, and the medicinal herb (285 ff., Eur. Alc. 649).—Not, ‘ease on his path’ (ease in movement), as if the search for the herb alone were meant. Some read po/rwn as=‘resources’: but, in this sense, the associations of the plur. would have been too prosaic for an Attic poet. For the theory that po/ron should be read, and taken with ei(=rpe, see Appendix on 695 f.
e)canei/h, remit its violence: 639 n.
dake/qumos, like dhci/qumos, qumodakh/s, qumobo/ros, etc.
i(era=s: cp. 391.
ai)/rwn denotes the simple act of lifting, and is thus more picturesque than ai)ro/menos. Cp. Ar. Ran. 1339ka/lpisi/ t' e)k potamw=n dro/son a)/rate.

a)/llwn, such as fruits, milk, etc.: from ai)/rwn we supply a word of more general sense. The gen. is partitive ( Xen. Cyr. 1. 4. 20labw
 tw=n...i(/ppwn te kai\ a)ndrw=n). This is better than to repeat forba
 with it (‘food consisting in other things’). Such a constr. would be awkward when forba
 is in apposition with spo/ron. tw=n, relat. (14)= tou/twn a(/.

a)lfhstai/. The popular deriv., from a)/lfi and e)d (‘meal-eating’), may possibly have been in the poet's mind here; though this inference would be stronger if he had placed the word in closer connection with spo/ron. Curtius, on the other hand, can fairly cite Aesch. Th. 771a)ndrw=n a)lfhsta=n o)/lbos a)/gan paxunqei/s, in support of the sense ‘workers,’ ‘earners,’ men who eat their bread in the sweat of their brow (rt a)lf, Lat. lab-os).
a)ne/res, with epic a_, as Tr. 1010, O. T. 869a)ne/rwn. There is a reminiscence of Od. 13. 261a)ne/ras a)lfhsta/s, as well as of ib. 9. 89 oi(/tines a)ne/res ei)=en e)pi\ xqoni\ si=ton e)/dontes.

ptanoi=s is a purely poetical image for speed, while the Homeric ptero/entes o)i+stoi/ more readily suggests the actual feathers on the arrow ( Tr. 567komh/thn i)o/n: Aesch. fr. 135 mhxanh\n pterw/matos: Eur. Or. 274to/cwn pterwta\s glufi/das).

i)oi=s (restored by Brunck) was evidently lost through the likeness of ending in ptanoi=s. Then the gap was filled by inserting ptanw=n (to agree with to/cwn), and ptanoi=s was explained as, ‘with birds’ ( Ai. 168pthnw=n a)ge/lai).
yuxa/, o(\s: cp. Il. 18. 177ou)de\ ga\r ou)de\ bi/h *(hraklh=os fu/ge *kh=ra, | o(/sper fi/ltatos e)/ske *dii\ *kroni/wni a)/nakti. Cp. Ant. 341 n.
o(\s mhd), ‘one who did not’...: the generic mh/ with causal force: cp. 170 n.
h(/sqh, with a gen., such as follows verbs of enjoying, a)polau/w, eu)wxou=mai, etc.: Il. 11. 780au)ta\r e)pei\ ta/rphmen e)dhtu/os h)de\ poth=tos.
oi)noxu/tou: oi)no/x. pw=ma=oi)/nou kexume/nou p.: cp. 208 n., Eur. Cycl. 66krh/nais par' u(droxu/tois.

deke/tei xro/nw|. The simple dat. here denotes the time within which a thing has not happened (cp. 769). For this sense e)n is usu. added. But, as e)n xro/nw| makrw=| (235), and xro/nw| makrw=| simply (598 n.), can alike mean ‘after a time,’ so the use of the simple dat. is extended to that sense for which e)n is more specially needed,—‘within a time.’ The acc., deke/th xro/non, which Blaydes reads, is less suitable here. The point is that, for ten years, Ph. has not once tasted wine. A prose-writer would usu. express this by de/ka e)tw=n: cp. Plat. Gorg. 448A ou)dei/s me/ pw h)rw/thke kaino
 ou)de
 pollw=n e)tw=n. In our v., the acc. would rather suggest that Ph. had not had ten years continuous enjoyment of wine. Cp. Lys. or. 19 § 60 o)li/gon me
 xro/non du/nait' a)/n tis pla/sasqai to
 tro/pon to
 au(tou= (the dissimulation being continuous): e)n e(bdomh/konta de\ e)/tesin ou)d' a)
 ei(=s la/qoi ponhro\s w)/n (i.e., at some moment or other within the 70 years he will be found out).

leu/sswn, absol., looking about him, o(/pou gnoi/h (to see) where he could perceive (stagnant water), prosenw/ma, he used to bend his way towards it. ei)s stato
 u(/dwr is joined with prosenw/ma, instead of standing (without ei)s) as object to gnoi/h. The latter is oblique for o(/pou gnw=| (delib. subjunct.). Cp. Ai. 890a)/ndra mh\ leu/ssein o(/pou: O. C. 135o(
 e)gw\ leu/sswn peri\ pa=n ou)/pw | du/namai te/menos gnw=nai pou= moi/ | pote nai/ei (n.). prosenw/ma intrans.: cp. 168 n.—The usage of leu/ssein in Soph. makes this constr. preferable to the other, which is possible: leu/sswn ei)s stato
 u(/dwr (fixing his gaze on it), o(/pou gnoi/h, wherever he might perceive it (oblique of o(/pou a)
 gnw=|).— stato
 … u(/dwr, water collected in stagnant pools: cp. Arist. fr. 207 (Berl. ed. p. 1515 b 25) pro/sfato/n e)sti kai\ ne/on u(/dwr to\ u(o/menon, e(/wlon de\ kai\ palaio
 to\ limnai=on. Her. 2. 108platute/roisi e)xre/wnto toi=si po/masi, e)k frea/twn xrew/menoi (‘somewhat brackish’). Odysseus remembered a spring near the cave (21), and Ph. speaks of krh=nai (1461): but the imagination of the Chorus e)pi\ to\ mei=zon pa/nta deinoi=.
a)ndrw=n a)g., Peleus and Achilles; cp. 384.

u(panth/sas in prose would mean, ‘having come to meet,’ and would take a dat. A poet might feel that the gen. was sufficiently warranted by the Homeric a)nth/sw ga\r e)gw\ tou=d' a)ne/ros ( Il. 16. 423), etc.: indeed, the gen. differs from the dat. only by its more vivid suggestion of the idea, ‘face to face’ (a)nti/on tino/s). Cp. 320 n. Here the phrase, ‘having come face to face’ with him, suggests not merely the good fortune of the meeting, but the intercourse,—frank on the side of Philoctetes,—which had followed it.—As Ph. and Neoptolemus are now seen to be leaving the cave, the Chorus once more speaks language designed to support N.'s plan.
a)nu/sei eu)dai/mwn (sc. w)/n, cp. Ant. 177), will finish his course in happiness; =teleutw=n eu)daimonh/sei. (Not, I think, ‘will succeed in becoming happy,’ sc. gene/sqai.)
e)k kei/nwn (neut.) after those troubles: cp. 271.
pontopo/rw|: epith. of nai+/ in Ai. 250.

dou/rati: the only example of this epic form in Soph. (for dori/ and do/rei cp. Soph. O. C. 1304). Aesch. has douri/klutos, douri/plhktos, and Eur. dou/rata. Cp. Pind. P. 4. 27ei)na/lion do/ru (trabs), Aesch. Pers. 411e)p' a)/llhn (sc. nau=n) a)/llos hu)/qunen do/ru.
plh/qei … mhnw=n, after the ten years at Lemnos: 598 n.

patri/an is prob. a true correction of patrw/|an. There is no other instance in Soph. of patrw=|os with the 2nd syll. short (though he often shortens ai before a vowel, Soph. Ant. 1310). In Eur. there are a few such instances, but in all of them pa/trios should be restored, as by Porson in Eur. Hec. 78(=82 Dind.). As to the sense, either word would serve here: properly, patri/an=ancestral; patrw/|an, belonging to one's father: but Tragedy does not always observe the distinction (cp. 398 n.: conversely, O. C. 736qew=n patrw/|wn=patri/wn).

*malia/dwn: the Ionic form (cp. 4 n.), which the MSS. give, can hardly be kept here: cp. 688 a)mfipla/ktwn. *mal. numfa=n is more naturally joined with au)la\n than (as Cavallin prefers) with o)/xqas: ‘his ancestral abode, haunt of the Malian nymphs,’ is a phrase which suggests the hills, woods and streams of Malis. So the nymphs of Helicon ( O. T. 1109), Parnassus ( Ant. 1128), and Lemnos (below, Ant. 1454) are associated with the rural scenery of those places. For au)lh/ in the general sense, ‘abode,’ cp. Ant. 786a)grono/mois au)lai=s: Eur. Alc. 259neku/wn e)s au)la/n.

par' o)/xqas. Unless, with Blaydes, we change *sperxeiou= te to *sperxeioi=o, the acc. is necessary here. The MSS. give o)/xqais. For other instances in which the case of the noun after para/ has prob. been corrupted, cp. nn. on Ant. 966, Ant. 1123 f. As to the topography, cp. 490 n.

o( xa/lkaspis a)nh, Heracles. The epithet has an archaeological interest. In the Homeric poems, when reference is made to the exploits of Heracles, his weapon is the bow ( Il. 5. 395: Od. 8. 224, Od. 11. 607). Some ancient writers, however, expressly say that the equipment of Heracles with bow, club, and lion's skin was a comparatively late invention of the poets, and that in the oldest works of art he was represented with the armour of the ordinary Homeric warrior. According to Strabo (15. 688), the innovation could be traced back to the epic *(hra/kleia, ascribed to Peisander (circ. 650 B.C.): kai\ h( tou= *(hrakle/ous de\ stolh\ toiau/th polu\ newte/ra th=s *trwikh=s mnh/mhs e)sti/, pla/sma tw=n th
 *)hra/kleian poihsa/ntwn, ei)/te *pei/sandros h)=n, ei)/t' a)/llos tis: ta\ d' a)rxai=a zo/ana ou)x ou(/tw dieskeu/astai (implying that he had seen old images or statues in which Heracles had armour). Athenaeus (12. 512 F) quotes Megacleides (who wrote peri\ *(omh/rou, prob. in the 4th cent. B.C.), as referring the invention to Stesichorus (c. 620 B.C.), and adding that Xanthus, an earlier lyric poet, had clad Heracles in the Homeric armour:—tau=ta pla/sai prw=ton *sthsi/xoron to
 *(imerai=on. kai\ *ca/nqos d' o( melopoio/s, presbu/teros w)
 *sthsixo/rou,...ou) tau/thn au)tw=| periti/qhsi th
 stolh/n, a)lla\ th
 *(omhrikh/n. Strabo and Megacleides, then, agree thus far,— that the invention was not older than the 7th cent. B.C.

In this play Heracles figures especially as the former possessor of the invincible bow. Why, then, has Soph. here chosen an epithet, xa/lkaspis, which suggests the hoplite type of Heracles? The answer seems to turn on two points. (1) A compromise between the hoplite and the archer type of Heracles can sometimes be traced in ancient art. Thus a statue belonging to the east pediment of the Aeginetan temple gives Heracles a helmet (or bonnet) of lion's skin, a bow, and a qw/rac (Baumeister, Denkm. p. 335: cp. ib. p. 652 a). Sophocles himself makes a similar compromise when in Tr. 510 ff. he arms Heracles with bow, club, and two spears. (2) The Heracles of this play is associated with the legends of Oeta and Trachis. In them, as in those of Boeotia, Heracles was preeminently the warrior, who sacked Oechalia ‘with the spear’ ( Tr. 478), and for whom Hephaestus had wrought the a)spi/s described in the Hesiodic poem.

pla/qei. The aor. e)pla_/qhn is used by Aesch. and Eur. ; and pla/qh (Bergk) is tempting here: but the historic pres. seems confirmed by such examples as Soph. O. T. 113(sumpi/ptei), ib. 560 (e)/rrei). Heracles was burned alive, by his own command, on the top of Mount Oeta. As the flames rose, a storm broke forth; and, amid thunder and lightning, the hero was taken up to heaven. Apollod. 2. 7. 14kaiome/nhs de\ th=s pura=s le/getai ne/fos u(posta
 meta\ bronth=s au)to
 ei)s ou)rano
 a)nape/myai. Diod. 4. 38. 4keraunw=n e)k tou= perie/xontos peso/ntwn h( pura\ pa=sa katefle/xqh. By qei/w| puri\ pamfah/s the poet probably meant to suggest both the flaming pyre and the splendour of the lightnings.

*patro\s is my emendation of the corrupt pa=si. In the str., 716, o(/pou is clearly sound; and a long syllable is metrically impossible here. Nor can we save pa=si by transposition: both pla/qei and qei/w| are plainly genuine. Hermann's conjecture, qeoi=s | pla/qei qeo\s, presupposes that pa=si was either a gloss, or an arbitrary substitute for a lost word; but it was more probably a corruption of the true word. Now we might certainly expect here some reference to Zeus. Oeta was sacred to him; his were the lightnings (cp. Tr. 436tou= kat' a)/kron *oi)tai=on pa/gon | *zhno\s katastra/ptontos); and it was as his son that Heracles entered Olympus. At this moment, above all others, there is a poetical fitness in some allusion to the hero's divine parentage, which is elsewhere made so prominent in the play (802, Tr. 943, Tr. 1415). patro\s supplies this touch.

The burning of Heracles, and his apotheosis, are combined in some vase paintings. (1) A bowl (krath/r) of the 4th cent. B.C., now in the Collegio Rainone at Agata S. dei Goti: Milani, Mito di Filottete, p. 65: Baumeister, Denkm., p. 307, fig. 322. In the lower part of the picture is the still burning pyre, which a Nymph on the left is trying to quench by pouring water from a jug. The trunk of the hero's mortal body lies on the pyre. On the right, a bearded figure in a peaked cap is hastily receding. This is either Poeas or Philoctetes: at his side is the quiver given him by the hero for kindling the pyre. Above, a Doric portal represents the entrance to Olympus. Apollo, laurel-crowned, sits on the left of it; a four-horse chariot approaches him, preceded by Hermes. It is driven by a winged goddess (a *ni/kh): on her left sits Heracles, crowned with laurel, his club in his left hand; a light garment (a sort of chlamys) floats round his shoulders. (2) A Lucanian vase, now at Munich: Baumeister, p. 669, fig. 734. Below is the pyre, with the trunk of Heracles on it: the fire is being quenched by two Nymphs on the right *a*p*e*q*o*s*a and *p*r*e*m*n*o*s*i*a (an Attic fountain). On the left are two Satyr figures. Above, Athena Nikè, with helmet, lance, and chequered aegis worn as a corslet, is driving Heracles to Olympus; his left hand holds the club, and round his left arm is wound his chlamys.—We notice how the participation of Nymphs in these scenes illustrates the poet's *malia/dwn numfa=n (v. 725).
o)/xqwn (o)/xqos), not o)xqw=n (o)/xqh): cp. Ant. 1132 n.

div2.p: Second e)peiso/dion. Philoctetes is attacked by sharp pain, and hands his bow to Neoptolemus, asking him to keep it till the spasms pass off. Presently the sufferer falls asleep,—though not before he has received the youth's promise to remain by him.

div3.p: ei) qe/leis, ‘if you please,’ like ei) dokei= (526). But ei) bou/lei usu.=‘if you prefer it’ ( Xen. An. 3. 4. 41).
a)po/plhktos e)/xei, attonitus haeres: for a)po/pl., cp. Ant. 1189: for the pass. e)/xomai, ib. 1140.
ti/ d' e)/stin; cp. 753, 917, O. T. 319.It does not seem likely that Soph. would have preferred to write ti/ e)/stin (with hiatus), though several recent editors give this: cp. 100 n.

th=s parestw/shs, not, ‘which is upon thee at this moment’ (765 to\ ph=ma ...to\ nu=n paro/n), but rather, ‘which is habitual to thee’: hence the word is not superfluous. Often, however, parestw/s, is nearly synonymous with parw/n: cp. 1340, O. T. 633.

735 The intrans. koufi/zein is rare in Attic: in Helen. 1555 koufi/zonta, ‘treading lightly,’ seems (as Paley says) to imply an ellipse of po/das. But in this application (to illness) the phrase may have been familiar, as Hippocr. Epid. 2. 10(quoted by Musgrave) has e)kou/fisen o)li/gw|, ‘he became a little better.’

736 f. I follow A here (see cr. n.), for a reason which was felt by Hermann, but which has not been sufficiently considered by some other editors,—viz., that i)w\ qeoi/ (scanned as a bacchius, ˘¯¯) does not receive sufficient emphasis or prominence unless it stands extra metrum. Cp. 750 i)/q' w)= pai=, and 219. I. T. 780 has been compared: *o*r. w)= qeoi/. *i*f. ti/ tou\s qeou\s a)nakalei=s e)n toi=s e)moi=s; But there, as Herm. says, the w)= qeoi/ is quite unlike the i)w\ qeoi/ here: it is the rapid utterance of one who fears to betray himself, not a cry of anguish extorted by physical torment. For the absence of caesura, cp. 101. Cavallin reads i)w\ qeoi/.
ti/ qeou\s a)naste/nwn kalei=s; Cp. Ai. 1129mh/ nun a)ti/ma qeou/s, qeoi=s seswsme/nos. But the art. before qeou\s, in which L and A agree, seems genuine here.
kurw=n: cp. 544 n.
die/rxetai. In 758 the disease is personified as au(/th, in 807 as h(/de: here the subject might be simply kako/n from 742.
bru/komai: cp. 7: Tr. 987h( d' au)= miara\ bru/kei (the no/sos).

746 Written as above, the exclamations represent three successive cries of pain, each longer than the last, as the agony becomes sharper; they seem to suggest the convulsive movement of the lips from which the sounds are wrung.

ei)/ ti/ soi ci/fos pro/xeiron (= pa/resti) xeroi=n, if you have any sword ready in your hands. pro/xeiros can be combined with xeroi=n (as in Soph. El. 696pro/xeiron e)/gxos xeiri\ basta/zous' e)mh=|) without seeming pleonastic, since the derived sense of the compound adj. (promptus) is prominent. Cp. 407 n.: Plat. Theaet. 200C e)a\n mh\ proxei/rous e)/xh| (e)pisth/mas) e)n th=| yuxh=|.

pa/tacon ei)s a)/kron po/da. The ulcered heel is to be severed from the foot. a)/kros pou=s seems to mean simply, ‘the end of the foot,’ i.e. the heel (pte/rna), the seat of the ulcer. Cp. 824. The phrase could also mean, ‘the foot at the end of the leg,’ as in Il. 16. 640e)k kefalh=s ei)/luto diampere\s e)s po/das a)/krous (=simply ‘from head to foot’): but this is less fitting here.
i)/q' w)= pai=, an earnest entreaty: cp. O. T. 1468i)/q' w)=nac, | i)/q' w)= gonh=| gennai=e.

neoxmo\n e)cai/fnhs: cp.
