Tr. 1130a)rti/ws neosfagh/s, and Ant. 1283.—o(/tou, causal, with the whole sentence: 327 n.: sautou= with i)ugh/n, etc.; object. gen.—I give poei=, instead of the vulg. poei=s. poiei=sqai (midd.) sto/non=ste/nein: whereas poiei=n sto/non could mean only, ‘to cause, or excite, it.’ We cannot defend poei=s here by Il. 15. 363poih/sh| (act.) a)qu/rmata, which is not a mere periphrasis for a)qu/rein, but = ‘making playthings’ in the sand,—houses, dykes, etc. Nor can deina\ poiw= be cited, which is not an equiv. for deino\n poiou=mai, but means ‘to do dreadful things,’ referring to the outward display of horror or grief by gestures or cries. (Cp. my n. on Andoc. or. 1 § 41.) In Soph. Ai. 75, where a)rei= (midd.) is now read by most edd., L has a)/rhis.

ti/ soi/; These words clearly belong to Neopt., and mean, ‘What is the matter with thee?’ The phrase is not a usual one; but it is clear enough here, esp. as e)/stin can easily be carried on. Hermann, giving ti/ soi/ to Philoctetes, took it as meaning ‘What is that to thee?’ (quid tua refert?)—a protest against closer questioning.

tou)pi/sagma. e)pisa/ttein is classical as=‘to put a load on’ a baggageanimal, or ‘to saddle’ a horse (Her. , Xen. , etc.): and e)pi/sagma was a common word, at least in later Greek, as may be inferred from the schol. on Nub. 450 (e)pi/sagma tw=n o)/nwn), and from its use by the LXX. (Lev. xv. 9). In the marg. of L the gl. is, h( e)pei/sodos: h( prosqh/kh. The second word suits tou)pi/sagma: the first refers to the v. l. tou)pei/sagma, in the sense of ‘access.’ But such a word is neither extant nor conceivable. Bergk's tou)pi/sigma (e)pisi/zw), ‘hounding on,’ would mean here, ‘exasperation,’—as if some Fury were stimulating the no/shma. The word was used by Soph. in his Athamas, acc. to an amended gloss in Hesychius ( Soph. fr. 8).
ga\r=‘indeed,’ in assent; cp. O. T. 1117 n.
dra/sw: aor. subj.

h(/kei … e)ceplh/sqh. Ph. fears that the sight of his horrible sufferings may deter Neopt. from taking him on board. He says,—‘Do not be scared into abandoning me. For this tormentor (au(/th, the personified no/sos) comes only now and then (dia\ xro/nou),—when she has been sated, haply, with her roamings.’ And so—since the voyage to Greece will take less than one whole day (480)—he is not likely to have an attack while at sea. Three points deserve notice. (1) h(/kei=‘is wont to come,’—a sense which is as fitting for it as for a regular perfect tense used in the ‘gnomic’ manner (o)/pwpe, Soph. Ant. 1126). So in Plat. Symp. 188A h(/kei is joined to the gnomic aor. h)di/khsen: and in Xen. Oec. 21. 3e)kbai/nousin...h(/kousi denotes a repeated occurrence. (2) dia\ xro/nou, ‘after an interval of time,’ implies here, as it usually does, that the interval is a considerable one: cp. 285 n., where Lys. or. 1 § 12 is cited. (3) pla/nois is contrasted with h(/kei. The word was suggested by the fact that intermittent fevers (etc.) were called pla/nhtes (Hippocr. Epid. 1. 944). The term implied that the intervals were irregular: cp. Erotian Gloss. p. 306 (quoted by Arndt) pla/nhtes puretoi\ le/gontai oi( mh\ kata\ ta/cin foitw=ntes. This may be illustrated by the use of plana=sqai in Her. 6. 52, h)\n de\ plana=tai...e)nalla\c poieu=sa (‘if she is capricious, varying the order’— opp. to kata\ tau)ta\ ai)ei\ poieu=sa). So id. 7. 16. 2 e)nu/pnia...ta\ e)s a)nqrw/pous peplanhme/na (‘the dreams which are wont at times to visit men’). It was easy, then, for the poet to imagine the fitful no/sos as a personified wanderer, who, when sated with wandering, comes back to her abode:—much as Aesch. ( Aesch. P. V. 275) speaks of calamity ‘roaming’ among men: planwme/nh | pro\s a)/llot' a)/llon phmonh\ prosiza/nei. Cp. below, Aesch. P. V. 808o)cei=a foita=| kai\ taxei=) a)pe/rxetai. So the schol., who explains pla/nois by o(doipori/ais:—h(/kei h( no/sos, i)/sws o(/te e)kore/sqh planwme/nh: w(s e)pi\ qhro\s de\ poiei=tai to\n lo/gon. This is clearly better than to understand,—‘when it has once been sated, it returns only after a long interval,—in wandering fashion, seemingly’ (pla/nois being then a modal dat.).—For conjectures, see Appendix.

e)ceplh/sqh. — i)w/. There is no other example of such a hiatus in a tragic trimeter. (As to lyrics, cp. 832, 851.) Probably, however, the text is sound. The verse is divided between two speakers, there is a full stop after e)ceplh/sqh, and the second speaker begins with an interjection. Thus the hiatus has an exceptional excuse. On the other hand no emendation is probable. feu= (instead of the first i)w/) is certainly not so, whether it be given to Ph. or Neoptolemus. Gaisford says, ‘e)ce/plhs’, ut videtur, conj. Elmsleius.’ This would require us to read pla/nous, or (keeping pla/nois) to understand au)tou/s. But the context strongly confirms e)ceplh/sqh.

760 There is an error in the traditional numbering here, as the fourth verse after this is called 765. The origin of this error is explained in the Appendix. To avoid changing the usual numeration throughout the rest of the play, I designate the next verse as 762.
dh=ta. Cp. El. 1163w(/s m' a)pw/lesas, | a)pw/lesas dh=t).

du/sthne … fanei/s: the predicative adj. is assimilated to the vocative partic. Cp. 828 n.: Aesch. Pers.w)= polu/klaute fi/loisi qanw/n. Eur. Tro. 1221su/ t' w)= pot' ou)=sa kalli/nike muri/wn | mh=ter tropai/wn. Propert. 2. 15. 2 Lectule deliciis facte beate meis.
dia\ po/nwn pa/ntwn, ‘in all manner of troubles,’—i.e., ‘in the course’ of them: O. T. 773dia\ tu/xhs toia=sd' i)w/n. I. T. 988 dia\ po/nwn t' a)/gei (sc. o( dai/mwn).

bou/lei la/bwmai ..; El. 80qe/leis | mei/nwmen...; This idiom is a parataxis of two questions originally distinct: bou/lei; la/bwmai; Where the subjunctive stands first, as in Dem. or. 14 § 27 qw= bou/lesqe...; the verb of wishing might seem to be parenthetic. But such an example as Plat. Rep. 372C, ei)...bou/lesqe... qewrh/swmen, ou)de\n a)pokwlu/ei, shows that the subjunctive had come to be felt as depending on the verb of wishing. In classical Greek no conjunction could be used to link the verbs, since bou/lomai and qe/lw took only the inf. In later Greek we still have qe/leis poih/sw; (St Luke xviii. 41:) but also qe/lw i(/na dw=|s (St Mark vi. 25). dh=ta has been suspected here, because it occurs in 757, Plat. Rep. 760, Plat. Rep. 763.Nauck would remove it by rewriting the passage thus:—bou/lei la/bwmai kai\ qi/gw; *f*i*l. mh\ tou=to/ ge, | a)ll' w(/sper h)/|tou m' a)rti/ws, ta\ to/c' e(lw/n, | e(/ws a)nh=| to\ ph=ma tou=to th=s no/sou, | sw=|z) au)ta\ kai\ fu/lasse. But here, as in 757, it is interrogative, while in 760 and 763 it is otherwise used; and this difference of usage palliates the iteration. Cp. the threefold a)lla\ in 645, Plat. Rep. 647, Plat. Rep. 651: also Soph. O. T. 517fe/ron, Soph. O. T. 519fe/ronti, Soph. O. T. 520fe/rei, where the excuse is the same as here, viz. that, in the 1st and 3rd places the word means ‘tend,’ but in the 2nd, ‘bear.’ No weight attaches to the fact that the 1st hand in L accidentally omitted dh=ta, which the reviser added. In 772 L lacks tau=ta altogether; and yet that word is certainly sound.
moi: ethic dat.: O. C. 1475 n.
e(/ws without a)/n, as Tr. 148, Ai. 555.Cp. 917.
to\ ph=ma … th=s no/sou: Ai. 363to\ ph=ma th=s a)/ths: Aesch. Ag. 850ph=u) a)postre/yai no/sou.
ga\r ou)=n: ‘for indeed’ (prefacing an explanation); Ant. 489.
e)ci/h|, draw to an end: Her. 2. 139w(s ou)=n o( xro/nos ou(=tos e)ch/ie.

lh=cai. The subject to the inf. is to\ kako/n. When the pain is subsiding (e)ci/h|), the patient falls asleep; and it is only by sleep that the pain can be wholly allayed (lh=cai). The schol. explains lh=cai by th=s o)du/nhs pau/sasqai, as if the subject were me: but where lh/gw is so used the gen. is commonly added, as in Ai. 274e)/lhce...th=s no/sou.
e(/khlon eu(/dein. me is easily supplied from 767; the omission is thus less bold than that in 801 (e)/mprhson).— tw=|de tw=| xro/nw|, within it; cp. 715 deke/tei xro/nw|, n.
e)kei=noi: Odysseus and Diomedes (570).

e(ko/nta mh/t' a)/konta. A mh/te is understood before e(ko/nta: cp. Aesch. Ag. 532*pa/ris ga ou)/te suntelh\s po/lis: and Soph. O. T. 236 ff. (n.): Soph. Ant. 267.Dindorf changes mh/t) to mhd). This is, of course, admissible. When a single ou)de/ (or mhde/) connects two words, the negative force is more often, indeed, confined to the second, as in 756 deino
 ga ou)de\ r(hto/n. But there are also many examples in which ou)de/ negatives the preceding word also: as Thuc. 8. 99ai( *foi/nissai nh=es ou)de\ o( *tissafe/rnhs...h(=kon. Ar. Av. 694gh= d' ou)d' a)h ou)d' ou)rano\s h)=n. Where, however, ou)de/ is thus retrospective, another negative (such as ou)de/n) is usu. joined to the verb: Her. 1. 215sidh/rw| de\ ou)d' a)rgu/rw| xre/wntai ou)de/n: Thuc. 6. 55*qessalou= me
 ou)d' *(ippa/rxou ou)dei\s pai=s ge/graptai (add id. 5. 47 cited below): Dem. or. 22 § 4 a(plou=n me
 ou)de\ di/kaion ou)de
 a)
 ei)pei=n e)/xoi.

mh/te tw| te/xnh|. Here again Dindorf writes mhde/. Note that, whether mh/te or mhde/ be read, it does not here balance the preceding mh/te (or mhde/), since e(k. mh/t' a)/k.=(mh/q)) e(k. mh/t' a)/k.: hence we might read mh/t) a)/konta, and yet mhde/ tw| te/xnh|. Cp. Plat. Rep. 426B ou)/te fa/rmaka ou)/te kau/seis ou)/te tomai\ ou)d' au)= e)pw|dai/. But it is needless to alter mh/te.—For te/xnh|, cp. Soph. Ai. 752pantoi/a| te/xnh|: Thuc. 5. 47o(/pla mh\ e)ce/stw e)pife/rein...te/xnh| mhde\ mhxanh=| mhdemia=|: Xen. Anab. 4. 5. 16e)dei=to au)tw=n pa/sh| te/xnh| kai\ mhxanh=| mh\ a)polei/pesqai.
pro/stropon: in this sense only here and in O. T. 41.Cp. 470 i(ke/ths i(knou=mai: 930: to\n prostro/paion, to\n i(ke/thn.
ktei/nas ge/nh|: cp. 1067: Ai. 588mh\ prodou\s h(ma=s ge/nh|. Plat. Soph. 217C mh\...a)parnhqei\s ge/nh|.

pronoi/as ou(/nek). One MS. (B) adds g) to pronoi/as. Where ou(/neka or e(/neka has this sense (‘so far as’ a thing ‘is concerned’), ge is certainly frequent: cp. O. T. 857 f. mantei/as g)...ou(/nek): El. 387 and 605 tou=de/ g' ou(/nek). In O. C. 22xro/nou me\n ou(/nek), the me/n is equiv. to ge. On the other hand in El. 787tw=n th=sd' a)peilw=n ou(/nex), no MS. has a)peilw=n g). And here the emphasis of ge is not required.
plh\n soi/ te ka)moi/: i.e., as I receive them from thee, so to thee alone will I give them up. They shall pass between no hands save thine and mine. Cp. 668 kai\ do/nti dou=nai, n.

cu
 tu/xh|, a poet. equiv. for the familiar tu/xh| a)gaqh=| (quod bene vertat): Plat. Symp. 177E tu/xh| a)gaqh=| katarxe/tw *fai=dros. Cp. Aesch. Ch. 138e)lqei=n d' *)ore/sthn deu=ro su
 tu/xh| tini\ | kateu/xomai/ soi: Ar. Av. 1723peripe/tesqe ma/kara | ma/kari su
 tu/xh|.

to
 fqo/non de\ pro/skuson, do reverence (cp. 657) to the divine jealousy, i.e., propitiate it by some gesture or word showing that you fear it. To hold the bow—though only as a temporary loan— was an honour so high that it might well excite that fqo/nos qew=n which resents too great eu)tuxi/a in men. Pind. I. 6. 39o( d' a)qana/twn mh\ qrasse/tw fqo/nos | o(/ ti terpno
 e)fa/meron. Aesch. Ag. 904fqo/nos d' a)pe/stw: polla\ ga ta\ pri
 kaka\ | h)neixo/mesqa: id. Aesch. P. V. 936oi( proskunou=ntes th
 *)adra/steian sofoi/ (i.e. *ne/mesin). Plat. Rep. 451A proskunw= de\ *)adra/steian...xa/rin ou(= me/llw le/gein. I do not write *fqo/non, since it seems unnecessary to assume a definite personification: cp. 436 po/lemos, n.
mh/ … gene/sqai depends on pro/skuson as on a verb of praying. (This is simpler than to make the inf. epexegetic ‘so that,’ etc.)

polu/pona. Ph. speaks as if his own sufferings in Lemnos, and the various trials of Heracles, were due to the bow, once Apollo's: i.e., as if its mortal owners had been punished by jealous gods for the excessive goodfortune of possessing it.
mhd' o(/pws, sc. e)ge/neto, in the sense of sunh/negke, turn out as they did for me. For o(/pws instead of oi(=a, cp. O. C. 1124kai/ soi qeoi\ po/roien w(s e)gw\ qe/lw (n.).
qeoi/: for the synizesis cp. 196.
ge/noito … ge/noito de\: cp. 633 n.— tau=ta nw=|n: the vague phrase covers his secret prayer,—that, sharing the possession of the bow with Ph. , he may also share the victory over Troy (115).
keu)stalh/s, well-sped, expeditious: cp. 516 n.
o(/poi pote\ k.t.l.: with the same ambiguity as in 529.

a)ll' *o)/knos k.t.l. The MSS. have a)lla\ de/doik), w)= pai=, mh/ m' a)telh\s eu)xh/. Camerarius conjectured a)ll' ou)=n de/doika mh\ ma/thn eu)/xh|, te/knon, which Cavallin prints. Wecklein gives de/doika d), w)= pai=, mh\ ma/thn eu)/xh| ta/de,...in which ta/de is his own, and de/doika d) (instead of a)lla\ de/doik)) is Neue's. The conjecture in the text is my own. I differ from Camerarius in holding that the traditional w)= pai= is genuine, and from Neue in holding that the a)lla\ is genuine also. The spurious word is de/doik), a gloss upon some rarer expression in the same sense, as Hermann saw; who wrote, a)ll' ou)/ ti/ soi, pai=, mh\ )telh\s eu)xh\ pe/lh|. First, as to metre. The words a)lla\ de/doik), w)= pai=, mh/ m' a)telh\s eu)xh/ can be read as a dochmiac dimeter, though of an unusual type (cp. J.H.Heinrich Schmidt, Rhythmic and Metric, p. 77). But they cannot be construed: m) can be only me: and, though we read eu)/xh|, mh/ m' a)telh\s (or a)telw=s) eu)/xh| could not mean, ‘lest thou pray vainly on my behalf.’ An iambic trimeter is required here. On this point recent edd. and critics are practically unanimous. In the whole passage from 730 to 826 the series of trimeters is otherwise unbroken, save by those brief cries of Ph. which occur ‘extra metrum’ (785, 787, 790, 796, 804). A solitary dochmiac dimeter is here inconceivable. The corruption of the trimeter began with the loss of the last word, as in Ant. 1301 the MS. pe/ric came from peri\ ci/fei. Among the words suggested are pe/lh|, tu/xh|, kurh=|, me/nh|, ta/d' h)=|, ta/de, te/knon. Of these, tu/xh| alone has any resemblance to eu)xh/: but e)/xei might easily have dropped out after eu)/xhi. For the phrase cp. O. C. 652tou= ma/list' o)/knos s' e)/xei; Next, as to a)te/lest). An ellipse of h)= with mh\ a)telh\s eu)xh/ would be too harsh: we must read eu)/xh|. Again, mh\ a)telh\s eu)/xh| could not mean, ‘lest thou pray in vain.’ In Pind. Pyth. 5. 83 a)telh\s ...manteu/masin is said of the god. On the other hand cp. Od. 8. 570ta\ de/ ken qeo\s h)\ tele/seien | h)/ k' a)te/lest' ei)/h. And when *e*u*x*h*i had become eu)xh/, *a*t*e*l*e*s*t would easily become a)telh/s, the t) being taken for an intruded te.— See Appendix.

For mh\ followed by a, cp. 933: O. T. 1388to\ mh\ a)poklh=|sai: El. 1169mh\ a)polei/pesqai: Aesch. Eum. 85to\ mh\ a)dikei=n: Eur. Tro. 981mh\ a)maqei=s poi/ei qea/s. Most edd. now write mh\ a)dikei=n, etc., assuming synizesis, rather than ma)dikei=n (crasis), or mh\ )dikei=n.
khki=on: cp. 696 khkiome/nan, n.— ne/on with a sinister sense: cp. 554 ne/a, 560 new/teron, 751 neoxmo/n.

e)rga/sei=me/lleis e)rga/sesqai: cp. 441 e)rei=s, 581 le/cei. The fut. is better suited than e)rga/zei to the presentiment of agony (prose/rpei). For the latter cp. Tr. 1010h(=ptai/ mou...h(/d' au)=q' e(/rpei.
ta/las, nom.; cp. O. C. 753w)= ta/las e)gw/ (n.).
e)/xete, ‘know,’ as Ant. 9e)/xeis ti kei)sh/kousas;
mhdamh=| is supported by L here, and is not less fitting than mhdamw=s, which Blaydes desires. Cp. O. C. 1104 n.
*kefallh/n: cp. 263 f., n.

sou= with e)/xoito, cleave to thee, diampere\s ste/rnwn, piercing thy breast (and not merely thy foot). sou=, not sou, is needed here, where there is a contrast between the actual sufferer and the man to whom he wishes the plague transferred. If we read sou, the chief emphasis would fall on diampere\s ste/rnwn.
ma/l' au)=qis: cp. O. T. 1316oi)/moi, | oi)/moi ma/l' au)=qis.
w)= diploi= str.: cp. 264.

*)aga/memnon, w)= *mene/lae. A proper name excuses an anapaest in any foot except the 6th (cp. O. C. 1). The fact that this licence has been used in the 1st foot is no reason why it should not recur in the same v., if, as here, a second proper name requires it. We need not assume, then, with Hermann, that the second anapaest marks a laxity peculiar to the later period of tragedy. Blaydes conjectures, and Nauck adopts, *mene/lae/ t' *)aga/memno/n te—to the detriment, surely, of the verse.—For pw=s a)/n with optat., cp. 551 n.: for tre/foite, Ai. 503latrei/as...tre/fei.

to\n i)/son xro/non. Here, again, the anapaest has been impugned, on the ground that it ought to be contained in a single word. But, as a prep. and its case are excepted from this rule ( Eur. Or. 898e)pi\ tw=|de d' h)go/reue *diomh/dhs a)/nac), so also are an art. and its noun.

w)= *qa/nate. So Aeschylus, too, made Philoctetes invoke Death: fr. 250 w)= *qa/nate paia/n, mh/ m' a)tima/sh|s molei=n: | mo/nos ga\r ei)= su\ tw=n a)nhke/stwn kakw=n | i)atro/s. Cp. O. C. 1220(Death as the last e)pi/kouros), and Ai. 854.
a)ei\ … kat' h)=mar: cp. O. C. 681qa/llei...kat' h)=mar a)ei\ | na/rkissos.
du/na|, admitted in Attic verse as an equiv. for du/nasai (Porson Hec. 253): in prose it is postclassical. Cp. 849.
w)= te/knon, w)= gennai=on. Cp. Il. 6. 55w)= pe/pon w)= *mene/lae: Ar. Av. 1271w)= *peisqe/tair), w)= maka/ri), w)= sofw/tate. Eur. Cycl. 266w)= ka/lliston w)= *kuklw/pion.
a)lla\, hortative: cp. 230, 950.

tw=| *l. tw=|d' a)nak. puri\: you fire, famed as Lemnian; pu=r o(\ *lh/mnion a)nakalou=si:—the volcano Mosychlus, which was always associated with Lemnos, and which had given rise to the proverb *lh/mnion pu=r. One meaning of a)nakalei=n is ‘to call to’ a person by his name: Thuc. 7. 70§ 8 a)nakalou=ntes o)nomasti\ to\n trih/rarxon. Hence the verb is sometimes joined with appellatives, as Thuc. 1. 3*danaou\s...e)n toi=s e)/pesi...a)nakalei= (Homer designates the Greeks as Danai): Soph. El. 693*)argei=os me\n a)nakalou/menos.—Not: ‘Yon Lemnian fire, which is so famous’ (as if a)nakaloume/nw|, by itself, could mean ‘celebrated’): nor, ‘yon Lemnian fire which is invoked by me.’ There is thus no difficulty in a)nakaloume/nw| when rightly understood, while the proposed substitutes (cr. n.) are all unsatisfactory.

The volcanic mountain called *mo/suxlos appears to have been on the east coast of Lemnos, south of the rocky promontory (*(ermai=on o)/ros, v. 1459) to which the cave of Philoctetes was adjacent. No volcanic crater can now be traced in Lemnos; and it is probable that the ancient Mosychlus has been submerged. See Appendix. *lh/mnion pu=r was proverbial for ‘a fierce fire’ ( Ar. Lys. 299). Lycophron (227) has tefrw/sas gui=a *lhmnai/w| puri/ in this sense, and calls Ajax o( *lh/mnios | prhsth\r *)enuou=s (462), ‘Lemnian thunderbolt of war.’ Cp. Hesych. *lh/mnion ble/pein: e)peidh\ to\ pu=r *lh/mnion. The legendary association of Lemnos with fierce crime (*lh/mnia kaka/) may have helped to suggest such phrases.

e)/mprhson: the omission of me is somewhat bold here: but cp. 769, 1368: Ai. 496a)fh=|s, O. T. 461la/bh|s (sc. me). If we read puri/ m) |, the e)pisunaloifh/ might be defended by the elision of d), t), and once tau=t) ( O. T. 332) at the end of a verse ( O. T. 29 n.). But the fact seems to be that sullabw\n in 799, which at once suggests me, excuses the absence of the pron. here.
to\n tou= *dio\s pai=d), Heracles: cp. 727 f. n.
sw/|zeis, as their temporary guardian: cp. 766.

tou=t); i.e. e)mprh=sai, cp. 670. Heracles was conveyed to the summit of Oeta by his son Hyllus, who helped to make the pyre, but refused to kindle it ( Tr. 1214). It was kindled, acc. to one account, by Philoctetes; acc. to another, by his father Poeas. The former version was naturally preferred where the aim of the legend was to honour Philoctetes, since thus he inherited the bow directly from Heracles: and, since Philoctetes was a more important figure than Poeas, this was the prevailing account. The other version, which made Poeas the kindler, had a recommendation of a different kind in the eyes of mythologists who aimed at a strict chronology,—viz., that the episode was thus confined to the generation before the Trojan war. Tzetzes, in his scholia on Lycophron, gives the first version in one place (on vv. 914 ff.), and the second in another (on v. 50).—Cp. Met, 9. 229 At tu, Iovis inclyta proles, | Arboribus caesis quas ardua gesserat Oete | Inque pyram structis, arcus pharetramque capacem | Regnaque visuras iterum Troiana sagittas | Ferre iubes Poeante satum; quo flamma ministro | Subdita.
e)phci/wsa, brought myself to do it, here almost=e/to/lmhsa. Cp. El. 1273filta/tan | o(do\n e)paciw/sas...fanh=nai.
dra=n with double acc., as 315, 918, 924, 940.

ti/ fh/s, pai=; Neopt. has no answer for the prayer, e)/mprhson. A genuine pity for the sufferer is beginning to move him; and he knows that, if the plot succeeds, this wretched man will be carried to the place which he most dreads. He remains silent.
pou= pot' w)/n, mentally: cp. Ant. 42pou= gnw/mhs pot' ei)=; (n.)
pa/lai dh\: cp. 589.

ta)pi\ soi\ … kaka/, the ills which lie on thee: cp. Tr. 981a)ll' e)pi/ moi mele/w| | ba/ros a)/pleton: e)mme/monen frh/n. Not, ‘the ills which have come upon thee,’ as though h(/konta could be understood ( O. C. 1472h(/kei tw=|d' e)p) a)ndri\...telenth/). Nor, ‘the ills in thy case.’
kai\ qa/rsos i)/sxe, have good hope also (as well as a)/lgos): for, as the access of the malady is sharp, so it will also be transient.—Nauck enfeebles the sense by changing kai\ to moi.
foita=|, of periodical visitations: Hes. Op. 103nou=soi... | au)to/matoi foitw=si: An. Hist. 7. 3 (p. 583 a 26 Berl. ed.) ai(... kaqa/rseis foitw=si.
o)cei=a, taxei=a adverbially: cp. 526, 1080.

ou) mh/n. In this formula, as in kai\ mh/n, a)lla\ mh/n, mh/n is properly adversative (‘however’): cp. O. T. 810ou) mh\n i)/shn g' e)/teisen. Here mh/n is like ‘nay,’ or ‘well’: i.e., the thought implied is, ‘I should prefer a promise on oath; however, I do not like to ask for it.’
e)/norkon … qe/sqai, = o(/rkw| pistw=sai: cp. O. T. 276w(/sper m' a)rai=on e)/labes. So Oed. to Theseus, in a like case: O. C. 650ou)/toi s' u(f' o(/rkou g' w(s kako\n pistw/somai, where see n.

w(s, (be sure) that: 117 n.— qe/mis receives a slight emphasis from ge: ‘it is needless for me to take an oath: even if I wished to leave thee, it is not lawful for me to do so.’ By qe/mis Philoctetes understands the youth's sense of duty towards a suppliant (773): the spectators know that Neopt. is thinking of the oracle (841).
e)mou)/sti: so Ai. 1225mou)/sti (moi/ )sti L).

e)/mballe k.t.l. Here Philoctetes receives this pledge in place of an oath. In Tr. 1181 ff. the intense anxiety of Heracles is marked by the fact that he exacts from Hyllus, first the decia/, and then the o(/rkos:—e)/mballe xei=ra decia\n prw/tista/ moi:—o)/mnu *dio\s nu=n tou= me fu/santos ka/ra. When belligerents had taken oaths to a treaty, the hand-pledge followed, as the seal of mutual confidence: it was the moral sanction added to the religious. Xen. Anab. 2. 3. 28w)/mosan kai\ decia\s e)/dosan.

e)kei=se nu=n m). On leaving the cave with Neopt., Ph. had moved a few steps on the path leading down the cliffs to the shore. When the first attack of the disease came on (732), he stopped. The second attack (782) found him stationary in the same spot. A third is now beginning; and he begs Neopt. to take him e)kei=se, i.e., up to the cave, where he will at least have the couch of leaves (33) to rest upon. Neopt. does not understand that e)kei=se means, to the cave: so Ph. adds, a)/nw. Neopt. has meanwhile taken hold of Ph. , fearing that he may fall, or throw himself, from the cliffs (1001): his speech and manner show a fresh frenzy of agony (parafronei=s au)=), and his rolling eyes are upturned to the sky (to\n a)/nw leu/sseis ku/klon). The mere touch of the youth's hands is torture to the sufferer (817): and Neopt. releases him the moment that he seems to be recovering self-mastery (ei)/ ti dh\ ple/on fronei=s).
au)=, as at 732 ff., 782 ff.

to\n a)/nw ku/klon, the vault of the sky (to\n ku/klon pa/nta tou= ou)ranou=, Her. 1. 131): cp. Au. 1715 o)smh\ d' a)nwno/mastos e)s ba/qos ku/klou | xwrei=.—Not, ‘the orb of the sun’ (h(li/ou ku/klos, Ant. 416, fr. 668).
pote/, tandem aliquando: 1041, O. T. 335.

a)po/ m' o)lei=s: cp. 1177. Such tmesis, though frequent in tragic lyrics, is rarer in dialogue: Ant. 432su\n de/ nin | qhrw/meq): Eur. Or. 1047e)/k toi/ me th/ceis: perh. parodied by Vesp. 784 a)na/ toi/ me pei/qeis: id. Ach. 295kata/ se xw/somen: Plut. 65 a)po/ s' o)lw= kako\n kakw=s.
kai\ dh\ meqi/hm), I do release thee: O. C. 31 n.
ei)/ ti dh\: here dh/ nearly= h)/dh: cp. O. T. 968 n.

ple/on fronei=s, art more sane. Cp. Ai. 81memhno/t' a)/ndra...o)knei=s i)dei=n;—fronou=nta ga/r nin ou)k a)\n e)ce/sthn: and ib. 344 a(nh\r fronei=n e)/oiken (when Ajax is ‘in his right mind’ again). The 1st hand in L wrote here, kai\ dh\ meqei/hmi (sic): ti/ dh\ ple/on fronei=s. No MS. has ei), which Hermann restored. But it has not been noticed that the mis-spelling meqei/hmi in L may have been due to the fact that its archetype had meqi/hm' ei).

qana/simon, proleptic, as in Ai. 516kai\ mhte/r' a)/llh moi=ra to
 fu/santa/ te | kaqei=len *(/aidou qanasi/mous oi)kh/toras. Cp. Pind. P. 1. 51su
 d' a)na/gka| min fi/lon | kai/ tis e)w
 megala/nwr e)/sanen (so as to make him a friend).
o(/pws e)/xw, forthwith: Ant. 1108w(=d' w(s e)/xw stei/xoim' a)/n.
o)rqou=sqai, here, to be (not to become) o)rqo/s, i.e., ‘to stand upright’: cp. Xen. Cyr. 8. 8. 10e)kfe/rontai, e)peida\n mhke/ti du/nwntai o)rqou/menoi e)cie/nai (‘on their own feet’).
ou) makrou= xro/nou: cp. O. C. 397h(/conta baiou= kou)xi\ muri/ou xro/nou (n.).

ge/ toi, as O. C. 1324, Ai. 534, Tr. 1212: ge/ toi dh/, O. T. 1171.Here ge/ toi is like gou=n, i.e., it gives a reason for their belief. (Cp. 767.) ‘He seems likely to fall asleep soon, since (ga/r) his head is sinking back; at any rate, a sweat is certainly breaking out,’ etc.

a)/kron … podo\s: cp. 748.— fle/y, not a vein of the body, but the thin stream in which the blood issues: cp. Polyb. 34. 9 (the removal of an obstruction) e)leuqeroi= ta\s fle/bas th=s phgh=s, w(/st' a)nablu/ein eu)po/rws. So Martial 10. 30. 10 Lucrina vena.

div2.p: The place of a second stasimon is taken by this kommo/s. The strophe (827—838) is divided from the antistr. (843—854) by a mesw|do/s, consisting of four hexameters for Neoptolemus. The antistr. is followed by an e)pw|do/s (855—864). For the metres, see Metrical Analysis.

A kommo/s was properly a lyric lamentation (qrh=nos) in which one of the actors took part with the Chorus. But the name can be used in a larger sense to describe any lyric dialogue between actor and Chorus, even when the character of a lamentation is not present.

The strophe here was sung by one half of the Chorus, and the antistrophe by the other. Sophocles had raised the number of the tragic Chorus from 12 to 15 by adding a coryphaeus (whose part had hitherto been taken by one of the ordinary choreutae), and two leaders of h(mixo/ria,—called parasta/tai, because, when the Chorus was drawn up facing the actors, they stood on either side of the coryphaeus. The Ajax affords another certain instance of h(mixo/ria (866 ff.).

The Chorus urge Neoptolemus to seize the moment while Philoctetes sleeps, and to sail away with the bow. He replies that it would be as useless as it would be base to take the bow without its master, whom the oracle has declared to be indispensable. They are still pressing their counsel when the youth perceives that Philoctetes is about to awake.
827 ff. The first *(/upne has u_, but the second, u^: cp. 296 n.
o)du/nas alludes to the sharp physical anguish of Ph. : a)lge/wn is the more general word,—pain, whether of body or of mind.
*(/upne d): the de/ stands here as it would stand after the repeated adj., *(/upne, a)dah\s (me\n) o)d., a)dah\s de\ a)lge/wn: cp. 633.

eu)ae\s instead of eu)ah\s, the predicative adj. being assimilated to the subject (*(/upne) in the voc.: cp. 760: Ai. 695 ff. a(li/plagkte...fa/nhq): Theocr. 17. 66 o)/lbie kw=re ge/noio: Callimachus fr. 213 a)nti\ ga\r e)klh/qhs *)/imbrase *parqeni/on (the river Imbrasus in Samos): Tibullus 1. 7. 53 venias hodierne.

eu)ae\s must certainly be a dactyl (see Anal.), and in 844 the words w(=n d' a)\n a)mei/bh| appear sound. But the short a^ in eu)ae\s has caused perplexity. Certainly elsewhere we find a_ ( Hes. Op. 597xw/rw| e)n eu)aei=, Hom. Od. 12. 289*zefu/roio dusae/os). But on the other hand a^ occurs in other Homeric forms from the same root,—a)/h, a)/hton, a)/hto, a)h=nai, a)h/menai, a)h/menos, a)h=tai. Thus, even though a_ was usual in eu)ah/s, general epic associations would have made it easy for Sophocles to use eu)a^h/s where metrical convenience required it.

eu)ai/wn, happy, and giving happiness. At Sicyon Pausanias (2. 10. 2) saw a statue of *(/upnos, with the surname of e)pidw/ths,—i.e. the giver of ever fresh gifts to men,—the renewer of life. The epithet is explained by Paus. 8. 9. 1 where a Mantinean hieron of *zeu\s *)epidw/ths is mentioned,—e)pidido/nai ga\r dh\ a)gaqa\ au)to\n a)nqrw/pois. The word paiw/n in 832 recalls the fact that this Sicyonian *(/upnos stood near the *)asklhpiei=on.

These beautiful verses, which seem to breathe the very spirit of rest, are illustrated by a bronze statue of *(/upnos now at Vienna. (Baumeister, p. 707.) The Sleep-god is advancing softly; his head is bent; a kindly smile is on his face; his eyes are half-closed; and in his outstretched right hand he holds the horn from which the poppy-juice (mhkw/nion) is to be shed on weary mortals. The right hand (as replicas show) once held a poppy-stalk,—answering to the r(a/bdos with which Hermes seals the eyes of men. Cp. Callim. Hym. Del. 134 ou)d' o(/te oi( lhqai=on e)pi\ ptero\n *(/upnos e)rei/sei. Statius Silv. 5. 4. 16(invoking Somnus): —Nec te totas infundere pennas | Luminibus compello meis: hoc turba precetur | Laetior; extremo me tange cacumine virgae. Silius 10. 354 (Somnus) Per tenebras portat medicata papavera cornu...quatit inde soporas | Devexo capiti pennas, oculisque quietem | Irrorat, tangens Lethaea tempora virga.

div3.p: o)/mmasi d' a)nti/sxois, and keep before his eyes, ta/nd' ai)/glan a(\ te/tatai tanu=n, this light which is spread before them now. By ‘this light’ I do not understand ‘a light which is no light,’ i.e., ‘darkness,’—as if this were an oxymoron like ble/pein sko/ton ( O. T. 419), e)n sko/tw| o(ra=n (ib. 1273), for tuflo\s ei)=nai. Rather ta/nd' ai)/glan is ‘dreamlight,’—such as illuminates the visions that come in sleep. Cp. Eur. Alc. 354e)n d' o)nei/rasi | foitw=sa/ m' eu)frai/nois a)/n: h(du\ ga\r fi/los | ka\n nukti\ leu/ssein, o(/ntin' a)\n parh=| xro/non. The pron. ta/nde marks that ai)/glan has this poetical sense, —the o)/nar, not the u(/par, of light. Cp. Aesch. Ag. 942h)= kai\ su\ ni/khn th/nde dh/rios ti/eis; i.e., a ni/kh which consists in yielding.—For te/tatai, referring to light, cp. Soph. Ant. 600o(\ te/tato fa/os (n.).

The words could not mean, ‘keep off this sunlight from his eyes.’ o)/mmasi might, indeed, be a dat. of interest; but a)nti/sxois could not mean, defendas. In O.C. 1651 xei=r' a)nte/xonta krato/s certainly refers to shading the eyes; but the object of the verb is that which is held before them, not that which is warded off.— Hesych. has ai)/glh: xli/dwn. *sofoklh=s *threi=. xitw/n: kai\ pe/dh para\ *)epixa/rmw| e)n *ba/kxais. The word xli/dwn (xlidh/) meant an ‘ornament,’ esp. an armlet (ye/lion). If ai)/glh was used for xli/dwn, it was so because ai)/glh could mean ‘a gleaming object’ (cp. trofh/=qre/mma). The same explanation applies to xitw/n and pe/dh,—‘a glistering tunic,’ ‘a bright chain.’ Cp. the Homeric glh/nea, prop. ‘bright objects,’ then ‘trinkets’ or the like ( Il. 24. 192). The meanings of ai)/glh given in Bekker Anecd. p. 354 add nothing, for our purpose, to Hesychius. We cannot, then, accept Welcker's version of ai)/glan here:—‘keep upon his eyes this bandage (fasciam) that is bound upon them now’ (Rhein. Mus. p. 125, 1828). —No alteration, either of a)nti/sxois or of ta/nd' ai)/glan, seems probable.
i)/qi i)/qi. The hiatus is defensible because the words are virtually interjections; i.e., there is a slight pause after the first i)/qi. Cp. Ant. 1276feu= feu=, w)= po/noi: ib. 1328 i)/tw i)/tw.

pou= sta/sei, in a fig. sense, combined with poi=...ba/sei (‘what your attitude is to be,’—‘what steps you are to take’), as oft. in expressions of perplexity; cp. Eur. Hec. 1079pa=| bw=, pa=| stw=, pa=| ka/myw; Eur. Alc. 864poi= bw=; pa=| stw=; ti/ le/gw; ti/ de\ mh/;

The MSS. give here poi= de\ ba/sei pw=s de/ moi ta)nteu=qen, and in the corresponding v. of the antistrophe (850), kei=no/ moi, kei=no la/qra|. The want of a verb for pw=s de/ moi ta)nteu=qen suggests some corruption: we cannot well take ba/sei with both clauses by changing pw=s de/ (as Hermann proposed) to pw=s te. Nor, again, is it satisfactory to expand v. 850 by adding tou/tou or ta)ndro\s after la/qra|, or by repeating la/qra| itself. Wecklein, leaving kei=no/ moi kei=no la/qra| untouched, writes here poi= de\ ta)nqe/nde ba/sei (omitting pw=s de/ moi ta)nteu=qen). But then,—granting that a dittographia was the cause of error,—it is hard to see how moi could have crept in between pw=s de/ and ta)nteu=qen. I prefer to read poi= de/ moi ta)nqe/nde ba/sei here, and to insert dh/ (this with Hermann) after the first kei=no in 850. The MS. reading may have arisen thus. A transcriber, whose eye chanced to pass over moi ta)nqe/nde, wrote poi= de\ ba/sei. Then, perceiving that he had missed two words, he preferred to begin anew, and wrote the whole verse right, but either forgot, or failed to mark clearly, that his original poi= de\ ba/sei should be deleted. (A similar case occurs in L's text of the metrical *(upo/qesis to this play: see p. 3.) A successor, finding poi= de\ ba/sei poi= de/ moi ta)nqe/nde ba/sei, deemed it obvious that the second ba/sei should be omitted. The verse thus became, poi= de\ ba/sei poi= de/ moi ta)nqe/nde. But the metrical context showed that a long final syllable was needed; and nothing seemed easier than to correct ta)nqe/nde into ta)nteu=qen. Lastly, as a verb such as pra/ceis seemed to be understood with ta)nteu=qen fronti/dos, the second poi= was altered to pw=s.—Join poi= with fronti/dos (partit. gen.): cp. O. C. 170poi= tis fronti/dos e)/lqh|;
ta)nqe/nde, adverbial: cp. 895.

o(ra=|s h)/dh, ‘thou seest now’ (how matters stand),—said with a glance or gesture towards the sleeping Philoctetes. There is a certain awkwardness in these words, since, coming so soon after o(/ra pou= sta/sei, they might naturally mean, ‘thou art already taking heed.’ Herwerden and Wecklein conjecture o(ra=|s, eu(/dei. This may be right. But the cautious vagueness of o(ra=|s h)/dh is perhaps a little in its favour.
pro\s ti/ menou=men (w(/ste) pra/ssein (au)to/): for the epexegetic inf., cp. 62 n.

kairo/s, occasion, pa/ntwn gnw/man i)/sxwn=pa/nta gignw/skwn, taking cognisance of all things,—discerning, in every case, whether the circumstances warrant prompt action. For gnw/mhn e)/xein as = gignw/skein, cp. El. 214ou) gnw/man i)/sxeis, e)c oi(/wn, k.t.l. The general sense is the same as in El. 75 f., nw\ d' e)/cimen: kairo\s ga/r, o(/sper a)ndra/sin | me/gistos e)/rgou panto/s e)st' e)pista/ths. Though we need not write *kairo/s, still kairo/s is virtually personified both by gnw/man i)/sxwn and by a)/rnutai. Pausanias (5. 14. 7) saw two altars at the entrance to the Olympian stadium; one was to Hermes *)enagw/nios,—the other to *kairo/s, who enabled athletes to seize the critical moment in a struggle. Cp. Anthol. 10. 52 eu)= ge le/gwn to\n *kairo\n e)/fhs qeo/n, eu)= ge *me/nandre.—Blaydes takes kairo\s gnw/man i)/sxwn as=‘opportunity combined with judgment,’ and joins pa/ntwn with kra/tos (‘superiority in all cases’). The order of the words seems against this.

< polu/ ti > polu\. No curtailment of v. 854 (ma/la toi a)/pora pukinoi=s e)nidei=n pa/qh) is probable. The addition of polu/ ti makes v. 838 equal to v. 854: and the remedy, however uncertain, is at least not violent. See Appendix on vv. 852 ff.
para\ po/da, ‘then and there,’ extemplo,—by a prompt stroke of action. Cp. Plat. Soph. 242A mh/ pote dia\ tau=ta/ soi maniko\s ei)=nai do/cw, para\ po/da metabalw\n e)mauto\n a)/nw kai\ ka/tw.

a)ll' o(/de me\n k.t.l.: i.e., ‘It is true that he would be unconscious of our flight: but I know that it would be useless to sail without him.’ The stately hexameters—in contrast with the lighter rhythms of the Chorus—suit the authoritative tone in which Neoptolemus declares the purport of the oracle. As vv. 844 ff. show, he speaks in a louder voice than the Chorus deem safe.
qh/ran … e)/xomen: cp. Ai. 564dusmenw=n qh/ran e)/xwn: O. T. 566a)ll' ou)k e)/reunan tou= qano/ntos e)/sxete;
tou=de … tou=ton: cp. 1331, 1434 f., 1437.

o( ste/fanos, fig.: cp. Eur. Hec. 660ou)dei\s ste/fanon a)nqairh/setai, no one will take the palm (for misery) in her stead. Helenus had declared that the victory would belong jointly to Philoctetes and Neoptolemus, as the latter says at 1335.

kompei=n d) k.t.l. It will be a disgrace to them, when they go back to Troy, to boast of their task as accomplished, when it will be, in fact, only half done, if they bring the bow without its master. And the discredit of such a result will be aggravated by the deception used towards Philoctetes. The words a)telh= su
 yeu/desin are closely connected; ‘an incomplete result, combined with falsehood,’ i.e. not only incomplete, but obtained by falsehood. This seems better than to take su
 yeu/desin as merely=yeudw=s, ‘to boast falsely.’—Cp. El. 641du
 fqo/nw|, Ai. 933ou)li/w| su
 pa/qei, O. T. 585cu
 fo/boisi.

a)lla/, te/knon. The Chorus reply,—‘If an oracle has said that Ph. must be brought to Troy, the god himself will provide for the fulfilment of that decree. Meanwhile, thy part is to secure the bow.’ Cp. Soph. O. T. 724w(=n ga\r a)\n qeo\s | xrei/an e)reuna=| r(a|di/ws au)to\s fanei=.
o)yetai, look to it, provide for it: Ai. 1165ka/peto/n tin' i)dei=n: Theocr. 15. 2 o(/rh di/fron, *eu)no/a, au)ta=|.
w(=n for ou(/s, by attraction to lo/gwn: for the double acc. with a)mei/bh|, cp. O. C. 991.

pa/ntwn masc.: in sickness all men's sleep,—if, indeed, it can be called sleep at all,—is quick of vision (leu/ssein, epexeg. of eu)drakh\s). Words appropriate to eyesight are here used to denote perception generally. The slightest sound will stir consciousness in the sick sleeper. For a somewhat similar use of language cp. Aesch. Eum. 104eu(/dousa ga\r frh\n o)/mmasin lampru/netai.
a)ll' o(/ti du/na| k.t.l. The connection of thought is:—‘A sick man is very easily awakened. But the bow must be carried off without awakening him (la/qra|).’
du/na|=du/nasai, cp. 798. (Not Doric for du/nh|, as some have thought: h| was not changed in the Doric subjunct.)

kei=no … kei=no, with the same kind of emphasis as au)to\ tou=to in 77. The Chorus are unmoved by what N. has said (841). They repeat that the bow should be taken, and Ph. left behind. As to the conjectural insertion of dh/, see on 834.
moi, ethic (763).

o(/ti d. ma/kiston (Doric for mh/kiston) e)cidou=, lit., ‘look forth to the furthest possible point,’ i.e., ‘use all possible precaution,’—a fresh warning not to disturb the sleeper by the slightest noise, but to depart while there is yet time. Cp. Il. 20. 342me/g' e)/ciden o)fqalmoi=sin, he strained his sight (in eager search): ib. 23. 477 ou)/te toi o)cu/taton kefalh=s e)kde/rketai o)/sse.
o(/pa| is preferable to o(/pws where the particular mode of effecting the object is in question; and it is supported by the corrector of L (cr. n.).

oi)=sqa ga a(
 … pa/qh. I read a(
 (=h(
), with Hermann, for the w(=n or o(
 of the MSS. ‘If thou holdest this purpose—thou knowest what purpose I speak of—in relation to this man (Philoctetes), truly there are desperate troubles (a)/pora pa/qh, sc. e)/sti) for shrewd men to foresee’ (lit., ‘to see in’ such a deed). The gnw/man is the purpose of Neoptolemus to take Philoctetes on board the ship—ostensibly for conveyance to Greece—and then carry him to Troy. The allusive phrase, oi)=sqa ga a(
 au)dw=mai, is used, because they are afraid of breathing a word which might betray the secret to the sick man, if he should awake while they were speaking. tau/tan emphatically opposes this plan to kei=no—the course which they themselves recommend. tou/tw| is a dat. of relation, nearly=peri\ tou/tou: cp. Plat. Rep. 598D u(polamba/nein dei= tw=| toiou/tw| o(/ti eu)hqh/s tis a)/nqrwpos (‘in the case of such a person’). pukinoi=s: cp. Critias *si/s. fr. 1. 12 pukno/s tis kai\ sofo\s gnw/mhn a)nh/r. e)nidei=n, oft. used of seeing a difficulty or danger in a proposed course of action: Her. 1. 89ei)/reto *kroi=son o(/ ti oi( e)norw/|h e)n toi=si poieume/noisi (what harm he foresaw for him in what was being done). Id. 1. 120ei) fobero/n ti e)nwrw=men, pa=n a)
 soi\ proefra/zomen. The a)/pora pa/qh are the horrors of the disease,—the fury which would burst forth in Philoctetes when he learned that they were taking him to Troy,—and the curses which he would invoke from *zeu\s *(ike/sios on his betrayers.—For other views of this passage, see Appendix.

ou)=ros, a fair wind, meaning here an opportune moment: schol. kairo\s e)pith/deios. The metaphor is a fitting one for sailors. When ou)=ros is fig., it more oft.= ‘a prosperous course’ ( Tr. 815).—This is better than to take the word literally, as if the wind, which had been adverse (640), had just changed.
ou)d' e)/xwn a)rwga\n, because his bow is in N.'s hands (cp. 931). nu/xios=sko/tios, in the darkness of sleep.

a)leh\s u(/pnos e)sqlo/s. If these words are right, they can mean only, ‘sleep in the heat is sound,’—a parenthetic comment on the preceding e)kte/tatai nu/xios. In the excitement of the Chorus, it is perhaps not strange that they should use a phrase scarcely consistent with their own u(/pnos a)/u+pnos (848). Cp. Theocr. 7. 21 mesame/rion .. | a(ni/ka dh\ kai\ sau=ros e)f' ai(masi/aisi kaqeu/dei. We certainly cannot render (with Cavallin), ‘a warm sleep (i.e. a sound one, in which a gentle warmth pervades the body) is favourable to our plan.’ a)leh/s occurs only here, though Hesych. has a)leo/s= a)leeino/s. It is, however, a correct formation from a)le/a: and a)le/as (gen.) is not a probable correction. The easy emendation a)deh\s (*d for *l) would give the sense, ‘'tis a secure (i.e. tranquil), sound sleep.’ This may be right; but I have preferred to keep the MS. reading. The addition of d) after a)leh\s might seem desirable in such a parenthesis: cp. Dem. or. 18 § 308 h)\ a)/llo ti du/skolon ge/gone, (polla\ de\ ta\ a)nqrw/pina,) ei)=t' e)pi\ tou/tw| tw=| kairw=| k.t.l.

Some reject a)leh\s u(/pnos e)sqlo/s as a mere gloss. But a marginal commentator might have been expected to use more prosaic language,—e.g., o( meshmbrino\s u(/pnos baqu/s. Dobree, reading a)deh\s, supposed the following process. (1) In v. 864 Soph. wrote a)deh\s po/nos e)sqlo/s. This was supplanted by a gloss, po/nos o( mh\ fobw=n kra/tistos, which now stands there. (2) Then the displaced a)deh\s po/nos e)sqlo/s was corrupted into a)leh\s u(/pnos e)sqlo/s, and inserted in the text after nu/xios. This hypothesis is very ingenious, but it seems much too complex to be probable.
ou)/ tinos. The conjecture, ou) freno\s, has found much favour; but, in a picture of utter helplessness, is not the vulg. more forcible? Cp. 1161 mhke/ti mhdeno\s kratu/nwn.

*)ai+/da| pa/ra kei/menos. Cp. O. T. 972kei=tai par' *(/aidh| *po/lnbos. This mode of writing is preferable to parakei/menos because parakei=sqai/ tini=‘to lie beside one,’ or ‘before one,’ with ref. to things which are ready to one's hand, or at one's disposal. But when the sense is, ‘to be lodged or deposited with one,’ kei=sqai para/ tini is used.

o(/ra, ble/p). For the double imperat. in excited utterance, cp. 981, O. C. 121prosde/rkou, leu=ssedh/. Seyffert's o(/ra is much better here than the MS. o(ra=|, ‘he sees as the dead see,’ i.e., not at all. After a)no/mmatos and nu/xios, this would be weak.

ei) kai/ria fqe/ggei. ‘See whether thy words are seasonable’ means here, ‘We fear that thy counsel (839 ff.) is unseasonable.’ We miss our kairo/s, if we stay here with Philoctetes, instead of escaping with the bow.

to\ d' a(lw/simon e)ma=| fr., as far as my thought can grasp the question, =kaq' o(/son e)gw\ katanow= to\ pra=gma. Cp. Plat. Tim. 29A to\ lo/gw| kai\ fronh/sei perilhpto/n. The acc. is one of ‘respect’ (like tou)mo\n me/ros, etc.).

po/nos o( mh\ fobw=n kra/tistos, ‘the enterprise not fraught with fear is best’ (Whitelaw): a sententious utterance, like bra/xista ga\r kra/tista ta)n posi\n kaka/ ( Ant. 1327). They mean that it is best to depart noiselessly with the bow, and so avoid the risks involved in taking Philoctetes. o( mh\ fobw=n is left vague by the proverb-like brevity of the phrase: it means, ‘which does not disturb the sleeping Philoctetes.’ The word po/nos is also in keeping with the gnomic form,—implying that there will be least po/nos in such a course; as if it were, po/nos e)la/xistos kra/tistos. Cp. sigh=s a)ki/ndunon ge/ras (meaning that sigh/, though it wins no positive ge/ras, risks nothing): ‘Discretion is the better part of valour,’ etc.

div2.p: Third e)peiso/dion. Neoptolemus, overcome by remorse, confesses that Troy is their destination. Philoctetes demands the restoration of the bow; and Neoptolemus is on the point of restoring it, when Odysseus enters. As Ph. refuses to accompany them, Odysseus decides to leave him behind, and departs for the ship, ordering N. to follow him. Meanwhile, by N.'s command, the Chorus remain with Ph. , in the hope that he may alter his resolve.

div3.p: mhd' a)festa/nai frenw=n: Eur. Or. 1021e)ce/sthn frenw=n. For a)festa/nai, cp. Vesp. 1457 to\ ga\r a)posth=nai xalepo\n | fu/seos. The words convey a hurried reproof and warning,—‘do not lose your wits’ (through fear). All their presence of mind is needed, since Philoctetes is awaking.
w)= fe/ggos...to/ t) k.t.l. For a voc. thus combined with a nom. (and art.), cp. 986: Ai. 861(w)=) kleinai/ t' *)aqh=nai kai\ to\ su/ntrofon ge/nos.

e)lpi/dwn a)/piston, not credited by my hopes,— such that my hopes could not have believed it possible. Cp. 1067: Ant. 847fi/lwn a)/klautos (=ou) klaiome/nh u(po\ fi/lwn), and n.: El. 1214a)/timos...tou= teqnhko/tos (=ou) timwme/nh u(po\ tou= t.). So e)lpi/dwn a)/piston=ou) pisteuo/menon u(po\ tw=n e)lpi/dwn. This is better than to take it as=e)lpi/dwn pi/stin ou)k e)/xon, in the sense, ‘not having the pledge, assurance, given by hopes,’ ‘not warranted’ by them (like a)nh/nemos xeimw/nwn, O. C. 677 n.).— oi)kou/rhma, as having guarded the place while he slept. So a watch-dog is called oi)kouro/s in Vesp. 970: cp. below, 1328. For the periphrasis cp. El. 417 f. patro\s...o(mili/an: Eur. Alc. 606a)ndrw=n *ferai/wn eu)menh\s parousi/a.

tou=t) is governed by e)chu/xhs), not by tlh=nai, which interprets it. a)\n might go with tlh=nai (=o(/ti tlai/hs a)/n), but is better taken, as its position suggests, with e)chu/xhs). The sense of a)\n e)chu/xhs) warrants the use of tlh=nai, without a)/n, instead of tlh/sesqai. See Appendix.
mei=nai (depending on tlh=nai) governs ta)ma\ ph/mata, to ‘wait for’ them, i.e., to wait till they were better: cp. Aesch. fr. 35 a)gw\n ga\r a)/ndras ou) me/nei leleimme/nous.

cunwfelou=nta/ moi, helping to do me good, with dat. instead of the usual acc.; cp. Ant. 560toi=s qanou=sin w)felei=n (n.). It is possible, but less simple, to supply au)ta/ (sc. ta\ ph/mata) with cunwf., ‘helping me to assuage them.’
ou)/koun: ‘the Atreidae, at any rate (ou)=n), did not thus.’ Here ou)=n (like gou=n) justifies his wonder at the youth's constancy. Cp. 907: 1389: Ant. 321(n.).
eu)fo/rws is the best correction of the MS. eu)po/rws (see cr. n.). Cp. Hippocr. Aph. 1242eu)forw/tata fe/rein: ib. 1244 dusfo/rws fe/rein (as Soph. O. T. 783dusfo/rws | tou)/neidos hgon).
ka)c eu)genw=n: cp. 384: 719.— e)n eu)xerei= e)/qou: cp. 498 e)n smikrw=| poiou/menoi (n.); and for this use of ti/qesqai, 451, 473.
ge/mwn: cp. Dem. or. 18 § 308 fula/ttei phni/k' e)/sesqe mestoi\ tou= sunexw=s le/gontos.
lh/qh: cp. Eur. Or. 211w)= fi/lon u)/pnou qe/lghtron, e)pi/kouron no/sou... | w)= po/tnia lh/qh tw=n kakw=n.
dh/=h)/dh.

su/ m' au)to\s … pote/. Philoctetes has awakened to find that the acute pains have ceased (768); but, after the violent attack of the disease, a sense of faintness (ko/pos) remains. He has been lying on his back (822). He now asks Neoptolemus to assist him in rising to his feet: ou/ m' au)to\s a)=ron, su/ me kata/sthson: where au)to/s means that he does not wish the Chorus to approach him at present. He is afraid that disgust might render them unwilling to take him on board (890). In his crippled state,— now aggravated by exhaustion,—the mere act of rising was a serious exertion. At v. 886 Neoptolemus gives the aid of his hands to the recumbent sufferer, at the same time asking him to make an effort,

nu=n d' ai)=re sauto/n: which is not, of course, contrasted with su/ m' au)to\s a)=ron, as if N. meant that Ph. must rise without help: that would be, su d' au)to\s ai)=re sauto/n. At the same time, N. says that, if Ph. prefers it, the sailors will lift him up and carry him. Ph. replies, ‘No, thank you—help me to rise, as you propose’ (889). N. assents (893), saying, ‘Stand up, and take hold of me yourself’ (as I am holding you). And v. 894 marks the moment at which Ph. slowly rises, leaning on N. Then there is naturally a pause, in order that Ph. may rest after this effort, and may feel whether he is yet strong enough to attempt walking. It is this pause which is foreshadowed by the words, i(/n), h(ni/k' a)\n ko/pos m' a)palla/ch| pote/ (880). And it is in this pause that the remorse of Neoptolemus gains the mastery.

ZippmannA. , whom Nauck and Cavallin follow in their texts, deletes both v. 880 and v. 889 as spurious, and transposes 879 to a place between 888 and 890. His two main objections to the traditional text are:—Why should Ph. , formerly so eager to start, now wish to wait till his ko/pos has passed off? (880). And why should he desire to rise before that moment, instead of resting on the ground? The view of the whole situation which I have given above will show why I believe the traditional text to be sound.

e)pi/sxwmen, intrans. (the use of this verb in 349 is a different one); to\ plei=n defines the act in regard to which delay is forbidden. Cp. M. 3. 6. 10 peri\ pole/mou sumbouleu/ein th/n ge prw/thn e)pisxh/somen. For the art. prefixed to the inf., cp. 118: 1241 o(/s se kwlu/sei to\ dra=n.

a)ll' h(/domai me/n: here me/n slightly emphasises the verb, but does not oppose it to any other thought: the nu=n d' in 886 should not be regarded as answering to it. Cp. 1278: O. T. 82a)ll' ei)ka/sai me/n, h(du/s: ib. 769 a)ll' i(/cetai me/n.

a)nw/dunon masc., to be taken adverbially with both participles (‘living and breathing, free from pain’): not neut., with ble/ponta only, as if the sense were, ‘showing the absence of pain by thy looks.’
ble/ponta=zw=nta (though here with special reference to his recent slumber, cp. 856 a)no/mmatos): Ai. 962kei) ble/ponta mh\ )po/qoun, | qano/nt' a)\n oi)mw/ceian.
ka)mpne/ont): Aesch. Ag. 671e)kei/nwn ei)/ tis e)sti\n e)mpne/wn.

w(s ou)ke/t' o)/ntos. Here sumbo/laia are the signs observable by one who watched Ph. sleeping after the attack of the disease, when he seemed like one *)ai+/da| pa/ra kei/menos (861). The chief of such signs would be, a deathly pallor, and the absence (as a spectator might think) of respiration.—By ta\s parou/sas cumfora\s are meant the agonies of disease to which he is subject, and which he had endured just before his sleep. ta\s parou/sas might be the part. of the imperf., ai(\ parh=san (cp. Soph. Ant. 1192 n.), but is more forcible if taken as pres.,=ai(\ pa/reisin: cp. 734 th=s parestw/shs no/sou. Thus the meaning is:—‘Thy symptoms (in sleep), judged in the light of (pro\s) the sufferings which afflict thee, seemed like those of a dead man.’ Such a sleep, following on such paroxysms, might well have been mistaken for death. For pro/s as= ‘in view of,’ cp. Thuc. 7. 47e)bouleu/onto pro/s te th
 gegenhme/nhn cumfora
 kai\ pro\s th
 parou=san e)n tw=| stratope/dw| kata\ pa/nta a)rrwsti/an.—Not: ‘In view of thy plight just now (i.e., while sleeping), thy symptoms seemed like those of a dead man.’ ta\s par. cumfora/s would then mean merely the condition of the sleeper, as distinguished from the sumbo/laia or outward signs thereof. But, since the inference was drawn wholly from the outward signs, the words pro\s ta\s par. cumfora\s would lose their natural force, and mean no more than ta\ paro/nta sumbo/laia skopou=nti.

sumbo/laia=su/mbola: the only Attic example of this sense; which occurs, however, in Her. 5. 92§ 7, pisto\n ga/r oi( h)=n to\ sumbo/laion (the token, or proof, martu/rion). In Eur. Ion 411a(/ te nw=|n sumbo/laia pro/sqen h)=n, the meaning is ‘dealings,’ ‘intercourse’ (the regular Attic sense of sumbo/laia being that of ‘covenants’).

nu=n d' ai)=re sauto/n. The reflexive pron. is not necessarily emphatic when thus used with an active verb: cp. Aesch. P. V. 747ti/ dh=t' e)moi\ zh=n ke/rdos, a)ll' ou)k e)n ta/xei | e)/rriy' e)mauth\n th=sd' a)po\ stu/flou pe/tras...; At v. 879 Ph. asked N. to assist him; and now—after a kindly greeting—N. proceeds to do so. His hands are now stretched forth to Ph. , ready to raise him, and the words nu=n d' ai)=re sauto/n prepare Ph. for the effort.
ei) de/ soi ma=llon fi/lon: i.e., he need not make even this effort, but can be lifted from the ground.
tou= po/nou ga\r: since Neoptolemus and Philoctetes are agreed upon the voyage, the sailors will not grudge the trouble of carrying their master's friend.

ai)nw= ta/d), w)= pai=. ‘Thanks, my son’ (lit., ‘I commend what you say’). The phrase implies a courteous recognition of the proposal that the sailors should carry him: but, as is shown by kai/ m) e)/pair) w(/sper noei=s, it is not a direct way of refusing the offer, like ‘No, thank you.’ The formula ai)nw= ta/de regularly means, as here, ‘I commend your words’ ( Eur. Or. 786, Eur. Med. 908). Eur. Itis known, indeed, that Soph. used ai)nw= like e)painw=, as a civil form of refusal, in his Alcmaeon (Hesych. s. v. ai)nw=): cp. Hes. Op. 641nh=) o)li/ghn ai)nei=n, mega/lh| d' e)ni\ forti/a qe/sqai. But here ai)nw= ta/de is better taken in its simple and usual sense.
e)/ason: cp. 1257.
sunnai/ein (epexeg. inf.) can be said of companionship in a brief voyage, as nai/ein is oft. no more than ‘to be in’ a place: O. C. 117 n.
e)/stai ta/d): cp. O. C. 1773dra/sw kai\ ta/de.
i(/stw=a)ni/stw: O. T. 143, O. T. 147.

kau)to\s a)nte/xou, sc. e)mou=: i.e., as I am supporting thee, so, on thy part, cling to me. Cp. Her. 2. 121e)kei/nou th=s xeiro\s a)nte/xesqai. For the omission of the gen., cp. Ar. Ach. 1120fe/re, tou= do/ratos a)felku/swmai tou)/lutron. | e)/x), a)nte/xou, pai=.
su/nhqes … e)/qos: cp. Ant. 502kle/os...eu)klee/steron (n.).

ti/ dh=t' a)\n drw=|m). Schaefer's insertion of a)/n is not indispensable. The simple optat. is grammatically possible. But a)/n is clearly right, because the question here is a practical one (not the less so, because no answer is expected); i.e., the speaker is really deliberating what he shall do next: it does not refer merely to abstract possibility, like tea/n, *zeu=, du/nasin ti/s...kata/sxoi; ( Ant. 605). Cp. O. C., Appendix on v. 170. The case is precisely similar to that in 1393 (where a)/n is certain), ti/ dh=t' a)\n h(mei=s drw=|men;

drw=|m). Contracted verbs had two ways of forming the act. optat. pres.: (1) with i, as dra/-o-i-mi, contr. drw=|mi, the mode proper to verbs with a thematic vowel: (2) with ih, as dra-o-i/h-n, contr. drw/|hn, where, though the thematic vowel o is kept, the endings follow the analogy of the verbs which have no such vowel (‘verbs in mi’). The only Homeric examples of (2) are Od. 4. 692filoi/h, and ib. 9. 320 foroi/h. But in the 5th cent. B.C. this second formation was already predominant in For Attic. the sing. number the first formation had become rare, though Attic poets could still use it whenever it was metrically convenient: e.g. 1044 (and Soph. O. T. 1470) dokoi=m): Soph. Tr. 1235nosoi=: Aesch Aesch. P. V. 978nosoi=m' a)/n. Some instances of the 3rd sing. occur also in Attic prose: as Thuc. 2. 79(and 100) dokoi=: Legg. 664 E phdw=|, etc. (Cp. Curtius, Greek Verb, ch. XIV., p. 335 Eng. tr.) In dual and plur. the prevalence of the second formation appears to have been less decisive; and the 3rd pers. plur. always retained the first formation (e.g. drw=|en, not drw/|hsan).

tou)nqe/nde ge, adverbial: cp. 834: O. C. 476to\ d' e)/nqen (n.). ge at the end of the v., as 438, O. C. 265, etc. The emphasis is fitting here. He has reached the furthest point to which the deception can be carried, since it must be revealed by the presence of Odysseus at the ship.

e)ce/bhs, ‘digressed’ from the matter in hand: cp. Dem. or. 18 § 211 e)panelqei=n ou)=n, o(po/qen e)ntau=q' e)ce/bhn, bou/lomai. I. T. 781 (Orestes to Iphigeneia, whom he has interrupted by an unguarded exclamation) ou)de/n: pe/raine d): e)ce/bhn ga\r a)/llose (‘my thoughts had wandered’).
lo/gw| is better here than lo/gwn. The latter is more suitable in such a phrase as poi= lo/gwn a)mhxanw=n | e)/lqw; El. 1174.

ou)k oi)=d' o(/poi xrh\ k.t.l.: he does not know in what words he can break the truth to Ph. ,—that they are going to Troy. After an obscure hint in vv. 912 f., he at last speaks bluntly (915). Cp. Hipp. ma. 297 D ou)k e)/ti e)/xw, w)= *(ippi/a, o(/poi tra/pwmai, a)ll' a)porw=: su\ de\ e)/xeis ti le/gein;—Nauck wishes for stre/fein, which would imply an artful ‘twisting’ of speech; cp. Ar. Th. 1128ai)ai=: ti/ dra/sw; pro\s ti/nas strefqw= lo/gous; But tre/pein better suits the ingenuous perplexity of one who simply doubts what course he ought to take.
a)porei=s de\ tou= su/; Remembering the behaviour of his former visitors when it came to the all-important point (310), Ph. is alarmed at the first trace of embarrassment in Neoptolemus.

e)nqa/de … tou=de tou= pa/qous (partit. gen.)=e)nqa/de th=s a)pori/as: at such an advanced point in it that I do not know what to say next (897).—Not, as Wunder took it, ‘at such a point that I must speak’ (referring to mh\ le/ge).
ou) dh/...; as Tr. 668: and with pou added, O. T. 1472, Ant. 381.—For w(/ste after e)/peisen cp. 656 n.
nau/thn= nauba/thn (246), vectorem: so Aesch. Pers. 719pezo\s h)\ nau/ths, C. 3. 4. 30 navita.

a(/panta dusxe/reia: for the neut. plur. as subject, with sing. subst. as predicate, cp. O. C. 883a)=r' ou)x u(/bris ta/d); Od. 24. 433lw/bh ga\r ta/de g' e)sti/: Stobaeus Flor. 5. 3 fo/bos ta\ qei=a toi=si sw/frosin brotw=n: Lys. or. 4 § 7 pw=s tau=t' e)sti\ pro/noia; Dem. or. 19 § 72 e)/sti de\ tau=ta ge/lws.

th\n au(tou= fu/sin lipw/n, whereas to\ gennai=on is to\ mh\ e)cista/menon e)k th=s au(tou= fu/sews (cp. 51 n.). Fraud was foreign to his nature (88).— ta\ mh\ proseiko/ta, such things as do not befit him: for the generic mh/, cp. 170, 409, 444, 909.

ou)de
 e)/cw tou= futeu/santos, nothing that deviates from his example. The father (Achilles) is the para/deigma which regulates the son's conduct,—as in Eth. N. 3. 6 the spoudai=os is w(/sper kanw
 kai\ me/tron (tw=n kalw=n). Thus the use of e)/cw is justified: it expresses a departure from the lines of the pattern. Cp. Legg. 876 E dou=nai ta\ paradei/gmata toi=s dikastai=s tou= mh/pote bai/nein e)/cw th=s di/khs. Musgrave quotes Libanius 1. 574 tou= th=s po/lews h)/qous kai\ th=s e)mh=s politei/as e)/cw to\ pra=gma ei)=nai dokei=. The boldness of the expression e)/cw tou= futeu/santos finds some analogy in the phrase kata/ tina as=kata\ tro/pon tino/s: Plat. Parm. 126C kata\ to
 pa/ppon...pro\s th=| i(ppikh=| diatri/bei (following his example). So Alciphron can say o( pai=s e)cema/cato to
 dida/skalon (took the stamp of his teacher), instead of to
 tou= didaska/lou xarakth=ra (3. 64). I cannot, then, think with Nauck that futeu/santos is spurious. proseiko/tos would be but a tame substitute. A reference to the youth's inherited generosity seems fitting here: cp. 874, 1310. tou)mfuteuqe/ntos (Tournier) is ingenious, but less forcible than tou= futeu/santos.

e)sqlo\n: Blaydes would take this as= ‘of noble birth,’ in order that Ph. may not praise himself. A similar feeling has prompted conjectures (cr. n.). But by e)sqlo/n Ph. means that the kindness of N. is not disgraced by its recipient. The situation is one in which he can say this with perfect dignity and propriety. So he refers to himself elsewhere as the comrade (1131) and benefactor (670) of Heracles; as a zealous ally of the Greek chiefs (1027); as one who has shown rare courage under his trials (535), and who will not fail in gratitude to his deliverer (1370). In like manner Oedipus reminds his Attic hosts that he is no unworthy guest ( Soph. O. C. 287, Soph. O. C. 625 f.).
pa/lai: cp. 589.

ou)/koun (872 n.) e)n oi(=s ge dra=|s (ai)sxro\s fanei=): in respect of thy deeds (thus far) thou certainly wilt not be found ai)sxro/s: e)n oi(=s de\ au)da=|s, but in respect of what thou sayest—i.e., in respect of the future conduct which thy words foreshadow,
o)knw= (mh\ ai)sxro\s fanh=|s).—For the emphasis given to dra=|s by place and pause, cp. 989 (*zeu/s), 1009 (sou=): Ant. 555su\ me\n ga\r ei(/lou zh=n, e)gw\ de\ katqanei=n.

dra/sw, delib. aor. subjunc.: cp. 757.—a(\ mh\ dei=: cp. 903. He has been base, first, as le/gwn ai)/sxist' e)pw=n —telling the falsehood that he was sailing to Greece: next, as kru/ptwn a(\ mh\ dei=— hiding the truth, that Ph. must go to Troy.
a(nh\r o(/d): the transition to the 3rd pers., marking bitter indignation, is like that in Tr. 1238, where Heracles fears disobedience in Hyllus.

ei) mh\ )gw\: cp. O. T. 1086ei)/per e)gw\ ma/ntis ei)mi\ kai\ kata\ gnw/man i)/dris: El. 472ei) mh\ )gw\ para/frwn ma/ntis e)/fun | kai\ gnw/mas leipome/na sofa=s.—For gnw/mhn (which Naber alters to gnw/mwn) cp. El. 546a)bou/lou kai\ kakou= gnw/mhn: O. T. 687a)gaqo\s w)\n gnw/mhn. The dat. in Ai. 1374gnw/mh sofo\n | fu=nai.
to\n plou=n stelei=n: Ai. 1045w(=| dh\ to/nde plou=n e)stei/lamen. But ste/llw without plou=n in 571, Ai. 640.
lipw\n (sc. to\n plou=n stelw=) after e)klipw/n, as 1383 ai)sxu/noit) after kataisxu/nei. Cp. O. C. 841proba=q' w(=de, ba=te.

pe/mpw, convey: cp. 1368, 1399, 1465. The v. l. pe/mpwn (prob. a mere error caused by lipw
) would require us to supply to
 plou=n ste/llw (subjunct.).— tou=t), emphatic, as Tr. 458to\ mh\ puqe/sqai, tou=to/ m' a)lgu/neien a)/n: cp. O. C. 504, O. T. 407.Remark the repetition of tou=t' a)niw=mai pa/lai so soon after 906. So Ant. 613 and 618 ou)de
 e(/rpei: ib. 614 and 625 e)kto\s a)/tas.
ou)de/n se kru/yw: for the double acc., cp. El. 957ou)de\n ga/r se dei= kru/ptein m' e)/ti: Aesch. P. V. 625mh/toi me kru/yh|s tou=q). So a)pokru/ptomai/ tina/ ti.
ga\r merely prefaces the statement: O. T. 277.

ti/ <d)> ei)=pas; I insert d), which might easily have dropped out. Such a hiatus as ti/ ei)=pas is not Sophoclean. Cp. 100 n. After a voc., we elsewhere find de/ thus used in a question: O. C. 332te/knon, ti/ d' h)=lqes; ib. 1459 pa/ter, ti/ d' e)sti\ ta)ci/wm' e)f' w(=| kalei=s; The objection to ti/ m' ei)=pas (‘what hast thou said of me?’) is that it does not suit the sense here (‘what purpose hast thou declared in regard to me?’). And ti/ g' ei)=pas would be weak.

pri\n ma/qh|s, without a)/n: cp. e(/ws without a)/n, 764. Soph. affords some 14 instances of pri\n a)/n with subjunct. (as 332, Soph. 1332), and 7 instances (besides this) of simple pri/n with subjunct.,— Soph. Ant. 619; Soph. Tr. 608, Soph. Tr. 946; Soph. Ai. 742, Soph. Ai. 965; fr. 583. 2, fr. 596.
poi=on ma/qhma; Cp. Ant. 42poi=o/n ti kindu/neuma; For the verb with its cognate noun, cp. 150 me/lon...me/lhma.
dra=sai with double acc.: 803 n.
sw=sai kakou=: cp. Ant. 1162sw/sas me\n e)xqrw=n...xqo/na (n.).
cu\n soi\: cp. 1335.
kai\ tau=t)...; For kai/ in preface to an indignant question, cp. O. C. 263 n.

a)lhqh=, predicative adj., with adverbial force, and so here=a)lhqw=s (a word not extant in Soph. ). In Plat. Lach. 186A, tou=to me\n a)lhqh= le/geis (as also in Menon 98 B etc.), Krüger and others take a)lhqh= as an adv.,=a)lhqw=s: but the sense there is, ‘you are right as to that,’—tou=to being acc. of respect, and a)lhqh= acc. governed by le/geis.
kratei= tou/twn, controls these things (like kratei=n tw=n pragma/twn, Dem. or. 1. § 26), i.e., ordains that they must be so.
w)= ce/ne, a form which he has not used since 219. He has hitherto addressed N. as w)= te/knon, or w)= pai=. Cp. 932.
a)ll' ou)x oi(=o/n te: so O. C. 1418.Other places where e)sti/ is omitted after oi(=o/s te are O. C. 1136, Tr. 742, O. T. 24.
tw=n e)n te/lei: 385 n.

927 ff. While Philoctetes makes this appeal, Neoptolemus stands with averted face (935), still holding the bow. Despairing anguish could not be more pathetically expressed than by the transitions from imprecation to entreaty, and from entreaty to the half-soliloquy in which he imagines the future (952).

pu=r, the symbol of a ruthless destroyer. Neoptolemus is leaving utter desolation behind him. The image is one which Lemnos itself might well suggest (cp. 800 n.). The combination of pu=r with dei=ma (‘monster’) curiously recalls a passage in the Lysistrata (which appeared two years before this play), 1014 f. ou)de/n e)sti qhri/on gunaiko\s a)maxw/teron, | ou)de\ pu=r, ou)d' w(=d' a)naidh\s ou)demi/a po/rdalis. Elsewhere pu=r is a figure for warlike rage, as Il. 20. 371tw=| d' e)gw\ a)nti/os ei)=mi, kai\ ei) puri\ xei=ras e)/oike: or, generally, for an irresistible bane, as Eur. fr. 432 a)nti\ puro\s ga\r a)/llo pu=r | mei=zon e)bla/stomen gunai=|kes polu\ dusmaxw/teron. Cp. C. 4. 4. 42 Dirus per urbes Afer ut Italas, | Ceu flamma per taedas etc. Tennyson: ‘The children born of thee are fire and sword.’

pa=n dei=ma, utter monster. As h( pa=sa bla/bh (622), said of a man, is equiv. to o( pa=s bla/bh (w)/n), so here pa=n dei=ma is equiv. to pa=s dei=ma. The latter would describe the man as effaced; the former describes the dei=ma as perfect; and thus the sense is not affected by the assimilation of the adj. pa=s to the subst. But we cannot compare Ar. Th. 787w(s pa=n e)sme\n kakon <*>, ka)c h(mw=n e)stin a(/panta, | e)/rides, nei/kh, sta/sis, a)rgale/a k.t.l., since there the sense is, ‘every sort of ill,’ not, ‘utter ill.’ For dei=ma cp. Eur. H. F. 700pe/rsas dei/mata qhrw=n.

panourgi/as … te/xnhma, a work of art in panourgi/a (defining gen.),—i.e., a man in whom panourgi/a assumes its subtlest form; not, a work of art produced by (personified) *panourgi/a (like Shakespeare's, ‘Confusion now hath made his masterpiece,’ Macb. 2. 3. 71). te/xnhma could not stand for texni/ths, ‘contriver’ of panourgi/a, as Nauck implies by comparing Hor. Epod. 17. 35(of Canidia) cales venenis officina Colchicis. For the neut. noun, cp. a)/lhma, kro/thma, la/lhma, mi/shma, paipa/lhma, etc. ( Ant. 320 n.).
ei)rga/sw, followed by h)pa/thkas. A perf. follows an aor. in 676, 1172: an aor. follows a perf. in 666.
to\n prostro/paion: cp. 773.

to\n bi/on. This verse deserves notice as one of those which indicate the sensitiveness of the Athenian ear to accent. For if bi/on could have been mistaken for bio/n, the effect would have been as unhappy as when the actor pronounced galh/n) too much like galh=n ( Ar. Ran. 304).—Cp. 1282.
932 A dactyl is here followed by a tribrach, as in 1029 we have two tribrachs. In both verses the rhythm marks agitation.
qew=n patrw/|wn, the gods of Achilles and Peleus. Cp. O. C. 756 n.

me mh\ a)fe/lh|: for mh/ followed by a, cp. on 782 n. Either the act. or the midd. is admissible. But a strong reason for preferring the midd. is that Soph. uses it in three other places; and if in 376 there was a metrical motive for a)fairh/soito, there was none in 1303 for a)fei/lou, or in Soph. Ai. 100 for a)fairei/sqwn. On the other hand, he nowhere uses the active a)fairei=n. In Soph. O. T. 1522, where L has the true e(/lh|, some later MSS. have e(/lh|s: and probably a)fe/lh|s in L here is merely a like error.
prosfwnei=: for the 3rd pers., cp. 910.

w(s meqh/swn mh/poq). The mh/ here is probably ‘generic,’ as in 253 w(s mhde\n ei)do/t' i)/sqi, and 415 w(s mhke/t' o)/nta ...no/ei. ‘He looks away, like one who will never give it up.’ [Another view is that it is the mh/ of ‘strong assurance’; see 1329, O. C. 656oi)=d' e)gw/ se mh/ tina | e)nqe/nd' a)pa/cont' a)/ndra: i.e., as we could say, oi)=da au)to\n mh/pote meqh/sonta, so in o(ra=| pa/lin w(s mh/pote meqh/swn the mh/ emphasises the speaker's conviction of N.'s resolve. This is possible, but seems less natural.] For the omission of the object to meqh/swn, cp. 801 (e)/mprhson).— o(ra=| pa/lin: cp. Il. 21. 415pa/lin tre/pen o)/sse faeinw/. Eur. Hec. 343pro/swpon e)/mpalin | stre/fonta.

lime/nes, bays or creeks, near the cave,—not necessarily implying anchorage: cp. 302 ou) ga/r tis o(/rmos e)sti/n (n.). So in Il. 1. 432 the limh\n polubenqh/s is merely the bay, while the o(/rmos is the anchorage within it (ib. 435).— problh=tes here=a)/krai, promontories: in Homer always an adj. (with a)ktai/, etc.). It is curious to note that, just in that part of his epic for which he would naturally have consulted this play, Quintus Smyrnaeus reproduces this use of problh/s (10. 175 ou)de/ nu to/n ge | ei)/rgousin problh=tes).
cunousi/ai qhrw=n: for the periphrasis cp. 868.
katarrw=ges, only here: a poet. substitute for a)porrw=ges ( Xen. An. 4. 6. 3pe/tra a)porrw/c).
le/gw, subj.: cp. Ant. 1341ou)d' e)/xw | pro\s po/teron i)/dw.
a)naklai/omai, lament aloud. Antiphon A. d. § 1 ta\s...a)tuxi/as a)naklau/sasqai pro\s u(ma=s.

parou=si, present with me as ye are, toi=s ei)wqo/sin (parei=nai), ye, who are wont to be so. In freely rendering these words, ‘my wonted companions,’ we must remember that parou=si is not a subst. (like qeatai=s or ma/rtusi): i.e., we could not say, oi( ei)wqo/tes paro/ntes, meaning, ‘my wonted companions.’ That would be possible only if parw/n had acquired a definitely substantival use (like a)/rxwn). Thus in Thuc. 7. 75oi( zw=ntes kataleipo/menoi is not ‘the living remnant,’ but ‘those who were left behind alive’ (zw=ntes katelei/ponto).
o)mo/sas, by giving his promise (527), though no formal oath had been exacted (811).

prosqei/s, having added the pledge of the hand (813) to his word. So fr. 428 o(/rkou de\ prosteqe/ntos (added to the yilo\s lo/gos, cp. O. C. 651 n.) e)pimeleste/ra | yuxh\ kate/sth. The v. l. proqei/s is weaker, and strange as a substitute for protei/nas (cp. 1292): it is not adequately defended by Eur. Hec. 66bradu/poun | h)/lusin a)/rqrwn protiqei=sa. Cp. Xen. An. 3. 2. 4(the Persian king) au)to\s o)mo/sas h(mi=n, au)to\s decia\s dou/s, au)to\s e)capath/sas sune/labe tou\s strathgou/s.

i(era\ sc. o)/nta, sacred as the bow is: because it had been given by Apollo to Heracles, himself now a god (728). Cp. 198 ta\ qew=n a)ma/xhta be/lh: 657.— tou= *zhno\s *(hrakle/ous, gen. of o( *zhno\s *(hraklh=s, the bow, once, of Heracles son of Zeus. I do not take i(era\ with this gen., because, though the bow may fitly be called ‘sacred,’ it cannot be called ‘sacred to Heracles’ without straining the natural sense of i(ero/s tinos. Rather tou= *z. *(hr. is an indignant development of i(era/:—‘he has stolen my bow,—a sacred one,—the bow of Heracles.’—For tou= *z. *(hrakl., cp. O. C. 623xw( *dio\s *foi=bos, Ai. 172tauropo/la *dio\s *)/artemis (without art.).

fh/nasqai: the aor. midd. of the simple fai/nw occurs nowhere else; nor is there any other place where any part of the simple midd. fai/nomai is trans., ‘to show.’ (a)pefhna/mhn is frequent.) The poet prob. meant fh/nasqai here to be a little more than fh=nai,— i.e., ‘to show for his own glory,’ ‘to display.’ The object to fh/nasqai is ta\ to/ca only. It would be awkward to understand (with Nauck) e)me\ kai\ ta\ to/ca: and the display of the captive is implied in the next vv.

Seyffert, placing only a comma after qe/lei, and reading kou)x w(s for kou)k oi)=d) in 946, understands:—‘He wishes to boast (fh/nasqai, gloriose de se praedicare) among the Argives that (w(s 945) he is bringing me by force, a strong man whom he has taken, and not as it were a dead man whom he is slaying’ (kou)x w(s e)nai/rwn nekro/n). But the awkwardness of this conjectural kou)x w(s is intolerable, when w(s in 945 is to mean ‘that.’ Further, it is clearly essential to the force of the passage that there should be a full stop (or colon) at qe/lei. Verse 945 is an indignant amplification of 941, e)s *troi/an m' a)/gei. ‘He is taking me by force, I say, as if he had captured (w(s e(lw\n) a strong man,’ etc.

kou)k oi)=d). Neoptolemus knows, of course, that Ph. is feeble. But these words mean that, in taking Ph. to Troy, N. does not realise what he is doing; he will not gain a triumph, but merely extinguish a flickering life. As this speech wavers between curses and prayers, so it vacillates between denunciation of the youth's cruel guile (926 f.), and something like pity for his thoughtless folly. Cp. 1010.
e)nai/rwn nekro\n: cp. Ant. 1030to\n qano/nt' e)piktanei=n (n.).
kapnou= skia/n: Ant. 1170ta)/ll' e)gw\ kapnou= skia=s | ou)k a)\n priai/mhn (n.).

ei)/dwlon a)/llws: O. C. 109oi)kti/rat' a)ndro\s *oi)di/pou to/d' a)/qlion | ei)/dwlon: ou) ga\r dh\ to/ g' a)rxai=on de/mas (n.). The adv. a)/llws means (1) ‘otherwise,’ O. C. 492: (2) ‘besides,’ ‘moreover,’ O. T. 1114: (3) ‘otherwise than well,’ and so, ‘vainly,’ O. T. 333,—as e(/teros oft.=kako/s: (4) with a subst. implying disparagement, ‘merely’; Nub. 1203 a)riqmo/s, pro/bat' a)/llws, ‘ciphers—very sheep’: Dem. or. 19 § 24 oi( d' a)ntile/gontes o)/xlos a)/llws kai\ baskani/a katefai/neto, ‘the opposition was pronounced to be mere obstructiveness and spite’ (where see Shilleto). This sense comes through that of ‘vainly,’ ‘uselessly.’
e)pei\ ou)d): for the synizesis cp. 446 n.

a)ll), though only conjectural (cr. n.), is confirmed by the fact that elsewhere also the hortative is combined with the limiting a)lla/: see 1040 f.: O. C. 238 ff. a)ll' e)pei\...a)ll' e)me\ (me, at least). The loss of a)ll) before a)po/dos here may have been due to a reminiscence of 932.
a)lla\ nu=n: cp. El. 411sugge/nesqe/ g' a)lla\ nu=n.

e)n sautw=| genou=: Xen. An. 1. 5. 17e)n e(autw=| e)ge/neto, he recovered himself (after an outbreak of passion). So Her. 1. 119ou)/te e)cepla/gh e)nto/s te e(wutou= gi/netai, ‘he did not lose his presence of mind, but mastered his feelings.’ The simple gen. of the reflex. pron. is similarly used, Soph. O. C. 660(n.): Dem. or. 2 § 30 (which confirms e)/ti here): dei= dh\...u(mw=n au)tw=n e)/ti kai\ nu=n genome/nous k.t.l.—The v. l. e)n sautou= here has been supported by Vesp. 642 skordina=tai ka)/stin ou)k e)n au(tou=. But there I should read either e)/q' au(tou= or e)n au(tw=|. In Plat. Charm. 155D ou)ke/t' e)n e)mautou= h)=n, other readings are e)p' e)mautou= and e)n e)mautw=|; the last is prob. right.
siwpa=|s: cp. O. C. 1271ti/ siga=|s; ou)de/n ei)m', am as dead: El. 677: O. C. 393o(/t' ou)ke/t' ei)mi/, thnikau=t' a)/r' ei)/m' a)nh/r;

w)= sxh=ma pe/tras di/pulon, not dipu/lou, since sxh=ma-pe/tras forms one notion: cp. Ant. 794nei=kos a)ndrw=n cu/naimon.—The word sxh=ma, in such a periphrasis, usu. denotes stateliness (as in Eur. Alc. 911w)= sxh=ma do/mwn, and so Eur. Hec. 619w)= sxh/mat' oi)/kwn): here it marks the distinctness of the form present to his thoughts (like sw=ma...qhro\s in Soph. O. C. 1568). Alike in bodily and in mental suffering, the outlines of surrounding objects become vividly stamped upon the mind. Cp. Byron, Prisoner of Chillon (stanza x): ‘But then by dull degrees came back | My senses to their wonted track; | I saw the dungeon walls and floor | Close slowly round me as before.’
au)=qis au)= pa/lin, a rarer phrase than au)=qis pa/lin (342), or au)=qis au)= ( Ar. Ach. 854): in Soph. O. C. 1418 we should read au)=qis a)\n pa/lin.

953 The MSS. and edd. give pro\s se\ here: but pro/s se is surely required by the sense. There is no emphasis on the pron. (as if the cave were contrasted with some other abode). The stress is on yilo/s: his former life in the cave, when he had the bow, is contrasted with the life now before him.
yilo/s: cp. O. C. 1029ou) yilo\n ou)d' a)/skeuon (n.).
au)anou=mai: El. 819a)/filos au)anw= bi/on. This is one of the rare instances in which a true reading, lost to the text of L, has been preserved by the schol.: cp. Ant. 40, Ant. 235.
pthno\n (cp. 288)...o)reiba/thn (cp. 937): the epithets are not merely ornamental; they suggest the distance of the prey, and so the helplessness of the unarmed man.

toisi/d), if right, is the only example of this Ionic form in Soph. ; nor is there any in In Eur. Med. 1295, where the MSS. have toi=sin or toi=sde/ g), Canter gave toi=sid), which Elms. wrote toisi/d) (comparing toio/nd)): Wecklein there, as here, conjectures toi=sd' e)/t) (Ars Soph. em. p. 33); though here, in his ed., he keeps toisi/d). The question here is,—Does L's toi=sid), corrected by the 1st hand from toi=sin, point rather to toisi/d) or to toi=sd' e)/t)? To the former, I think. If toi=sd' e)/t) had been the original reading, the unusual form toi=sid) would hardly have supplanted it. The accent proves nothing, for the epic toi/sdessi used to be written toi=sdessi.
pare/cw dai=ta (tou/tois) u(f' w(=n e)ferb.: cp. O. T. 1362o(mogenh\s d' a)f' w(=n e)/fun. M. 1. 2. 6 diale/gesqai par' w(=n a)\n la/boien to\n misqo/n (i.e., tou/tois par' w(=n).

Wunder proposes a)f) w(=n, objecting that u(f) w(=n implies active ministration, ‘as by a nurse.’ It is true that tre/fomai u(po/ tinos properly refers to the nurse, while the source of nourishment is denoted by tini/, a)po/ tinos, or e)/k tinos (cp. 535). But here Ph. is poetically saying that he had forced the beasts to become his trofei=s,—as he will now be theirs; and so u(po/ is right. a)po/ would also be right, but tamer.
kai/ m), not ka)/m), because the contrast between e)qh/rwn and qhra/sousi suffices. Cp. 47 n.

r(u/sion is what one ‘draws to oneself,’ as spoil, or by way of security ( O. C. 858 n.), or in reprisal. fo/non fo/nou … r(u/sion tei/sw=I shall pay (to the beasts) my life-blood, taken by them in reprisal for life-blood (fo/nou, gen. of the price or equivalent). Cp. Polyb. 4. 53 r(u/sia kath/ggeilan toi=s *(rodi/ois, ‘formally threatened them with reprisals’ (for bloodshed).—tei/sw, e)/teisa, was the Attic spelling in the poet's time, as inscrr. prove: O. T. 810(2nd ed.).
tou= dokou=ntos, partic. of the imperf. (o(\s e)do/kei): cp. O. T. 835pro\s tou= paro/ntos n.: O. C. 1565 n.: Ant. 1192.
ou)de\n ei)de/nai kako/n, not, ‘to have no evil sentiment’ (like the epic h)/pia ei)dw/s, etc.), but simply, ‘to know no evil’: cp. Ant. 301dusse/beian ei)de/nai (n.).

mh/pw. The mere fact that o)/loio comes first means that the curse does pass his lips,—though it is instantly qualified by mh/pw. Hence the effect of the Greek is not like this—‘I say not yet, Mayest thou perish’: but rather;—‘Perish !—no, not yet,’ etc. Just so in Eur. Med. 83o)/loito me\n mh/: despo/ths ga/r e)st' e)mo/s, ‘curse him—I may not,’ etc. (In Soph. Tr. 383o)/lointo mh/ ti pa/ntes k.t.l., the context is different.)
pri\n ma/qoim): the optat. is due to o)/loio: cp. 325 n.: Tr. 655mh\ stai/h | ... pri\n a)nu/seie.

ei) kai\ pa/lin. Nauck, referring to Porson's note on Eur. Phoen. 1464(=1450 Dind.)—as to which, see Appendix—says that kai\ cannot be right; and on that assumption various emendations have been proposed.
