The defence of the metre turns on the distinction between two classes of monosyllables: (1) those which count as belonging to the words after them, viz., the article; prepositions; ei), h)/, kai/, mh/, ou), w(s; and the interrogatives, ti/s, pw=s, pou=, poi=, ph=|: (2) those which count as belonging to the words before them, viz., all enclitics, and such other words as cannot begin a sentence. Since ei) and kai\ are both of the first class, ei) kai\ pa/lin is metrically equivalent to a quadrisyllable like ai(rou/menon, and therefore the rule against a final cretic does not apply. On the other hand such an ending as pri\n ma/qoim' ou)=n kai\ pa/lin would be wrong, because ou)=n is a monosyllable of the second class.

kai\ closely with pa/lin: cp. Plat. Menex. 249E i(/na kai\ au)=qi/s soi...a)pagge/llw. This seems better than to take it with metoi/seis (‘if thou wilt indeed change’). pa/lin metoi/seis is pleonastic, since Ph. does not now suppose that N.'s purpose was ever honest: cp. 1270: Thuc. 2. 13mh\ e)la/ssw a)ntikatasth=sai pa/lin.
drw=men; subjunct.
e)n soi\ k.t.l.: cp. O. T. 314 n.: I. T. 1057 kai\ ta)/m' e)n u(mi=n e)stin h)\ kalw=s e)/xein | h)\ mhde\n ei)=nai kai\ sterhqh=nai pa/tras.
prosxwrei=n: cp. e)pixwrei=n in Ant. 219: Eur. Med. 222xrh\ de\ ce/non me\n ka/rta prosxwrei=n po/lei (‘comply’).
e)moi\ me\n: for me/n emphasising the pron. (without an answering de/), cp. Ant. 11 n.

e)mpe/ptwke: cp. Philippides *)arguri/ou *)afanismo/s 1 a)ll' e)/leos e)mpe/ptwke/ tis moi tw=n o(/lwn. Soph. has used the acc. with this verb in Soph. O. C. 942(n.).— ou) nu=n prw=ton: Soph. El. 1049pa/lai de/doktai tau=ta kou) vewsti/ moi.
e)le)hson: cp. on 307 ff.

parh=|s sautou= br. o)/neidos, allow men to have ground for reproaching thee: a poet. modification of the more usual constr., parh=|s seauto\n brotoi=s o)neidi/zein (as Plat. Phaedo 101C parei\s a)pokri/nasqai toi=s... sofwte/rois). So oft. o)/neidos katalei/pein.
e)kkle/yas=e)capath/sas, as in 55 (n.): not, ‘having stolen me out of Lemnos.’

mh/pot), though it belongs to lipei=n, can be prefixed to w)/felon because the whole phrase is felt as a wish: so Od. 11. 548w(s dh\ mh\ o)/felon nika=|n. In Tr. 997 the inf. has its due precedence: h(\n mh/ pot' e)gw\ prosidei=n o( ta/las | w)/felon o)/ssois.
*sku=ron: 240 n.

nu=n d' a)/lloisi dou\s, sc. ta\ ai)sxra/, having left the base deeds to others, whom they befit (oi(=s ei)ko/s, sc. dou=nai au)ta/). Cp. 405—409. As the chief emphasis here is on the character of N. (ou)k ei)= kako\s su/), a)/lloisi is naturally contrasted with su/, rather than with kakw=n a)ndrw=n.

Other interpretations are: (1) dou\s= dou\s seauto/n, ‘yielding to others’ (than the kakoi\ a)/ndres),—i.e., to Philoctetes himself. The objection here is the use of dou/s. Eur. Phoen. 21, o( d' h(donh=| dou/s, is the only extant example of this usage in the classical period, and there it denotes self-abandonment to impulse; a tone which was apparently associated with it by Alciphron also, when he wrote dro/mw| dou\s fe/resqai (3. 47), me in pedes coniciens. (2) Reading a)/llois se dou\s: ‘having allowed thyself to be overruled by others’ (i.e., by Ph. ). But this phrase implies relations of confidence and friendship (cp. 84): it does not suit the stern and cold admonition which these verses convey. (3) With Dindorf's oi(=a (which he does not explain) the obvious sense would be, ‘having given others their due,’—an anticipation of ta)ma/ moi meqei\s o(/pla. The objection to this is that a)/lloisi then becomes strange, since Ph. is no longer contrasted with bad advisers, but is merely the recipient of the bow.

974 We are to suppose that Odysseus,—disquieted when he found that the e)/mporos (627) was not quickly followed by N.,—had set out to inquire into the cause of the delay. From a place of concealment close to the scene he has overheard the last part of the conversation, and now, at the critical moment, he springs forward. The abruptness of his entrance is marked by the divided verse (a)ntilabh/).
975 Join ei)= … pa/lin; Neoptolemus was in the act of approaching Philoctetes: Odysseus places himself between them. Cp. O. C. 1398nu=n t' i)/q' w(s ta/xos pa/lin: ib. 1724 pa/lin, fi/la, suqw=men.
pe/pramai: cp. 579 diempola=| (n.).

a(/m' au)toi=s, sc. toi=s to/cois. So in 1059 tou/twn refers to ta\ o(/pla in 1056.— stelou=si/ se, sc. the two attendants of Odysseus, who have entered along with him (cp. 985 oi(/de, and 1003). It should be remembered that, to the spectators, there could be nothing obscure in stelou=si, since Odysseus would glance or point at the men. There is no need, then, for the conjectures (cr. n.) which have sought either to introduce oi(/de or to remove au)toi=s. Greek idiom readily tolerated either change or ellipse of subject: cp. n. on O. C. 1065a(lw/setai.—We cannot well refer au)toi=s either to the attendants of Od., or to Neoptolemus and the Chorus. Odysseus would rather say, h(mi=n. If it is objected that the bow cannot be said stei/xein, the answer is that stei/xein a(/m' au)toi=s is merely a way of saying stei/xein a(/ma toi=s ta\ to/ca fe/rousi.

tolmh/state=tolmhe/state, superl. of tolmh/eis. Odysseus says in Od. 17. 284tolmh/eis moi qumo/s, e)pei\ kaka\ polla\ pe/ponqa. The contracted form has been much suspected here; Nauck pronounces it corrupt, because (1) tragic dialogue nowhere admits adjectives in a/eis, h/eis, o/eis, and (2) the contr. h/statos from he/statos is unexampled. As to (1), we may observe that in O. T. 1279 it is almost certain that Soph. used ai(mato/eis: Porson there conjectured ai(matou=ss) (for ai(/matos): Heath, with greater probability, ai(matou=s. As to (2), it is true that there is no other instance of this contr. in a superlative: but there are epic examples of the same contr. in the positive: Hom. Od. 7. 110texnh=ssai, restored by Bekker from texnh=sai (schol. texnh/essai, texniti/des): Hom. Il. 18. 475kai\ xruso\n timh=nta kai\ a)/rguron (where no emend. is probable). I do not add Hom. Il. 9. 605ou)ke/q' o(mw=s timh=|s e)/seai: for, though we cannot read o(mw=s timh=s, I would suggest that the change of one letter will restore the true reading, viz. o(mh=s timh=s: and C. LobeckA. , while conceding that Florian Lobeck (Quaest. Ion. p. 8) used ‘too great severity’ in condemning tolmh/statos, agrees with him in pointing out that such a contraction as texnh=|s for texnh/eis cannot be safely inferred from texnh=ssa for texnh/essa (Pathol. 1. 343). This consideration is a fresh argument against Hermann's conj. xalazh=|s in O. T. 1279: and it also reminds us that tolmh/statos does not imply tolmh=|s. The example of Oppian (Cyneg. 2. 140 a)rgh=nta xalina/) shows that late poets did not shrink from this contraction. In Pindar we find ai)gla/enta (P. 2. 10), a)lka/entas (O. 9. 77), a)rga/enta (O. 13. 69), fwna/enta (O. 2. 93), with synizesis of ae; though recent edd. no longer write ai)gla=nta, etc. On the whole, I believe that Soph. would have felt that he had sufficient poetical warrant for tolmh/state. No emendation seems possible which is at once tolerable in itself, and such as to account for the tradition. tolmi/state was a worthless conjecture. Such forms as klepti/statos, farmaki/statos always imply a positive in -hs or -os, and occur only in Comedy or in late prose.

mh\ e(/rph|s: the coalescence of final h with an aspirated e or a is extremely rare: Ar. Ach. 828ei) mh\ e(te/rwse (cp. Ar. Ran. 64, Ar. Lys. 736): Philemon *pareisi/wn 3 h)\ a(ma/rthma ti/;—The addition of g) to e(/rph|s is plausible: but the placid answer is perhaps more effective without it: cp. 105.
986 f. For the voc. combined with nom., cp. 867 n.

to\ pagkrate\s se/las *(hfaisto/teukton. As to the place of the second adj., see note on eu)/xruson in 393. The ‘flame wrought by Hephaestus’ is the flame which he causes to break forth from the summit of the volcano Mosychlus (800 n.): cp. Antimachus fr. 6 *(hfai/stou flogi\ ei)/kelon, h(/n r(a titu/skei | dai/mwn a)krota/tais o)/reos korufh=|si *mosu/xlou. We need not suppose, with the schol., that the epithet refers directly to Hephaestus working at his forge within the mountain. When hurled by Zeus from Olympus, Hephaestus fell on Lemnos, and was there tended by the *si/nties ( Il. 1. 593). The isle was sacred to him,—*(hfai/stw|...gaia/wn polu\ filta/th ( Od. 8. 284): kranao\n pe/don *(hfai/stoio (Perieget. Dionys. 522): Vulcania Lemnos (Valerius Flaccus 4. 440: cp. Fasti 3. 82). The chief seat of his worship was the town of Hephaestia, situated on the northern inlet (now the bay of Purnia).

The Lemnians had an early repute as workers in iron: Tzetzes on Lycophr. 460 *lh/mnioi, w(s fhsi\n *(ella/nikos, eu(=ron o(plopoii+/an. The local cult and the local industry of Lemnos were both expressed by its name *ai)qa/leia (‘sooty’), acc. to Polybius ap. Byz. Steph. s. v. *ai)qa/lh. The same name was given to Ilva (Elba), on account of its iron-stone.

ei) … a)pa/cetai: ei) with fut. ind. is oft. thus used, where indignation is implied: cp. n. on 376: El. 1210: Lys. or. 12 § 15 ou)k e)leou=ntes...ta\ tei/xh, ei) pesei=tai, ou)de\ khdo/menoi tw=n new=n, ei)... paradoqh/sontai.
tw=n sw=n: ta\ sa/, the precincts of Lemnos and her e)gxw/rioi qeoi/.

*zeu/s. Philoctetes has appealed to the local deities of Lemnos. Odysseus retorts that Zeus is above them all, and that Zeus (by his oracle) has given the behest which is now being executed.— i(/n' ei)dh=|s, here like ‘let me tell thee,’— with a dictatorial tone. Schneidewin cp. Od. 2. 111soi\ d' w(=de mnhsth=res u(pokri/nonq), Od. i(/na ei)dh=|s | au)to\s sw=| qumw=|, ei)dw=si de\ pa/ntes *)axaioi/.
mi=sos: cf. Ant. 760a)/gete to\ mi=sos.

kai\ e)caneuri/skeis, ‘dost indeed invent’ (not, ‘dost invent besides,’ i.e., pro\s toi=s e)/rgois): cp. 234 feu= to\ kai\ labei=n: and so in a question expressing surprise, O. T. 1129poi=on a)/ndra kai\ le/geis;—The compound e)caneuri/skw (like e)cafora/w in O. C. 1648) is otherwise strange to classical Greek, but appears to have been common later: Wyttenbach, in his Index to Plutarch (p. 595), quotes eight instances of it from the Moralia. The inf. le/gein is epexeg. (‘for thyself to say’): we cannot compare O. T. 120e(\n ga\r po/ll' a)\n e)ceu/roi maqei=n (n.). Perhaps it should be le/gwn.

protei/nwn, as in skh=yin protei/nein, putting the gods forward as authority for thy deed: yeudei=s ti/qhs, thou makest them false,—i.e. responsible for thy fraud. (Not, ‘makest them false prophets,’ because Ph. will never go to Troy.) For the art. with the repeated word, cp. Soph. O. C. 277kai\ mh\ qeou\s timw=ntes e<*>ta tou\s qeou\s | moi/rais poei=sqe mhdamw=s.
a)lhqei=s, because their oracle will be fulfilled: Ph. will be brought to Troy. Thus Hom. Od.parries the thrust given by yeudei=s ti/qhs.
h( d' o(do\s: cp. El. 1501po/ll' a)ntifwnei=s, h( d' o(do\s bradu/netai.
ou) fh/m).

e)gw\ de\ fhmi/. So Gernhard. The MSS. have ou)/ fhm' e)/gwge.—fhmi/. Now, fhmi/ could stand thus alone, if it were the answer to a question, fh\s h)\ ou) fh/s; but not here, where two persons are opposed to each other. Cp. O. C. 840*x*o. xala=n le/gw soi. *k*r. soi\ d' e)/gwg' o(doiporei=n.
peiste/on ta/de=dei= pei/qesqai ta/de. Cp. 1252.

h(ma=s me\n: cp. 965. These words show the speaker's bitter sense that, while he is not inferior to his enemy in point of birth, he has been superior to him in such deeds as become an e)leu/qeros. It was Odysseus, not Philoctetes, who had gone to Troy, only ‘when brought under the yoke’ (1025).
toi=s a)ri/stoisin is far better here than toi=s a)risteu=sin, in which the idea of rank partly obscures that of personal prowess.
kataska/yai: cp. O. C. 1421pa/tran kataska/yanti: ib. 1318 kataskafh=|...dh|w/sein.
ou)de/pote/ g): Ar. Pax 109ma\ to\n *dio/nuson ou)de/pote zw=nto/s g' e)mou=.
pa=n … kako/n: cp. El. 615xwrei=n a)\n ei)s pa=n e)/rgon.

gh=s to/d' ai)peino\n ba/qron= to/de gh=s ai)peinh=s ba/qron (952), this pedestal of (=consisting in) a steep land, i.e. the island, with its sheer cliffs, on which he is standing. Cp. Ai. 859<*> gh=s i(ro\n oi)kei/as pe/don | *salami=nos, w)= patrw=|on e(sti/as ba/qron (cp. ib. 135), where, as here, the whole island is the ba/qron.
e)rgasei/eis; Cp. Tr. 1232e)rgasei/wn: Ai. 326drasei/wn: fr. 900 a)kousei/wn. The only other examples in Tragedy are Eur. Phoen. 1208drasei/eton: Eur. H. F. 628feucei/w.
pe/tra|, locative (rather than instrum.) dat. with ai(ma/cw: cp. O. T. 1266e)pei\ de\ gh=| | e)/keito.

pe/tras, from the rock, with pesw/n: cp. 613, 630. Such a use of the simple gen. with pi/ptein would be somewhat harsh, were there nothing in the context to explain it; but here the adv. a)/nwqen, ‘from above,’ placed between pe/tras and pesw/n, prevents any obscurity. (a)/nwqen cannot be a prep. governing pe/tras, since it could mean only, ‘above the rock.’) Cp. Tr. 782(where Lichas is hurled from the cliff) krato\s diaspare/ntos ai(/mato/s q' o(mou=.

culla/beton au)to/n is far the best correction of L's culla/bet' au)to/n. The addition of ge to culla/bete was a feeble makeshift, and cannot be excused by assuming that the attendants had taken the initiative, so that their master merely says, ‘Yes, seize him.’ The use of the dual—‘Seize him, you two men’— is the more natural here, since each grasps one of his arms. Cp. O. C. 1437me/qesqe d' h)/dh, xai/reto/n t) (as here, in 1054, we have the plur.): so in Plut. 76 the imperat. dual a)kou/eton follows me/qesqe in 75. Other Attic examples of the imperat. dual are Ar. Av. 107ei)/paton: Plat. Euthyd. 294C e)pidei/caton. In Homer it is frequent ( Il. 1. 322; 7. 279; 8. 186, Il. 191; 20. 115; 23. 443; Od. 4. 60).
mh\ )pi\ tw=|d): for this e)pi/ with dat. (penes eum), cp. O. C. 66h)\ )pi\ tw=| plh/qei lo/gos; El. 1431.

w)= xei=res: his arms have been seized by the two attendants, one of whom stands on each side of him: but we are not to infer from 1016 (sundh/sas) that he was actually bound. Cp. 1054. Heracles in Tr. 1089 uses a similar apostrophe; w)= xe/res, xe/res k.t.l.
e)n xrei/a|: for e)n, denoting circumstance, cp. 185 n.
sunqhrw/menai: cp. Ant. 432su\n de/ nin | qhrw/meq' eu)qu/s.

w)= mhde
 u(gie\s … fronw=n. The phrase ou)de
 u(gie/s was a common one in Attic, and is often used by Eur. , though never by Aesch. , and only here by It Soph. is thrice combined with fronei=n by Eur. ,—twice to denote malevolence; fr. 496 ou)de
 dokou=sin u(gie\s a)ndra/sin fronei=n: fr. 821 w(s u(gie\s ou)de
 fasi\ mhtruia\s fronei=n | no/qoisi paisi/n: and in Androm. 448 to describe the dishonesty of Spartans,—e(likta\ kou)de
 u(gie\s a)lla\ pa=n pe/ric | fronou=ntes.

mhde
 u(gie/s, the generic mh/: i.e., the man is of the kind to have no sound thoughts: cp. 409 mhde
 di/kaion, n. This use of mhde/n (instead of ou)de/n) here would probably sound the more natural, since the same combination oft. occurred in phrases with the inf.: as Soph. Ph. 200h(donh\ de/ tis | gunaici\ mhde
 u(gie\s a)llh/lais le/gein: fr. 660 a)/llw| d' a)re/skei mhde
 u(gie\s e)k frenw=n | le/gonti pei/qein tou\s pe/las to/lmh| kakh=|: Ar. Plut. 50 to\ mhde
 a)skei=n u(gie/s.
e)leu/qeron=e)leuqe/rion: Tr. 63dou/lh me/n, ei)/rhken d' e)leu/qeron lo/gon: fr. 855 ei) sw=ma dou=lon, a)ll' o( nou=s e)leu/qeros.

oi(=) au)= m' u(ph=lqes: Odysseus had ‘stolen upon’ Ph. before, when he contrived that he should be left on Lemnos: cp. 264, 407 ff. Thus oi(=) au)= m) is the best and simplest correction of L's oi(=a/ m). But Nauck is too hasty in saying that oi(/ws m) is impossible, because the adv. was always oi(=on or oi(=a. In Vesp. 1362 f., certainly, i(/n' au)to\n twqa/sw neanikw=s | oi(/ws poq' ou(=tos e)me\ pro\ tw=n musthri/wn, the v. l. oi(/ois is tenable: but in Ai. 923oi(=os w)\n oi(/ws e)/xeis is beyond fair suspicion. And in Apoll. Rhod. 4. 786 oi(/ws is much more probable than oi(/h.
u(ph=lqes: cp. O. T. 386la/qra| m' u(pelqw/n: cp. u(potre/xein. Ovid Ars amat. 1. 742 Si tibi laudanti credidit, ipse subit (‘supplants thee’).

pro/blhma, a screen: Plat. Soph. 261A (a sophist is dusqh/reutos), fai/netai ga\r ou)=n problhma/twn ge/mein (to have a large supply of outworks), w(=n e)peida/n ti proba/lh|, tou=to pro/teron a)nagkai=on diama/xesqai pri\n e)p' au)to\n e)kei=non a)fike/sqai.

a)na/cion me\n sou=, too good for thee: cp. ou)k i)/sos as=‘greater,’ ou)x o(/mo<*>os as=‘more important’: O. T. 810 n. Wakefield cp. Phorm. 2. 2. 28 te indignas seque dignas contumelias | Numquam cessavit dicere hodie. For the emphatic place of sou=, cp. 907 dra=|s (n.).
ou)de\n h)/|dei plh\n k.t.l., i.e., ‘had no ideas’ beyond obedience to orders: a freq. phrase in Comedy ( Ar. Av. 19, Ar. Ran. 740, etc.).
kai\ nu=n, already, though the time for remorse has been short.
oi(=s= tou/tois (causal dat.) a(/.—)paqon: cp. )fa/nh Ant. 457 n.

dia\ muxw=n ble/pous), peering forth through (the obscurity of) the secret places from which it watches. Cp. Tr. 914laqrai=on o)/mm' e)peskiasme/nh | frou/roun: El. 490deinoi=s kruptome/na lo/xois (*)erinu/s). Plat. Rep. 519A h)\ ou)/pw e)nneno/hkas, tw=n legome/nwn ponhrw=n me/n, sofw=n de/, w(s drimu\ me\n ble/pei to\ yuxa/rion kai\ o)ce/ws diora=| e)f' a(\ te/traptai...; The words are illustrated by the keenness with which Odysseus had seized, and used, the weak side of the youth's character,—his desire for glory (113—120).

a)fua=. When -ea is preceded by e, the contr. is -ea=, as e)ndea=: when by i or u, it is alternatively -ia= or -lh=; -ua= or -uh=. Of the alternative forms, those with a= were the standard Attic down to about 350 B.C.: thus *eu)fua= is attested by an Attic inscription of 356 B.C. Afterwards the forms with h= prevailed. Cp. Meisterhans, p. 66, who cites Moeris p. 316: u(gia= *)attikw=s, u(gih= *(ellhnikw=s.
prou)di/dacen implies gradual teaching: cp. 538 prou)/maqon: Ai. 163gnw/mas prodida/skein.
sundh/sas with a)/gein. He anticipates such an indignity from the fact that the two attendants are still holding his arms (1005).

prou)ba/lou is an exceptional use of the midd. in this sense: but cp. Her. 6. 101i(/ppous...e)ceba/llonto (put them ashore). The word is much stronger than e)ce/qhk) (5), or proqe/ntes (268): like e)/rriyan (265), it implies ruthless scorn: cp. Soph. Ai. 830r(ifqw= kusi\n pro/blhtos.
a)/polin: cp. O. C. 1357ka)/qhkas a)/polin. To have no po/lis was to be an outcast from human society. It is the Homeric a)frh/twr, a)qe/mistos, a)ne/stios ( Il. 9. 63).
qeoi\: for the synizesis, cp. 1036, O. C. 964 n.

1022 ff. Seyffert puts a comma after zw=, and takes su
 kakoi=s polloi=s with gelw/menos (‘mocked, in addition to my woes’). This punctuation, he argues, is necessary to the sense; for Ph. means that life itself (a joy to others) is a pain to him; whereas, if su
 kakoi=s polloi=s be joined with zw=, Ph. will merely say that his pain consists in the misery of his life. Cavallin adopts this view. The answer to Seyffert's dilemma is, I think, that su
 kakoi=s polloi=s is not merely an adverbial qualification of zw= (‘live miserably’), but is here equivalent to kakoi=s polloi=s sunw/n (‘live,—in company with many woes’). There is no objection to a comma after zw=, provided that there be one after ta/las also; but it seems unnecessary. For su/n, cp. 268 n.
tw=n *)atre/ws … strathgw=n: cp. 943 n.

kloph=| te ka)na/gkh| zugei\s, brought under the yoke (of military service) by stratagem and compulsion. For zugei\s, cp. Aesch. Ag. 841mo/nos d' *)odusseu/s, o(/sper ou)x e(kw\n e)/plei, | zeuxqei\s e(/toimos h)=n e)moi\ seirafo/ros. Odysseus was in Ithaca when he was called to the war, and feigned madness. Palamedes, the envoy of the Greeks, found him ploughing with an ox and an ass yoked together, and placed the infant Telemachus in front of the plough; when Odysseus betrayed his sanity by stopping. As in the case of Solomon's judgment, the typically shrewd man relied on his conviction that art could be surprised by nature. Cp. Lycophron 815 ff., where Cassandra says to Odysseus, w)= sxe/tli), w(/s soi krei=sson h)=n mi/mnein pa/tra| (in Ithaca) | bohlatou=nti,... | plastai=si lu/sshs mhxanai=s oi)strhme/nw|. Tzetzes ad loc., and Hyginus Hyg. Fab. 95, tell the story. In Ovid Met. 13. 34Ajax contrasts himself with Odysseus:—An quod in arma prior nulloque sub indice veni | Arma neganda mihi? Potiorque videbitur ille | Ultima qui cepit, detrectavitque furore | Militiam ficto: donec sollertior isto, | Sed sibi inutilior, timidi commenta retexit | Naupliades animi, vitataque traxit in arma? Sophocles wrote an *)odusseu\s *maino/menos on this theme. According to Od. 24. 115 ff. Agamemnon and Menelaus brought Odysseus from Ithaca to Troy by persuasion.

e(pta\ nausi\, the ‘sociative’ use of the dat., to denote attendant circumstance: cp. El. 704e(/ktos e)c *ai)twli/as | canqai=si pw/lois. Xen. An. 3. 2. 11e)lqo/ntwn...*persw=n...pamplhqei= sto/lw|. The poet follows Il. 2. 718tw=n de\ *filokth/ths h)=rxen, to/cwn e)u\ ei)dw/s, | e(pta\ new=n.

e)/balon=prou)/balon: cp. Ai. 1333a)/qapton...balei=n (and ib. 1309).— w(s su\ fh/s k.t.l.: Blaydes (who compares Ar. Th. 801h(mei=s me\n ga/r famen u(ma=s, | u(mei=s d' h(ma=s) asks how Philoctetes could know this. We can only suppose that, before he was put on shore at Lemnos, the decision was announced to him by the Atreidae, who laid the responsibility on Odysseus. It was he who actually put Philoctetes ashore; and, when doing so, he may have cast the blame on his superiors,—as he does in v. 6. The occasional visitors to Lemnos (307) cannot well have been Ph. 's informants, since the Atreidae and Odysseus would not court notoriety for their deed (cp. 257).
a)/gete, take me away,—referring to the use of physical force; a)pa/gesqe, carry me with you,—referring to their ulterior purpose. For the midd., cp. 613, 988.

ou)de/n ei)mi: cp. 951.— te/qnhx' u(mi=n, dat. of relation, meaning here, ‘so far as it rested with you to kill me.’ Cp. O. C. 429a)na/statos | au)toi=n e)pe/mfqhn (n.): Ai. 1128qeo\s ga\r e)ksw/|zei me, tw=|de d' oi)/xomai.
soi, ‘in thy sight,’ ethic dat.: cp. O. T. 40kra/tiston pa=sin: Ant. 904 n.

dusw/dhs. This word might suggest that it was the presence of Ph. in the same ship which the Greeks found insupportable. But the poet cannot have meant that. Chrysè was imagined by him as close to Lemnos (fr. 352); and Ph. would have been put on board one of his own ships (1027). dusw/dhs must refer, then, to his presence at the sacrifices in Chrysè, which his cries interrupted (cp. 8, n.). Sophocles probably took this touch from the Cypria—the epic prelude to the Iliad—in which it was said that Ph. was bitten at Tenedos, where the Greek warriors were feasting, and then dia\ th\n dusosmi/an e)n *lh/mnw| katelei/fqh (Proclus Chrest. p. 475 ed. Gaisford).

pw=s … e)/cesq), o(mou= k.t.l. The MSS. have pw=s … eu)/cesq), e)mou=. For eu)/cesq) only two senses are possible: (1) ‘vow’ to sacrifice. The pres. inf. could stand: cp. Aesch. Ag. 933hu)/cw qeoi=s dei/sas a)\n w(=d' e)/rdein ta/de. But here the question is of actual sacrificing, not of vowing to do so at a future time. (2) ‘How will ye boast that ye sacrifice?’—a way of saying, ‘how will ye be able’ to do so. But such a phrase would be peculiarly awkward when the other sense of eu)/cesqe would necessarily be suggested by qeoi=s, ai)/qein, spe/ndein. Thus the context condemns eu)/cesq). With regard to the conjecture e)/cesq) it should be noted that its probability is confirmed by that of the further conjecture, o(mou= instead of e)mou=. The traditional eu)/cesq' e)mou= might, indeed, have arisen from e)/cest' e)mou=, but would have been a still easier corruption of e)/cesq' o(mou=. Given q), the proximity of qeoi=s would suggest to a scribe that e)/cesq) must be a blunder for eu)/cesq). The corruption of e)/cesq) into eu)/cesq) occurred earlier, we may infer, than that of o(mou= into e)mou=. And this inference is supported by the fact that a tradition of o(mou= as a current v. l. is preserved in *g, while the only trace of e)/cesq) appears to be a correction (prob. conjectural) in V.

Against e)/cesq) it has been objected that the fut. is required. But Ph. is ironically repeating what the Greek chiefs said long ago, and is supposing that he is once more their comrade. ‘When I have once sailed with you, how can ye sacrifice?’ With o(mou= pleu/santos, e)mou= is easily understood: cp. Soph. Tr. 803tosau=t' e)piskh/yantos (sc. au)tou=): Plat. Parm. 137C e)me\ ga\r le/geis to\n new/taton le/gwn. a)ll' e)rw/ta w(s a)pokrinonme/nou (sc. e)mou=).
o)/loisq): o)lei=sqe d): Blaydes cp. Ar. Th. 887kakw=s a)/r' e)co/loio: ka)colei= g' e)/ti [ge/ toi vulg.].—qeoi=sin, ¯˘: cp. 1020.
me/lei g): ge emphasises the verb, cp. 660.

e)pei\ ou)/pot): for this synizesis, cp. 446 n.—Philoctetes has not found the gods kindly: cp. 254, 452, 1020. But the very fact that Odysseus and his comrade have taken the trouble to visit Lemnos shows that at least the gods have some care for justice. Maimed as Ph. is (a)ndro\s a)qli/ou), he is not one whom those pitiless warriors would have sought, had not the gods driven the sense of need for him like a goad into their souls. The Greeks must be failing at Troy; and their failure is the proof that the gods are just.
1039 For the place of ti, cp. 104 n.

ke/ntron … e)mou=, the sting of need for me. The objective gen. is like that after e)piqumi/a, since ke/ntron, like oi)=stros, was constantly associated with that idea. Plat. Rep. 573E w(/sper u(po\ ke/ntrwn e)launome/nous tw=n ... e)piqumiw=n ... oi)stra=n (‘rage’). Eur. Hipp. 39ke/ntrois e)/rwtos: ib. 1303 dhxqei=sa ke/ntrois (*)afrodi/ths). So an objective gen. can follow oi)=stros when it means oi)strw/dhs e)piqumi/a: Anthol. II. 389. 4 mh\ se/ g' a)peiresi/wn oi)=stros e(/lh| ktea/nwn.

qeoi/ t' e)po/yioi, gods who look upon the deeds of men, noting the good and the evil. The name e)po/yios was specially given to Zeus,—primarily in reference to the fact that, as u(/yistos, he was so often worshipped on mountain summits,—as on Parnassus, Cithaeron, Parnes, Hymettus, Ida, the heights near Cenaeum ( Tr. 238 n.), etc. Hence his epithets e)pa/krios, a)krai=os, and in Boeotia karai=os.

Thus the invocation of patrw/|a gh=, in connection with e)po/yioi, is peculiarly appropriate for Ph. , in whose country Zeus was worshipped on Oeta (cp. 728 n.). The secondary sense of e)po/yios—‘watching over’ human life—is associated with the first by Callimachus in his Hymn to Zeus, 82 ff.: dw=kas de\ ptoli/eqra fulasse/men: i(/zeo d' au)to\s | a)/krh|s e)n ptoli/essin, e)po/yios oi(/ te di/kh|si | lao\n u(po\ skolih=|s, oi(/ t' e)/mpalin i)qu/nousin. Apoll. Rhod. 2. 1125 a)nto/meqa pro\s *zhno\s e)poyi/ou: and ib. 1182 *zeu\s au)to\s ta\ e(/kast' e)pide/rketai (as Soph. El. 175*zeu\s o(\s e)fora=| pa/nta kai\ kratu/nei). As the vindicator of right, Zeus was also called dikaio/sunos, a)la/stwr, timwro/s. Acc. to Hesych. s. v. e)po/yios, the epithet was also given to Apollo. But, next to Zeus, the deity whom e)po/yios most directly suggests is Helios pano/pths,—qew=n skopo\s h)de\ kai\ a)ndrw=n (Hom. hym. 5. 62).
tei/sasqe: cp. 959.
a)lla\ tw=| xro/nw|: so in El. 1013: in Tr. 201a)lla\ su\n xro/nw|. Cp. above, Tr. 950 n.
ka)/m): i.e., ‘me, on the other part’: for this kai/, cp. O. C. 53o(/s' o<*>da ka)gw\ (n.).
th=s vo/sou: Od. 1. 18ou)d' e)/nqa pefugme/nos h)=en a)e/qlwn. Cp. Ant. 488 n.
baru/s: 368 n.
kou)x u(pei/k.: cp. Ant. 472ei)/kein d' ou)k e)pi/statai kakoi=s (n.).
parei/koi, impers., here=sxolh\ ei)/h: Thuc. 3. 1prosbolai\...e)gi/gnonto... o(/ph| parei/koi.

e(no\s kratw= lo/gou, ‘I have the power (i.e., leisure) to say only one thing.’ Cp. O. T. 409i)/s' a)ntile/cai: tou=de ga\r ka)gw\ kratw=.—Not, ‘lay hold upon’ one saying, i.e., ‘take my stand upon’ it.
ga\r, prefacing the statement: 915.

toiou/twn, ‘such or such’ a man,— ‘any given kind’ of person:—euphemistic for doli/wn, or the like. Such a colloquial use of toiou=tos seems quite intelligible, since it could be interpreted by an expressive tone of the voice, or by a slight gesture. (Not, ‘such as thou hast described.’) It would be grievous to change toiou/twn into panou/rgwn, as Nauck proposes.
kri/sis, lit., trial, competition ( Tr. 266pro\s to/cou kri/sin): the usual word would be a)gw/n, but euphony would not permit it here.
mou: see n. on 47.
ge me/ntoi: 93 n.
ei)s se/, with regard to thee: Ant. 731eu)sebei=n ei)s tou\s kakou/s. Odysseus is resigned to Ph. carrying his point by staying in Lemnos.
e)ksth/somai, ‘make way for’ (and so, here, ‘defer to’): Ar. Ran. 353eu)fhmei=n xrh\ ka)ci/stasqai toi=s h(mete/roisi xoroi=sin.
a)/fete ga\r au)to/n k.t.l. The ga\r confirms e)ksth/somai. ‘I will yield; for (I now say) ‘loose him.’’ Hence we may render, ‘Yes, loose him.’ Cp. 1004.

ou)de\ sou=. If we wrote ou)de/ sou, then the stress would fall on prosxrh/|zomen ‘(We shall leave thee here.) Nor do we need thee.’ This is possible. But it seems to extort a little too much from the verb: and sou= is also recommended by the contrast with ta/ g' o(/pl) in 1056.

*teu=kros: Il. 13. 313*teu=kro/s q), o(/s a)/ristos *)axaiw=n | tocosu/nh|, a)gaqo\s de\ kai\ stadi/h| u(smi/nh|. The words th/nd' e)pisth/mhn express that skill with the bow was not a regular attribute of the Homeric warrior—whose ordinary weapon was the spear—but the special accomplishment of a few, such as Teucer, Meriones, Philoctetes. Cp. Ai. 1120, where Menelaus tauntingly calls Teucer o( toco/ths.

par' h(mi=n. The addition of para/, after pa/resti, is unusual: but cp. Phaedr. 243 E ou)=tos para/ soi ma/la plhsi/on a)ei\ pa/restin: where Thompson rightly rejects Cobet's proposal (Var. Lect. p. 119) to delete pa/restin and write pa/ra soi. It should be noticed that, both there and here, a slightly different shade of meaning is given by the presence of the prep.: i.e., pa/resti *teu=kros h(mi=n=simply, ‘Teucer is with us’: but pa/resti *teu=kros par' h(mi=n=‘Teucer is available, being with us,’—‘Teucer is at hand to serve us.’—So in Plato l.c., ‘he is at your command,—quite near you.’ parei=nai para/ tini, though rare, is parallel with su\n di/kh sunei=nai ( El. 610 f.), e)nei=nai e)/n tini ( O. C. 115 f.), and similar to pa/ros tino\s proti/qesqai (ib. 418).

e)gw/ q). After pa/resti me\n *teu=kros, the regular constr. would have been pa/reimi de\ e)gw/. But, having omitted to repeat the verb, the poet has written e)gw/ q), since e)gw\ d) would now have been awkward. Cp. Ant. 1162sw/sas me\n... | labw/n te (n.).

mhd' e)piqu/nein. The Ionic and Epic form i)qu/nw, though unknown to Comedy or classical prose, occurs in our MSS. of Aesch. and Eur. ,—and not in lyrics only. Some edd. now always give eu)qu/nw in Trag.; unnecessarily, I think.

After a verb of thinking or saying, ou) is the ordinary negative with the inf.: but mh/ sometimes occurs ( O. T. 1455 n., 2nd ed.). Here the question is, why the second inf. should have mhd), when ou)de
 precedes the other. Two answers are possible. I place first that which seems to me right. (1) ou)de
 belongs to ka/kion only, and not to kratu/nein. Thus there is no incongruity between ou)de/n and mhde/, since only mhde/ belongs to an inf. This may be seen by supposing an equivalent phrase substituted for sou= ka/kion ou)de/n: e.g., oi)=mai o(/moia soi\ tou/twn a)
 kratu/nein, mhde\ xei=ron e)piqu/nein. Schneidewin cp. Plat. Prot. 319B o(/qen de\ au)to\ h(gou=mai ou) didakto
 ei)=nai, mhd' u(p' a)nqrw/pwn paraskeuasto
 a)nqrw/pois, di/kaio/s ei)mi ei)pei=n: where, if ou) belonged to ei)=nai, the immediately following mhde/ would be extremely harsh; while there is no such harshness if ou) belongs to didakto
 only, ou)-didakto
 being equivalent to a)du/naton dida/skesqai.

(2) The less probable view is that ou)de\n belongs to kratu/nein, and, in using mhd) instead of ou)d) before e)piqu/nein, the writer has merely used the other alternative which oi)=mai left to him. Now, idiom is partly governed by association, and can even be influenced by false analogy. The sequence of ou) and mhde/ was most familiar to the Attic ear in a constr. which opposed their clauses to each other (ou) qa=sson oi)/seis mhd' a)pisth/seis e)moi/;). It seems unlikely, then, that an Attic writer would wantonly have used ou) … mhde/ instead of ou) … ou)de/ in a short sentence where the two negatives were simply coordinate.— Eur. Andr. 586(quoted by Schneidewin) is not apposite: dra=n eu=), kakw=s d' ou)/, mhd' a)poktei/nein bi/a|: where e)/sti is understood with dra=n, and again with ou)/: ‘they are thine to benefit, (but not to injure,)—and not to slay’: i.e., mhde/ contrasts a)pokt. with dra=n eu)=, and the words kakw=s d' ou)/ form a parenthesis.
Nauck's conjecture, h)d' e)peuqu/nein, is specious, but not necessary.
th\n *ah=mnon: the art. here is like our possessive pron. used with a scornful tone: cp. 381: Ant. 324ko/myeue/ nun th\n do/can.
ge/ras, the bow, which can be fitly so called because Ph. received it as a reward for good service (670).

h(
 se\ xrh=n. It is possible to write h(
 s' e)xrh=n, as though se\ (not se) were elided: cp. 339. But h(
 se\ xrh=n is here much better, and is favoured by the fact that Soph. has xrh=n in nine other places (430, Soph. 1363: Soph. O. T. 1184, Soph. O. T. 1185: Soph. El. 529, Soph. El. 579, Soph. El. 1505: Soph. Tr. 1133: fr. 104. 5), but e)xrh=n only once, viz. in fr. 104. 6, where metre prompted it. The form e)xrh=n, though a product of false analogy (since xrh=n=xrh\ h=)n), was, of course, equally correct in Attic: it is attested by metre in Ar. Eq. 11: Ar. Pax 135: Ar. Av. 364, Ar. Av. 1177, Ar. Av. 1201: Ar. Ran. 152, Ar. Ran. 935: Ar. Th. 598: Ar. Eccl. 19: fr. 110 and 304.

1064 Since e)n must be considered as belonging to *)argei/ois, this v. has no caesura either in the 3rd or in the 4th foot: cp. 101, 1369. It may seem strange that the poet did not write o(/plois e)n *)argei/oisi kosmhqei\s fanei=, as Mekler proposes. But the halting rhythm of o(/ploisi kosmhqei\s, etc., seems to express the anguish with which Ph. dwells on this bitter thought,—that his bow is to win glory for his enemy. A similar effect of rhythm occurs in Soph. Ant. 44, h=) ga\r noei=s qa/ptein sf), a)po/rrhton po/lei;

mh/ m' a)ntifw/nei: the acc., as with prosfwnw= or a)mei/bomai ( O. C. 991e(
 ga/r m' a)/meiyai mou=non): so Ai. 764o( me
 ga au)to
 e)nne/pei.
dh/=h)/dh. Cp. Ant. 939a)/gomai dh\ kou)ke/ti me/llw.
prosfqegkto/s: see n. on 867 f. e)lpi/dwn | a)/piston.
ou(/tws, without more ado: Ant. 315ei)pei=n ti dw/seis, h)\ strafei\s ou(/tws i)/w;

gennai=o/s per w)/n, noble, generous, though thou art,—and therefore naturally disposed to pity him. (Not, ‘loyal to thy duty,’—and so capable of pitying him without yielding to him.)— th\n tu/xhn diafqerei=s, i.e., spoil the good fortune which has enabled us to secure the bow. He fears that N. may give the bow back.

o(/pws mh\ with fut. ind., as an object clause, would be regular if a verb of ‘taking care’ (like fula/ssomai) had preceded. But here a final clause with the subjunct. (o(/pws mh\ diafqei/rh|s) would be usual. Cp. Andoc. or. 1 § 43 e)/fh xrh=nai lu/ein...to\ yh/fisma..., o(/pws mh\ pro/teron nu\c e)/stai pri\n puqe/sqai. Xen. Cyr. 2. 1. 21ou)de\ di) e(\n a)/llo tre/fontai h)\ o(/pws maxou=ntai.
naukra/twr=nau/arxos: elsewhere=nausi\ kratw=n, ‘having naval superiority’ ( Her. and Thuc. , always in plur.).
a)kou/somai, have it said of me: cp. 378, 382.
ei)s o(/son: cp. 83 n.

ta/ … e)k new\s stei/lwsi, make ready the things in the ship,—i.e., set the tackle, etc., in order. The only difference between ta\ e)k new/s here and ta\ e)n nhi/ is that the former suggests the notion of the quarter —at some distance from the speaker— where the preparations are to be made. Cp. Plat. Lach. 184A h=)n de\ ge/lws kai\ kro/tos u(po\ tw=n e)k th=s o(lka/dos:—‘the people off there in the merchant-ship.’ Thuc. 6. 32sunephu/xonto de\ kai\ o( a)/llos o(/milos o( e)k th=s gh=s (where e)k carries the mental eye from the scene on board the ships to the scene ashore). stei/lwsi, as Hom. Od. 2. 287nh=a qoh\n stele/w (fit out).—On reaching Lemnos, the sailors—if they followed Homeric practice—would have unshipped the mast (i(sto/s), and laid it down so that its top should rest on the mast-holder (i(stodo/kh) at the stern. Cp. Hom. hym. 2. 278 ou)d' e)pi\ gai=an | e)kbh=t), ou)de\ kaq' o(/pla melai/nhs nho\s e)/qesqe; They have now to raise the mast,—make it fast by the fore-stays (pro/tonoi),—and hoist the sails. (Cp. Od. 2. 416 ff.)

qeoi=s eu)cw/meqa. When all was ready for sailing, a prayer was recited, and libations poured. Cp. Thuc. 6. 32eu)xa\s de\ ta\s nomizome/nas pro\ th=s a)nagwgh=s... e)poiou=nto. Hom. Od. 2. 430dhsa/menoi d' a)/ra o(/pla qoh\n a)na\ nh=a me/lainan | sth/santo krhth=ras.

o(rmw/meqon: pres.subjunct. Only two other instances of a 1st pers. dual occur in texts of the classical period: (1) Il. 23. 485h)\ tri/podos peridw/meqon h)e\ le/bhtos. Here, while the greater MS. authority supports the dual, one MS. gives peridw/meqa: and the hiatus can be defended by the ‘bucolic diaeresis,’ just as in Il. 5. 484oi=(o/n k' h)e\ fe/roien *)axaioi\ h)/ ken a)/goien. (2) El. 950lelei/mmeqon: where again one of the minor MSS. has lelei/mmeqa. Elmsley denied the existence of such a 1st pers. dual, because it is so rare, and is nowhere required by metre. Bieler (De duali numero, p. 18) pushes this unsafe argument further by pointing out how often Homer and the dramatists abstained from this form where they might have used it. Leaf (on Il. 23. 485) thinks that it can be explained only as due to the analogy of the 2nd dual (i.e., -meqon : -meqa :: -sqon : -sqe). But even so, analogy might have produced this form before the time of the dramatists: we cannot assume that it was merely a figment of later grammarians. I should therefore keep o(rmw/meqon here and lelei/mmeqon in El. 950; though in Il. 23. 485, considering all the facts, I should prefer peridw/meqa.
o(rma=sqai, infin. for imperat. (57): taxei=s with adverbial force (526).

div2.p: Second kommo/s (cp. 827), taking the place of a third stasimon. 1st strophe, 1081 — 1101 = 1st antistr. 1102—1122: 2nd str. 1123—1145=2nd antistr. 1146—1168. From 1169 to 1217 the verses are without strophic correspondence (a)nomoio/strofa). For the metres see Metrical Analysis.

Philoctetes apostrophises the cave which has so long known his miserable life, and must soon witness his death,— since, now that he has lost his bow, he has no means of procuring food. The Chorus remind him that the fault is his own, as he has chosen to stay in Lemnos; and urge him to come with them to the ship. He passionately refuses, and begs for some weapon with which to kill himself.—Then Neoptolemus enters, followed by Odysseus.

div3.p: gu/alon, ‘hollow’ ( O. C. 1491 ff., n.), is here properly the chamber itself, while koi/las pe/tras (possessive gen.) is the cavernous rock which contains it. Cp. Helen. 189 pe/trina mu/xata | gu/ala, ‘inmost recesses of the rocks.’
qermo\n kai\ pagetw=des. Contrast this with the description by Odysseus, 17 ff. Cp. Hes. Op. 640*)/askrh, xei=ma kakh=|, qe/rei a)rgale/h|, ou)de/ pot' e)sqlh=|.

qnh/|skonti sunei/sei, thou wilt be conscious of my death,—i.e., wilt be the only witness of it. Cp. El. 92ta\ de\ pannuxi/dwn h)/dh stugerai\ | cuni/sas' eu)nai\ mogerw=n oi)/kwn: and so oft. The MSS. have sunoi/sei. This has been rendered: (1) ‘thou wilt be a fit place for me’ to die in,—i.e., good enough. Now, the midd. sumfe/romai does, indeed, mean ‘to agree with’ one,—in opinions, or tastes: O. C. 641 n.: Her. 4. 114ou)k a)\n w)=n dunai/meqa e)kei/nh|si sumfe/resqai (‘live in harmony with them’). But sunoi/sei here could not mean simply, conveniet mihi morienti. (2) ‘Thou wilt be profitable to me,’—by giving me a grave. So the first schol.: a)pollume/nw| moi su/mforon e)/sei kai\ w)fe/limon, kai\ de/cei me a)poqano/nta. This version confounds sunoi/sei with sunoi/seis. (3) ‘Thou wilt be with me,’ —simply. This last is impossible. sumfe/romai never means, or could mean, merely su/neimi or sundia/gw. Dindorf, who quotes a schol. for this, has not perceived that this schol.,—the second, prefaced by h)\ ou(/tw,—is explaining, not sunoi/sei, but, manifestly, sunei/sei:—su\n e)moi\ e)/sei kai\ o)/yei me a)poqano/nta.
au)/lion: cp. 19 n.

lu/pas ta=s a)p' e)mou=. Ph. addresses the cave as if it were a living companion, long condemned to endure his presence. (With plhre/staton cp. what he says of Neopt. in v. 876, boh=s te kai\ dusosmi/as ge/mwn.) Hence lu/pas ta=s a)p) e)mou= (instead of ta=s e)ma=s) is fitting,—‘the anguish on my part,’—so painful for thee to witness. Cp. Soph. O. C. 292ta)nqumh/mata...ta)po\ sou= (n.).

ti/pt' au=) (= 1105 a)ndrw=n), Bothe's correction of ti/ pot' au=), has been generally received. As Dind. remarks, Aesch. has twice used this epic ti/pte in lyrics ( Aesch. Ag. 975, Aesch. Pers. 554).

to\ kat' a)=mar, daily provision. Cp. Isocr. or. 11 § 39 a)lh=tai kai\ tw=n kaq' h(me/ran e)ndeei=s. Eur. uses this phrase as an adv. (‘every day,’ Eur. Ion 123, Soph. El. 182), like to\ kaq' h(me/ran ( Ar. Eq. 1126 etc.).

sitono/mou … e)lpi/dos. As sitono/mos (found only here)=si=ton ne/mwn, affording food, sitono/mos e)lpi/s=‘a hope concerning the provision of food.’ Hence the phrase is not really parallel with a)stuno/moi o)rgai/ ( Ant. 355), ‘dispositions which regulate cities.’ It is more like au)da\ trusa/nwr in 208 (n.).
tou= … po/qen: for the double question, cp. 243, and n. on 220.
1092 ff. A discussion of this passage, and a notice of conjectures, will be found in the Appendix. Here I briefly give the results.

pe/leiai d' a)/nw is my emendation of the corrupt † ei)/q ai)qe/ros † a)/nw. The word ei)/q) would be possible only if, in 1094, we read m' e(/loien for the MS. e(/lwsi/ m). But the general sense of the passage forbids this. e)lw=sin (conjectured by Erfurdt and others, and found (as e)lw=si/ m)) in one MS.) is a certain correction of e(/lwsi/ m): as i)/sxw (Heath) is of i)sxu/w. He is not here praying to be caught up by winds, or slain by birds, but saying—in continuation of tou= pote teu/comai | sitono/mou po/qen e)lpi/dos—that now the birds will fly unharmed over his head. That ai)qe/ros, no less than ei)/q), is spurious, is made almost certain by two distinct considerations. (1) The antistrophic v., 1113, i^<01>doi_ ma_n de^ | ni_n, is a dochmiac. ai)qe/ros resolves the second long syll. of the bacchius (= the final syll. of i)doi/man); not an unexampled licence, but still a most rare one. (2) ptwka/des is sound, but could not be used, without art. or subst., to denote ‘timid birds.’ ai)qi/ros has probably supplanted that subst.

But if so, the corruption has been a deep one; i.e., ei)/q' ai)qe/ros was an attempt to supply, from the context, words which had been wholly or partly lost. Now suppose that the words *p*e*a*e*i*a*i *d *a*n*w had been partly obliterated, so as to leave only *e*i*a*i *a*n*w. The words a)/nw and o)cuto/nou pneu/matos would readily suggest that AI was a vestige of ai)qe/ros. And the very fact that the schol. accepts ei)/qe e(/lwsi/ me as possible shows how, in post-classical times, e(/lwsi might have elicited ei)/q) from the letters EI. The birds which will now fly harmless over his head are such as those which his bow used to slay,—ta\s u(popte/rous | ba/llon pelei/as (288).
o)cuto/nou … pneu/matos, shrill-sounding breeze: cp. Il. 14. 17lige/wn a)ne/mwn ai)yhra\ ke/leuqa. The epithet is perh. intended to suggest also the pterw=n r(oi=bdos ( Ant. 1004).

ou)ke/t' i)/sxw, I do not restrain them, i.e., do not arrest their career (e)lw=sin) by my arrows. Cp. 1153 ff. For this sense of i)/sxw cp. El. 242e)kti/mous i)/sxousa pte/rugas | o)cuto/nwn go/wn,—where L has i)sxu/ousa, by the same error as here. The MS. ou) ga\r e)/t' i)sxu/w raises the question whether we should read e)lw=s): e)/t' ou) ga\r i)/sxw. For e)/t' ou), cp. 1217: Tr. 161w(s e)/t' ou)k w)/n. But the MS. e(/lwsi/ m) would have arisen from e)lw=sin more easily than from e)lw=s' e)/t). It is more probable that ga\r was an interpolation here, as it is in L's text of O. C. 1766 and Ai. 706.

su/ toi … a)po\ mei/zonos. In this passage I adhere to the MS. text, merely writing, with Wecklein, kou)k for ou)k. The words a)/lloqen e)/xei tu/xa| ta=|d) cannot be metrically reconciled with the corresponding words in the antistrophe (1118 f.), e)/sx' u(po\ xeiro\s e)ma=s. Dindorf assumes that the latter words are sound, and that the fault is in the strophe. He therefore writes a)/lloqen a( tu/xa a(/d) a)po\ mei/zonos, and thus obtains a dactylic tetrameter, answering to e)/sx' u(po\ xeiro\s e)ma=s: stugera\n e)/xe. This alteration is, however, extremely bold, since it eliminates e)/xei without attempting to account for it. On Dindorf's view, I should prefer to conjecture kou)/ s) | a)/llou e)/xei tu/xa a(/d) a)po\ mei/zonos. The traditional tu/xa| ta=|d) would thus be explained; it would have arisen from the ambiguous e)/xei, after kou)/ s) had become kou)k. But, on the whole, it appears safer to suppose that the fault is in the antistrophe. A very slight change will bring the words e)/sx' u(po\ xeiro\s e)ma=s into agreement with a)/lloqen e)/xei tu/xa| ta=|d). We have only to write, with Bergk, e)/sxen u(po\ xeiro\s a)m|a=s. (Wecklein obtains the same metrical result by conjecturing e)/sxe pala/mais e)mai=|sin.)—See Appendix.
kathci/wsas, hast thought it right (to have it so). Cp. O. T. 944a)ciw= qanei=n: Plat. Rep. 337D ti/ a)cioi=s paqei=n;
e)/xei tu/xa| ta=|d): cp. Ai. 272oi(=sin ei)/xet' e)n kakoi=s.
a)po\ mei/zonos, explaining a)/lloqen: for this a)po/, cp. O. C. 1533 ff. n.

paro
: cp. fr. 323 h)
 paro
 qe/sqai kalw=s | au)to/s tis au(tw=| th
 bla/bhn prosqh=| fe/rwn.
fronh=sai, to come to a sound mind (ingressive aor.). Cp. 1259 e)swfro/nhsas. So the aor. partic. in O. T. 649piqou= qelh/sas fronh/sas t) (n.).

The gen. tou= … dai/monos depends not on ei(/lon alone (as if it were proe/krinas), but on the idea of comparison suggested by the whole phrase ei(/lou to\ ka/kion ai)nei=n. Cp. Ai. 1357nika=| ga\r a(reth( me th=s e)/xqras polu/, where polu\ nika=| me= polu\ krei/sswn par' e)moi/ e)sti. For ai)nei=n as=ste/rgein, cp. Eur. Alc. 2qh=ssan tra/pezan ai)ne/sai.

tou= lw/|onos dai/monos, the MS. reading, is metrically impossible. The words tou= lw/|onos must represent ¯˘˘¯ (= 1121 kai\ ga\r e)moi\). But the first syllable of lw/|onos is necessarily long. A shortening of wi before o cannot be justified by the similar shortening of ai or oi, as in dei/laios ( Ant. 1310 n.) or oi)wnou/s ( El. 1058). Musgrave compares zwh=s and dh|w/sas from Eur. ; but in Eur. Hec. 1108 we must read zo/hs, and in Eur. Heracl. 995diw/sas. In the few places where patrw=|os appears to have the 2nd syll. short, pa/trios is a certain correction (cp. 724 n.).

Are we, then, to admit the v. l. tou= ple/onos? It occurs in the first schol. on this v.:—plei/onos de\ dai/monos le/gei tou= lusiteleste/rou kai\ sumfo/rou. Hermann, Dindorf and Wecklein are among those who accept it. In its favour two points may be noticed. (a) dai/mwn, when it means moi=ra, is sometimes quite impersonal; e.g., fr. 587 mh\ spei=re polloi=s to\n paro/nta dai/mona (‘spread not thy present trouble abroad’—by speech). (b) tou= ple/onos dai/monos would be suggested by such phrases as ple/on e)/xein: i.e., it might be possible to say to\n plei/w dai/mon' e)/xw, or the like, though not o( plei/wn dai/mwn me sw/|zei. And so the bold phrase seems just conceivable here, where the idea is, ‘Instead of the better portion, thou hast chosen the worse.’ Omitting tou=, Bothe would read lwi+/onos (cp. Simonides Amorg. 7. 30 lwi+/wn gunh/), and Wunder lwi+te/rou. But, for Soph. , neither seems probable.

I should like to read eu=)te/ ge paro\n kurh=sai lw/|onos au=) dai/monos ei(/lou to\ ka/kion ai)nei=n. The loss of au=) might have led to tou= being added by some one who thought that the first syll. of lw/|onos could be short.

h)/dh...u(/steron … ei)sopi/sw: the redundant diction marks strong feeling, as in Ai. 858panu/staton dh\ kou)/pot' a<*>qis u(/steron. u(/steron: for the short syll. at the end of the verse, cp. 184 n.

prosfe/rwn, bringing home. The act. denotes the simple act of ‘carrying towards’ the cave; the midd. prosfero/menos would have further expressed that the food was for his own use. Cp. 708 ai)/rwn: O. C. 6fe/ronta (=fero/menon).

ou) ptanw=n … i)/sxwn. The only food which Ph. could obtain was that which his bow procured (287). And here the loss of the bow is uppermost in his thoughts. Hence the emphatic repetition :—ou) forba
 e)/ti prosfe/rwn, ou) (prosfe/rwn) ptanw=n a)p' e)mw=n o(/plwn. The general word, prosfe/rwn, is understood again with the adverbial phrase which specialises it. Thus the rhetorical effect is much as if he had said, ou)k a)greu/wn o)/rniqas, ou) toceu/wn. The object to i)/sxwn is au)ta/ (i.e. ta\ o(/pla) understood. Cp. 1058 ka/kion ou)de
 a)
 | tou/twn kratu/nein mhd' e)piqu/nein xeri/. Hartung objects that it is the bow which is held, whereas ptanw=n suits only the arrows: hence he writes, ou) ptanw=n o(/pl) e)mw=n to/cwn (for the final spondee cp. 1151 a)lka/n). The simple answer is that, at the moment of shooting, the archer holds both bow and arrow: and the epithet krataiai=s suits precisely that moment, since it suggests the effort of drawing the bow. Brunck was clearly wrong in supplying forba/n with i)/sxwn.

a)/skopa=a)prosdo/khta: cp. El. 1315ei)/rgasai de/ m' a)/skopa.—The dative with u(pe/du would not be unusual if the sense were, ‘came into my thoughts’: Od. 10. 398pa=sin d' i(mero/eis u(pe/du go/os: Tr. 298e)moi\ ga\r oi=)ktos ei)se/bh: cp. O. C. 372 n. But here the sense is, ‘beguiled,’ for which we should have expected the acc., as after u(pe/rxomai, u(popi/ptw. The explanation may be that the sense, ‘beguiled,’ is here derived from the sense, ‘insinuated themselves into my mind.’
i)doi/man: for the midd., cp. 351.

po/tmos … daimo/nwn: Ant. 157qew=n...suntuxi/ais, n. Two constructions are possible: I prefer the first. (1) ta/de (nom.) se po/tmos … e)/sxen, ‘these things have come upon thee as a doom from heaven.’ (2) po/tmos se ta/de (cogn. acc.) e)/sxen, ‘fate hath put this constraint on thee.’ We can say bia/zomai (or a)nagka/zw) tina/ ti: but e)/xw tina/ ti would be harsher. There is a like ambiguity in Aesch. Pers. 750pw=s ta/d' ou) no/sos frenw=n | ei=)xe pai=d' e)mo/n; and there, too, ta/d) seems best taken as nom. For the sense of e)/sxen, cp. 331 n.
ou)de\ se/ ge: for ge with the repeated se, cp. Ant. 790.
a)ma=s, Bergk's correction of e)ma=s: cp. 1095 ff., n.
stugera\n, pass., abhorred, dreadful: cp. Ai. 1214stugerw=| dai/moni. —e)/xe, ‘direct,’ like a missile: cp. Il. 3. 263pedi/ond' e)/xon w)ke/as i(/ppous.

e)p' a)/llois: cp. Tr. 468 f. soi\ d' e)gw\ fra/zw kako\n | pro\s a)/llon ei=)nai, pro\s d' e)/m' a)yeudei=n a)ei/: Il. 1. 295a)/lloisin dh\ tau=t' e)pite/lleo, mh\ ga\r e)moi/ ge. There is no reference to Odysseus, whom they presently defend (1143), or to any definite person.

kai\ ga\r e)moi\ k.t.l. The sense is:—‘Do not blame us: so far from being thy foes, we are sincerely anxious to win thy friendship.’ tou=to, i.e., mh\ filo/tht' a)pw/sh|. The constr. of me/lei with mh\ a)pw/sh| is like that of o(rw= and skopw= (meaning, ‘to take care’) with mh/ instead of o(/pws mh/. Others make mh\ … a)pw/sh| imperative: ‘do not reject,’ etc. Then tou=to becomes awkward, since it can hardly refer to the coming deprecation, nor can it well mean ‘thy welfare.’

polia=s, not poliou=, since the words po/ntou qino\s form a single notion: Ant. 794 n. The gen. goes with e)fhme/nos: cp. Pind. N. 4. 67ta=s...e)fezo/menoi: Ap. Rhod. 3. 1000 f. nho\s...e)fezome/nh. Some take the gen. as partitive, after pou: but the latter clearly means here, ‘I ween’: cp. Ai. 382h=) pou polu\n ge/lwq' u(f' h(donh=s a)/geis.

1125 *e)ggela=| is my emendation of gela=| mou. The antistrophic verse (1148 xw=ros ou)resibw/tas) shows the true metre; and a substitution of ˘¯¯ for ¯˘¯ is impossible here. If, on the other hand, the e)g of e)ggela=| had been accidentally lost, the insertion of mou is just such an expedient as might have occurred to a post-classical corrector. There is no classical example of a gen. after the simple gela=n, though Lucian has that construction ( Dem. Enc. 16gela=n e)/peisi/ moi tou= ta\s o)fru=s suna/gontos).
ta\n e)ma\n mele/ou: cp. O. C. 344ta)ma\ dusth/nou kaka/.
trofa/n: cp. 931.

h=) pou: cp. 1123 kai/ pou n.— e)leino
 o(ra=|s, lookest piteously, i.e., with a look expressing sorrow for thyself, and pity for him. Cp. Tr. 527 f. o)/mma... | e)leino
: Scut. 426 deino
 o(rw=n o)/ssoisi.

to\n *(hra/kleion a)/rqmion, the ally, friend, of Heracles. a)/rqmion seems a certain correction of the MS. a)/qlion. The word a)/rqmios (expressing the bond of alliance or friendship) was a poet. synonym for fi/los: Od. 16. 427oi( d' h(mi=n a)/rqmioi h)=san: Theognis 1312 oi(=sper nu=n a)/rqmios h)de\ fi/los. Cp. Hom. hym. 3. 524 e)p' a)rqmw=| kai\ filo/thti: and the Homeric e)ri/hres e(tai=roi. The adj. *(hra/kleion represents the gen. *(hrakle/ous, since a)/rqmios with the art. can be treated as a subst. (like oi)kei=os, e)pith/deios, etc.): cp. O. T. 267tw=| Aabdakei/w| paidi/ (n.). Prof. Campbell reads a=)qlon <e)/m)> w(=de/ soi, adopting a)=qlon from the margin of L, and conjecturally adding e)/m). He renders: ‘me thus destined no more to use thee in the Heraclean exercise,’—taking the *(hra/kleios a=)qlos to be archery.

a)/llou d' e)n metallaga=| is Hermann's emendation of a)ll' e)n metallaga=|, which is shorter by a syllable than the antistrophic v., 1157 e)ma=s sarko\s ai)o/las. It is the simplest and most probable correction. e)n here denotes an attendant circumstance (cp. Eur. H. F. 931o( d' ou)ke/q' au(to\s h)=n, | a)ll' e)n strofai=sin o)mma/twn e)fqarme/nos): and the gen. after metallaga=| denotes the ownership to which the change is made: cp. Thuc. 6. 18a)pragmosu/nhs metabolh=|, a change to inactivity. Thus the phrase is equiv. to metalla/can a)/llon polumh/xanon a)/ndra, e)re/ssei (u(p' au)<*>u=): ‘having got a new master—a man of many wiles—thou art wielded (by him).’ For the idiomatic a)/llou cp. Aesch. Th. 424gi/gas o(/d' a)/llos.

e)re/ssei means that the new owner's hands can deal with the bow as they will. For e)re/ssw (‘row,’ then fig., ‘ply’), cp. Ant. 158 n. The word is here a poet. synonym for nwma/w. Cp. Il. 5. 594e)/gxos e)nw/ma: Tr. 512to/ca kai\ lo/gxas r(o/palo/n te tina/sswn.

Cavallin's conject., a)ll' ai)e\n met' a)gka/lais (which others have modified, see cr. n.), is liable to this primary objection, that met' a)gka/lais could not here stand for meta\ xersi/n. Such phrases as e)n a)gka/lais e)/xein are used only of what is carried ‘in the arms.’ Odysseus does not hug the bow.
o(rw=n me\n: for the place of me/n, cp. 279 n.
stugno/n te: for te after me/n, cp. 1058 n.
fw=t' e)xqodopo/n is a periphrasis for e)xqro/n (subst.), hence e)xqodopo/n can follow stugno/n without seeming weak.

w)= *zeu= is Dindorf's correction of *)odusseu/s, instead of which we require a spondee or trochee (=ai)=a 1162). Cp. the w)= *zeu= in O. T. 1198 and Tr. 995: and Ar. Ach. 225o(/stis, w)= *zeu= pa/ter kai\ qeoi/, toi=sin e)xqroi=sin e)spei/sato. But he might still more fittingly have quoted Dem. or. 19 § 113, where, as here, the indignant invocation closes the sentence: —pollou\s e)/fh tou\s qorubou=ntas ei)=nai, o)li/gous de\ tou\s strateuome/nous, o(/tan de/h|, (me/mnhsqe dh/pou,) au)to/s, oi)=mai, qauma/sios stratiw/ths, w)= *zeu=. At v. 1181 Ph. appeals to a)rai=os *zeu/s. Reading w)= *zeu=, it is best to adopt Bothe's o(\s for the MS. o(/s), and to make a)nate/llonq) intrans.: ‘countless ills, arising from (effected by) shameful arts.’

Next to w)= *zeu=, the most attractive correction of *)odusseu/s is Arndt's ou)dei/s, which would require us to take a)nate/llonq) as acc. sing. masc., with transitive sense, and to keep o(/s): ‘causing countless ills to spring up..., more than any other man ever contrived against me.’ Cp. Il. 22. 380o(\s kaka\ po/ll' e)/rrecen, o(/s' ou) su/mpantes oi( a)/lloi. But this is far less forcible.

a)ndro/s toi ta\ me
 e)/ndik' ai)e
 ei)pei=n. Arndt thus amends the MS. a)ndro/s toi to\ me
 eu)= di/kaion ei)pei=n. The change involved is very slight,

ta\ for to\, n for u, and e for o. The sense is:— ‘The part of a (true) man is ever to assert what is right, but to do so without adding invectives.’ That is, Philoctetes is justified in expressing his sense of the wrong done to him; but not in reviling Odysseus. Odysseus was merely the agent of the Greek army, and acted for the public good. Cp. O. T. 1158mh\ le/gwn ge tou)/ndikon: Eur. Tro. 970kai\ th/nde dei/cw mh\ le/gousan e)/ndika. Nauck objects that with ai)e\n we ought to have the pres. inf. le/gein. But ai)e\n ei)pei=n=‘to assert on each occasion,’—the aor. inf. marking the moment of the assertion. The combination of ai)e/n with the aor. is therefore no less correct than (e.g.) in Il. 21. 263w(s ai)ei\ *)axilh=a kixh/sato ku=ma r(o/oio.

The only sound version of the vulgate, a)ndro/s toi to\ me\n eu)= di/kaion ei)pei=n, is Hermann's:—‘It is the part of a man to say that what is expedient (quod utile est) is just’:—i.e., Philoctetes, if he is a true man, ought to remember that the act of taking him to Troy is for the public good (to\ eu)=); and ought therefore to admit that it is just. But we may object:—(1) This sense of to\ eu)= is too obscure. (2) The Chorus may properly remonstrate with Philoctetes on his invectives against Odysseus; but they could scarcely require him to allow that his treatment had been di/kaion. (3) The antithesis between the first clause and the second (ei)po/ntos de\ k.t.l.) thus loses its force; for a man who conceded the justice of the act would not revile the agent.—Other versions of the vulgate, and other emendations, will be found in the Appendix.

ei)po/ntos de\ … o)du/nan. The gen. ei)po/ntos depends, like a)ndro/s, on e)sti/ understood. ei)po/nta would be equally correct, but would be subject to e)cw=sai. Cp. 552 prostuxo/nti, where similarly the acc. could stand.
e)cw=sai, like a sting: cp. Vesp. 423 ka)cei/ras to\ ke/ntron ei(=t' e)p' au)to\n i(/eso.
glw/ssas o)du/nan, lit., ‘pain arising from (given by) the tongue,’ i.e., galling speech: not ‘garrulity,’ like glwssalgi/a.
kei=nos d). Odysseus acted by the public command for the public good. He himself has used a similar plea (109).
ei(=s a)po\ pollw=n taxqei\s, appointed to the task as one out of many, i.e., as their agent. For the prep., cp. 647 n. Though v. 6 might suggest u(po\, change is needless.

e)fhmosu/na|=e)fetmh=|, e)ntolh=|: a Homeric and Pindaric word.— tw=nd) is a clearly true correction of the MS. tou=d). Blaydes, reading ta/nd' e)fhmosu/nan, joins it with taxqei/s (‘intrusted with this commission’).

e)s fi/lous, ‘towards’ his friends,—in their interest. e)s has been suspected (see cr. n.); but e)s fi/lous is better than toi=s fi/lois here, where two aspects of the same act are contrasted. Cp. Ai. 679o(/ t' e)xqro\s h(mi=n e)s toso/nd' e)xqarte/os | w(s kai\ filh/swn au)=qis: e)/s te to\n fi/lon | tosau=q' u(pourgei=n w)felei=n boulh/somai k.t.l.

xaropw=n. The rt xar (xai/rw, xara/, xa/ris) is akin to the Sanskrit ghar (har), ‘glow,’ ‘shine’ (Curt. Etym. § 185). xaropo/s, ‘bright-eyed,’ was used esp. to denote the fierce light in the eyes of wild animals: Od. 11. 611xaropoi/ te le/ontes. So in Ar. Pax 1065, where xaropoi=si piqh/kois alludes <*>o the Spartans, the adj. implies ‘truculent.’ In men, according to Physiogn. 3, the xaropo\n o)/mma is characteristic of the a)ndrei=os, and also of the eu)fuh/s. Though not descriptive of colour, xaropo/s is sometimes associated, or even identified, with glauko/s (Theocr. 20. 25 o)/mmata/ moi glauka=s xaropw/tera pollo\n *)aqa/nas): cp. Germ. 4truces et caerulei oculi.

ou)resibw/tas, acc. plur., ‘finding food on the hills’: cp. 937, 955: Il. 12. 299le/wn o)resi/trofos: Scut. 407 ai)go\s o)ressino/mou: and so o)reilexh/s, o)reivo/mos, o)reskw=|os, ou)resi/foitos, etc. If we took the adj. as nom. sing., with xw=ros, it would mean, ‘affording pasture on the hills’: as Ai. 614freno\s oi)obw/tas, ‘feeding lonely thoughts.’ But the first view seems to agree better with usage: and in such a compound the ending -bw/ths could represent either bo/skwn or bosko/menos.

1149 f. *mhke/t' a)p' au)li/wn fug<*> | *mhda=t). The MSS. give fuga=| m' ou)ke/t<*> a)p) au)li/wn | pela=t), of which the only tenable rendering is Hermann's:—‘No more, in your flight, will ye draw m<*> after you from my cave.’ On this w<*> remark:—(1) The use of pela=t), though possible, is strange. When pela/zein i<*> trans., the place to which the object i<*> brought is almost always expressed, eithe<*> by a dat., or by a prep. and case: or, i<*> not expressed, it is at least clearly im<*> plied; as in Il. 21. 92ou) ga\r o)i+/w | sa\<*> xei=ras feu/cesqai, e)pei/ g) e)pe/lasse/ g<*> dai/mwn: where the context implies e)m<*> far more clearly than fuga=| here implie<*> u(mi=n au)toi=s. Comparing Il. 5. 766h(/<*> ma/list) ei)/wqe kakh=|s o)du/nh|si pela/zein, and Pind. O. 1. 77e)me\...kra/tei...pe/lason, w<*> might surmise that, to a Greek ear, fug<*> m) ou)ke/t) a)p) au)li/wn | pela=t) would rathe<*> suggest this sense,—‘Ye will no longe<*> force me to flight from my cave.’ (2) But apart from the use of pela=t), there i<*> a further difficulty. Verse 1149 shoul<*> correspond with v. 1126, ta\n e)ma\n mele/o<*> trofa/n. These are glyconic verses. A<*> iambus, fuga=|, could not begin such<*> verse, unless its first syll. served merel<*> as anacrusis. If we transpose fuga=| b<*> keep m' ou)ke/t), then we have anothe<*> impossibility, viz. a sentence beginnin<*> with me. Other versions of the vulgate which have been proposed are examined in the Appendix.

Auratus and Canter saw that m' ou)ke/t) is corrupted from mhke/t). Auratus, keeping pela=t), understood (like Wunder), ‘No longer approach, in order to fly from my cave,’—an impossible sense for the dat. fuga=|: though pela=t) as imperat. might be defended by the verse of an unknown poet in Plut. Mor. 457D bai=ne la\c e)pi\ traxh/lou, bai=ne kai\ pe/la xqoni/. Canter read e)la=t), ‘no longer rush.’ For this imperat. (from e)la/w) cp. Eur. H. F. 819(e)/la), and Eur. fr. 779 e)/la de\ mh/te k.t.l. But I feel certain that the true reading is phda=t), which I proposed in the Journ. of Philology vol. II. p. 80 (1869). *p*e*d*a*t) (as it would have been written by Sophocles) would most easily become *p*e*d*a*t). The change of phda=t) into pela=t) would have facilitated that of mhke/t) into m' ou)ke/t), since pela=t) would naturally be taken as fut. indic. of pela/zw, not as imperat. of pela/w.

The metre would be restored by reading mh\ fugai=s e)/t' a)p' au)li/wn. But a simpler remedy is to place fuga=| last, instead of first, in the v. It is not essential to the correspondence of glyconic verses in strophe and antistrophe that the dactyl should occur in the same place: thus v. 1124 po/ntou qino\s e)fh/menos answers to 1147, e)/qnh qhrw=n ou(\s o(/d' e)/xei.—See Appendix.

a)ll' a)ne/dhn k.t.l. The reading of the MSS. here (see cr. n.) presents two great difficulties. (1) a)ne/dhn yields no possible sense when joined with e)ru/ketai. That adv. (from a)ni/hmi, ‘to let go’) means, ‘without restraint,’ ‘with free course’ (immissis habenis), as in Suppl. 15 feu/gein a)ne/dhn dia\ ku=m' a(/lion. (2) e)ru/ketai, as the whole usage of the verb shows, must mean either ‘is detained,’ or else, ‘is warded off.’ Hence the following versions of the MS. text are impossible:—(a) ‘this place is remissly guarded’; (b) ‘this place is held by you in freedom’ (schol. e)ru/ketai: kate/xetai). Seyffert understands, ‘this place detains you with it in freedom’: but, even if we could make the verb midd., a)ne/dhn could not represent a)netou/s or a)neime/nous.

In the Journ. Phil. II. p. 80 (1869) I proposed the emendation which I believe to be true. e)ru/ketai ought to be a)/r' ou)ke/ti. The error would have been an easy one if the apostrophe after a)/r) had been lost, since xw=ros has no verb. That the initial a of a)/r) would have been no obstacle, may be seen from the converse case in O. C. 550, where the MSS. give a)pesta/lh, corrupted from e)f' a(sta/lh. Many other false readings have arisen from two words being made into one (or vice versa), often with a further corruption of the letters; as O. C. 775tosau/th for ti/s au(/th; ib. 1482 suntu/xoimi for sou= tu/xoimi. The parenthesis, o( de\ xw=ros a)/r' ou)ke/ti | fobhto/s, ou)ke/q' u(mi=n, is naturally placed, because the emphatic word of the whole sentence is a)ne/dhn, and the parenthesis justifies it: ‘Without restraint—and there is nothing here now, it seems, to restrain you—go on your way.’ a)/ra expresses his new and bitter sense of helplessness. With regard to the repeated ou)ke/ti, it should be noted that such pathetic iteration is peculiarly frequent in this kommo/s: see 1095 su/ toi, su/ toi: 1102 w)\ tla/mwn, tla/mwn a)/r' e)gw/: 1128 w)= to/con fi/lon, w)= fi/lwn k.t.l.: 1165 a)lla\ gnw=q), eu)= gnw=q): 1186 dai/mwn, dai/mwn: 1197 ou)de/pot), ou)de/pot).

The simple transposition, fobhto/s, ou)ke/q) (for the MS. ou)ke/ti fobhto/s), is the best mode of restoring the metre (=1131 e)/xeis to\n *(hra/kleion). Cp. 156 where mh\ prospesw/n me la/qh| has become in the MSS. mh/ me la/qh| prospesw/n (n.).—See Appendix.
nu=n kalo\n: cp. Ar. Pax 292nu=n e)stin eu)/casqai kalo/n.
a)nti/fonon, taking blood for blood: El. 248a)ntifo/nous di/kas.
pro\s xa/rin, ‘at your pleasure’: see Ant. 30 n.

ai)o/las, discoloured, spotted, by the disease. When this word refers to light or colour, the primary notion of rapid movement is usu. present,—i.e., the sense is ‘glancing,’ ‘gleaming’ (as in the Homeric sa/kos ai)o/lon, Il. 7. 222, with Leaf's n.), or ‘sheeny’ (dra/kwn, II Tr.). But it could also mean ‘variegated’ simply, as in Callim. Dian. 91(of a speckled hound).—Some take it here as=‘quivering’ (cp. Il. 22. 509ai)o/lai eu)lai/).
a)po\ … lei/yw: cp. 817 n.

e)n au)/, iis tre/fetai=e)c a)ne/mwn tre/fetai (schol.). With tre/fesqai, the prep. e)n usu. denotes the surroundings of the trofh/, as Plat. Theaet.p. 175 D e)n e)leuqeri/a|...teqramme/nou: but it can also denote, as here, the aliment; id. Plat. Tim.p. 81 C teqramme/nhs...e)n ga/lakti.
mhke/ti: the generic mh/ (being one who commands not...), cp. 170 mh/ tou khdome/nou.
mhdeno\s (pa/ntwn) o(/sa: the relative clause here takes the place of a partitive gen.: cp. Xen. Cyr. 8. 1. 20h)/n tis a)ph=| oi(=s parei=nai kaqh/kh|. Cp. 957 n.
pe/mpei here=a)nape/mpei like i(/hsi for proi+/hsi etc.
bio/dwros: cp. 391.

ei)/ ti se/bei ce/non, if thou hast any regard for a friendly stranger, eu)noi/a| pa/sa| pela/tan, who draws near to thee with all good will, pe/lasson (intrans.), draw near to him:—i.e., meet his advances half way, instead of repelling him. For the epic ss, cp. Ai. 390o)le/ssas: ib. 926 e)canu/ssein.

Philoctetes is at the mouth of his cave, as if about to enter it (952): the Chorus now advance a little towards him, as they make this earnest appeal. The position of pe/lasson, between ce/non and eu)n. p. pela/tan, is warrantable, since the latter words suggest a reason for the prayer, pe/lasson. Bolder collocations of words occur elsewhere in Soph. : e.g. Soph. O. C. 1427ti/s de\ tolmh/sei klu/wn | ta\ tou=d' e(/pesqai ta)ndro/s; cp. Soph. O. T. 1251.The word pela/tan gives a certain tone of deference, since pela/ths was familiar in Attic as = ‘dependent’ ( Euthyphr. p. 4 C).— Other versions are:—(1) ei)/ ti se/bei, ce/non pe/lasson, ‘if anything is sacred to thee, approach the stranger’: (2) ei)/ ti se/bei ce/non, pe/lasson...pela/tan, ‘approach him who approaches thee.’ But pela/zein (intrans.) could not take an acc. of the person approached: see Append. on 1149 ff. (3) ei)/ ti se/bei, ce/non pe/lasson (trans.), bring the stranger near thee (i.e., ‘allow him to approach thee’).

Arndt conjectures: ei)/ ti se/bei ce/non g) e)/lasson,...a)lla\ gnw=q) k.t.l.: ‘if thou hast too little respect for a guest-friend, at least (a)lla\) think’ of thine own interest. Such a use of e)/lasson would be obscure; and the supposed antithesis of ideas seems forced; since, even if he did ‘revere the stranger,’ that feeling would not be his only motive for leaving Lemnos.

e)pi\ soi\ (cp. 1003) is Seyffert's correction of the MS. o(/ti soi (or soi/), which could not mean, ‘that it is for thee,’ i.e., ‘in thy power.’ The objection to reading o(/ti so/n is that this would mean rather, ‘that it is thy part’ (or ‘duty’): cp. O. C. 721 n.
bo/skein, i.e., to feed with thine own flesh: cp. 313. For the omission of me/n, cp. Ant. 806, O. C. 1275.

a)dah\s d' e)/xein k.t.l., while it cannot be taught to bear the countless woes that attend upon it. e)/xein here=sustinere, as in O. C. 537e)/paqon a)/last' e)/xein, and Ant. 421.It is needless to read o)xei=n.

o(\ cunoikei=: cp. O. C. 1237gh=ras a)/filon, O. C. i(/na pro/panta | kaka\ kakw=n cunoikei=, and ib. 1134. The context here slightly favours o(\ as against w(=|, though the latter is possible. The only source of obscurity here is that in the first clause (oi)ktra\ ga\r bo/skein) the kh/r is the disease itself, while in the second (a)dah\s d)) it is identified with the patient. The sense is, ‘thy disease is dreadful, and no length of time could inure thee to the countless other ills that accompany it’ (hunger, hardship, solitude).
palaio\n a)/lghm), the pain which the proposal that he should return to Troy has caused to him from the first moment that he heard of it: see vv. 622, 917, 999.
u(pe/mnasas without me: cp. 801.—w)= lw=|ste k.t.l.: their words grieve him the more, because they have otherwise shown him so much sympathy (cp. 1121, 1163 f.).

tw=n pri\n e)nto/pwn, those mentioned in 307 ff.: for pri\n cp. Ant. 100ka/lliston... | ...tw=n prote/rwn fa/os. The adj. here=merely ‘present in a place’ (at a given moment), as in 211, O. C. 1457: not ‘resident,’ as in O. C. 841.

w)/lesas. A return to Troy is more dreadful to him than death (999), and the mere suggestion of it has pierced him to the heart. This verb can denote the infliction, not only of physical (817), but also of mental anguish: cp. El. 831*h*l. a)polei=s. *x*o. pw=s; | *h*l. ei) tw=n fanerw=s oi)xome/nwn | ei)s *)ai+/dan e)lpi/d' u(poi/seis, kat' e)mou= takome/nas | ma=llon e)pemba/sei. (But in 1388 below o)lei=s is not similar.)
ei)/rgasai: perf. following aor., as 676, 929.
ti/ tou=t' e)/lecas; Cp. Ai. 270pw=s tou=t' e)/lecas;—(w)/lesa/s me), ei) … h)/lpisas, if thou hast indeed conceived the hope: cp. e)lpi/sai in 629.
a)/cein with double acc.: cp. Ant. 811(n.).
a)po/ … lei/pet): cp. 817.
nun, ‘then,’ i.e., ‘if ye persist’ (as the present tense now= implies). This is better here than nu=n.

fi/la moi … parh/ggeilas e(ko/nti te pra/ssein. The te after e(ko/nti has been suspected (see cr. n.). But analogous instances occur, where conjunctions, which might have been omitted, couple dissimilar clauses: as Plat. Prot. 336A a)pekri/nato dia\ braxe/wn te kai\ au)ta\ ta\ e)rwtw/mena: Thuc. 1. 67ou)x h(su/xazon a)ndrw=n te sfi/sin e)no/ntwn kai\ a(/ma...dedio/tes. Here, e(ko/nti te would probably seem all the more natural to a Greek ear, since boulome/nw| moi/ e)sti tou=to was so familiar an equivalent for prosfile/s moi/ e)sti tou=to. Cavallin's e(ko/nta (acc. neut. plur.) te cannot be justified by Soph. O. T. 1229, where kaka\ | e(ko/nta is merely a bold way of saying, kaka\ a(\ e(kw/n tis e)poi/hse.

nao\s (partit. gen.) i(/n' h(mi=n te/taktai, to that part of the ship where (=whither) it has been appointed for us to go. The Chorus are common seamen, who have to take their places on the rowing benches or at other posts. The moment of sailing is now at hand (cp. 1076).

a)rai/ou *dio/s, Zeus i(ke/sios (484 n.) in another aspect,—as the god who hears the imprecation of the rejected suppliant. a)rai=os does not occur elsewhere as an epithet of Zeus, but among his titles were a)la/stwr (Cramer Anecd. Ox. 1. 62), timwro/s (Clemens Protrept. p. 24) and palamnai=os ( De Mundo 7).
e)/lqh|s=a)pe/lqh|s: 48 n.
1183 The older edd. give metri/aze in full (making the choriambic verse hypercatalectic): Brunck wrote metri/az). For the sense, cp. Plat. Rep. 603E metria/sei de/ pws pro\s lu/phn.
dai/mwn: for the nom., cp. Ant. 891w)= tu/mbos.
w)= pou\s pou/s: cp. 786.
ti/ se teu/cw ;=ti/ se poih/sw, ti/ soi xrh/somai ; ‘what shall I do with thee,’—how endure the pain,—now that my doom is otherwise so much worse?
meto/pin, used by Rh. 4. 1764, occurs nowhere else in class. Greek, but is related to the epic meto/pisqen (used by Eur. fr. 449) as the Attic kato/pin to the epic kato/pisqen.

e)/lqet' e)ph/ludes: cp. 1222: Suppl. 388 pali/ssutos | stei=x): Legg. 879 D neh/ludos a)figme/nou. The adj. here=‘coming back’ (answering to e)pane/rxomai rather than e)pe/rxomai): yet au)=qis need not be regarded as redundant (like a)rti/ws with neosfagh/s in Tr. 1130); for they had once before been on the point of departing (1070). Elsewhere e)/phlus always=advena.

ti/ r(e/contes, to do what, gnw/ma| a)lloko/tw| tw=n pa/ros, with a purpose different from (that of) the former course, w(=n (by attract. for a(\) prou)/faines, which thou didst prescribe? He had told them to go away and leave him (a)po/ nu/n me lei/pet' h)/dh, 1177). They ask if they are now to contravene that order, and if so, what they are to do. For the gen. tw=n pa/ros after a)lloko/tw|, cp. M. 4. 4. 25 a)/lla tw=n dikai/wn. The verb profai/nein can be used of any utterance ( Tr. 324); but, as it is said of oracles ( O. T. 790 n.), so it is peculiarly applicable to commands.

The objection to the plausible conjecture r(e/contos is not the omission of sou=, which is quite possible (cp. 801 n.), but the fact that Greek idiom would require w(s ti/ r(e/contos. In the very rare instances where this w(s is omitted, the fut. partic. refers to the subject of the principal verb, as Eur. Hec. 631 ff. u(/lan... | e)ta/meq), a(/lion e)p' oi)=dma naustolh/swn (cp. Paley in Journ. Phil. vol. VIII. p. 80).

ou)/toi nemeshto/n, since the feeling of ne/mesis is justified only when fair allowance has been made for human weakness. ( Andoc. or. 1. 57 xrh\ ga a)nqrwpi/nws peri\ tw=n pragma/twn e)klogi/zesqai, w(/sper a)
 au)to
 o)/nta e)n th=| sumfora=|.) Cp. Il. 9. 523pri
 d) (before the amend was made) ou)/ti nemesshto
 kexolw=sqai.
a)lu/onta: 174 n.
xeimeri/w|: cp. 1460: Ai. 206*a<*>as qolerw=| | kei=tai xeimw=ni nosh/sas.

kai\ para\ nou=n qroei=n, referring to his abrupt dismissal of them (1177). kai/ (‘e'en’) expresses the relation of cause and effect. para\ nou=n like para\ di/khn etc.: cp. O. T. 550tou= nou= xwri/s.

ou)d' ei) purfo/ros a)sterophth\s: cp. Il. 1. 580*)olu/mpios a)sterophth/s: O. T. 200w)= ta=n purfo/rwn | a)strapa=n kra/th ne/mwn. This is a repetition, in stronger words, of ou)d' h)\n xrh=| me pa=n paqei=n kako/n (999). To brave the lightnings of Zeus is to face death in its most appalling form: so Ares says that he will avenge his son, ei)/ pe/r moi kai\ moi=ra *dio\s plhge/nti keraunw=| | kei=sqai o(mou= neku/essi ( Il. 15. 117). And Dido: Vel pater omnipotens adigat me fulmine ad umbras | ... Ante, Pudor, quam te violo ( Aen. 4. 25).
bronta=s au)gai=s: cp. Aesch. P. V. 1043pro\s tau=t' e)p' e)moi\ r(ipte/sqw me\n | puro\s a)mfh/khs bo/struxos: ib. 1083 e(/likes d' e)kla/mpousi | steroph=s za/puroi.

ei)=si flogi/zwn, lit., ‘shall be in the course of consuming,’ i.e., in the very act of doing so:—as if he should behold Zeus in heaven, with the thunderbolt already brandished in his uplifted right hand. The peculiar vividness of the phrase depends on the somewhat rare use of the pres. part. with e)/rxomai—a use quite distinct from that of the fut. part. Thus e)/rxetai kathgorh/swn mou ( Euthyphro 2 C)=simply, ‘he is going to accuse me’; but e)/rxomai e)pixeirw=n soi e)pidei/casqai ( Phaedo 100B)=‘I am proceeding with an attempt to show you’: cp. Her. 1. 122h)/ie tau/thn ai)ne/wn dia\ panto/s: Pind. N. 7. 69e)/rxomai...e)nne/pwn.
e)rre/tw *)/ilion: not a curse on Troy itself, but a way of saying that he cares not how the Trojan war may end.
oi(/ q' u(p' e)kei/nw|: cp. Eur. Hec. 764tw=n qano/ntwn...u(p' *)ili/w|.

to/d' e)mou= podo\s a)/rqron, this limb (cp. a)/rqra in 1207), my foot: podo\s is here a defining genitive, and the phrase is a periphrasis for to\n e)mo\n po/da, with a certain added pathos,—‘this poor lame foot.’ But in O. T. 718a)/rqra podoi=n are the ankles.— a)pw=sai, act., as in Ai. 446a)ndro\s tou=d' a)pw/santes kra/th: cp. 600 e)kbeblhko/tes. (But the midd. a)pw/sh| in 1122, of repelling advances.) He speaks as if the tortured limb were a mute suppliant that might well have moved their pity: cp. 1188 w)= pou\s pou/s.
a)ll), appealing (230).

o)re/cate, extend it to me, concede it: cp. Pind. N. 7. 56ou)k e)/xw | ei)pei=n ti/ni tou=to *moi=ra te/los e)/mpedon | w)/rece: a poet. use, like that of e)gguali/zw. (Distinguish the sense in Il. 12. 328h)e/ tw| eu)=xos o)re/comen h)e/ tis h(mi=n, ‘give glory.’)

e)rei=s: for the fut., cp. 441 n.— ei)/ poqen sc. prope/myai e)/xete,=‘from any quarter.’ So in Ai. 886ei)/ poqi...leu/sswn=leu/sswn, ei)/ pou (leu/ssei). The elliptical use of ei)/ tis is frequent ( Thuc. 4. 26e)sa/gein si=to/n te...kai\ ei)/ ti a)/llo brw=ma).
ge/nun, axe: El. 485a)mfa/khs ge/nus: cp. Ant. 249 n.

prope/myate. This use of the verb is somewhat strange at first sight, and has led to conjectures (see cr. n.). But it seems to be justified by the context. The group of fifteen men is standing before him, and he sees that they are not regularly armed; but, as ei)/ poqen shows, he hopes that some one of their number may have some weapon. prope/myate means strictly, ‘pass forward,’ from hand to hand. Cp. Ar. fr. 427 fe/re pai= taxe/ws kata\ xeiro\s u(/dwr, | para/pempe to\ xeiro/maktron,—‘pass’ it round.
w(s ti/na dh\ r(e/ch|s...; So O. C. 398(Ismene having said that Creon will come) *o*i. o(/pws ti/ dra/sh|; cp. ib. 1724: El. 390*x*r. o(/pws pa/qh|s ti/ xrh=ma;
pala/man, ‘deed of violence’; a sense in which the sing. does not seem to occur elsewhere, though the plur. often=‘violent hands’ ( Il. 3. 128u(p' *)/arhos palama/wn).

1207 *xrw=t), Hermann's correction of kra=t), seems to me certain. For the interchange of x and k, cp. bru/xomai corrupted from bru/komai in 745 (cr. n.). Here the error may have been facilitated by a recollection of 618 ka/ra | te/mnein. The sense is, ‘hew all the flesh (from my bones), and sever limb from limb,’—a frenzied exaggeration of his prayer in 748, pa/tacon ei)s a)/kron po/da, | a)pa/mhson w(s ta/xista: mh\ fei/sh| bi/ou. Sophocles knew the History of Herodotus (cp. O. C. 337 n.). Is it not possible that the poet's diction here may have been influenced by a reminiscence of the passage describing the ghastly suicide of the insane Cleomenes (6. 75)? Cleomenes, like Philoctetes, ‘asked for a sword,’— which the terrified Helot gave him. Then, paralabw
 to
 si/dhron a)/rxeto e)k knhme/wn e(wuto
 lwbw/menos: e)pita/mnwn ga kata\ mh=kos ta\s sa/rkas (cp. *xrw=ta pa/nta) proe/baine e)k tw=n knhme/wn e)s tou\s mhrou/s, e)k de\ tw=n mhrw=n e)/s te ta\ i)sxi/a kai\ ta\s lapa/ras, e)s o(\ e)s th
 gaste/ra a)pi/keto, kai\ tau/thn kataxordeu/wn a)pe/qane.

If the MS. kra=t) be kept, pa/nta must be taken in one of two ways. (1) As acc. masc. with kra=t). Cp. Ionfr. 61 to
 au(tou= kra=ta: Eur. fr. 243 to
 so
 kra=t). But with Sophocles kra=ta is elsewhere neut.: cp. 1001, 1457. (2) As adverbial neut. pl., ‘utterly.’ In either case the sense is weak. We cannot take pa/nta kai\ a)/rqra as=kai\ pa/nta a)/rqra. (In Aesch. P. V. 51, e)/gnwka toi=sde kou)de
