 a)nteipei=n e)/xw, the comma should stand after toi=sde, not after e)/gnwka.) A transposition is, indeed, possible—kra=ta kai\ a)/rqr' a)po\ pa/nta. But, even then, there is the difficulty that he cuts off his own head before mangling his limbs. This, surely, is more than the figure of ‘prothysteron’ will comfortably excuse. Prof. Campbell compares Soph. Ai. 238kefalh
 kai\ glw=ssan a)/kran | r(iptei= qeri/sas: but Ajax is not decapitating himself.
fona=|: cp. Ant. 117 n.
ti/ pote; the verb understood is e)/stin, not fona=|: cp. Ant. 381ti/ pot); ‘What means this?’
pate/ra mateu/wn, as if fonw= rather than fona=| no/os had preceded: cp. O. T. 159 n.

In vv. 492 ff. he had expressed the fear that his aged father must be dead; and here, in the bitterness of despair—when he feels himself utterly friendless upon earth—he utters a yearning to join Poeas in the world below. At brighter moments, again—when there is a gleam of hope that he may return to Malis—he thinks of his father as still living (665, 1371). And Heracles tells him that Poeas is indeed alive (1430).

ou) ga\r e)n fa/ei g' e)/ti. Hermann's deletion of the e)/st) before e)n is probable on metrical grounds; and the interpolation might easily have arisen, as he says, from a superscript gloss e)sti/. On the other hand it is simpler and better to understand e)sti/ than (as Hermann prefers) mateu/wn.
w)= po/lis: Trachis (491): for the nom., cp. 1186 n.
pw=s a)\n with optat. in a wish; cp. 531.

a)/qlio/s g' a)nh/r. This, the reading of the MSS., is confirmed, as against Dindorf's conjecture (see cr. n.), by a point which seems to have escaped notice. The ge after o(/s marks the causal force of the relat. pron. (as in 663); and this indicates that a)/qlios means, not merely ‘unhappy,’ but ‘wretchedly foolish’ (as in O.T. 372). The reflective emphasis which g) adds to a)/qlios is thus exactly in place,— ‘misguided indeed that I was.’ A comma after ei)si/doimi/ s) makes this clearer.

i(era\n liba/d), the Spercheius (492), neighbour to the haunts of the Malian nymphs (725). All rivers were i(eroi/, but here the epithet has a special force, which e)xqroi=s brings out: he had voluntarily withdrawn himself from the realm of friendly deities. Cp. his appeal in 1040 a)ll' w)= patrw/|a gh= qeoi/ t' e)po/yioi.
e)/t' ou)de/n ei)mi: for the place of e)/t), cp. O.T. 24 e)/t' ou)x oi(/a te (n.).

div2.p: Exodos. Neoptolemus restores the bow, and resolves to keep his word by taking Philoctetes home. Heracles appears, and at his bidding Philoctetes consents to sail, not for Greece, but for Troy.

It is unusual for two actors (neither being a mute person) to enter together,— as Odysseus and Neoptolemus do here (1222),—except in the opening scene. This is the peculiarity to which the scholiast calls attention: e)nteu=qen diplou=n e)sti to\ e)peiso/dion. Of the other six plays, the Trachiniae is the only one in which the e)/codos begins with the entrance of more than one person (v. 971: Hyllus, and the pre/sbus with Heracles). In O. C. 1099(third e)peiso/dion) Theseus enters with Antigone and Ismene.

div3.p: Much suspicion has fallen upon these verses. Some critics, indeed, hold that the only resource is to write them anew (see cr. n.). The points to which objection is made are the following.

(1) o(mou= as a prep. with the gen. (schol., e)ggu/s). The dat. is the usual case ( O. T. 1007). There are, however, two other passages in which the gen. is a well-attested reading. (a) Xen. Anab. 4. 6. 24pri\n de\ o(mou= ei)=nai tou\s pollou\s a)llh/lwn: three of the best MSS. support the gen., while others give a)llh/lois. (b) Menander fr. incert. 204. The schol. on Rh. 2. 121 quotes it as o(mou= de\ tw=| ti/ktein parege/neq' h( ko/rh: but the mutilated form of it found in Suidas, Photius and Harpocration has tou= ti/ktein o(mou=. It is noteworthy that the use of o(mou= in the sense of e)ggu/s (as distinguished from the sense ‘along with’) is said by the schol. on Apollonius to be distinctively AndAttic. , when it bore this sense, the analogy of e)ggu/s, pe/las, etc., might easily permit it to be sometimes construed with the gen. See Appendix.
(2) stei/xwn is suspected by Nauck, who says, ‘one would rather have expected the aorist (a)pelqw/n).’ But the pres. partic. is quite right: ‘moving on my way, I should now have been near my ship.’

(3) stei/xonta following stei/xwn. This is a real blemish, though a small one. But it does not follow that it is corrupt. There are several proofs that Sophocles, writing rather for hearers than for readers, was not always careful to avoid such iteration of commonplace words. The emphasis here falls on the contrasted qualifications (new\s o(mou=, and pe/las), not on the participles themselves. A recurrence which, in print, catches the eye would hardly have offended the ear. Cp. 87, 88 pra/ssein bis, with n.,—265 a)gri/a|, 267 a)gri/w|: 1268 f. lo/gwn, lo/gois.

(4) pro\s h(ma=s deu=r' i)o/nt), repeating the sense of pe/las stei/xonta. The words are certainly unnecessary; but they are nothing worse. For a like redundancy, cp. Lysias or. 16 § 13 toi=s me\n i(ppeu/ousin a)sfa/leian ei)=nai dei=n nomi/zontas, toi=s d' o(pli/tais ki/ndunon h(goume/nous, where the second participle merely repeats the sense of the first, and might have been omitted. We could, indeed, take i)o/nt) as=i)o/nte (for the elision of the dual, cp. Hes. Op. 199i)/ton prolipo/nt' a)nqrw/pous), placing commas after go/non and i)o/nt). Then stei/xonta would refer to both men. ‘I see Hom. Od.and N. approaching, on their way hither to us.’ But this is less natural.
On the whole, I incline to think that these four vv. are sound, though (like vv. 265 ff.) they are somewhat carelessly written.
stei/xwn a)\n h)= soi. The ethic dat. implies, ‘thou would'st have seen me depart’: cp. O. C. 81h)= be/bhken h(mi\n o( ce/nos;
e)leu/ssomen: for the plur. following the sing. (h)=) cp. 1394: Ant. 734 n.
ou)k a)\n fra/seias: cp. Il. 5. 456ou)k a)\n dh\ to/nd' a)/ndra ma/xhs e)ru/saio metelqw/n..; the formula is more courteous than ou) with fut. ind. ( O. T. 430 n.). He seeks to restrain himself.
pali/ntropos: cp. 1190 n.
ke/leuqon: cp. Ant. 1212a)=ura dustuxesta/thn | ke/leuqon e(/rpw...;
su\n spoudh=| taxu/s; for su/n, cp. 268 n.
lu/swn: cp. Ar. Ran. 691lu=sai ta\s pro/teron a(marti/as. Thuc. 3. 46metagnw=nai kai\...th\n a(marti/an katalu=sai.
deino/n ge fwnei=s: for ge in such comment, cp. O. T. 1035deino/n g' o)/neidos sparga/nwn a)neilo/mhn: Ai. 1127ktei/nanta; deino/n g' ei)=pas, ei) kai\ zh=|s qanw/n: El. 341.

h(\n soi\ piqo/menos. This passage (down to 1234) well illustrates the dramatic use of interruption in stichomuthia. The spectators are now to learn that the repentance of Neoptolemus is complete. Obeying his superiors (1226), he did a base deed (1228); he will restore the bow (1230, 1232); for he has no right to it (1234). Each point is thrown into relief by the excited interpellations of Odysseus. Cp. 210 n.
w(=n ou)/ soi pre/pon = tou/twn a(\ ou)/ soi pre/pon h)=n pra=cai. Cp. O.T. 862.

e(lw/n. The partic. answers the question asked by poi=on: ‘what unbecoming deed didst thou do?’ ‘(I did such a deed) by capturing,’ etc. Thus we understand e)/praca e)/rgon ou) pre/pon moi. The verb which N. would naturally have used, if Od.had allowed him to finish his sentence, would have been h(/marton, to which h(\n in 1226 would have been cogn. acc.: but, after the interruption, the verb is best supplied from v. 1227. Thus h(\n remains actually an acc. of respect, ‘(the sin), by which.’ Blaydes suggests ei(=lon a)/ndra kai\ do/lois. It is true that in stichomuthia an interrupted speaker usually ends with a finite verb (as O. T. 560e)/rrei, O. C. 646krath/sw). But in this context e(lw/n is more forcible than ei(=lon, since then it is Od.himself who supplies the description of the deed as ou) pre/pon.
ne/on: for the sinister sense, cp. 784 n.

w(/s m' u(ph=lqe/ tis fo/bos. For this use of tis, in foreboding, cp. Ai. 1163e)/stai mega/lhs e)/rido/s tis a)gw/n: for its place, cp. 104, 519, 1039. w(s (‘how!’) as in El. 1112ti/ d' e)/stin, w)= ce/n); w(/s m' u(pe/rxetai fo/bos.—Seyffert's conject., toi for tis ( El. 928qau=ma/ toi/ m' u(pe/rxetai), seems less fitting after w(s. With regard to Nauck's u(ph/luqen, it may be noted that neither Aesch. nor Soph. admits h)/luqon in dialogue, though Eur. does so ( Soph. El. 598).
par' ou(=per e)/labon: for the tribrach (not contained in one word), cp. 1247: O. C. 26a)ll' o(/stis o( to/pos: and n. on O. T. 537.
ti/ le/ceis; for the fut., cp. 1204 n. —The interrogative ou)/ ti/ pou, like ou) dh/ (900) and ou) dh/pou, was freq. in Attic ( Ar. Ran. 522, etc.).

po/tera dh\ seems clearly right (see cr. n.): the dh/ gives indignant emphasis. de\ is also possible (cp. 917); but it is weaker, and gives a less good rhythm. For po/tera in a simple question (like Lat. an), cp. O. C. 333.
kertomw=n, of bitter jest; cp. Ant. 956 n.
ei) kerto/mhsis. The quiet force of the answer would be rather spoiled by adding g): cp. 105 n.

a)napolei=n, to plough anew; hence, fig., ‘to go over the same ground’ again. Pind. N. 7. 104tau)ta\...tri\s tetra/ki t' a)mpolei=n. In this sense Attic prose preferred e)panapolei=n: Plat. Phileb. 60A eu)= d' h( paroimi/a dokei= e)/xein, to\ kai\ di\s kai\ tri\s to/ ge kalw=s e)/xon e)panapolei=n lo/gw| dei=n: Legg. 723 E e)panapolh/swmen. Cp. tripo/liston oi)=kton, Ant. 858 n.
a)rxh\n, adv., placed before the negative word; cp. Ant. 92 n.
a)\n with e)boulo/mhn: cp. 427, 1278: Lys. or. 12 § 22 e)gw\ d' e)boulo/mhn a)\n au)tou\s a)lhqh= le/gein.
eu)= nu=n. Though in O. T. 658 and El. 616 we have eu)= nun e)pi/stw, the temporal nu=n seems fitter in this curt response.

a)khkow\s is much better here than a)kh/koas. In Ai. 480pa/nt' a)kh/koas lo/gon is fitting at the end of a speech: cp. above 241 n. But in a brief statement of resolve, such as this, the compact unity given by the participial construction suits the placid firmness of the speaker's tone. Cp. 253, 567.
to\ dra=n: for the art., cp. 118 n.

ti/s e)/stai m' ou(pikwlu/swn ta/de; for this use of the fut. partic. with art., cp. O. T. 297.Dindorf is not quite accurate in saying that, after e)/stai, ou(pikwlu/wn ‘would have sufficed,’ and that the poet preferred the fut. partic. only for the sake of correspondence with kwlu/sei. The fut. partic. was required by Greek idiom, whether the principal verb was to be past, pres., or future. Cp. Xen. An. 2. 4. 5o( h(ghso/menos ou)dei\s e)/stai, ‘there will be no one to lead us’ ( Xen. could not have written o( h(gou/menos). For the place of m) cp. Soph. O. T. 139e)kei=non o( ktanw/n. The compound e)pikwlu/swn comes after the simple kwlu/sei as in Soph. O. T. 566 f. pare/sxomen after e)/sxete, ib. 575 f. e)kma/nqan) after maqei=n. Cp. above, Soph. O. T. 249: and for the converse, Soph. O. T. 911 f. ta/de: for the double acc. (a rare constr. with kwlu/w), cp. Lys.p. 207 E e)me/ ge...kai\ ma/la polla\ kwlu/ousin (sc. oi( gonei=s).
e)n de\ toi=s. Attic usage recommends toi=s, in preference to toi=sd) here: see on O. C. 741pa=s de *kadmei/wn lew\s | kalei= dikai/ws, e)k de\ tw=n ma/list' e)gw/.
drasei/eis: cp. 1001 n.
sofa/ is right, as di/kaia shows: sofo/n would be intolerable here.

a(/ g' e)/labes: the g) with causal force (quae ceperis): cp. 663. For the tribrach, cp. 1232. Odysseus, ignoring the moral question, asserts a right of property in the bow, because his boulai/ (as he euphemistically calls them) have won it.
th\n a(marti/an. The a)ntilabh/ marks a rising tone of excitement (cp. 54 n.). These words sum up N.'s resolve, and his mentor turns from expostulations to threats.

a)nalabei=n, ‘retrieve.’ So Eur. Ion 426ta\s pri\n a)nalabei=n a(marti/as. This sense comes through that of ‘recovering’ (since the a(marti/a may be regarded as a loss of character),—not through the notion of ‘taking back’ a false move (for which the word was a)nati/qesqai). Cp. Her. 5. 121tou=to to\ trw=ma a)ne/labon: id. 8. 109 a)nalamba/nein th\n prote/rhn kako/thta.

cu
 tw=| dikai/w|, i.e., having it on my side, as an ally: cp. su
 qew=|. So Ai. 1125cu
 tw=| dikai/w| ga\p me/g' e)/cestin fronei=n.

to
 so
 ou) tarbw= fo/bon, I do not fear the terror (=terrible thing) of which thou speakest,—i.e., the wrath of the army. For this objective sense of fo/bos, cp. O. C. 1651w(s deinou= tinos | fo/bou fane/ntos. For to
 so
, El. 1110ou)k oi)=da th
 sh
 klhdo/n): fr. 169 ou)k oi)=da th
 sh
 pei=ran: e(
 d' e)pi/stamai.—I prefer this version to the other which is possible:— ‘I do not feel the fear which thy words suggest.’

Hermann's earlier view (see cr. n.) seems clearly the true one. Verse 1252, a)ll' ou)de/ toi k.t.l., is the reply to a lost verse, in which Odysseus said that he would enforce his will with his own hand. Throughout this passage it is Odysseus who threatens, while Neoptolemus stands on the defensive. To Odysseus must belong ou)/ ta)/ra *trwsi/n, a)lla\ soi\ maxou/meqa, and xei=ra...e)piyau/ousan: while e)/stw to\ me/llon and a)lla\ ka)me/...kou) me/llont' e)/ti are the answers of Neoptolemus. Hence, if we reject the hypothesis of a lost verse, only three resources remain.

(1) To transpose vv. 1252 and 1253. This was Hermann's later theory. The objection to it is that N. then says, a)ll' ou)de/ toi sh=| xeiri\ pei/qomai to\ dra=n. | e)/stw to\ me/llon,—when the last three words lose the force which they now possess as a short and direct reply to a threat. Further, the verbal echoes in this dialogue (tw=n sofw=n in 1246, di/kaion in 1247, fo/bon in 1251) make it probable that sh=| xeiri\ in 1252 referred to words of Odysseus which either included xei/r, or at least foretold his personal interference more explicitly than is done by maxou/meqa.
(2) To remove v. 1252. Wunder proposes to delete it: Todt, to place it after v. 1290. Neither course is warrantable.

(3) To assume that vv. 1251, 1252 were spoken consecutively by N., and that v. 1252 alludes to a menacing gesture of Odysseus. This is Wecklein's view. But it appears scarcely consonant with the character and practice of Greek Tragedy that words spoken by one person should require the dumb action of another to make them clear.

If, then—as seems hardly doubtful—a verse has dropped out, its loss may have been due to the fact that it began with the same words as one of its next neighbours. In dialogue of this kind, anger is sometimes marked by derisive repetition: cp. O. T. 547*k*r. tou=t' au)to\ nu=n mou prw=t' a)/kouson w(s e)rw=. | *o*i. tou=t' au)to\ mh/ moi fra/z) etc. (with n. there). Odysseus—who asserts a di/kaion of his own (1247)—may have replied to N.'s words, cu
 tw=| dikai/w| to
 so
 ou) tarbw= fo/bon, with some such retort as, cu
 tw=| dikai/w| xei e)mh/ s' a)nagka/sei. Or v. 1252, a)ll) ou)de/ toi k.t.l., may have answered such a verse as, a)ll' ou)d' a)/lupos th=s e)mh=s e)/sei xero/s.
The textual history of this passage is parallel with that of O. T. 622—626, where the loss of one verse led to a similar confusion of persons in the MSS.

a)ll' ou)de/ toi: cp. O. C. 47a)ll' ou)d) e)moi/ toi. ou)de/ refers to sh=| xeiri\: as he does not fear the Greek army (1250), so neither does he fear the violence of Odysseus. ‘But neither do I obey thy hand (=yield to thy threat of force), to\ dra=n, so as to do thy bidding.’ —For the constr. of pei/qomai with dat. and inf., cp. Plat. Prot. 338A kai\ pei/qesqe/ moi r(abdou=xon...e(le/sqai: for the art. with the inf., Plat. Prot. 118 n.: Soph. Ant. 1105kardi/as d' e)ci/stamai | to\ dra=n.

e)/stw. Wecklein reads i)/tw, which is the fitter word where bold indifference to possible consequences is declared (cp. 120 n., and O. T. 1458a)ll' h( me\n h(mw=n moi=r), o(/poiper ei)=s), O. T. i)/tw). But the calmer word e)/stw is more dignified and more effective here. Cp. O. C. 1205e)/stw d' ou)=n o(/pws u(mi=n fi/lon.
kou) me/llont' e)/ti: cp. 567.

kai/toi, ‘however.’ Odysseus, who is not naturally du/sorgos (377), has quickly recovered his self-control. He recalls his threat of violence—speaking as if he had not heard N.'s reply. He now leaves the scene—in the hope that his parting threat will suffice—but remains near, to watch unseen. At the crisis he again interposes (1293),—as in v. 974.
e)lqw/n: cp. El. 1033e)lqou=sa mhtri\ tau=ta pa/nt' e)/ceipe sh=|.
e)swfro/nhsas: for the aor., cp. 1099 fronh=sai (n.).

klauma/twn: cp. Ant. 931toi=sin a)/gousin | klau/maq' u(pa/rcei. The familiar use of klai/wn in threats (ib. 754) made it natural to use the subst. as =‘troubles’: hence the confusion of metaphor would not be felt. For like phrases with po/da, see on Ant. 619.

*filokth/thn le/gw: for this use of le/gw cp. Ant. 32(n.). Matthiae's ground for proposing to read *filokth/ths (as nom. for voc., cp. 432) was that the accus. seems awkward when it refers to a person who is accosted: but we may properly compare Ai. 71 ff. ou(=tos, se\... | ... prosmolei=n kalw= | *ai)/anta fwnw=: stei=xe dwma/twn pa/ros: for, though the sense of fwnw= (‘I call to’) is different from that of le/gw, yet the objection to the accus. would be the same.
a)mei/yas, of leaving a place (as Tr. 659): but it can also denote ‘entering,’ as Her. 5. 72pri\n ta\s qu/ras au)to\n a)mei=yai (cp. Soph. Ant. 945a)lla/cai (of leaving), n.).
petrh/reis: here no more than petri/nas. Cp. the phrase of Eur. in Ar. Th. 889tumbh/reis e(/dras, ‘seat on a tomb.’
ti/s au)=: cp. O. C. 1500(Theseus entering) ti/s au)= par' u(mw=n koino\s h)xei=tai ktu/pos...;
a)/ntrois, poet. plur., like dw/mata, au)lai/ ( Ant. 945), qro/noi ( O. C. 425), etc.
i(/statai: cp. I. T. 1307 ti/s a)mfi\ dw=ma qea=s to/d' i(/sthsin boh/n;

e)kkalei=sqe: the midd. here differs from the act. ( O. T. 597 n.) only by suggesting that their own interests are involved.— kexrhme/noi. The form ke/xrhmai (xra/omai) in classical prose always means either, ‘to have used,’ or ‘to have been used.’ In poetry it means also, ‘to stand in need of.’ The partic. occurs only in poetry, as Od. 1. 13no/stou kexrhme/non: Eur. Ion 1199pw/matos kexrhme/noi.

w)/moi: kako\n to\ xrh=ma. Philoctetes, in the recesses of his cave, did not recognise the voice that called to him, and expected to see only the sailors, —who were still in front of the cave when he entered it (1217), and whom he regards as friends (1171). It is when he comes to the mouth of the cave, and sees Neoptolemus—the stealer of his bow— —that he exclaims w)/moi, kako\n to\ xrh=ma. (For this use of xrh=ma, familiar in Attic, cp. Vesp. 799 o(/ra to\ xrh=ma: ib. 834 ti/ pote to\ xrh=m);)

mw=n ti/ moi ve/a … kaka/; Bergk's correction ve/a is confirmed by the kaka in the text of L. Probably kako/n was merely a conjecture made to suit me/ga,—a corruption which doubtless arose from the ti (‘perchance,’ O. C. 969) just before it.

pe/mpontes, ‘ushering in,’ ‘heralding’: cp. Ant. 1286w)= kaka/ggelta/ moi | prope/myas a)/xh, ‘O thou herald of evil, bitter tidings.’ (The use of prope/myate in 1205 is different.) His fear is that Neoptolemus has come to execute the threat of taking him to Troy by force (983). That is, indeed, the only evil that could now be added to his lot.
e)k lo/gwn, through them: cp. 88 n.
lo/gois: for the repetition, cp. 88 n.
toiou=tos is explained by pisto/s etc.: cp. O. T. 435h(mei=s toioi/d' e)/fumen, w(s me\n soi\ dokei=, | mw=|roi: O. C. 62toiau=ta/ soi tau=t' e)sti/n, w)= ce/n), ou) lo/gois | timw/men).
pisto/s, inspiring confidence: cp. 71.
a)ll' ou)/ ti mh\n: the same formula occurs in El. 817: and mh\n seems here better than the v. l. mh\.
pau=e: cp. O. C. 1751 n.

a(\n ei)/ph|s ge. Dobree ( II. Adv. 47) would alter ge to su\, comparing Eur. Bacch. 655(sofo\s sofo\s su/), where su/, lost in the MSS., was restored by Porson from Chr. Patiens 1529. But ge is right. ‘All thy words will be in vain (though I cannot resist force, if that be used).’ He knows what their lo/goi are worth (cp. 1268 f., 1271).

kai\ pe/ra g), i)/sq), h)\ le/gw: ‘yes, (I am so resolved,) and more strongly than my words express.’ Though dedogme/non might be supplied with i)/sq), it is better to supply de/doktai. The simple i)/sqi i(s sometimes, like sa/f' i)/sqi, parenthetic: O. T. 1022dw=ro/n pot), O. T. i)/sqi, tw=n e)mw=n xeirw=n labw/n. For h)\ le/gw, cp. Eur. Alc. 1082a)pw/lese/n me, ka)/ti ma=llon h)\ le/gw: id. Eur. Hec. 667w)= panta/laina, ka)/ti ma=llon h)\ le/gw.

a)ll' h)/qelon me\n a)/n: cp. 427, 1239: and for a)lla\ me/n, 882 n.— pro\s kairo\n=kairi/ws ( O. T. 325 n.).— pe/paumai: for the perf., cp. 76 o)/lwla. Similarly pepau/somai ( Ant. 91 n.).— pa/nta ga\r: for this use of ga/r, marking assent, cp. Ant. 639.
kth/sei: cp. 1370: Ai. 1360kta=sqai fi/lous: and for the constr. here, Eur. Or. 267to\ qei=on dusmene\s kekth/meqa.

o(/stis g). When o(/stis refers, with causal force, to a definite antecedent ( O. T. 1184), the addition of ge to it is comparatively rare in Soph. ( Soph. O. C. 810o(/tw| ge is not similar): while o(/s ge is frequent (663).
a)peste/rhkas, with acc. of the thing only: 931.
e)lqw/n implies, ‘after robbing me, thou wilt not even leave me in peace.’ Cp. Ai. 1276e)rru/sat' e)lqw\n mou=nos.
e)/xqistos gegw/s, having proved thyself a most hateful son of a noble sire. Achilles was fi/ltatos to Ph. (242): the son has become e)/xqistos by his theft of the bow.

The force of this passage will not be fully appreciated unless we remember that N. is now completely identified, in Ph. 's mind, with the action of Odysseus. Ph. was ready to allow that N.'s better instincts had been warped by evil guidance (971, 1014). But then he hoped that N. would restore the bow. Odysseus prevented this: N. made no direct reply to the last appeal (1066 f.), and carried off his prize.

Pierson's conjecture ai)/sxistos was approved by Porson, and has received weighty support from recent critics. Cp. 906 ai)sxro\s fanou=mai. In Soph. Ph. 585(=594 Porson) ai)/sxiston is a v. l. for e)/xqiston: in Soph. O. T. 1519 at least one late MS. has ai)/sxistos for e)/xqistos: and in Soph. Ai. 1059Triclinius gave e)xqi/stw| for ai)sxi/stw|. But, as it seems to me, we should rather lose than gain by forsaking the MSS. here.

a)=ra seems the true correction of the MS. ou)k a)=ra or ou)k a)/ra. The expected answer to a question asked by a)=ra may be either ‘yes’ ( Ant. 405), or ‘no’ ( Ai. 1304): here it suits the suspense between fear and hope. a)=r' ou) is unsuitable; it would mean, ‘Is it not clear that I am being deceived again?’ When a)=r' ou) is used, the answer ‘yes’ is always inevitable, and the tone of the query is usually triumphant (see O. T. 540, O. T. 823, O. T. 828: O. C. 791, O. C. 883: Ai. 1034: El. 614). The other conjecture, ou) ga\r, is also inappropriate; that would mean, ‘what, am I not being deceived again?’ (as if a second fraud had been expected. Cp. 246: O. T. 1017: Ai. 1348). The intrusion of ou)k before a)=ra in the MSS. here may have been due to the scribe's reminiscence of passages in which the question pw=s ei)=pas is followed by ou) (246, O. T. 1017).

a)pw/mos), ‘I swear, ‘No’’ (like a)po/fhmi, ‘I say ‘No,’’ O. C. 317): Ar. Eq. 424tou\s qeou\s a)pw/mnun. For the aor., cp. 1314: Ai. 536e)ph/nes): ib. 693 e)/fric): El. 668e)deca/mhn: Eur. Hec. 1276a)pe/ptus).
a(gnou=: cp. Suppl. 652 *zhno\s i(/ktoras a(gnou=. The fact that a(gno/n is oft. an epithet of se/bas (as in O. T. 830) is no adequate reason for writing a(gno\n … u(yi/stou here.
pare/stai, ‘shall be forthcoming’ (in fulfilment of thy word,—cp. O. C. 726): fanero/n, ‘before thine eyes’; cp. O. C. 910e)nargei=s.

e)gw\ d' a)paudw= g): ge emphasises the verb: cp. 660, 1037. Odysseus darts forward from his place of concealment (cp. 1257 n.),—his voice being heard before he is seen (1295). At v. 974 he was just in time to prevent the bow being restored; now he is too late.

w(s qeoi\ cuni/stores: cp. Ant. 542w(=n tou)/rgon, *(/aidhs xoi( ka/tw cuni/stores: Suppl. 1174 *zeu\s de\ cuni/stwr oi(/ t' e)n ou)ranw=| qeoi/. For the invocation of the gods in a protest, cp. Thuc. 4. 87ma/rturas me\n qeou\s... poih/somai w(s e)p' a)gaqw=| h(/kwn ou) pei/qw: and id. 1. 78, Thuc. 2. 71.
u(pe/r t): te irregularly placed, as in 185: O. C. 33th=s u(pe/r t' e)mou= | au(th=s q' o(rw/shs.
te/knon: a mode of address which he has not used since v. 997 (w)= pai=). Cp. 923 w)= ce/ne (n.).

ti/nos fw/nhma; In this agitated and rapid utterance, it seems best to understand e)sti/ with fw/nhma, and to take e)ph|sqo/mhn with *)odusse/ws, rather than to suppose that fw/nhma is governed by e)ph|sqo/mhn and understood again with the proper name.
a)postelw=, here, ‘convey away’; cp. 983 stelou=si (=a)/cousin in 985).

a)ll' ou)/ ti xai/rwn: a regular formula in threats,—most forcible when, as here, the verb is left to be supplied from the last speaker's words: so Eur. Or. 1592 f. *o*p....a)rke/sw d' e)gw\ le/gwn. | *m*e. a)ll' ou)/ ti xai/rwn, h)/n ge mh\ fugh=|s pteroi=s. Her. 3. 36a)po\ de\ w)/lesas *ku=ron peiqo/meno/n soi. a)ll' ou)/ ti xai/rwn, e)pei\ k.t.l. Sometimes, again, the verb is expressed: as in Soph. O. T. 363: Ar. Ran. 843a)ll' ou)/ ti xai/rwn au)/t' e)rei=s: id. Ar. Ach. 563a)ll' ou)/ti (so Bentley for ou)de\) xai/rwn tau=ta tolmh/sei le/gein.
o)rqwqh=|, be directed straight: fr. 430. 5 o)rqou=tai kanw/n. Cp. the fig. sense in Ant. 675tw=n... o)rqoume/nwn, ‘lives whose course is fair.’

a)=, in reproof, as O. T. 1147a)=, mh\ ko/laze: Aesch. Ag. 1087a)=, poi= pot' h)/gage/s me; the doubled a)= a)= also occurs in trimeters, as Eur. Or. 1598 OP.e)/stai ta/d). *m*e. a)= a)=, mhdamw=s dra/sh|s ta/de.

meqh=|s is altered to a)fh=|s by Nauck, who thinks that me/qes in 1301 caused the error. But two points claim notice. (1) meqh=|s, ‘permit to escape from thy hand,’ ‘allow to fly,’ is a more forcible word than a)fh=|s (‘discharge’) when, as here, the archer is at the very point of shooting. Cp. O. T. 784tw=| meqe/nti to\n lo/gon, ‘who had let that taunt escape him’ (with n. there). Xen. Cyr. 4. 3§ 9 palta\...oi)=s kai\ meqie/ntes kai\ e)/xontes xrw/|meq' a)/n (‘darts which will serve us, whether our hands release or retain them’). (2) It is no objection to meqh=|s that me/qes in 1301 has a different application. Cp. n. on 762 (dh=ta).
me/qes me … xei=ra: the second acc. defines the part: cp. Il. 11. 240to\n d' a)/ori plh=c' au)xe/na: Tr. 831 ff. ei) ga/r sfe... | xri/ei... | pleura/.

ti/ m' a)/ndra pole/mion k.t.l. At first sight it might appear simplest to suppose that a)fei/lou governs a double accus., mh\ ktanei=n being epexegetic (‘thou hast robbed me of the man, so that I should not slay him’). But other passages show that there was an idiomatic use of a)fairou=mai with the inf., in which it was nearly equivalent to kwlu/w. Pindar I. 1. 60 pa/nta d' e)ceipei=n... | ...a)fairei=tai braxu\ me/tron e)/xwn | u(/mnos, ‘hinders from uttering.’ Eur. Andr. 913ka)/kteinas, h)/ tis sumfora/ s' a)fei/leto; (i.e., to\ ktei=nai,—‘prevented thee’). Eur. Tro. 1145to\ despo/tou ta/xos | a)fei/let' au)th\n pai=da mh\ dou=nai ta/fw|, ‘her master's haste deprived her of the power to bury her son.’ So, here, the true construction seems to be, ti/ a)fei/lou me mh\ ktanei=n a)/ndra pole/mion; ‘why hast thou robbed me of the chance of slaying a foe?’ In admitting, but not requiring, mh/ with the inf., this a)fairou=mai is like other verbs of hindering. pole/mion: for the tribrach in the 5th place, cp. Soph. O. T. 719 n. This is the rarest form of it (the last word of the verse being a ‘paeon quartus’): cp. 1327: Aesch. Eum. 780e)gw\ d' a)/timos h( ta/laina baru/kotos.
e)xqro/n t): cp. 1323 pole/mion dusmenh= q). He has avowed his hostility to the whole Greek army (1200), and can properly call Odysseus pole/mios,—as Menelaus gives that name to Ajax ( Ai. 1132).
a)ll' ou)=n … ge: cp. Ant. 84 n.
tou\s pr. stratou=: for the omission of tou=, cp. Ant. 10 n.

yeudokh/rukas, ‘lying heralds.’ The word alludes more particularly (as is indicated by e)n de\ toi=s lo/gois qrasei=s) to the protest which Odysseus has just made ‘in the name of the whole army’ (1293 f.), and to his threat at vv. 1257 f.:—it is not merely an equivalent for ‘false envoy’ (because he had executed his mandate by fraud). In Attic Tragedy the kh=ruc was especially associated with unsuccessful bluster. Examples are afforded by the herald of Aegyptus ( Suppl. 836 ff.), the herald of Creon ( Suppl. 399 ff.), and the herald of Eurystheus (id. Heracl. 55 ff.). Menelaus plays a similar part when he forbids the burial of Ajax ( Ai. 1047), and he is then attended by a kh=ruc (ib. 1115 pro\s tau=ta plei/ous deu=ro kh/rukas labw/n k.t.l.). With yeudokh=ruc cp. yeudo/mantis ( O. C. 1097): for the allusive plur., O. T. 366 n.
pro\s ai)xmh/n: cp. Tr. 266pro\s to/cou kri/sin.
ei)=en, ‘so far so good’: cp. Helen. 761 *e*l. ei)=en: ta\ me\n dh\ deu=r' a)ei\ kalw=s e)/xei: similarly it marks a pause between statement and comment ( O. C. 1308 n.).
o(/tou, causal gen.: cp. O. T. 698o(/tou pote\ | mh=nin tosh/nde pra/gmatos sth/sas e)/xeis. The MS. o(/pou, though defensible, seems less suitable here.
ei)s e)me/: cp. 522.
th\n fu/sin d): the elision gives quasi-caesura: cp. 276 and 101 n.— e)c h(=s, since the fu/sis, or inherited strain of the ge/nos, can stand in poetry for the ge/nos itself.

e)/blastes: for the e^ before bl, cp. El. 440pasw=n e)/blaste, fr. 119 e)pei\ de\ bla/stoi, O. T. 717paido\s de\ bla/stas: also O.C. 972, Eur. fr. 432, fr. adesp. 376. So Eur. fr. 698 ptw/x' a)mfi/blhta sw/matos. On the other hand, the i of perible/pw is regularly long (O.C. 996 n.).

ou)xi\ *sisu/fou patro/s, explaining what precedes: (‘thou hast shown, I say, that thou dost not spring from) Sisyphus.’ It is simpler to supply blastw/n (from e)/blastes) than fu/sin. The gen. is influenced by the prep. before h(=s: for patro/s, cp. 3.

meta\ zw/ntwn q). The q), though wanting in L, seems genuine. For te... de/ (instead of te...te), cp. Ant. 1096 n.— teqnhko/twn might be governed by meta/, but really depends rather on the unexpressed a)/rista a)kou/ei. The poet may have been thinking of Od. 11. 482 ff., sei=o d' *)axilleu=, | ou)/tis a)nh propa/roiqe maka/rtatos ou)/t' a)/r' o)pi/ssw: | pri
 me
 ga/r se zwo
 e)ti/omen i)=sa qeoi=sin | *)argei=oi, nu=n d' au)=te me/ga krate/eis neku/essin.
h(/sqhn: for the aor., cp. 1289 n.: for the acc., O. T. 236(n.): Ai. 136se\ me\n eu)= pra/ssont' e)pixai/rw: Eur. Hipp. 1339tou\s ga\r eu)sebei=s qeoi\ | qnh/|skontas ou) xai/rousi.

a)mo
 for e)mo
 is the best correction. The phrase pate/ra to
 a)mo
 occurs in El. 279, El. 588, El. 1496, and in the first two of those passages a)mo
 in L has been made from e)mo
. Cp. 1118 above (a)ma=s for e)ma=s).—With h(/sqhn pate/ra te to
 e)mo
, or h(/sqhn ge pate/ra to
 e)mo
, the rhythm is enfeebled by two consecutive tribrachs,—without the justification given in 1029 by the pause after a)/gete. And ge would be somewhat weak.
w(=n … sou tuxei=n: for the double gen., cp. Xen. An. 5. 7. 33ou(= de\ dh\ pa/ntwn oi)o/meqa teu/cesqai e)pai/nou (‘in a case where we expect to win praise from all men’): and Soph. O. C. 1170 n.
e)fi/emai, ‘desire,’ with inf., as Thuc. 6. 6e)fie/menoi ...th=s pa/shs a)/rcein.
ta\s me\n e)k qew=n tu/xas doqei/sas: for this order (instead of soqei/sas tu/xas), cp. Thuc. 7. 23ai( pro\ tou= sto/matos nh=es naumaxou=sai: O.T. 1245 (n.): for e)k, O.T. 590 n.

e(kousi/oisin, since, though Ph. could not have avoided the woes of the past ten years, their prolongation is now his own choice. Cp. Soph. El. 215oi)kei/as ei)s a)/tas | e)mpi/pteis. e(kou/sios is in Attic either of two or of three terminations: cp. Soph. Tr. 727e)c e(kousi/as, ib. 1123 e(kousi/a: Thuc. 8. 27kaq' e(kousi/an (yet id. 7. 57 e(kou/sios...stratei/a): Plat. Rep. 603C biai/ous h)\ e(kousi/as pra/ceis. But of a)kou/sios the fem. in -i/a, -iai seems not to occur: cp. Legg. 861 E bla/bai... a)kou/sioi.

e)/gkeintai, ‘are intent upon,’ meaning here, ‘persist in enduring,’ though a release is offered to them. Cp. Eur. Andr. 91oi)=sper e)gkei/mesq' a)ei\ | qrh/noisi kai\ go/oisi kai\ dakru/masi, | pro\s ai)qe/r' e)ktenou=men: e)mpe/fuke ga\r | gunaici\ te/ryis tw=n parestw/twn kakw=n: where the sense is, ‘to which I give my days.’ So id. I. T. 144 i)/deq' w(s qrh/nois e)/gkeimai: Ion 182oi(=s d' e)/gkeimai mo/xqois. But sometimes Eur. uses this verb as simply =kei=mai e)n: Helen. 269 pollai=s sumforai=s e)gkei/meqa (‘are plunged in’): and so ib. 924.

h)gri/wsai expresses the temper which fiercely rejects friendly remonstrance (whereas in 226 a)phgriwme/non referred to aspect): cp. Od. 8. 575h)me\n o(/soi xalepoi/ te kai\ a)/grioi ou)de\ di/kaioi, | h)e\ filo/ceinoi. So in Plat. Rep. 410D a)grio/ths is associated with sklhro/ths.— For ou)/te … te, cp. 1363: O. C. 1397 n. Here, as often, the clause with te expresses the contrary of that with ou)/te (‘so far from accepting advice, you resent it’): Her. 1. 63o(/kws mh/te a(lisqei=en e)/ti oi( *)aqhnai=oi, dieskedasme/noi te ei)=en: cp. id. 1. 119 quoted above on v. 950.

eu)noi/a|: cp. El. 233a)ll' ou)=n eu)noi/a| g' au)dw=. Schneidewin's view that L's reading, eu)/noia/n soi le/gwn, arose from eu)/soian le/gwn (cp. O.C. 390 eu)soi/as xa/rin), is more ingenious than probable: rather soi was a mere gloss, explaining the object of the eu)/noia.
dusmenh= q): cp. 1303.

*zh=na … o(/rkion, Zeus, the guardian of oaths,—who punishes men who break them. In the bouleuth/rion at Olympia there was a statue of *zeu\s *(/orkios, with a thunderbolt in each hand ( Paus. 5. 24. 9). Cp. O.C. 1767 xw( pa/nt' a)i+/wn *dio\s *(/orkos (n.). Eur. Hipp. 1025nu=n d' o(/rkio/n soi *zh=na kai\ pe/don xqono\s | o)/mnumi: id. Eur. Med. 208ta\n *zhno\s o(rki/an *qe/min.

gra/fou frenw=n e)/sw: so Aesch. Cho. 450toiau=t' a)kou/wn e)n fresi\n gra/fou. More often this metaphor is developed by the word de/ltos ( Aesch. P. V. 789, Soph. Tr. 683, fr. 537), or a derivative of it ( Suppl. 179 deltoume/nas, Eum. 275deltogra/fw|...freni/).

gra/fou. The midd. gra/fomai is used in prose also (apart from its legal sense, ‘to indict’) of writing down something for one's own use: cp. Her. 2. 82, Her. 8. 135(suggraya/menon), Plat. Theaet. 142 So D. a)pogra/fomai, of taking an inventory (Lys. or. 12, § 8).
su\ ga\r: for ga/r prefacing a statement, cp. 1337: O. T. 277 n.

e)k qei/as tu/xhs: cp. fr. 198 pw=s ou)=n ma/xwmai qnhto\s w)\n qei/a| tu/xh|; Philoctetes has shown no consciousness that his misfortune was anything more than an ordinary accident (cp. 267, 632). He now learns that it was ordained by the gods,—in order that he might not reach Troy before the time appointed for that city's fall (197 ff.).

to
 a)kalufh= shko
 = to\ u(pai/qrion te/menos, the sacred precinct, open to the sky. This form a)kalufh/s is similarly used by De Anim. 2. 9 (Berl. ed. 422 a 1), to\ o)sfrantiko
 ai)sqhth/rion a)ka/lufes (better a)kalufe\s) ei)=nai,— opp. to e)/xein e)pika/lumma. Here it is opposed to u(po/stegos or stegano/s. The word shko/s, in ref. to sacred places, properly means, as here, an enclosure without any roofed building (cp. Her. 4. 62), though poets sometimes use it as a general term for ‘shrine’: Eur. Ion 300shkou\s...*trofwni/ou (his cave): [Eur. ] Rhes. 501 ei)s *)aqa/nas shko/n. For a)kalufh= at the end of the v., cp. 1302 n.

kru/fios oi)kourw=n o)/fis. The epic version speaks merely of an o)loo/frwn u(/dros ( Il. 2. 723). But the Attic poet feels that the mysterious significance of the event is enhanced, if the serpent which inflicted the bite is conceived as the fu/lac of the shrine. Clearly Sophocles does not identify Chrysè with any form of Athena; Chrysè is, for him, a lesser deity: yet the associations of the Erechtheum have suggested the word oi)kourw=n. The sacred serpent in that temple,—representative of Erichthonius, and guardian of Athena Polias,—was regularly called oi)kouro\s o)/fis. Hesych. oi)kouro
 o)/fin: to
 th=s *polia/dos fu/laka dra/konta. Ar. Lys. 758a)ll' ou) du/namai )gwg' ou)de\ koima=sq' e)n po/lei (in the acropolis), | e)c ou(= to
 o)/fin ei)=don to
 oi)kouro/n pote. Her. 8. 41le/gousi *)aqhnai=oi o)/fin me/gan fu/laka th=s a)kropo/lios e)ndiaita=sqai e)n tw=| i(rw=|.—For the verb oi)kourei=n, cp. Soph. O. C. 343.

The sacred precinct of Chrysè, with the serpent, is depicted on a sta/mnos (wine-jar) of about 400 C.B. , now in the Campana collection at the Louvre. The image of Chrysè stands in the open air on a low pedestal; just in front of it is a low and rude altar, with fire burning on it; close to this is the serpent, at which Agamemnon is striking with his sceptre, while the wounded Philoctetes lies on the ground, with Achilles and others around him. See Introd. § 21.

pau=lan, subject to tuxei=n: cp. 275 oi(=) au)toi=s tu/xoi. This is better than to make pau=lan the object of tuxei=n as =‘obtain’: since the acc. after tugxa/nw is elsewhere a neut. pron. or adj., or art. with inf. ( Ant. 778 n.). The correction of the MS. e)ntuxei=n to a)\n tuxei=n seems certain. In Aesch. P. V. 667kei) mh\ qe/loi, purwpo\n e)k *dio\s molei=n | kerauno/n, o(\s pa=n e)cai+stw/soi ge/nos, the future sense of the simple aor. inf. is sufficiently marked by the context.
mh/pot). The use of mh/ here is due to the notion of ‘feeling confident,’ not to the imperat.: see on O. T. 1455tosou=to/n g' oi)=da, mh/te m' a)\n no/son | mh/t' a)/llo pe/rsai mhde/n.

e(/ws a)
 is a certain emendation of w(s a)
, which would mean ‘in whatever way,’ ‘however’ ( Ai. 1369). But, ‘however the sun may rise,’ etc., could not stand for, ‘so long as the sun continues to rise.’ w(s a)/n never means, or could mean, ‘while.’ For e(/ws scanned as one syllable (by synizesis), cp. Il. 17. 727, Od. 2. 148.Cp. O. C. 1361e(/wsper (w(/sper MSS.) a)
 zw=: Ai. 1117e(/ws (w(s MSS.) a)
 h)=|s oi)=o/s per ei)=.

au(to\s h(/lios. Cp. Her. 8. 143nu=n te a)pa/ggelle *mardoni/w| w(s *)aqhnai=oi le/gousi, e)/st' a)
 h(/lios th
 au)th
 o(do
 i)/h| th=| per kai\ nu=n e)/rxetai, mh/kote o(mologh/sein h(me/as *ce/rch|. ‘While the same sun rises,’ etc.,=‘while the sun rises as he now does.’ It is possible that au(to\s may be a reminiscence of th
 au)th
 o(do/n in Her. ; at any rate it is decidedly more forcible here than Brunck's ou(=tos, which he illustrates from Plut. Arist. 10, to
 h(/lion dei/cas: a)/xris a)
 ou)=tos tau/thn poreu/htai th
 porei/an, *)aqhnai=oi polemh/sousi *pe/rsais. The gesture implied by ou(=tos would be superfluous here, since in saying tau/th|, th=|de, he points to the east and to the west. (For the combination of these pronouns, cp. 841 n.)
ai)/rh|: there seems to be no other classical instance of this intrans. use; but cp. a)ni/sxw, a)ne/xw (of sunrise).

e(kw\n au)to\s, a pleonasm (used also by Soph. Ph. 476), like, ‘of thine own free will.’ The oracle had made the consent of Ph. a condition (612): the use of fraud was an unauthorised device of Odysseus (103).

e)ntuxw\n with gen., instead of the usual dat., as in Her. 4. 140, quoted on v. 320, where see n. The gen. here (like that with suntuxw/n there) has a special warrant, since the idea is that of ‘obtaining their aid.’

tw=n par' h(mi=n … *)asklhpidw=n: cp. Il. 2. 731(referring to the warriors from Tricca, Ithomè, and Oechalia in Thessaly), tw=n d' au)=q' h(gei/sqhn *)asklhpio/o du/o pai=de, | i)hth=r' a)gaqw/, *podalei/rios h)de\ *maxa/wn.— The form *)asklhpi/dhs, for *)asklhpia/dhs, occurs nowhere else, and is wrongly formed from *)asklhpio/s. The rule for masc. patronymics is as follows:—(1) Stems in a_ and -io- take the suffix -da_-, when a_ becomes a^, and -io- becomes -ia-: as *)argea/-dh-s, from *)arge/a_-s, *menoitia/-dh-s from *menoi/tio-s. (2) All other stems take -ida_, as *tantal-i/dh-s from *ta/ntalo-s. But the first formation is sometimes used by poets instead of the second, for metre's sake: e.g. *xalkwdontia/dhs ( Il. 2. 541) for *xalkwdonti/dhs, *telamwnia/dhs (ib. 9. 623) for *telamwni/dhs. And the converse licence is attested by Etym. Magn. p. 210. 11 (quoted by Herm. ): oi( de\ poihtai\ polla/kis a)poba/llousi to\ a, oi(=on, *)erixqonia/dhs (from *)erixqo/nio-s), *)erixqoni/dhs. [The writer wrongly adds *telamwnia/dhs, *telamwni/dhs, as if the latter were the irregular form.] *)erixqoni/dai occurs in C. I. 1. 411. The form *)asklhpi/dhs, then, though incorrect, may well be genuine.

This verse implies that both the sons of Asclepius were to have a part in the cure; and so in 1378 f. the plural is used. But, in the prevailing form of the legend, Machaon alone was the healer; probably because, in post-Homeric poetry, Machaon was the representative of surgery, as his brother was of medicine (cp. Preller, 1. p. 409). So Lesches in the Little Iliad, acc. to Proclus, p. 481 ed. Gaisford: the Orphic *liqika/, 342 ff., where Machaon uses a powder made from a stone called o)fih=tis: Tzetzes, Posthom. 580 ff., where the stone is e)xih=tis: Propertius 2. 1. 59. An epic poet, Dionysius, represented Apollo as putting Ph. to sleep, when Machaon amputated the diseased part (Tzetzes on Lycophron 911: schol. Pind. P. 1. 109). Quintus Smyrnaeus is singular in making the healer Podaleirius (9. 463).

The scene of the cure occurs on a fragment of a bronze mirror (found in south Etruria, and ascribed to the 5th or 4th cent. B.C.), now in the archaeological Museum of the University of Bologna. It bears an Etruscan legend, Pheltute (Philoctetes), Machan (Machaon). The healer is in the act of bandaging the hero's foot; a sponge and a box of ointment rest on a sort of camp-stool (di/fros o)kladi/as) between them. (Milani, Mito di F., pl. III. 49; pp. 104 ff.)
This verse has been thought inconsistent with 1437: but see n. there.
no/sou malaxqh=|s: the gen. as after verbs denoting cessation or respite: Ai. 274ka)ne/pneuse th=s no/sou: Eur. Or. 43sw=ma koufisqh=| no/sou: so lwfa=n, etc.

cu
 toi=sde to/cois, with its aid: cp. Xen. An. 3. 2. 8su
 toi=s o(/plois...di/khn e)piqei=nai au)toi=s. But su/n with dat., in ref. to arms, is oft. no more than e)/xwn with acc.; e.g. Il. 11. 251sth= d' eu)ra\c su
 douri/.
pe/rsus fanh=|s: the phrase suggests the glory of the exploit; cp. 1064: Thuc. 2. 11ka/lliston...pollou\s o)/ntas e(ni\ ko/smw| xrwme/nous fai/nesqai.

The language here is not strictly logical. It implies that, before the pau=la can come, he must not only have been relieved (malaxqh=|s), but also have taken Troy. The explanation seems to be simply that the writer was thinking of the victory as an event which was to follow closely on the cure. So, having used malaxqh=|s, he subjoined kai\...pe/rsas fanh=|s, instead of making the second statement independent of pri
 a)/n (e.g., kai\ e)/peita pe/rsas fanei=). It is much as if one said, ‘You will never be cured until you find health and glory at Troy,’—instead of, ‘find health at Troy,—where you will also find glory.’ Schneidewin and others compare Ai. 106—110: qanei=n ga au)to
 ou)/ ti/ pw qe/lw...pri
 a)
...nw=ta foinixqei\s qa/nh|. The parallel would be closer if, there, we had foinixqh=| kai\ qa/nh|,—meaning foinixqh=|: kai\ e)/peita qanei=tai.
We cannot remove the difficulty by supposing that malaxqh=|s denotes merely alleviation, not cure; for the poet clearly thinks of the cure as preceding the victory (919 f.: 1345 ff.: 1424 ff.).

w(s d' oi)=da tau=ta k.t.l. The report of the prophecy given by the pretended e)/mporos in 603—613 was true as far as it went, but designedly incomplete. Neoptolemus, we must suppose, derived his knowledge from the Atreidae or Odysseus (cp. 114 w(s e)fa/sket)): who, however, had omitted to tell him that the aid of the bow was indispensable to his own success (112 ff.).
ga\r as in 1326.
h(mi=n e)/stin (‘we have a man,’ etc.), rather than h(mi=n e)stin (when the verb would be merely auxiliary to a(lou/s).
*(/elenos: see on 606 ff.: a)risto/mantis = a)/ristos ma/ntis, like a)lhqo/mantis ( Aesch. Ag. 1241), o)rqo/mantis ( Pind. N. 1. 92), etc.

w(s dei= gene/sqai tau=ta: i.e., if Ph. consents to come (1332): if he does not, then Troy cannot be taken (611). The change of dei= to xrh\ is unnecessary, since dei= can equally well denote what is ordained by fate: cp. 998: 1397: O. T. 825.

qe/rous: so Verg. Aen. 3. 8, vix prima inceperat aestas. The general tradition was that Troy fell about the end of May (late in the Attic month Thargelion): see Camill. 19 (where Ephorus and other writers are quoted for the statement), and Clemens Strom. 1. 21, p. 139 (where *dionu/sios o( *)argei=os is cited: cp. Müller Frag. Hist. III. p. 26). pa=san, adverbial: cp. 386.
di/dws' … e(auto/n, offers himself, ktei/nein, (for us) to slay: cp. 618: Nub. 440 touti\ to/ g' e)mo\n sw=m' au)toi=sin | pare/xw tu/ptein.

kalh\ ga\r h( )pi/kthsis. The further gain (e)pi/kthsis) is the fame which he will win, in addition to being cured. This is indicated by the place of the words *(ellh/nwn e(/na | kriqe/nt' a)/riston (for e(/na with the superl., cp. O. C. 563 f., n.). Then the clause relating to the cure is co-ordinated with the clause relating to victory; see on Ant. 1112.We should say rather, ‘that, while you are cured, you should also win fame.’ For tou=to me\n followed by ei)=ta, cp. Ant. 61 n.: for ei)=ta (without de/), El. 261 f. prw=ta me\n...ei)=ta. Ellendt says, ‘kth=sin interpretatus schol. errat’: but the schol.'s words are, h( )pi/kthsis: h( kth=sis th=s do/chs: which is exactly right.
w stugno\s ai)w/n: for the nom., cp. 1186, 1213. ai)w/n is here tinged with the notion of ‘fortune,’ cp. 179.
a)/nw: cp. Ant. 1068tw=n a)/nw (the living): El. 1167h(ni/k' h)=sq' a)/nw.
a)fh=kas … molei=n: for the inf. (which was unnecessary) cp. Her. 1. 194to\ ploi=on... a)piei=si kata\ to\n potamo\n fe/resqai.

The one feeling which now makes Ph. waver is reluctance to repel the kindly entreaties of Neoptolemus. His hatred of the Greek chiefs is undiminished by the knowledge that they were unconscious instruments of destiny. Nor is he moved by the assurance of health and fame.
ei)ka/qw: cp. O. C. 651 n.— ei)s fw=s … ei)=mi, into the public gaze; cp. 581: Xen. Ages. 9. 1, where to\ fw=s (‘publicity’) = to\ a)ei\ e)mfanh\s e<*>nai, as opp. to to\ spani/ws o(ra=sqai.

tw=| prosh/goros; the dat., as in Plat. Theaet. 146A fi/lous te kai\ proshgo/rous a)llh/lois: but mhdeno\s prosh/goros in Soph. O. T. 1437.Cp. Thuc. 6. 16w(/sper dustuxou=ntes ou) prosagoreuo/meqa: and the prosperous Creon's words in O. T. 596, nu=n me pa=s a)spa/zetai.

w)= ta\ pa/nt' i)do/ntes … ku/kloi. Although ta\ pa/nta a)mf' e)moi/ could stand for ta\ a)mf' e)moi\ pa/nta (cp. Ant. 659 n.), the interposed i)do/ntes here requires that a)mf' e)moi\ should be taken with it: literally, ‘ye that, in my case, have seen all,’— i.e., ‘ye that have seen all the wrong done to me’ (ta\ peri\ e)me\ pa/qh, schol.). Of the two readings, a)mf' e)moi\ (L) and a)mf' e)mou= (A), the first has the better MS. authority; and though the second is more euphonious, that fact does not warrant a preference. As used by Soph. , a)mfi/ with gen. =‘concerning’ (554): with dat., either ‘concerning’ ( Soph. Ai. 684a)ll' a)mfi\ me\n tou/toisin eu)= sxh/sei), or ‘around’ ( Soph. Ant. 1223 etc.). The sense ‘concerning’ is fittest here.

ku/kloi has been explained as ‘years’ (schol.), ‘the orbs of heaven’ (Brunck, Buttmann). Camerarius saw the true meaning. Cp. O. C. 704o( ga\r ai)e\n o(rw=n ku/klos (‘eye’) | leu/ssei nin *mori/ou *dio/s. O. T. 1270 ff.: e)/paisen a)/rqra tw=n au(tou= ku/klwn, | au)dw=n toiau=q' o(qou/nek' ou)k o)/yointonin | ou)d' oi=() e)/pasxen ou)/q' o(poi=) e)/dra kaka/.

Instead of saying, poi/ois o)/mmasi ble/pwn ( O. T. 1371 n.) cune/somai toi=s' *)atre/ws paisi/n, he asks how his own eyes could endure to see it. These are the words of one who has brooded for years on every aspect of his own wrongs,—wrestling with misery in solitude. His own faculties are his comrades. Compare 1004 w)= xei=res: Tr. 1090(Heracles in his agony), w)= nw=ta kai\ ste/rn), w)= fi/loi braxi/ones, | u(mei=s e)kei=noi dh\ kaqe/stat), k.t.l.

ou) ga/r me ta)/lgos k.t.l. ‘How can I return to the Atreidae? For it is not merely a question of forgetting the past; I dread the future.’ He does not mean that he has ceased to resent the former wrongs, but only that his present resolve is influenced less by resentment than by fear.

oi(=s ga\r … kakou/s: ‘for when a man's mind has (once) become a mother of evil deeds, it trains him to be evil in everything else,’—i.e., in all subsequent deeds. For kakou/s as proleptic predicate, cp. Ant. 475 n.; Eur. Med. 296pai=das perissw=s e)kdida/skesqai sofou/s.

A decision between the conject. kakou/s and the MS. kaka/ demands care. I prefer kakou/s, for these reasons. (1) kaka/, if retained, would naturally suggest this sense:—‘When a man's mind has once given birth to evil (counsels), it trains the rest also (i.e., his actions) to be evil.’ But the antithesis here is between the earlier and the later bad deeds; not between bad counsels and bad deeds. (2) The effect of kakou/s is to indicate that ta)/lla stands in antithesis, not with kakw=n only, but with the whole preceding clause, and thus to suggest its true sense, viz., ‘in all that follows.’ (3) It is true that the image, mh/thr ge/nhtai, is then no longer consistently maintained; but this very failure to persevere with a metaphor is Sophoclean (cp. n. on O. T. 866). mh/thr ge/nhtai is a poetical equivalent for, ‘make a beginning of.’ Hence the poet felt that he did not require a(/pac, though we should naturally add ‘once.’ The same delicate economy may be observed in Ant. 584oi(=s ga\r a)\n seisqh=| qeo/qen do/mos, a)/tas | ou)de\n e)llei/pei: ‘For when a house hath (once) been shaken from heaven, there the curse fails nevermore.’ The change of kakou/s into kaka/ might easily have been caused by ta)/lla.—See Appendix.

kai\ sou= d). The formula kai\... de/ means ‘and...also,’ with an emphasis on the intervening word. This is the only instance in Soph. : it occurs, however, in Aesch. P. V. 973(kai\ se\ d' e)n tou/tois le/gw), Aesch. Eum. 65: Soph. El. 1117(kai\ su\ d' au)qa/dhs e)/fus): Ar. Pax 250: and oft. in Attic prose. The usual account of it is that the kai/=‘also,’ while de/=‘and.’ This suits those instances in which, as here, kai\...de/ is preceded by a full stop, or by a pause; but it is less natural where kai\...de/ links a new clause to a preceding one in the same sentence; as in Thuc. 4. 24kai\ ma/lista e)nh=gon (tou\s *surakosi/ous) oi( *lokroi\ tw=n *rhgi/nwn kata\ e)/xqran, kai\ au)toi\ de\ e)sebeblh/kesan k.t.l.: id. 9. 71 o(/pws mh\ panta/pasin i(ppokratw=ntai, kai\ xrh/mata de\ a(/ma au)to/qen te culle/cwntai kai\ par' *)aqhnai/wn e)/lqh|, k.t.l. Examples of the latter class clearly suggest that in the combination kai\...de/, kai/ was the conjunction, while de/, ‘on the other hand,’ added the force of ‘also.’ Cp. the well-known use of de/ with the pron. after a voc.: *)antigo/nh, su\ d' e)nqa/de | fu/lasse, Soph. O. C. 507 n.

qauma/sas e)/xw=teqau/maka (emphatic): cp. Phaedr. 257 C to\n lo/gon de/ sou pa/lai qauma/sas e)/xw, and ib. 258 B teqaumako/tes. This constr. of qauma/zw with gen. of pers. and acc. of thing is common ( Plat. Phaedo 89A, etc.): the gen. is properly possessive (‘I wonder at this in you’). We find also the gen. with a dependent clause in place of the acc. ( H. 2. 3. 53 u(mw=n...qauma/zw ei) mh\ bohqh/sete); and the gen. alone (Lys. or. 7 § 23 kai\ tou/tou me\n ou) qauma/zw).
to/de: this advice of thine that I should go to Troy.
xrh=n: cp. 418 e)/dei.—For mh/te … te cp. 1321 n.—oi(/ ge=e)pei\ e)kei=noi: cp. O. C. 263(n. on oi(/tines): the plur. is implied in *troi/an: cp. ib. 941.
kaqu/brisan with gen., as O. C. 960.

patro\s ge/ras, the arms, wrought by Hephaestus, which were a gift of honour to Achilles (cp. note on se/bas u(pe/rtaton in 402). It would strain the words to render them, ‘a gift of honour (bequeathed to thee) from thy sire.’
[oi(\ to\n a)/qlion … e)/krinan.] It can hardly be doubted that these words are spurious. See Appendix.
a)nagka/zeis with double acc.: cp. O. T. 280.The present tense, expressing endeavour, is quite compatible with ei)= (‘dost thou intend to go..., and art thou trying to force...?’).
to/de (L) = to\ i)e/nai cummaxh/sonta. The occurrence of the same form in 1362 is no argument for ta/de: cp. 88 n.

cunw/mosas has been needlessly changed to cunh/|nesas, a weaker word. The sense here is, ‘thou didst make a compact with me, confirmed by thine oath’ (813, 941). This is but a slight deflection,—surely permissible for poetry,—from the ordinary sense, ‘to take an oath along with another person.’
pe/myon without me: cp. 801 n.

e)/a kakw=s k.t.l. The absence of caesura has the effect of allowing the words to fall from the speaker's lips with a certain deliberate emphasis: cp. 101 n. By a)po/llusqai he means the failure and ruin at Troy with which the gods will visit the Greeks: cp. 1035 ff. For kakw=s … kakou/s cp. 166 n.

diplh=n me\n … diplh=n de\: epanaphora (cp. Ant. 200 n.). The xa/ris will be diplh= because he will have rescued Philoctetes, and also forsaken the Atreidae. Here he thinks of his father as still living: cp. n. on 1209 f.
pisteu/santa, ‘in reliance’ upon the divine oracle, and upon the report of it given by N. (1336—1343). Though pisteu/w sometimes=‘obey’ ( Tr. 1228), it is unnecessary to suppose that sense here.
1377 The words tw=|de dusth/nw| podi/ (dat. of circumstance) have a compressed dramatic force. ‘What,—go to Agamemnon,—when I bear about with me this plague which caused him to cast me forth?’
me\n ou)=n: O. T. 705 n.

se th/nde t' e)/mpuon ba/sin: the phrase recalls those in which Ph. himself had spoken of the ulcered limb as if it had a being distinct from his own (786, 1188, 1202). Cp. O. C. 750a)ei/ se khdeu/ousa kai\ to\ so\n ka/ra.—u was short in pu/on and e)/mpuos (as in Lat. puter), though long in pu/qw (as in puteo, putidus): Empedocles 336 pu/on, e)/pleto leuko/n: Andromachus (flor. circ. 50 A.D. ) ap. Galen p. 876 kai\ mogerw=n ste/rnwn a)polu/etai e)/mpuon i)lu/n.
ka)posw/sontas is a necessary correction here (cp. cr. n.).

ai)=non ai)ne/sas. Though one sense of ai)=nos was a story with a moral ( Hes. Op. 200), it could hardly have been used as it is here, in the sense of ‘advice,’ unless the meaning had been helped out by the cognate verb. Cp. Aesch. Ch. 555ai)nw de\ kru/ptein ta/sde sunqh/kas e)ma/s (‘I recommend’).

a(\ … lw=|sq' o(rw= telou/mena (pres. part.), ‘what I see is in the way of being accomplished with the best results’ for us: i.e., what promises such results, if it be done. The pres. part., implying that the action is already in train, suits the speaker's hopeful tone. I should not, then, take telou/mena as fut. part. with pass. sense; esp. as there is no clear example in Attic of telou=mai as fut. pass., while telou/menos as pres. part. pass. is frequent (e.g. O. T. 797, El. 1344).

kai\ tau=ta le/cas k.t.l. The question of Ph. is, ‘Art thou not ashamed before heaven of pretending that a return to Troy is for my good?’ (For kataisxu/nei with acc., cp. Soph. O. T. 1424.) Now, if we retain in 1383 the MS. w)felou/menos, Neoptolemus replies,—‘Why should one be ashamed, when he is receiving a benefit?’ This would be a sentiment like that of Odysseus in 111, o(/tan ti dra=|s ei)s ke/rdos, ou)k o)knei=n pre/pei. But the rejoinder of Ph. shows that N. cannot have so spoken; for Ph. asks,—‘Dost thou mean a benefit to the Atreidae, or to me?’ N.'s words, then, must have been to this effect,—‘Why should one be ashamed, when he is conferring a benefit?’ If, therefore, w)felou/menos is to be kept, it must be midd., not pass., ‘benefiting.’ There are some instances of rare midd. forms in Soph. (as poqoume/na|...freni/= poqou/sh| in Soph. Tr. 103): but they usually occur in contexts which exclude the pass. sense. Here, a midd. w)felou/menos would be too ambiguous. The pass. sense of that form was familiar, whereas the midd. sense is unexampled.

Of emendations, Heath's w)feloume/nous is the most attractive at first sight. But, if qeou/s be left in 1382, then w)feloume/nous could refer to nothing else: and such phrases as tw=|...dai/moni...su/mmaxos pe/lw ( O. T. 244), or tw=| qew=| bohqw=n ( Plat. Apol. 23B), certainly do not warrant a description of the gods as ‘benefited’ when they are obeyed. w)feloume/nwn (gen. absol.), ‘when people are being benefited,’ would be too vague.

I am persuaded, then, that the fault in w)felou/menos is not confined to the termination. Buttmann's conjecture, w)felw=n fi/lous, gives precisely what is required; since fi/lous, in N.'s mouth, might well suggest Ph. 's reply in 1384, le/geis d' *)atrei/dais k.t.l. The origin of the corruption may have been the resemblance of the syllables *f*e*l and *f*i*l, leading a careless scribe to erase the second of them.
le/geis d) k.t.l.: ‘Is this benefit of which thou speakest for the Atreidae, or one that concerns me?’

e)p' e)moi\ =‘in my case’: cp. O. C. 414kai\ tau=t' e)f' h(mi=n *foi=bos ei)rhkw\s kurei=; The prep. e)pi/ might govern *)atrei/dais also (cp. O. T. 829 n.), but is better taken with the pron. only. L's reading, ta/de, is possibly right (cp. O. C. 885a)=r ou)x u(/bris ta/d);): but I prefer to/de in this direct reference to the last speaker's phrase (w)felw=n).

soi/ pou. The particle conveys the assurance with a shade of friendly irony (‘thy good, I should rather think’)— which marks surprise at Ph. 's question. Seyffert overlooks this when he objects to pou here as having ‘dissimulationis aliquid.’
pw=s (fi/los ei)=), o(/s ge: cp. 663 n.

w)= ta=n: a familiar, but not homely, form of address: cp. O. T. 1145 n. Cp. Curtius Etym., 5th ed. (1886), vol. II. p. 336 (Eng. tr.): ‘If...w)= ta=n (also w)= )ta=n) has anything to do with <*>ths, Lange's theory that *e)ta=n is an expansion of the st. veta, like megista/n from me/gistos, is the most probable one.’ (In earlier editions he had inclined to the theory that ta=n is an old form of tu/, tu/nh.) Others favour the view that ta=n comes from ta/lan.

qrasu/nesqai kakoi=s, to become too bold, to show contumacy, amid troubles. The dat. is not causal, but rather a dat. of circumstance, expressing the idea, ‘in time of misfortune.’ Cp. the use of the dat. with regard to festivals ( Ar. Av. 1519*qesmofori/ois nhsteu/omen: Soph. Ant. 691 n.).

o)lei=s me, ‘wilt work my ruin by these persuasions,—i.e., if thou prevail on me to go to Troy.’ The addition of se to gignw/skw has been suggested by the common idiom, gignw/skw se o(/ti o)lei=s: the sense is not, ‘I now see through thee’; and the dat. toi=sde toi=s l. should therefore be taken with o)lei=s, not with gignw/skw.
ou)/koun e)/gwge, ‘I, at least (ou)=n), will not ruin thee’—though possibly thou mayest ruin thyself. Cp. 872 n. on ou)/koun *)atrei=dai.
e)gw\ ou)k: cp. 585 n.
ou)de/poq), e(ko/nta g). In saying sw/sous), N. meant, ‘they will restore thee to health, and to honour.’ Ph. replies, ‘Never,—if I must visit Troy of my own free will.’

w(/ste expresses the condition: cp. n. on O. C. 602pw=s dh=ta/ s' a)\n pemyai/aq), w(/st' oi)kei=n di/xa; The comma is better placed after ou)de/poq) than after e(ko/nta g), since the latter thus gains emphasis. Cp. 1332.

i)dei=n is right: the variant e(lei=n arose from the likeness of *d to *l, helped, perhaps, by a reminiscence of vv. 347, 998, 1347. molei=n would be feebler. For this use of i)dei=n (‘to set eyes upon,’ ‘visit’), cp. O. T. 824ei)/...moi fugo/nti mh)/sti tou\s e)mou\s i)dei=n.
drw=|men: for the form, cp. 895 n.
e)n lo/gois: cp. 60 n.

pei/sein dunhso/mesqa. The fut. inf. is probably sound. It is made easier by the fact that du/namai is used in the fut. tense; not because the fut. indic. can be regarded as attracting the inf. into the same tense; but because, ‘we shall not be able to persuade,’ implies, ‘we cannot hope to persuade.’ Cp. Thuc. 3. 28gno/ntes de\ oi( e)n toi=s pra/gmasin ou)/t' a)pokwlu/sein dunatoi\ o)/ntes, ei)/ t' a)pomonwqh/sontai th=s cumba/sews, kinduneu/sontes k.t.l. (where the MSS. agree in a)pokwlu/sein, and a)pokwlu/ein is merely a conjecture). If pei/sein were to be altered, pei=sai would be more probable than pei/qein. See Appendix.
dunhso/mesqa … le/gw: cp. 1221.
w(s, causal (‘for’), referring to ti/...a)\n...drw=|men, which implies, ‘It is vain to do more.’

r(a=|st' e)moi\ me
 k.t.l.: the sentence is a compressed form of r(a=|sta e)moi/ e)stin, au)tw=| (or au)to
) me
... lh=cai, se\ de\ zh=n, k.t.l.
pa/sxein denotes the continuance of the sufferings: paqei=n, the sum of those sufferings, regarded as a doom. So dra/santi paqei=n ( Aesch. Ch. 313). Cp. 95 e)camartei=n...nika=n.
dei=: cp. 1339 n.
h)/|nesas=cunh/|nesas (cp. 122), w)molo/ghsas.
qigw/n: cp. 813.

pe/mpein. Here the inf. merely defines the action to which the pron. a(\ refers: the fut. inf. was therefore unnecessary: and the pres. inf. has been used, rather than the aor., because ‘sending’ is thought of as a process, not as a momentary act. Similarly the pres. (or aor.) inf. is sometimes used, rather than the fut., when the notion of fut. time is sufficiently expressed by the principal verb: cp. Thuc. 3. 13w(/ste ou)k ei)ko\s au)tou\s periousi/an new=n e)/xein, h)\n u(mei=s...e)pesba/lhte: and id. 1. 81 ou(/tws ei)ko\s *)aqhnai/ous...mh/te...douleu=sai k.t.l.

bra/dune, here intrans., as in Suppl. 730 ei) bradu/noimen boh=|, Plat. Rep. 528D speu/dwn...ma=llon bradu/nw, etc. Others take it transitively (‘delay us,’ or ‘delay the matter’). So taxu/nw also is either trans. or intrans.
teqrh/nhtai, impersonal.

go/ois is better than logois, which may have arisen through the scribe's eye wandering to v. 1393. The very name of Troy renews the memory of his sorrows; and lamentation has been his portion too long. He would fain turn to thoughts of home. Some supply *troi/a as subject to teqrh/nhtai: this seems less fitting here. If teqru/lhtai were read, then, indeed, *troi/a would be the subject; ‘its name has been heard often enough in my laments’ (satis decantata est...). But this v. l. seems to have arisen merely from the corruption teqrh/lhtai.

ei) dokei=, stei/xwmen. In a trochaic tetrameter the end of the fourth foot regularly coincides with the end of a word. This verse breaks the rule. The only other exception is Aesch. Pers. 165, tau=ta/ moi diplh= me/rimn' a)/frasto/s e)stin e)n fresi/n, where Porson wished to place diplh= after fresi/n, and Hermann, to read me/rimna frasto/s. Hermann holds that the breach of rule here is excused by the pause after stei/xwmen. This I believe to be the true explanation. As stei/xwmen is the signal that the prayer of Ph. has at last been granted, it demands emphasis. The unusual rhythm—which would be too harsh in a continuous verse—here serves to accentuate the joyful surprise of Philoctetes.

A reference to the critical note will show how unsatisfactory have been the attempts to alter the words, w)= gennai=on ei)rhkw\s e)/pos. Porson's fine instinct refrained from any such attempt; he felt that, if the verse was to be amended, only one remedy was tolerable,—viz., to strike out ei) dokei=, and leave an iambic trimeter. In favour of this view, it might be said that a scribe, or an actor, who wished to make v. 1402 into a tetrameter, might have been led to ei) dokei= by a reminiscence of 526 and 645: though we cannot concede to Burges that the spuriousness of ei) dokei= is bewrayed by the lack of the usual a)lla/ before it. The absence of a)lla/ merely renders ei) dokei= a little more abrupt.

But the real difficulty in Porson's view arises from a consideration of the whole context. The transition from iambic to trochaic metre marks, as usual, a stirring moment,—here, the moment of setting out for the ship. I<*> seems clear, then, that the words which first announce the departure should open the trochaics, rather than close the iambics. So in Eur. Phoen. 588, after the iambic dialogue between Iocasta and Eteocles, the first trochaic verse spoken by the latter is the sign that his fatal resolve is taken,— mh=ter, ou) lo/gwn e)/q' a(gw/n k.t.l. Cp. also Soph. O. T. 1515 ff.

a)nte/reide, plant firmly (on the ground). Lucian (perhaps with a reminiscence of this v.) uses the word of one who refuses to move,—tw\ po/de a)nterei/dwn pro\s tou)/dafos (*kata/plous § 4). Cp. Anthol. 12. 84 e)pi\ gai=an,...i)/xnos e)reido/menos. This is better than to render, ‘lean thy steps on mine.’

ti/ ga/r, e)a
 k.t.l. Cp. Nub. 1445 ti/ d), h)
 e)/xwn to
 h(/ttw | lo/gon se nikh/sw...; (also ti/ ga/r, h)/n k.t.l. ib. 351).
e)gw\ parw\n: for the interruption of the sentence, cp. 210 n., 1226.
proswfe/lhsin: a compound found only here.
e)/rceis: cp. Aesch. Pers. 786ph/mat' e)/rcantes.

1407 After pela/zein the MSS. have sh=s pa/tras. *n*e. a)ll' ei) dra=|s tau=q), w(/sper au)da=|s. This is probably an interpolation, which may have arisen in the first instance from sh=s pa/tras, a gloss explanatory of pela/zein, the rest being then added, to supply a supposed defect of metre. Some of the attempts which have been made to expand the words, a)ll' ei) dra=|s tau=q), w(/sper au)da=|s, will be found in the Appendix. Seyffert's is the best,— a)ll' ei) su\ dh\ | tau=ta dra/seis, w(/sper au)da=|s: but no one of them is very probable. To the objection that, without these words, stei=xe becomes too abrupt, we may perhaps reply that the decision of Neoptolemus has really been taken; these last misgivings which flit across his mind are not causes of serious hesitation. Thus the simple stei=xe—implying his inward contentment with the answer, ei)/rcw pela/zein—is in truer harmony with the context than a form of words which would suggest that his consent depended, even now, on an explicit assurance.
prosku/sas xqo/na: cp. 533: Ar. Eq. 156th\n gh=n pro/skuson kai\ tou\s qeou/s.

mh/pw ge k.t.l. This is one of the instances in which the appearance of the ‘deus ex machina’ is not preceded by any notice in the text. Similar cases are those of Athena in I. T. 1435 and Suppl. 1183, and the Dioscuri in Helen. 1642. It may be inferred that in these instances the apparition was a sudden one,—effected, perhaps, by the actor coming out upon a high platform (qeologei=on) at the back of the scene. When, on the other hand, the approach of the deity is described in the text (e.g. Androm. 1227 ff.), he was probably lowered, or raised, by machinery. (Cp. MA. üller, Griech. Bühnenalterthüm., pp. 151 ff.) The nine anapaests here are spoken as Heracles moves forward.— With regard to the dramatic fitness of this interposition, see Introd. § 11.
fa/skein d): inf. as imperat.: cp. 57. For this use of fa/skein, as= ‘deem,’ cp. O. T. 462 n.

a)koh=| te klu/ein. If we had simply, au)dh/n te klu/ein, leu/ssein t' o)/yin, the misplacing of the first te would be of a common kind (cp. O. T. 258 n.): the further peculiarity here is that a)koh=| te klu/ein suggests o)fqalmoi=s te leu/ssein, as if the object of both verbs were the person.

th
 sh
 … xa/rin: Tr. 485kei/nou te kai\ sh
 e)c i)/sou koinh
 xa/rin: Soph. Ph. 762tre/f' a)ci/ws nin sou= te th/n t' e)mh
 xa/rin.

ta\ *dio/s te fra/swn. The son of Zeus comes from heaven to declare, with his own lips, that Zeus ordains the return of Philoctetes to Troy. Thus a wholly new motive is brought to bear on Ph. , who hitherto knew merely (at second hand) what Helenus had prophesied (1336 ff.).
h(\n ste/llei: cp. Ap. Rh. 4. 296 ste/llesqai th/nd' oi)=mon.

kai\ prw=ta me/n would properly have been answered in 1421 by e)/peita de\ (kai\ soi\ tou=to e)pagge/llomai): but meanwhile the thought of sequence in the topics yields to that of parallelism between the two cases; and so in 1421 we have simply kai\ soi/, k.t.l.—The phrase ta\s e)ma\s le/cw tu/xas might naturally seem the prelude to a fuller recital: but the meaning is simply this:—‘I have to tell thee that, after many sufferings, I have been received among the gods; and for thee, too, suffering is to end in glory.’

a)qa/naton a)reth\n, ‘deathless glory.’ The difficulties felt regarding a)reth/n have arisen from the words w(s pa/resq' o(ra=n, which imply some visible sign, and thus suggest that a)qa/natos a)reth/ means something more than ‘undying fame of prowess.’ But no emendation is probable (see cr. n.). And the soundness of the text will appear from two considerations.

(1) The use of a)reth/ as=‘reputation won by merit’ was familiar: e.g., Lycurgus In Leocr. § 49 (quoted by Cavallin) ta\ ga\r a)=qla tou= pole/mou toi=s a)gaqoi=s a)ndra/sin e)sti\n e)leuqeri/a kai\ a)reth/. By an easy transition, this idea of fame won by deeds passed into that of ‘distinction’: cp. Theog. 29 mhd' ai)sxroi=sin e)p' e)/rgmasi mhd' a)di/koisin | tima\s mhd' a)reta\s e(/lkeo mhd' a)/fenos: ‘and do not, by shameful deeds or unjust, grasp at honours, or distinctions, or wealth’; where the timai/ refer to office or rank, and the a)retai/, as the context shows, also denote pre-eminence recognised in some external form.

(2) The force of the epithet should be observed. When Plato says, u(pe\r a)reth=s a)qana/tou...pa/ntes pa/nta poiou=sin ( Symp. 208D), the a)qa/natos a)reth/ is the reputation which survives on earth. But here a)qa/natos a)reth/ is ‘the distinction of one who has been made immortal’: i.e., ‘deathless glory’ here means ‘glorious immortality.’ Thus the peculiar sense of a)reth/n is helped by that sense which the context gives to a)qa/naton.
e)/sxon, (‘ingressive’ aor.,) ‘came to have,’ ‘won’: Ant. 1229: Ai. 465e)/sxe ste/fanon eu)klei/as.
w(s pa/resq' o(ra=n: a laurel-wreath perhaps sufficed as symbol of the apotheosis: see n. on 728.
tou=t) is explained by the next v.; cp. tou=to in 1440.
e)k, not merely ‘after’ (720), but ‘as a result of,’ ‘through.’
eu)klea= qe/sqai, make it glorious: cp. 532. (Not, ‘lay down, end, thy life in glory, as Ellendt takes it.)

prw=ton m<*> … a)reth=| te. The me/n here is not corr<*>ative to a(\ d) in 1431: it is followed by te: cp. 1058 n. So in 1426 ff., *pa/r<*> me/n...pe/rseis te. Possibly te ought to <*> de/ in one of the two places, or in both: but, in each case, the te may be a trace of the somewhat careless writing which appears in this speech.
e)kkr<*>ei\s, as Menelaus was for the monomal<*> with Paris ( Il. 3), and Ajax for that with Hector ( Il. 7).
*ha/rin: the slaying of Paris by Ph. was told by Lesches in the Little Iliad, and must have come into the *filokth/ths e)n *troi/a| of Sophocles.
ai)/tios kakw=n: cp. Alcman fr. 31 *du/sparis ai)no/paris, kako\n *(ella/di <*>tianei/rh|. Attius Philocteta fr. 18 Pari <*>yspari, si impar esses tibi, ego nunc non <*>ssem miser.

sku=la/ t) k.t.l. These spoils constitute the a)ristei\a. For the custom of hanging up such <*>la in temples or houses, cp. Aesch. Ag. 577: Aesch. Theb. 278: I. T. 74: Verg. Aen. I. 247 ff., 3. 286 ff., etc.

e)klabw
 is a more probable correction than e)klaxw
 of the MS. e)kbalw
. The force of the compound is, ‘having received from the hands of the army,’—as a reward due to him. So e)kla<*>ba/nein is said of receiving what is surrendered under a treaty (Isocr. or. 5 § 100 th
 *)asi/an... para\ tw=n *(ellh/nwn e)n tai=s sunqh/kais e)ce/laben): or of receiving ‘in full’ ( Legg. 958 D di/kas...e)klabo/nti). Cp. Her. 8. 123 where, after Salamis, the strathgoi/ meet at the Isthmus, a)risth/ia dw/sontes tw=| a)ciwta/tw|, and vote by laying yh=foi on Poseidon's altar.

pe/myeis seems here to mean ‘convey’ (implying triumphal pomp): though elsewhere this use seems restricted to the escorting of persons (1368, 1399). It may, however, mean merely ‘send’ in advance (as in the Heracles Trach.sends his captives before him with the kh=ruc).— *poi/anti: Ph. thus learns that his father is indeed alive.

a(\ d' a)\n la/bh|s k.t.l.: ‘and whatsoever spoils thou receivest from that army (the Greek strateu/matos of 1429), (from those spoils) take memorials of my bow (i.e., a thank-offering for its work) to my pyre.’ A portion of the sku=la is to be dedicated to Heracles on Mount Oeta; where in historical times such relics were doubtless shown at the so-called Pyra ( Liv. 36. 30: Introd. § 1).

After the relative clause, a(\ d' a)
 la/bh|s, we understand, not tau=ta (in apposition with mnhmei=a), but a partitive gen., tou/twn. This construction is a simple and natural one. For the partitive gen. thus understood, cp. n. on 1161 f., and Xen. Cyr. 8. 1. 20 quoted there. The sentence could have no ambiguity for a Greek audience, familiar with the custom that, after a victory, a part of the spoil (usually a deka/th) should be dedicated to the gods. Cp. Her. 8. 121(after the battle of Salamis) dieda/santo th
 lhi/hn kai\ ta\ a)kroqi/nia a)pe/pemyan e)s *delfou/s. Xen. Anab. 5. 3. 4th
 deka/thn h(
 tw=| *)apo/llwni e)cei=lon kai\ th=| *)efesi/a| *)arte/midi die/labon oi( strathgoi/, to\ me/ros e(/kastos, fula/ttein toi=s qeoi=s. As Cavallin remarks, the passage was rightly understood by the schol. on 1432, e)k tw=n a)ristei/wn ka)me\ ti/mhson. For the simple gen., tou=de tou= stratou=, after la/bh|s, cp. Soph. O. T. 580e)mou= komi/zetai, ib. 1022 dw=ro/n pot), Soph. O. T. i)/sqi, tw=n e)mw=n xeirw=n labw/n: ib. 1163 e)deca/mhn de/ tou.—For other views, see Appendix.

kai\ soi\ tau=t) k.t.l. Heracles now addresses Neoptolemus in a parenthesis which extends down to 1437: then, at the words e)gw\ d), he again turns to Philoctetes. Two views of these words are possible. I prefer the first.

(1) tau=t) refers to the general tenor of the preceding verses, from 1423 onwards, —viz., that Ph. is to go to Troy with N., and there triumph. ‘And to thee (as well as to Ph. ) I give these counsels’: i.e., it concerns thee, too, to note that he must accompany thee to Troy. In kai\ soi\ the kai\=‘and’: but the emphasis which falls on soi/ makes it equivalent to ‘thee also.’ If kai\ meant ‘also,’ the asyndeton would be too harsh. The change of tau=t) to tau)/t) seems needless. A modified form of this view refers tau=t) only to v. 1431, as if Heracles meant that Neoptolemus also must bring spoils to the pyre: but this seems less fitting.

(2) tau=t) refers to what follows: the aor. parh/|nesa is then like a)pw/mosa in 1289 (n.): and the ga\r after ou)/te merely introduces the statement (1049). I do not share Buttmann's feeling that kai\ soi\ ought then to be soi\ de\: but the whole context appears to render the first view more natural.

Heracles confirms what Odysseus had said (115). In glorifying Philoctetes, it was necessary to respect the legend which ascribed the capture of Troy to Neoptolemus (who was the hero of the *)ili/ou pe/rsis, by Arctînus).
For to\ *tr. pedi/on, cp. 69 n.

sunno/mw, ‘having the same pasture’—here, ‘seeking their prey on the same ground.’ Cp. Hist. An. 6. 18 oi( tau=roi ... o)/ntes su/nnomoi. This primary sense of the adj. is here blended with the derived sense, ‘partners.’ The image is Homeric: cp. Il. 10. 297ba/n r() i)/men w(/s te le/onte du/w dia\ nu/kta me/lainan (Odysseus and Diomedes): cp. Il. 5. 548.So Aesch. Cho. 938diplou=s le/wn (Orestes and Pylades): imitated by Eur. Or. 1401le/ontes *(/ellanes du/o didu/mw.

fula/sseton. Since neither can prevail without the other, each has the other's welfare in his keeping. We can perceive that the poet's mind glances from the metaphor to the thought of a di/kaios ka)gaqo\s parasta/ths ( Ant. 671 n.).

*)asklhpio\n. In the Iliad Asclepius is a mortal, an a)mu/mwn i)hth/r living in western Thessaly, whose two sons, the physicians Podaleirius and Machaon, go thence to Troy. But Sophocles here thinks of Asclepius as a god, whom Heracles is to send from heaven. Prosaic objections have been made to this passage, on the ground that in 1333 it was said that Ph. was to be healed by the Asclepiadae. But it might be replied that those were merely the words of Neoptolemus, who was giving his own interpretation to a vague prediction of Helenus that Ph. would be healed. Even, however, if the oracle itself spoke of the Asclepiadae, there is no poetical unfitness in this further promise—that the healing god himself should visit Troy, to direct and inspire their skill.

Tradition placed Sophocles in a near relation to the cult of Asclepius. The poet is said to have been invested with the ‘priesthood’ (i(erwsu/nh, Vit. Soph. § 6) of the hero Alcon, a healing-god akin to Asclepius; indeed, the name *)/alk-wn is cognate, if *)asklhpio/s be *)alec-h/pios, by metathesis of sk=c: cp. Preller I. 423 n. 2. A paean to Asclepius by Sophocles was extant in antiquity (Lucian Enc. Dem. 27 etc.), and legend declared that the god had visited the poet's hearth ( Plut. Num. 4§ 6).

to\ deu/teron. The first occasion was when Heracles himself made war on Laomedon, and, after taking Troy, gave the king's daughter, Hesione, to Telamon ( Ai. 1302: Il. 5. 638 ff.). Cp. Pind. I. 5. 36(the Aeacidae) di\s po/lin *trw/wn pra/qon, e(spo/menoi | *(hraklh=i pro/teron, | kai\ su
 *)atrei/dais. Propert. 3. 1. 32 Troia bis Oetaei numine capta dei.— au)th
=th
 po/lin, or *troi/an, implied in *)/ilion, which is regularly neuter (454) in post-homeric poetry. The exception in Eur. Andr. 103 occurs in a quasi-epic hexameter: conversely, *)/ilion ai)pu\ in Il. 15. 71 occurs in a suspected passage.

e)nnoei=q), as a correction of the MS. e)nnoei=sq), is commended by the fact that, out of five other places where Soph. uses this compound, there are two ( Soph. O. T. 559, Soph. Ant. 61) in which the act. form is proved by metre; while in a third, Soph. Tr. 578, e)nnoh/sas) is not likely to have come from e)nnohqei=s). On the other hand, the midd. was not less Attic than the act.; and, if e)nnoei=sq) here were not followed by an aspirate, it would have been rash to alter it.

eu)sebei=n. As the schol. observes, this warning derives force from the tradition that, after the fall of Troy, Neoptolemus ‘slew Priam, when he had taken refuge at the altar of *zeu\s e(rkei=os.’ Neoptolemus himself was afterwards assassinated at Delphi: whence the proverb *neoptole/meios ti/sis ( Paus. 4. 17. 4), meaning, to\ paqei=n o(poi=o/n tis kai\ e)/drase. The outrage of Ajax Oileus on Cassandra, in the temple of Athena at Troy ( Eur. Tro. 70), was another instance of dusse/beia.

w(s ta)/lla pa/nta k.t.l. The ground for the precept (eu)sebei=n) is given by w(s,—viz., that Zeus deems ‘all other things,’—such as conquest, or glory—of secondary moment (deu/ter' h(gei=tai: cp. O. C. 351). Then the sentence introduced by ga/r explains why Zeus so deems; viz., because the effect of eu)se/beia does not cease with man's life on earth, but is imperishable. That is, it brings happiness to the eu)sebh/s in the life beyond the grave; and it is also of good example to the men who come after. Heracles can fitly say this; he is himself enjoying the reward of eu)se/beia, and he comes from the presence of Zeus.

In v. 1443 the old emendation ou), for h(, seems an almost certain one: but the case in favour of it has not yet, perhaps, been adequately stated. It is not merely, or even chiefly, a verbal question; we must consider the whole passage. If we retain the MS. reading, h( ga\r eu)se/beia sunqnh/|skei brotoi=s, ‘piety dies with mortals,’ the meaning is, ‘piety passes with men into the other life,’ there to find a reward. (Cp. Rev. xiv. 13, ta\ ga\r e)/rga au)tw=n a)kolouqei= met' au)tw=n.) Now, this narrows the scope of the thought in an arbitrary way: for then eu)se/beia is regarded only in its influence on the happiness of the departed. If, however, we read ou) ga\r hu(se/beia sunqnh/|skei brotoi=s, this allows us to think also of the abiding influence upon human conduct; and the more comprehensive view is certainly the more fitting one in an exposition of the reason why Zeus attributes a paramount importance to eu)se/beia.

A further objection to the MS. reading arises from the sense given to sunqnh/|skei, which, though intelligible (in the light of v. 1444), would be forced. The regular meaning of qnh/|skw and its compounds, when used figuratively, is ‘to become inoperative’ or ‘extinct,’ in contrast with zh=n: e.g., O. C. 611qnh/|skei de\ pi/stis. Aesch.
