Cho. 846(lo/goi)...qnh/|skontes ma/thn. Eur. fr. 734 a)reth\ de/, ka)\n qa/nh| tis, ou)k a)po/llutai, | zh=| d' ou)ke/t' o)/ntos sw/matos: kakoi=si de\ | a(/panta frou=da sunqano/nq' u(po\ xqono/s: where it is immaterial that the reference is to fame living or perishing on earth: the point is that sunqano/nq) is opposed to zh=|. In Ar. Ran. 868, too—o(/ti h( poi/hsis ou)xi\ sunte/qnhke/ moi, | kei/nw| de\ sunte/qnhken—the jest turns on the fact that the verb would naturally mean, ‘has perished’ with the author.

Two objections have been made to the emendation ou) for h(. (1) The position of ou). But ou) is rightly so placed, because, as ta)/lla pa/nta indicates, there is an implied contrast between eu)se/beia and other things which do perish with men. Cp. Soph. fr. incert. 841 ou) toi=s a)qu/mois h( tu/xh cullamba/nei (though it does aid the brave). (2) The thought, ou) … sunqnh/|skei, is repeated by ou)k a)po/llutai. But v. 1444 is not a mere repetition; it is a re-statement in more forcible language, and, as such, it is rhetorically appropriate here.

Dindorf rejects all three verses (1442— 1444). But the conclusion, at v. 1441, would then be too abrupt. Schneidewin formerly spared v. 1442, rejecting only the two next vv. He supposed (a) that *zeu/s was a gloss on path/r: (b) that some one had written vv. 1443 f. in the margin, the original form of 1443 having been, a)ll' h( ga\r eu)se/beia sugghra=| (or sunnai/ei) brotoi=s: then a scribe evolved our text. This hypothesis is too complex: besides, the speech would not end well with v. 1442. One of Hermann's views (see cr. n.) was that v. 1444 only should be rejected (ou) being read in 1443): but this, too, would be ineffective.
poqeino\n e)moi\: for the neglect of the usual caesura after the second foot, cp. 1470: O. C. 1760, O. C. 1771.
pe/myas: cp. 846.
xro/nios here=xro/nw|, ‘after a long time’ (as in O. C. 441, n.): but in 1449 xro/nioi=‘for long’ (polu\n xro/non).

gnw/mhn tau/th| ti/qemai, ‘give my voice in this sense’: ti/qemai as in the phrase ti/qemai yh=fon. Cp. Lys. or. 24 § 23 mhdamw=s, w)= boulh/, tau/th| qh=sqe th
 yh=fon (so Taylor: tau/th|...th=| yh/fw| MSS.): Isae. or. 8 § 46 h=(| di/kaio/n e)sti, tau/th| th
 yh=fon ti/qesqe: Her. 1. 120tau/th| plei=stos gnw/mhn ei)mi/: id. 7. 143 tau/th| *qemistokle/ous a)pofainome/nou (gnw/mhn).—The reading gnw/mhn tau/thn is also possible: cp. Legg. 674 A ou)k a)
 tiqei/mhn tau/thn th
 yh=fon: Andoc. or. 3 § 21 ti/na gnw/mhn e)/qento peri\ u(mw=n...; In Ar. Eccl. 658 the MSS. give ka)gw\ tau/thn gnw/mhn e)qe/mhn: but Toup conjectures tau/th|, which Dindorf adopts.

The chief reason for preferring gnw/mhn tau/th| here is that it explains the alternative readings of the MSS., gnw/mh| tau/th| and gnw/mhn tau/thn. So in Ant. 125 f. the true reading a)ntipa/lw|...dra/kontos generated a)ntipa/lw|...dra/konti and a)ntipa/lou...dra/kontos.—Those who read gnw/mh| tau/th| ti/qemai suppose that yh=fon is understood with ti/qemai, the dat. being modal. This is very awkward, and cannot be supported by any sound example.
me/llete pra/ssein: for the inf., cp. O. C. 1627ti/ me/llomen | xwrei=n;

kairo\s kai\ plou=s: ‘occasion (the need of the hour) urges you on, and the fair wind yonder (o(/d)) at the ship's stern’: i.e., ‘it is time for you to sail, and the weather is fair.’ Cp. 466 f. (n.). For kata\ pru/mnan, cp. Thuc. 2. 97h)\n a)ei\ kata\ pru/mnan i(sth=tai to\ pneu=ma: Hom. Od. 11. 6meto/pisqe neo\s kuanoprw/roio | i)/kmenon ou)=ron i(/ei. It is best here to keep the ordinary Attic pru/mnan, which the MSS. give, since metre does not require pru/mnhn (cp. 482 n.).

The place of ga\r as sixth word is noteworthy. Soph. does not elsewhere place it later than fourth word (as in v. 1268); and this was the ordinary classical limit. But the examples in Comedy of the 4th cent. B.C. show that the Attic ear tolerated a greater licence. Thus ga/r stands as fifth word in Menander *trofw/nios fr. 1. 2 diafe/rei tw=| magei/rw| tou=to ga/r: as sixth, in Antiphanes *(alieuome/nh 22 e)pi\ to\ ta/rixo/s e)stin w(rmhkui=a ga/r (where Meineke needlessly writes ta/rixos d' e)sti\n w(rmhkui=) a)/far): as seventh, in Athenion *samo/qra|kes 4 tou= qhriw/dous kai\ paraspo/ndou bi/ou | h(ma=s ga\r a)polu/sasa etc. (But in Alexis fr. incert. 7. 3 ou(= mh/te pra/ttetai te/los | mhde\n ga\r h(ma=s, the emendation par' h(ma=s is clearly right.) The unusual position of ga\r led to a point being placed in L after o(/d), and has been one cause of doubt as to the construction of the whole passage (see cr. n.).
1452 The preceding anapaests 1445 ff.) indicated that the moment of departure was at hand; and now, as stei/xwn shows, the movement is beginning.
kale/sw, aor. subj., as usual with fe/re: cp. 300 n. The sense is strictly, ‘invoke’ (cp. 737): the land is addressed as a divine power, to which he makes a prayer (1464).

xai=r), w)= me/laqron k.t.l. The eight verses which follow call up a picture of his past life in Lemnos,—the lonely cave,—the plain to the west of it,—the loud sea to the east,—the echoing cliffs to the north. Then, at v. 1461, his thoughts turn to the voyage that lies before him.
cu/mfrouron, the witness of his weary watching and waiting: the cave is personified, as in 1081 ff. Cp. Aesch. P. V. 142th=sde fa/raggos skope/lois e)n a)/krois | froura\n a)/zhlon o)xh/sw.

*nu/mfai t) k.t.l. Next to the me/laqron itself, he naturally names the elemental deities of the region from which he obtained water, fuel, and the soothing fu/llon (292 ff., 649). Cp. Il. 20. 8numfa/wn, ai(/ t' a)/lsea kala\ ne/montai | kai\ phga\s potamw=n kai\ pi/sea poih/enta (grassy water-meadows). Ap. Rh. 2. 821 nu/mfai e(leiono/moi.

a)/rshn, of strong, deep sound: cp. Ar. Th. 124ki/qari/n te mate/r' u(/mnwn. | a)/rseni boa=| do/kimon. (In Soph. fr. 480 a)/rsenas xoa\s | *)axe/rontos is explained by some as ‘deep-sounding waves.’) Conversely in Hom. Od. 6. 122koura/wn...qh=lus a)uth/. A difference between deeper and shriller tone was expressed by the terms au)lo\s a)ndrh/ios and gunaikh/ios ( Her. 1. 17).

The MS. problh/s (without q)) cannot be defended as an epithet of ktu/pos,—‘a sound sent forth by the sea’ (as Seyffert takes it). We must read either (1) probolh=s with Hermann, or (2) problh/s q) with Musgrave and Schaefer. I prefer (1), because q) is decidedly tame, whether po/ntou be taken with problh/s only, or (as seems needful) with ktu/pos also. Nor can it be questioned that probolh=s gives a much finer verse. It is true that we have had problh=tes in 936, whereas this sense of probolh/ recurs only in later Greek (Quintus Smyrn. 9. 378 e)pi\ probolh=|si qala/sshs). But, if such a use of probolh/ was actually a rare one, the presence of po/ntou would make it clear.
ou(= seems to denote generally the region in which the cave was situated, —near, or perhaps upon, the po/ntou probolh/. We can hardly refer it back to the word me/laqron.
polla/ki, an epic and lyric form twice used in lyrics by Aesch. ( Aesch. Theb. 227, Suppl. 131), but not elsewhere by

e)ndo/muxon, a poet. word (like e)ndoma/xhs); but, in later Greek at least, the verb formed from it seems to have been common: thus the schol. on Vesp. 970 explains oi)kouro/s by e)ndomuxou=nta. For the place of e)ndo/muxon after kra=ta, see note on eu)/xruson in 393. The cave was on the east coast (see 1459 n.), but its seaward mouth is imagined as having a s. or S. E. aspect, so that the blasts of the stormy no/tos ( Soph. Ant. 335 n.) could carry rain and spray into the inmost recesses.
plhgai=si: cp. Lucr. 5. 955verbera ventorum.

1459 This *(ermai=on o)/ros is mentioned in only one other passage of classical literature,— Aesch. Ag. 283, where the *(ermai=on le/pas *ah/mnou is the signalling station intermediate between Ida and Athos. It is doubtless the N. E. promontory of Lemnos, now Cape Plaka.

The only rival claim is that of Mount Skopia, near Cape Murzephlo (the N.W. promontory), which has greatly the advantage of Plaka in height. But two points are in favour of Plaka. (1) It was a fitting place for the beacon; for it is in a direct line between Ida and Athos; it is the nearest point to the Troad; and it runs out far into the sea. (2) The cave of Philoctetes commanded a view of the volcano Mosychlus (v. 800), and his cries were re-echoed from Mount Hermaeum. The two hills were therefore at no very great distance from each other. But there is no reason to suppose that a volcano ever existed near Cape Murzephlo, while there is some ground for thinking that one may have existed on the eastern coast (cp. Appendix on v. 800). See Tozer, Islands of the Aegean, pp. 273 f. (1890).
Hermaeum occurs elsewhere also as the ancient name of a promontory,— e.g., in Sardinia (=C. Marrargiu, on the W. coast), and on the European shore of the Bosporus (=Rumili Hissar).

The MSS. give the accent *(/ermaion here, but *(ermai=on is right. Adjectives in -aios, of more than two syllables, were regularly properispomenon, like *)aqhnai=os. Neuter substantives in -aion were proparoxytone; hence *)aqh/naia, as the name of the festival (sc. i(era/), and e(/rmaion, a wind-fall.
a)nti/tupon: cp. 693 f. (n.)— xeimazome/nw|, fig., under stress of suffering; cp. 1194: Aesch. P. V. 562xalinoi=s e)n peri/noisin | xeimazo/menon.

*lu/kio/n te poto/n. There can be no doubt that *lu/kion is the true reading: the corruption glu/kion, facilitated by the use of a small l as initial, may have been due simply to the fact that the Greeks, like ourselves, spoke of ‘fresh’ water as ‘sweet’ (gluku/, as dist. from a(lmuro/n). The *lu/kion poto/n must be a spring, or fount, in Lemnos, so called after Apollo *lu/kios. There was a more elaborate legend,—that this god, wishing to alleviate the sufferings of Philoctetes, had caused two fountains to arise in the island,—one of wine, and the other of honey. (Zenobius 4. 99, etc.: cp. Hermann's note here.) We do not know whether this *lu/kion poto/n had been mentioned by any poet before Sophocles, —by Lesches, for example: but the way in which the name is introduced favours that supposition. Perhaps, indeed, a ‘Lycian’ fount at Lemnos may have been well known to Athenians in the poet's day.

Traces of Apollo *lu/kios in Lemnos are not surprising. From early times he had been worshipped under that title, not only in the valley of the Xanthus, but also in the Troad (cp. Il. 4. 101, with Leaf's note). A gloss in Hesychius (s.v. *lukai=on) points to a cognate worship of Apollo in the neighbouring islet of Chrysè. *lu/kios and *lu/keios may both alike be referred to luk, as designating the god of light. In actual Greek usage, while *lu/keios was usually connected with the idea of lukokto/nos ( O. T. 203 n.), *lu/kios was chiefly associated with Lycia. But, instead of the title *lu/kios being derived thence, it is more likely that the country of the people once called Trem&icaron;lae took its name from the cult of the *lu/kios. (Cp. Preller, I. 202.)
It has been objected to the mention of krh=nai that at v. 717 Ph. was described as having only stato\n u(/dwr: but that was merely the conjecture of the Chorus. Cp. 21 poto\n krhnai=on.

lei/pomen u(ma=s, lei/pomen h)/dh. Hermann's motive for converting v. 1463 into a paroemiac (see cr. n.) is that the emphasis seems to require such a pause. It would certainly be admissible; but it does not appear necessary. If v. 1463 remains an ordinary dimeter, then the final paroemiac (1468) is all the more effective. And the change is open to one decided objection. If h)/dh is altered to ou) dh\, the second lei/pomen becomes weak. As to the sequence of dactyls in 1463, cp. Eur. Hipp. 1361pro/sfora/ m' ai)/rete, su/ntona d' e(/lkete.
e)piba/ntes, ‘entered on’ that hope,—as upon ground which it was lawful to tread: cp. n. on O. C. 189eu)sebi/as e)pibai/nontes.
kai/ m' eu)ploi/a| pe/myon: for the modal dat., cp. O. T. 51a)ll' a)sfalei/a| th/nd' a)no/rqwson po/lin.

a)me/mptws, ‘so that I shall have no cause to complain’: cp. Suppl. 269 pra/cas a)me/mptws. (Others understand, ‘without complaint on thy part,’—because I leave thee, or because I have changed my resolve.)— Meineke objects that Ph. cannot properly ask the island for a good voyage. But just as Orestes prays Argos and her gods to welcome him ( Soph. El. 67), so Ph. here prays Lemnos to speed her parting guest. Cp. 986.
e)/nq)=e)kei=se o(/poi, as in El. 1099o(doiporou=men e)/nqa xrh/|zomen: similarly e)/nqa=e)kei=se o(/pou in O. T. 796e)/feugon, e)/nqa mh/pot' o)yoi/mhn.
*moi=ra: some write moi=ra, as in 331; but the epithet h( mega/lh seems here to imply definite personification.

fi/lwn: Heracles and Neoptolemus. —The pandama/twr dai/mwn is clearly Zeus, whose ordinances Heracles came to announce (1415). The epithet is fitting; for the stubborn purpose of Ph. has been overruled; and Troy is soon to fall. Cp. Soph. Ant. 605 ff.

*nu/mfais a(li/aisin e)peuca/menoi. Ritter, who rejects vv. 1469—1471, argues that the nymphs had no power over the sea; that belonged to Poseidon and other gods. But this was not the old Greek conception. The sea-nymphs, properly so called, were the Nereids (for the *)wkeani=nai were rather the nymphs of rivers and fountains). The list of the Nereids given by Hesiod ( Th. 250 ff.) shows that they were imagined, not merely as representing, but as influencing, the various moods of the sea. Thus he says of the Nereid *kumodo/kh that, with her sister *kumatolh/gh, ‘she quickly calms waves on the gloomy deep, and the blasts of fierce winds.’ The good offices of the Nereids to mariners are expressed by such names as *fe/rousa, *hontopo/reia, and *eu)lime/nh. A voyager, then, might well pay his vows to them.
no/stou, said by the Chorus of sailors who had come from Troy, means ‘return,’ rather than merely ‘journey’ (as in 43).
swth=ras with fem. subst.: cp. O. T. 81 n.
